7:25 The images of their gods you shall destroy by fire. Do not covet the silver or gold on them, nor take it for yourselves, lest you be ensnared by it; for it is an abomination to the , your God.
7:26 You shall not bring any abominable thing into your house, so as to be, like it, under the ban; loathe and abhor it utterly for it is under the ban.
8:1 Be careful to observe this whole commandment that I enjoin on you today, that you may live and increase, and may enter in and possess the land which the promised on oath to your ancestors.
8:2 Remember how for these forty years the , your God, has directed all your journeying in the wilderness, so as to test you by affliction, to know what was in your heart: to keep his commandments, or not.
8:3 He therefore let you be afflicted with hunger, and then fed you with manna, a food unknown to you and your ancestors, so you might know that it is not by bread alone that people live, but by all that comes forth from the mouth of the .
8:4 The clothing did not fall from you in tatters, nor did your feet swell these forty years.
8:5 So you must know in your heart that, even as a man disciplines his son, so the , your God, disciplines you.
8:6 Therefore, keep the commandments of the , your God, by walking in his ways and fearing him.
8:7 For the , your God, is bringing you into a good country, a land with streams of water, with springs and fountains welling up in the hills and valleys,
8:8 a land of wheat and barley, of vines and fig trees and pomegranates, of olive trees and of honey,
8:9 a land where you will always have bread and where you will lack nothing, a land whose stones contain iron and in whose hills you can mine copper.
8:10 But when you have eaten and are satisfied, you must bless the , your God, for the good land he has given you.
8:11 Be careful not to forget the , your God, by failing to keep his commandments and ordinances and statutes which I enjoin on you today:
8:12 lest, when you have eaten and are satisfied, and have built fine houses and lived in them,
8:13 and your herds and flocks have increased, your silver and gold has increased, and all your property has increased,
8:14 you then become haughty of heart and forget the , your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, that house of slavery;
8:15 he guided you through the vast and terrible wilderness with its saraph serpents and scorpions, its parched and waterless ground; he brought forth water for you from the flinty rock
8:16 and fed you in the wilderness with manna, a food unknown to your ancestors, that he might afflict you and test you, but also make you prosperous in the end.
8:17 Otherwise, you might say in your heart, It is my own power and the strength of my own hand that has got me this wealth.
8:18 Remember then the , your God, for he is the one who gives you the power to get wealth, by fulfilling, as he has now done, the covenant he swore to your ancestors.
8:19 But if you do forget the , your God, and go after other gods, serving and bowing down to them, I bear witness to you this day that you will perish utterly.
8:20 Like the nations which the destroys before you, so shall you too perish for not listening to the voice of the , your God.
9:1 Hear, O Israel! You are now about to cross the Jordan to enter in and dispossess nations greater and stronger than yourselves, having large cities fortified to the heavens,
9:2 the Anakim, a people great and tall. You yourselves know of them and have heard it said of them, Who can stand up against the Anakim?
9:3 Know, then, today that it is the , your God, who will cross over before you as a consuming fire; he it is who will destroy them and subdue them before you, so that you can dispossess and remove them quickly, as the promised you.
9:4 After the , your God, has driven them out of your way, do not say in your heart, It is because of my justice the has brought me in to possess this land, and because of the wickedness of these nations the is dispossessing them before me.
9:5 No, it is not because of your justice or the integrity of your heart that you are going in to take possession of their land; but it is because of their wickedness that the , your God, is dispossessing these nations before you and in order to fulfill the promise he made on oath to your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
9:6 Know this, therefore: it is not because of your justice that the , your God, is giving you this good land to possess, for you are a stiff-necked people.
9:7 Remember and do not forget how you angered the , your God, in the wilderness. From the day you left the land of Egypt until you came to this place, you have been rebellious toward the .
9:8 At Horeb you so provoked the that he was angry enough to destroy you,
9:9 when I had gone up the mountain to receive the stone tablets of the covenant which the made with you. Meanwhile I stayed on the mountain forty days and forty nights; I ate no food and drank no water.
9:10 The gave me the two stone tablets inscribed, by Gods own finger, with a copy of all the words that the spoke to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly.
9:11 Then, at the end of the forty days and forty nights, when the had given me the two stone tablets, the tablets of the covenant,
9:12 the said to me, Go down from here now, quickly, for your people whom you have brought out of Egypt are acting corruptly; they have already turned aside from the way I commanded them and have made for themselves a molten idol.
9:13 I have seen now how stiff-necked this people is, the said to me.
9:14 Let me be, that I may destroy them and blot out their name from under the heavens. I will then make of you a nation mightier and greater than they.
9:15 When I had come down again from the blazing, fiery mountain, with the two tablets of the covenant in both my hands,
9:16 I saw how you had sinned against the , your God, by making for yourselves a molten calf. You had already turned aside from the way which the had commanded you.
9:17 I took hold of the two tablets and with both hands cast them from me and broke them before your eyes.
9:18 Then, as before, I lay prostrate before the for forty days and forty nights; I ate no food, I drank no water, because of all the sin you had committed in the sight of the , doing wrong and provoking him.
9:19 For I dreaded the fierce anger of the against you: his wrath would destroy you. Yet once again the listened to me.
9:20 With Aaron, too, the was deeply angry, and would have destroyed him; but I prayed for Aaron also at that time.
9:21 Then, taking the calf, the sinful object you had made, I burnt it and ground it down to powder as fine as dust, which I threw into the wadi that went down the mountainside.
9:22 At Taberah, at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah likewise, you enraged the .
9:23 And when the sent you up from Kadesh-barnea saying, Go up and take possession of the land I have given you, you rebelled against this command of the , your God, and would not believe him or listen to his voice.
9:24 You have been rebels against the from the day I first knew you.
9:25 Those forty days, then, and forty nights, I lay prostrate before the , because he had threatened to destroy you.
9:26 And I prayed to the Lord and said: O Lord , do not destroy your people, the heritage you redeemed in your greatness and have brought out of Egypt with your strong hand.
9:27 Remember your servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Do not look upon the stubbornness of this people nor upon their wickedness and sin,
9:28 lest the land from which you have brought us say, The was not able to bring them into the land he promised them, and out of hatred for them, he brought them out to let them die in the wilderness.
9:29 They are your people and your heritage, whom you have brought out by your great power and with your outstretched arm.
10:1 At that time the said to me, Cut two stone tablets like the first ones and come up the mountain to me. Also make an ark out of wood.
10:2 I will write upon the tablets the words that were on the tablets that you broke, and you shall place them in the ark.
10:3 So I made an ark of acacia wood, and cut two stone tablets like the first ones, and went up the mountain with the two tablets in my hand.
10:4 The then wrote on the tablets, as he had written before, the ten words that the had spoken to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly; and the gave them to me.
10:5 Then I turned and came down from the mountain, and placed the tablets in the ark I had made. There they have remained, as the commanded me.
10:6 The Israelites set out from Beeroth Bene-jaakan for Moserah; Aaron died there and was buried. His son Eleazar succeeded him as priest.
10:7 From there they set out for Gudgodah, and from Gudgodah for Jotbathah, a region where there is water in the wadies.
10:8 At that time the set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the ark of the covenant of the , to stand before the to minister to him, and to bless in his name, as they have done to this day.
10:9 For this reason, Levi has no hereditary portion with his relatives; the himself is his portion, as the , your God, promised him.
10:10 Meanwhile I stayed on the mountain as I did before, forty days and forty nights, and once again the listened to me. The was unwilling to destroy you.
10:11 The said to me, Go now and set out at the head of the people, that they may enter in and possess the land that I swore to their ancestors I would give them.
10:12 Now, therefore, Israel, what does the , your God, ask of you but to fear the , your God, to follow in all his ways, to love and serve the , your God, with your whole heart and with your whole being,
10:13 to keep the commandments and statutes of the that I am commanding you today for your own well-being?
10:14 Look, the heavens, even the highest heavens, belong to the , your God, as well as the earth and everything on it.
10:15 Yet only on your ancestors did the set his heart to love them. He chose you, their descendants, from all the peoples, as it is today.
10:16 Circumcise therefore the foreskins of your hearts, and be stiff-necked no longer.
10:17 For the , your God, is the God of gods, the Lord of lords, the great God, mighty and awesome, who has no favorites, accepts no bribes,
10:18 who executes justice for the orphan and the widow, and loves the resident alien, giving them food and clothing.
10:19 So you too should love the resident alien, for that is what you were in the land of Egypt.
10:20 The , your God, shall you fear, and him shall you serve; to him hold fast and by his name shall you swear.
10:21 He is your praise; he is your God, who has done for you those great and awesome things that your own eyes have seen.
10:22 Seventy strong your ancestors went down to Egypt, and now the , your God, has made you as numerous as the stars of heaven.
11:1 Love the , your God, therefore, and keep his charge, statutes, ordinances, and commandments always.
11:2 Recall today that it was not your children, who have neither known nor seen the discipline of the , your God—his greatness, his strong hand and outstretched arm;
11:3 the signs and deeds he wrought in the midst of Egypt, on Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and on all his land;
11:4 what he did to the Egyptian army and to their horses and chariots, engulfing them in the waters of the Red Sea as they pursued you, so that the destroyed them even to this day;
11:5 what he did for you in the wilderness until you came to this place;
11:6 and what he did to the Reubenites Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab, when the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up out of the midst of Israel, with their families and tents and every living thing that belonged to them—
11:7 but it was you who saw with your own eyes all these great deeds that the has done.
11:8 So keep all the commandments I give you today, that you may be strong enough to enter in and take possession of the land that you are crossing over to possess,
11:9 and that you may have long life on the land which the swore to your ancestors he would give to them and their descendants, a land flowing with milk and honey.
11:10 The land you are to enter and possess is not like the land of Egypt from which you have come, where you would sow your seed and then water it by hand, as in a vegetable garden.
11:11 No, the land into which you are crossing to take possession is a land of mountains and valleys that drinks in rain from the heavens,
11:12 a land which the , your God, looks after; the eyes of the , your God, are upon it continually through the year, from beginning to end.
11:13 If, then, you truly listen to my commandments which I give you today, loving and serving the , your God, with your whole heart and your whole being,
11:14 I will give the seasonal rain to your land, the early rain and the late rain, that you may have your grain, wine and oil to gather in;
11:15 and I will bring forth grass in your fields for your animals. Thus you may eat and be satisfied.
11:16 But be careful lest your heart be so lured away that you serve other gods and bow down to them.
11:17 For then the anger of the will flare up against you and he will close up the heavens, so that no rain will fall, and the soil will not yield its crops, and you will soon perish from the good land the is giving you.
11:18 Therefore, take these words of mine into your heart and soul. Bind them on your arm as a sign, and let them be as a pendant on your forehead.
11:19 Teach them to your children, speaking of them when you are at home and when you are away, when you lie down and when you get up,
11:20 and write them on the doorposts of your houses and on your gates,
11:21 so that, as long as the heavens are above the earth, you and your children may live on in the land which the swore to your ancestors he would give them.
11:22 For if you are careful to observe this entire commandment I am giving you, loving the , your God, following his ways exactly, and holding fast to him,
11:23 the will dispossess all these nations before you, and you will dispossess nations greater and mightier than yourselves.
11:24 Every place where you set foot shall be yours: from the wilderness and the Lebanon, from the Euphrates River to the Western Sea, shall be your territory.
11:25 None shall stand up against you; the , your God, will spread the fear and dread of you through any land where you set foot, as he promised you.
11:26 See, I set before you this day a blessing and a curse:
11:27 a blessing for obeying the commandments of the , your God, which I give you today;
11:28 a curse if you do not obey the commandments of the , your God, but turn aside from the way I command you today, to go after other gods, whom you do not know.
11:29 When the , your God, brings you into the land which you are to enter and possess, then on Mount Gerizim you shall pronounce the blessing, on Mount Ebal, the curse.
11:30 (These are beyond the Jordan, on the other side of the western road in the land of the Canaanites who live in the Arabah, opposite Gilgal beside the oak of Moreh.)
11:31 Now you are about to cross the Jordan to enter and possess the land which the , your God, is giving you. When, therefore, you take possession of it and settle there,
11:32 be careful to observe all the statutes and ordinances that I set before you today.
12:1 These are the statutes and ordinances which you must be careful to observe in the land which the , the God of your ancestors, has given you to possess, throughout the time you live on its soil.
12:2 Destroy entirely all the places where the nations you are to dispossess serve their gods, on the high mountains, on the hills, and under every green tree.
12:3 Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, burn up their asherahs, and chop down the idols of their gods, that you may destroy the very name of them from that place.
12:4 That is not how you are to act toward the , your God.
12:5 Instead, you shall seek out the place which the , your God, chooses out of all your tribes and designates as his dwelling to put his name there. There you shall go,
12:6 bringing your burnt offerings and sacrifices, your tithes and personal contributions, your votive and voluntary offerings, and the firstlings of your herds and flocks.
12:7 There, too, in the presence of the , your God, you and your families shall eat and rejoice in all your undertakings, in which the , your God, has blessed you.
12:8 You shall not do as we are doing here today, everyone doing what is right in their own sight,
12:9 since you have not yet reached your resting place, the heritage which the , your God, is giving you.
12:10 But after you have crossed the Jordan and dwell in the land which the , your God, is giving you as a heritage, when he has given you rest from all your enemies round about and you live there in security,
12:11 then to the place which the , your God, chooses as the dwelling place for his name you shall bring all that I command you: your burnt offerings and sacrifices, your tithes and personal contributions, and every special offering you have vowed to the .
12:12 You shall rejoice in the presence of the , your God, with your sons and daughters, your male and female slaves, as well as with the Levite within your gates, who has no hereditary portion with you.
12:13 Be careful not to sacrifice your burnt offerings in any place you like,
12:14 but offer them in the place which the chooses in one of your tribal territories; there you shall do what I command you.
12:15 However, in any of your communities you may slaughter and eat meat freely, according to the blessing that the , your God, has given you; the unclean as well as the clean may eat it, as they do the gazelle or the deer.
12:16 Only, you shall not eat of the blood, but must pour it out on the ground like water.
12:17 Moreover, you may not, in your own communities, partake of your tithe of grain or wine or oil, of the firstborn of your herd or flock, of any offering you have vowed, of your voluntary offerings, or of your personal contributions.
12:18 These you must eat in the presence of the , your God, in the place that the , your God, chooses, along with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and the Levite within your gates; and there, in the presence of the , you shall rejoice in all your undertakings.
12:19 Be careful, also, that you do not neglect the Levite as long as you live in your land.
12:20 After the , your God, has enlarged your territory, as he promised you, and you think, I will eat meat, as it is your desire to eat meat, you may eat it freely;
12:21 and if the place where the , your God, chooses to put his name is too far, you may slaughter in the manner I have commanded you any of your herd or flock that the has given you, and eat it freely in your own community.
12:22 You may eat it as you would the gazelle or the deer: the unclean and the clean eating it together.
12:23 But make sure that you do not eat of the blood; for blood is life; you shall not eat that life with the flesh.
12:24 Do not eat of the blood, therefore, but pour it out on the ground like water.
12:25 Do not eat of it, that you and your children after you may prosper for doing what is right in the sight of the .
12:26 However, any sacred gifts or votive offerings that you may have, you shall bring with you to the place which the chooses,
12:27 and there you must sacrifice your burnt offerings, both the flesh and the blood, on the altar of the , your God; of your other sacrifices the blood indeed must be poured out against the altar of the , your God, but their flesh you may eat.
12:28 Be careful to heed all these words I command you today, that you and your descendants after you may forever prosper for doing what is good and right in the sight of the , your God.
12:29 When the , your God, cuts down from before you the nations you are going in to dispossess, and you have dispossessed them and are settled in their land,
12:30 be careful that you not be trapped into following them after they have been destroyed before you. Do not inquire regarding their gods, How did these nations serve their gods, so I might do the same.
12:31 You shall not worship the , your God, that way, because they offered to their gods every abomination that the detests, even burning their sons and daughters to their gods.
13:1 Every word that I command you, you shall be careful to observe, neither adding to it nor subtracting from it.
13:2 If there arises in your midst a prophet or a dreamer who promises you a sign or wonder,
13:3 saying, Let us go after other gods, whom you have not known, and let us serve them, and the sign or wonder foretold to you comes to pass,
13:4 do not listen to the words of that prophet or that dreamer; for the , your God, is testing you to know whether you really love the , your God, with all your heart and soul.
13:5 The , your God, shall you follow, and him shall you fear; his commandments shall you observe, and to his voice shall you listen; him you shall serve, and to him you shall hold fast.
13:6 But that prophet or that dreamer shall be put to death, because, in order to lead you astray from the way which the , your God, has commanded you to take, the prophet or dreamer has spoken apostasy against the , your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt and redeemed you from the house of slavery. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
13:7 If your brother, your fathers child or your mothers child, your son or daughter, your beloved spouse, or your intimate friend entices you secretly, saying, Come, let us serve other gods, whom you and your ancestors have not known,
13:8 any of the gods of the surrounding peoples, near to you or far away, from one end of the earth to the other:
13:9 do not yield or listen to any such person; show no pity or compassion and do not shield such a one,
13:10 but kill that person. Your hand shall be the first raised to put such a one to death; the hand of all the people shall follow.
13:11 You shall stone that person to death, for seeking to lead you astray from the , your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.
13:12 And all Israel shall hear of it and fear, and never again do such evil as this in your midst.
13:13 If you hear it said concerning one of the cities which the , your God, gives you to dwell in,
13:14 that certain scoundrels have sprung up in your midst and have led astray the inhabitants of their city, saying, Come, let us serve other gods, whom you have not known,
13:15 you must inquire carefully into the matter and investigate it thoroughly. If you find that it is true and an established fact that this abomination has been committed in your midst,
13:16 you shall put the inhabitants of that city to the sword, placing the city and all that is in it, even its livestock, under the ban.
13:17 Having heaped up all its spoils in the middle of its square, you shall burn the city with all its spoils as a whole burnt offering to the , your God. Let it be a heap of ruins forever, never to be rebuilt.
13:18 You shall not hold on to anything that is under the ban; then the will turn from his burning anger and show you mercy, and in showing you mercy multiply you as he swore to your ancestors,
13:19 because you have listened to the voice of the , your God, keeping all his commandments, which I give you today, doing what is right in the sight of the , your God.
14:1 You are children of the , your God. You shall not gash yourselves nor shave the hair above your foreheads for the dead.
14:2 For you are a people holy to the , your God; the , your God, has chosen you from all the peoples on the face of the earth to be a people specially his own.
14:3 You shall not eat any abominable thing.
14:4 These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat,
14:5 the deer, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.
14:6 Any among the animals that has divided hooves, with the foot cloven in two, and that chews the cud you may eat.
14:7 But you shall not eat any of the following that chew the cud or have cloven hooves: the camel, the hare, and the rock badger, which indeed chew the cud, but do not have divided hooves; they are unclean for you.
14:8 And the pig, which indeed has divided hooves, with cloven foot, but does not chew the cud, is unclean for you. Their flesh you shall not eat, and their dead bodies you shall not touch.
14:9 These you may eat, of all that live in the water: whatever has both fins and scales you may eat,
14:10 but all those that lack either fins or scales you shall not eat; they are unclean for you.
14:11 You may eat all clean birds.
14:12 But you shall not eat any of the following: the griffon vulture, the bearded vulture, the black vulture,
14:13 the various kites and falcons,
14:14 all kinds of crows,
14:15 the eagle owl, the kestrel, the long-eared owl, all species of hawks,
14:16 the little owl, the screech owl, the barn owl,
14:17 the horned owl, the osprey, the cormorant,
14:18 the stork, any kind of heron, the hoopoe, and the bat.
14:19 All winged insects are also unclean for you and shall not be eaten.
14:20 Any clean winged creatures you may eat.
14:21 You shall not eat the carcass of any animal that has died of itself; but you may give it to a resident alien within your gates to eat, or you may sell it to a foreigner. For you are a people holy to the , your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mothers milk.
14:22 Each year you shall tithe all the produce of your seed that grows in the field;
14:23 then in the place which the , your God, chooses as the dwelling place of his name you shall eat in his presence the tithe of your grain, wine and oil, as well as the firstlings of your herd and flock, that you may learn always to fear the , your God.
14:24 But if, when the , your God, blesses you, the journey is too much for you and you are not able to bring your tithe, because the place which the , your God, chooses to put his name is too far for you,
14:25 you may exchange the tithe for money, and with the money securely in hand, go to the place which the , your God, chooses.
14:26 You may then exchange the money for whatever you desire, oxen or sheep, wine or beer, or anything else you want, and there in the presence of the , your God, you shall consume it and rejoice, you and your household together.
14:27 But do not neglect the Levite within your gates, for he has no hereditary portion with you.
14:28 At the end of every third year you shall bring out all the tithes of your produce for that year and deposit them within your own communities,
14:29 that the Levite who has no hereditary portion with you, and also the resident alien, the orphan and the widow within your gates, may come and eat and be satisfied; so that the , your God, may bless you in all that you undertake.
15:1 At the end of every seven-year period you shall have a remission of debts,
15:2 and this is the manner of the remission. Creditors shall remit all claims on loans made to a neighbor, not pressing the neighbor, one who is kin, because the s remission has been proclaimed.
15:3 You may press a foreigner, but you shall remit the claim on what your kin owes to you.
15:4 However, since the , your God, will bless you abundantly in the land the , your God, will give you to possess as a heritage, there shall be no one of you in need
15:5 if you but listen to the voice of the , your God, and carefully observe this entire commandment which I enjoin on you today.
15:6 Since the , your God, will bless you as he promised, you will lend to many nations, and borrow from none; you will rule over many nations, and none will rule over you.
15:7 If one of your kindred is in need in any community in the land which the , your God, is giving you, you shall not harden your heart nor close your hand against your kin who is in need.
15:8 Instead, you shall freely open your hand and generously lend what suffices to meet that need.
15:9 Be careful not to entertain the mean thought, The seventh year, the year of remission, is near, so that you would begrudge your kin who is in need and give nothing, and your kin would cry to the against you and you would be held guilty.
15:10 When you give, give generously and not with a stingy heart; for that, the , your God, will bless you in all your works and undertakings.
15:11 The land will never lack for needy persons; that is why I command you: Open your hand freely to your poor and to your needy kin in your land.
15:12 If your kin, a Hebrew man or woman, sells himself or herself to you, he or she is to serve you for six years, but in the seventh year you shall release him or her as a free person.
15:13 When you release a male from your service, as a free person, you shall not send him away empty-handed,
15:14 but shall weigh him down with gifts from your flock and threshing floor and wine press; as the , your God, has blessed you, so you shall give to him.
15:15 For remember that you too were slaves in the land of Egypt, and the , your God, redeemed you. That is why I am giving you this command today.
15:16 But if he says to you, I do not wish to leave you, because he loves you and your household, since he is well off with you,
15:17 you shall take an awl and put it through his ear into the door, and he shall be your slave forever. Your female slave, also, you shall treat in the same way.
15:18 Do not be reluctant when you let them go free, since the service they have given you for six years was worth twice a hired laborers salary; and the , your God, will bless you in everything you do.
15:19 You shall consecrate to the , your God, every male firstling born in your herd and in your flock. You shall not work the firstlings of your cattle, nor shear the firstlings of your flock.
15:20 In the presence of the , your God, you shall eat them year after year, you and your household, in the place that the will choose.
15:21 But if a firstling has any defect, lameness or blindness, any such serious defect, you shall not sacrifice it to the , your God,
15:22 but in your own communities you may eat it, the unclean and the clean eating it together, as you would a gazelle or a deer.
15:23 Only, you must not eat of its blood; you shall pour it out on the ground like water.
16:1 Observe the month of Abib by keeping the Passover of the , your God, since it was in the month of Abib that the , your God, brought you out of Egypt by night.
16:2 You shall offer the Passover sacrifice from your flock and your herd to the , your God, in the place the will choose as the dwelling place of his name.
16:3 You shall not eat leavened bread with it. For seven days you shall eat with it only unleavened bread, the bread of affliction, so that you may remember as long as you live the day you left the land of Egypt; for in hurried flight you left the land of Egypt.
16:4 No leaven is to be found with you in all your territory for seven days, and none of the meat which you sacrificed on the evening of the first day shall be kept overnight for the next day.
16:5 You may not sacrifice the Passover in any of the communities which the , your God, gives you;
16:6 only at the place which the , your God, will choose as the dwelling place of his name, and in the evening at sunset, at the very time when you left Egypt, shall you sacrifice the Passover.
16:7 You shall cook and eat it at the place the , your God, will choose; then in the morning you may return to your tents.
16:8 For six days you shall eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day there shall be a solemn assembly for the , your God; on that day you shall do no work.
16:9 You shall count off seven weeks; begin to count the seven weeks from the day when the sickle is first put to the standing grain.
16:10 You shall then keep the feast of Weeks for the , your God, and the measure of your own voluntary offering which you will give shall be in proportion to the blessing the , your God, has given you.
16:11 You shall rejoice in the presence of the , your God, together with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and the Levite within your gates, as well as the resident alien, the orphan, and the widow among you, in the place which the , your God, will choose as the dwelling place of his name.
16:12 Remember that you too were slaves in Egypt, so carry out these statutes carefully.
16:13 You shall celebrate the feast of Booths for seven days, when you have gathered in the produce from your threshing floor and wine press.
16:14 You shall rejoice at your feast, together with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and also the Levite, the resident alien, the orphan and the widow within your gates.
16:15 For seven days you shall celebrate this feast for the , your God, in the place which the will choose; since the , your God, has blessed you in all your crops and in all your undertakings, you will be full of joy.
16:16 Three times a year, then, all your males shall appear before the , your God, in the place which he will choose: at the feast of Unleavened Bread, at the feast of Weeks, and at the feast of Booths. They shall not appear before the empty-handed,
16:17 but each with his own gift, in proportion to the blessing which the , your God, has given to you.
16:18 In all the communities which the , your God, is giving you, you shall appoint judges and officials throughout your tribes to administer true justice for the people.
16:19 You must not distort justice: you shall not show partiality; you shall not take a bribe, for a bribe blinds the eyes even of the wise and twists the words even of the just.
16:20 Justice, justice alone shall you pursue, so that you may live and possess the land the , your God, is giving you.
16:21 You shall not plant an asherah of any kind of wood next to the altar of the , your God, which you will build;
16:22 nor shall you erect a sacred pillar, such as the , your God, hates.
17:1 You shall not sacrifice to the , your God, an ox or a sheep with any serious defect; that would be an abomination to the , your God.
17:2 If there is found in your midst, in any one of the communities which the , your God, gives you, a man or a woman who does evil in the sight of the , your God, and transgresses his covenant,
17:3 by going to serve other gods, by bowing down to them, to the sun or the moon or any of the host of heaven, contrary to my command;
17:4 and if you are told or hear of it, you must investigate it thoroughly. If the truth of the matter is established that this abomination has been committed in Israel,
17:5 you shall bring the man or the woman who has done this evil deed out to your gates and stone the man or the woman to death.
17:6 Only on the testimony of two or three witnesses shall a person be put to death; no one shall be put to death on the testimony of only one witness.
17:7 The hands of the witnesses shall be the first raised to put the person to death, and afterward the hands of all the people. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
17:8 If there is a case for judgment which proves too baffling for you to decide, in a matter of bloodshed or of law or of injury, matters of dispute within your gates, you shall then go up to the place which the , your God, will choose,
17:9 to the levitical priests or to the judge who is in office at that time. They shall investigate the case and then announce to you the decision.
17:10 You shall act according to the decision they announce to you in the place which the will choose, carefully observing everything as they instruct you.
17:11 You shall carry out the instruction they give you and the judgment they pronounce, without turning aside either to the right or left from the decision they announce to you.
17:12 Anyone who acts presumptuously and does not obey the priest who officiates there in the ministry of the , your God, or the judge, shall die. Thus shall you purge the evil from Israel.
17:13 And all the people, on hearing of it, shall fear, and will never again act presumptuously.
17:14 When you have come into the land which the , your God, is giving you, and have taken possession of it and settled in it, should you then decide, I will set a king over me, like all the surrounding nations,
17:15 you may indeed set over you a king whom the , your God, will choose. Someone from among your own kindred you may set over you as king; you may not set over you a foreigner, who is no kin of yours.
17:16 But he shall not have a great number of horses; nor shall he make his people go back again to Egypt to acquire many horses, for the said to you, Do not go back that way again.
17:17 Neither shall he have a great number of wives, lest his heart turn away, nor shall he accumulate a vast amount of silver and gold.
17:18 When he is sitting upon his royal throne, he shall write a copy of this law upon a scroll from the one that is in the custody of the levitical priests.
17:19 It shall remain with him and he shall read it as long as he lives, so that he may learn to fear the , his God, and to observe carefully all the words of this law and these statutes,
17:20 so that he does not exalt himself over his kindred or turn aside from this commandment to the right or to the left, and so that he and his descendants may reign long in Israel.
18:1 The levitical priests, the whole tribe of Levi, shall have no hereditary portion with Israel; they shall eat the fire offerings of the and the portions due to him.
18:2 They shall have no heritage among their kindred; the himself is their heritage, as he has told them.
18:3 This shall be the due of the priests from the people: those who are offering a sacrifice, whether an ox or a sheep, shall give the priest the shoulder, the jowls and the stomach.
18:4 The first fruits of your grain, your wine, and your oil, as well as the first shearing of your flock, you shall also give him.
18:5 For the , your God, has chosen him out of all your tribes to be in attendance to minister in the name of the , him and his descendants for all time.
18:6 When a Levite goes from one of your communities anywhere in Israel in which he has been residing, to visit, as his heart may desire, the place which the will choose,
18:7 and ministers there in the name of the , his God, like all his fellow Levites who stand before the there,
18:8 he shall receive the same portions to eat, along with his stipends and patrimony.
18:9 When you come into the land which the , your God, is giving you, you shall not learn to imitate the abominations of the nations there.
18:10 Let there not be found among you anyone who causes their son or daughter to pass through the fire, or practices divination, or is a soothsayer, augur, or sorcerer,
18:11 or who casts spells, consults ghosts and spirits, or seeks oracles from the dead.
18:12 Anyone who does such things is an abomination to the , and because of such abominations the , your God, is dispossessing them before you.
18:13 You must be altogether sincere with the , your God.
18:14 Although these nations whom you are about to dispossess listen to their soothsayers and diviners, the , your God, will not permit you to do so.
18:15 A prophet like me will the , your God, raise up for you from among your own kindred; that is the one to whom you shall listen.
18:16 This is exactly what you requested of the , your God, at Horeb on the day of the assembly, when you said, Let me not again hear the voice of the , my God, nor see this great fire any more, or I will die.
18:17 And the said to me, What they have said is good.
18:18 I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their kindred, and will put my words into the mouth of the prophet; the prophet shall tell them all that I command.
18:19 Anyone who will not listen to my words which the prophet speaks in my name, I myself will hold accountable for it.
18:20 But if a prophet presumes to speak a word in my name that I have not commanded, or speaks in the name of other gods, that prophet shall die.
18:21 Should you say to yourselves, How can we recognize that a word is one the has not spoken?,
18:22 if a prophet speaks in the name of the but the word does not come true, it is a word the did not speak. The prophet has spoken it presumptuously; do not fear him.
19:1 When the , your God, cuts down the nations whose land the , your God, is giving you, and you have dispossessed them and settled in their cities and houses,
19:2 you shall set apart three cities in the land the , your God, is giving you to possess.
19:3 You shall measure the distances and divide into three regions the land of which the , your God, is giving you possession, so that every homicide will be able to find a refuge.
19:4 This is the case of a homicide who may take refuge there and live: when someone strikes down a neighbor unintentionally and not out of previous hatred.
19:5 For example, if someone goes with a neighbor to a forest to cut wood, wielding an ax to cut down a tree, and its head flies off the handle and hits the neighbor a mortal blow, such a person may take refuge in one of these cities and live.
19:6 Should the distance be too great, the avenger of blood might in hot anger pursue, overtake, and strike the killer dead, even though that one does not deserve the death penalty since there had been no previous hatred;
19:7 for this reason I command you: Set apart three cities.
19:8 But if the , your God, enlarges your territory, as he swore to your ancestors, and gives you all the land he promised your ancestors he would give,
19:9 because you carefully observe this whole commandment which I give you today, loving the , your God, and ever walking in his ways, then add three more cities to these three.
19:10 Thus, in the land which the , your God, is giving you as a heritage, innocent blood will not be shed and you will not become guilty of bloodshed.
19:11 However, if someone, hating a neighbor, lies in wait, attacks, and strikes the neighbor dead, and then flees to one of these cities,
19:12 the elders of the killers own city shall send and have the killer taken from there, to be handed over to the avenger of blood and slain.
19:13 Do not show pity, but purge from Israel the innocent blood, so that it may go well with you.
19:14 You shall not move your neighbors boundary markers erected by your forebears in the heritage that will be allotted to you in the land the , your God, is giving you to possess.
19:15 One witness alone shall not stand against someone in regard to any crime or any offense that may have been committed; a charge shall stand only on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
19:16 If a hostile witness rises against someone to accuse that person of wrongdoing,
19:17 the two parties in the dispute shall appear in the presence of the , in the presence of the priests and judges in office at that time,
19:18 and the judges must investigate it thoroughly. If the witness is a false witness and has falsely accused the other,
19:19 you shall do to the false witness just as that false witness planned to do to the other. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
19:20 The rest shall hear and be afraid, and never again do such an evil thing as this in your midst.
19:21 Do not show pity. Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, and foot for foot!
20:1 When you go out to war against your enemies and you see horses and chariots and an army greater than your own, you shall not be afraid of them, for the , your God, who brought you up from the land of Egypt, will be with you.
20:2 When you are drawing near to battle, the priest shall come forward and speak to the army,
20:3 and say to them, Hear, O Israel! Today you are drawing near for battle against your enemies. Do not be weakhearted or afraid, alarmed or frightened by them.
20:4 For it is the , your God, who goes with you to fight for you against your enemies and give you victory.
20:5 Then the officials shall speak to the army: Is there anyone who has built a new house and not yet dedicated it? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another dedicate it.
20:6 Is there anyone who has planted a vineyard and not yet plucked its fruit? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another pluck its fruit.
20:7 Is there anyone who has betrothed a woman and not yet married her? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another marry her.
20:8 The officials shall continue to speak to the army: Is there anyone who is afraid and weakhearted? Let him return home, or else he might make the hearts of his fellows melt as his does.
20:9 When the officials have finished speaking to the army, military commanders shall be appointed over them.
20:10 When you draw near a city to attack it, offer it terms of peace.
20:11 If it agrees to your terms of peace and lets you in, all the people to be found in it shall serve you in forced labor.
20:12 But if it refuses to make peace with you and instead joins battle with you, lay siege to it,
20:13 and when the , your God, delivers it into your power, put every male in it to the sword;
20:14 but the women and children and livestock and anything else in the city—all its spoil—you may take as plunder for yourselves, and you may enjoy this spoil of your enemies, which the , your God, has given you.
20:15 That is how you shall deal with any city at a considerable distance from you, which does not belong to these nations here.
20:16 But in the cities of these peoples that the , your God, is giving you as a heritage, you shall not leave a single soul alive.
20:17 You must put them all under the ban—the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—just as the , your God, has commanded you,
20:18 so that they do not teach you to do all the abominations that they do for their gods, and you thus sin against the , your God.
20:19 When you are at war with a city and have to lay siege to it for a long time before you capture it, you shall not destroy its trees by putting an ax to them. You may eat of them, but you must not cut them down. Are the trees of the field human beings, that they should be included in your siege?
20:20 However, those trees which you know are not fruit trees you may destroy. You may cut them down to build siegeworks against the city that is waging war with you, until it falls.
21:1 If the corpse of someone who has been slain is found lying in the open, in the land the , your God, is giving you to possess, and it is not known who killed the person,
21:2 your elders and judges shall go out and measure the distances to the cities that are in the neighborhood of the corpse.
21:3 When it is established which city is nearest the corpse, the elders of that city shall take a heifer that has never been put to work or worn a yoke;
21:4 the elders of that city shall bring the heifer down to a wadi with an everflowing stream at a place that has not been plowed or sown, and shall break the heifers neck there in the wadi.
21:5 The priests, the descendants of Levi, shall come forward, for the , your God, has chosen them to minister to him and to bless in the name of the , and every case of dispute or assault shall be for them to decide.
21:6 Then all the elders of that city nearest the corpse shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the wadi,
21:7 and shall declare, Our hands did not shed this blood, and our eyes did not see the deed.
21:8 Absolve, O , your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, and do not let the guilt of shedding innocent blood remain in the midst of your people Israel. Thus they shall be absolved from the guilt of bloodshed,
21:9 and you shall purge the innocent blood from your midst, and do what is right in the eyes of the .
21:10 When you go out to war against your enemies and the , your God, delivers them into your power, so that you take captives,
21:11 if you see a beautiful woman among the captives and become so enamored of her that you wish to have her as a wife,
21:12 and so you take her home to your house, she must shave her head, cut her nails,
21:13 lay aside her captives garb, and stay in your house, mourning her father and mother for a full month. After that, you may come to her, and you shall be her husband and she shall be your wife.
21:14 If later on you lose your liking for her, you shall give her her freedom, if she wishes it; you must not sell her for money. Do not enslave her, since you have violated her.
21:15 If a man has two wives, one loved and the other unloved, and if both the loved and the unloved bear him sons, but the firstborn is the son of the unloved wife:
21:16 when he comes to bequeath his property to his sons he may not consider as his firstborn the son of the wife he loves, in preference to the son of the wife he does not love, the firstborn.
21:17 On the contrary, he shall recognize as his firstborn the son of the unloved wife, giving him a double share of whatever he happens to own, since he is the first fruits of his manhood, and to him belong the rights of the firstborn.
21:18 If someone has a stubborn and rebellious son who will not listen to his father or mother, and will not listen to them even though they discipline him,
21:19 his father and mother shall take hold of him and bring him out to the elders at the gate of his home city,
21:20 where they shall say to the elders of the city, This son of ours is a stubborn and rebellious fellow who will not listen to us; he is a glutton and a drunkard.
21:21 Then all his fellow citizens shall stone him to death. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst, and all Israel will hear and be afraid.
21:22 If a man guilty of a capital offense is put to death and you hang him on a tree,
21:23 his corpse shall not remain on the tree overnight. You must bury it the same day; anyone who is hanged is a curse of God. You shall not defile the land which the , your God, is giving you as a heritage.
22:1 You shall not see your neighbors ox or sheep going astray and ignore it; you must bring it back.
22:2 If this neighbor does not live near you, or you do not know who the owner may be, take it to your own house and keep it with you until your neighbor claims it; then return it.
22:3 You shall do the same with a donkey; you shall do the same with a garment; and you shall do the same with anything else which your neighbor loses and you happen to find. You may not ignore them.
22:4 You shall not see your neighbors donkey or ox fallen on the road and ignore it; you must help in lifting it up.
22:5 A woman shall not wear a mans garment, nor shall a man put on a womans clothing; for anyone who does such things is an abomination to the , your God.
22:6 If, while walking along, you come across a birds nest with young birds or eggs in it, in any tree or on the ground, and the mother bird is sitting on them, you shall not take away the mother bird along with her brood.
22:7 You must let the mother go, taking only her brood, in order that you shall prosper and have a long life.
22:8 When you build a new house, put a parapet around the roof, so that you do not bring bloodguilt upon your house if someone falls off.
22:9 You shall not sow your vineyard with two different kinds of seed, or else its produce shall become forfeit, both the crop you have sown and the yield of the vineyard.
22:10 You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey harnessed together.
22:11 You shall not wear cloth made from wool and linen woven together.
22:12 You shall put tassels on the four corners of the cloak that you wrap around yourself.
22:13 If a man, after marrying a woman and having relations with her, comes to dislike her,
22:14 and accuses her of misconduct and slanders her by saying, I married this woman, but when I approached her I did not find evidence of her virginity,
22:15 the father and mother of the young woman shall take the evidence of her virginity and bring it to the elders at the city gate.
22:16 There the father of the young woman shall say to the elders, I gave my daughter to this man in marriage, but he has come to dislike her,
22:17 and now accuses her of misconduct, saying: I did not find evidence of your daughters virginity. But here is the evidence of my daughters virginity! And they shall spread out the cloth before the elders of the city.
22:18 Then these city elders shall take the man and discipline him,
22:19 and fine him one hundred silver shekels, which they shall give to the young womans father, because the man slandered a virgin in Israel. She shall remain his wife, and he may not divorce her as long as he lives.
22:20 But if this charge is true, and evidence of the young womans virginity is not found,
22:21 they shall bring the young woman to the entrance of her fathers house and there the men of her town shall stone her to death, because she committed a shameful crime in Israel by prostituting herself in her fathers house. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
22:22 If a man is discovered lying with a woman who is married to another, they both shall die, the man who was lying with the woman as well as the woman. Thus shall you purge the evil from Israel.
22:23 If there is a young woman, a virgin who is betrothed, and a man comes upon her in the city and lies with her,
22:24 you shall bring them both out to the gate of the city and there stone them to death: the young woman because she did not cry out though she was in the city, and the man because he violated his neighbors wife. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
22:25 But if it is in the open fields that a man comes upon the betrothed young woman, seizes her and lies with her, only the man who lay with her shall die.
22:26 You shall do nothing to the young woman, since the young woman is not guilty of a capital offense. As when a man rises up against his neighbor and murders him, so in this case:
22:27 it was in the open fields that he came upon her, and though the betrothed young woman may have cried out, there was no one to save her.
22:28 If a man comes upon a young woman, a virgin who is not betrothed, seizes her and lies with her, and they are discovered,
22:29 the man who lay with her shall give the young womans father fifty silver shekels and she will be his wife, because he has violated her. He may not divorce her as long as he lives.
23:1 A man shall not marry his fathers wife, nor shall he dishonor his fathers bed.
23:2 No one whose testicles have been crushed or whose penis has been cut off may come into the assembly of the .
23:3 No one born of an illicit union may come into the assembly of the , nor any descendant of such even to the tenth generation may come into the assembly of the .
23:4 No Ammonite or Moabite may ever come into the assembly of the , nor may any of their descendants even to the tenth generation come into the assembly of the ,
23:5 because they would not come to meet you with food and water on your journey after you left Egypt, and because they hired Balaam, son of Beor, from Pethor in Aram Naharaim, to curse you.
23:6 The , your God, would not listen to Balaam but turned his curse into a blessing for you, because the , your God, loves you.
23:7 Never seek their welfare or prosperity as long as you live.
23:8 Do not abhor the Edomite: he is your brother. Do not abhor the Egyptian: you were a resident alien in his country.
23:9 Children born to them may come into the assembly of the in the third generation.
23:10 When in camp during an expedition against your enemies, you shall keep yourselves from anything bad.
23:11 If one of you becomes unclean because of a nocturnal emission, he shall go outside the camp; he shall not come back into the camp.
23:12 Toward evening, he shall bathe in water; then, when the sun has set, he may come back into the camp.
23:13 Outside the camp you shall have a place set aside where you shall go.
23:14 You shall keep a trowel in your equipment and, when you go outside to relieve yourself, you shall dig a hole with it and then cover up your excrement.
23:15 Since the , your God, journeys along in the midst of your camp to deliver you and to give your enemies over to you, your camp must be holy, so that he does not see anything indecent in your midst and turn away from you.
23:16 You shall not hand over to their master any slaves who have taken refuge with you from their master.
23:17 Let them live among you in any place they choose, in any one of your communities that seems good to them. Do not oppress them.
23:18 There shall be no temple prostitute among the Israelite women, nor a temple prostitute among the Israelite men.
23:19 You shall not offer a prostitutes fee or a dogs pay as any kind of votive offering in the house of the , your God; both these things are an abomination to the , your God.
23:20 You shall not demand interest from your kindred on a loan of money or of food or of anything else which is loaned.
23:21 From a foreigner you may demand interest, but you may not demand interest from your kindred, so that the , your God, may bless you in all your undertakings on the land you are to enter and possess.
23:22 When you make a vow to the , your God, you shall not delay in fulfilling it; for the , your God, will surely require it of you and you will be held guilty.
23:23 Should you refrain from making a vow, you will not be held guilty.
23:24 But whatever your tongue utters you must be careful to do, just as you freely vowed to the , your God, with your own mouth.
23:25 When you go through your neighbors vineyard, you may eat as many grapes as you wish, until you are satisfied, but do not put them in your basket.
23:26 When you go through your neighbors grainfield, you may pluck some of the ears with your hand, but do not put a sickle to your neighbors grain.
24:1 When a man, after marrying a woman, is later displeased with her because he finds in her something indecent, and he writes out a bill of divorce and hands it to her, thus dismissing her from his house,
24:2 if on leaving his house she goes and becomes the wife of another man,
24:3 and the second husband, too, comes to dislike her and he writes out a bill of divorce and hands it to her, thus dismissing her from his house, or if this second man who has married her dies,
24:4 then her former husband, who dismissed her, may not again take her as his wife after she has become defiled. That would be an abomination before the , and you shall not bring such guilt upon the land the , your God, is giving you as a heritage.
24:5 When a man is newly wed, he shall not go out on a military expedition, nor shall any duty be imposed on him. He shall be exempt for one year for the sake of his family, to bring joy to the wife he has married.
24:6 No one shall take a hand mill or even its upper stone as a pledge for debt, for that would be taking as a pledge the debtors life.
24:7 If anyone is caught kidnapping a fellow Israelite, enslaving or selling the victim, that kidnapper shall be put to death. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.
24:8 In an attack of scaly infection you shall be careful to observe exactly and to carry out all the instructions the levitical priests give you, as I have commanded them: observe them carefully.
24:9 Remember what the , your God, did to Miriam on the journey after you left Egypt.
24:10 When you make a loan of any kind to your neighbor, you shall not enter the neighbors house to receive the pledge,
24:11 but shall wait outside until the person to whom you are making the loan brings the pledge outside to you.
24:12 If the person is poor, you shall not sleep in the pledged garment,
24:13 but shall definitely return it at sunset, so that your neighbor may sleep in the garment and bless you. That will be your justice before the , your God.
24:14 You shall not exploit a poor and needy hired servant, whether one of your own kindred or one of the resident aliens who live in your land, within your gates.
24:15 On each day you shall pay the servants wages before the sun goes down, since the servant is poor and is counting on them. Otherwise the servant will cry to the against you, and you will be held guilty.
24:16 Parents shall not be put to death for their children, nor shall children be put to death for their parents; only for ones own crime shall a person be put to death.
24:17 You shall not deprive the resident alien or the orphan of justice, nor take the clothing of a widow as pledge.
24:18 For, remember, you were slaves in Egypt, and the , your God, redeemed you from there; that is why I command you to do this.
24:19 When you reap the harvest in your field and overlook a sheaf in the field, you shall not go back to get it; let it be for the resident alien, the orphan, and the widow, so that the , your God, may bless you in all your undertakings.
24:20 When you knock down the fruit of your olive trees, you shall not go over the branches a second time; let what remains be for the resident alien, the orphan, and the widow.
24:21 When you pick your grapes, you shall not go over the vineyard a second time; let what remains be for the resident alien, the orphan, and the widow.
24:22 For remember that you were slaves in the land of Egypt; that is why I command you to do this.
25:1 When there is a dispute and the parties draw near for judgment, and a decision is given, declaring one party in the right and the other in the wrong,
25:2 if the one in the wrong deserves whipping, the judge shall have him lie down and in the presence of the judge receive the number of lashes the crime warrants.
25:3 Forty lashes may be given, but no more; or else, if more lashes are added to these many blows, your brother will be degraded in your sight. 
25:4 You shall not muzzle an ox when it treads out grain.
25:5 When brothers live together and one of them dies without a son, the widow of the deceased shall not marry anyone outside the family; but her husbands brother shall come to her, marrying her and performing the duty of a brother-in-law.
25:6 The firstborn son she bears shall continue the name of the deceased brother, that his name may not be blotted out from Israel.
25:7 But if a man does not want to marry his brothers wife, she shall go up to the elders at the gate and say, My brother-in-law refuses to perpetuate his brothers name in Israel and does not intend to perform his duty toward me.
25:8 Thereupon the elders of his city shall summon him and speak to him. If he persists in saying, I do not want to marry her,
25:9 his sister-in-law, in the presence of the elders, shall go up to him and strip his sandal from his foot and spit in his face, declaring, This is how one should be treated who will not build up his brothers family!
25:10 And his name shall be called in Israel, the house of the man stripped of his sandal.
25:11 When two men are fighting and the wife of one intervenes to save her husband from the blows of his opponent, if she stretches out her hand and seizes the latter by his genitals,
25:12 you shall chop off her hand; show no pity.
25:13 You shall not keep two differing weights in your bag, one heavy and the other light;
25:14 nor shall you keep two different ephahs in your house, one large and the other small.
25:15 But use a full and just weight, a full and just ephah, so that you may have a long life on the land the , your God, is giving you.
25:16 For everyone who does these things, everyone who does what is dishonest, is an abomination to the , your God.
25:17 Bear in mind what Amalek did to you on the journey after you left Egypt,
25:18 how he surprised you along the way, weak and weary as you were, and struck down at the rear all those who lagged behind; he did not fear God.
25:19 Therefore, when the , your God, gives you rest from all your enemies round about in the land which the , your God, is giving you to possess as a heritage, you shall blot out the memory of Amalek from under the heavens. Do not forget!
26:1 When you have come into the land which the , your God, is giving you as a heritage, and have taken possession and settled in it,
26:2 you shall take some first fruits of the various products of the soil which you harvest from the land the , your God, is giving you; put them in a basket and go to the place which the , your God, will choose as the dwelling place for his name.
26:3 There you shall go to the priest in office at that time and say to him, Today I acknowledge to the , my God, that I have indeed come into the land which the swore to our ancestors to give us.
26:4 The priest shall then take the basket from your hands and set it in front of the altar of the , your God.
26:5 Then you shall declare in the presence of the , your God, My father was a refugee Aramean who went down to Egypt with a small household and lived there as a resident alien. But there he became a nation great, strong and numerous.
26:6 When the Egyptians maltreated and oppressed us, imposing harsh servitude upon us,
26:7 we cried to the , the God of our ancestors, and the heard our cry and saw our affliction, our toil and our oppression.
26:8 Then the brought us out of Egypt with a strong hand and outstretched arm, with terrifying power, with signs and wonders,
26:9 and brought us to this place, and gave us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey.
26:10 Now, therefore, I have brought the first fruits of the products of the soil which you, , have given me. You shall set them before the , your God, and you shall bow down before the , your God.
26:11 Then you and your household, together with the Levite and the resident aliens who live among you, shall celebrate with all these good things which the , your God, has given you.
26:12 When you have finished setting aside all the tithes of your produce in the third year, the year of the tithes, and have given them to the Levite, the resident alien, the orphan and the widow, that they may eat and be satisfied in your own communities,
26:13 you shall declare before the , your God, I have purged my house of the sacred portion and I have given it to the Levite, the resident alien, the orphan and the widow, just as you have commanded me. I have not transgressed any of your commandments, nor forgotten any.
26:14 I have not eaten any of the tithe while in mourning; I have not brought any of it while unclean; I have not offered any of it to the dead. I have thus obeyed the voice of the , my God, and done just as you have commanded me.
26:15 Look down, then, from heaven, your holy abode, and bless your people Israel and the fields you have given us, as you promised on oath to our ancestors, a land flowing with milk and honey.
26:16 This day the , your God, is commanding you to observe these statutes and ordinances. Be careful, then, to observe them with your whole heart and with your whole being.
26:17 Today you have accepted the s agreement: he will be your God, and you will walk in his ways, observe his statutes, commandments, and ordinances, and obey his voice.
26:18 And today the has accepted your agreement: you will be a people specially his own, as he promised you, you will keep all his commandments,
26:19 and he will set you high in praise and renown and glory above all nations he has made, and you will be a people holy to the , your God, as he promised.
27:1 Then Moses, with the elders of Israel, commanded the people, saying: Keep this whole commandment which I give you today.
27:2 On the day you cross the Jordan into the land which the , your God, is giving you, set up some large stones and coat them with plaster.
27:3 Write on them, at the time you cross, all the words of this law, so that you may enter the land which the , your God, is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the , the God of your ancestors, promised you.
27:4 When you cross the Jordan, on Mount Ebal you shall set up these stones concerning which I command you today, and coat them with plaster,
27:5 and you shall build there an altar to the , your God, an altar made of stones that no iron tool has touched.
27:6 You shall build this altar of the , your God, with unhewn stones, and shall offer on it burnt offerings to the , your God.
27:7 You shall also offer communion sacrifices and eat them there, rejoicing in the presence of the , your God.
27:8 On the stones you shall inscribe all the words of this law very clearly.
27:9 Moses, with the levitical priests, then said to all Israel: Be silent, Israel, and listen! This day you have become the people of the , your God.
27:10 You shall obey the voice of the , your God, and keep his commandments and statutes which I am giving you today.
27:11 That same day Moses commanded the people, saying:
27:12 When you cross the Jordan, these shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph and Benjamin.
27:13 And these shall stand on Mount Ebal for the curse: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan and Naphtali.
27:14 The Levites shall proclaim in a loud voice to all the Israelites:
27:15 Cursed be anyone who makes a carved or molten idol, an abomination to the , the work of a craftsmans hands, and sets it up in secret! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:16 Cursed be anyone who dishonors father or mother! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:17 Cursed be anyone who moves a neighbors boundary markers! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:18 Cursed be anyone who misleads the blind on their way! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:19 Cursed be anyone who deprives the resident alien, the orphan or the widow of justice! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:20 Cursed be anyone who has relations with his fathers wife, for he dishonors his fathers bed! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:21 Cursed be anyone who has relations with any animal! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:22 Cursed be anyone who has relations with his sister, whether his fathers daughter or his mothers daughter! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:23 Cursed be anyone who has relations with his mother-in-law! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:24 Cursed be anyone who strikes down a neighbor in secret! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:25 Cursed be anyone who accepts payment to kill an innocent person! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
27:26 Cursed be anyone whose actions do not uphold the words of this law! And all the people shall answer, Amen!
28:1 Now, if you diligently obey the voice of the , your God, carefully observing all his commandments which I give you today, the , your God, will set you high above all the nations of the earth.
28:2 All these blessings will come upon you and overwhelm you when you obey the voice of the , your God:
28:3 May you be blessed in the city, and blessed in the country!
28:4 Blessed be the fruit of your womb, the produce of your soil and the offspring of your livestock, the issue of your herds and the young of your flocks!
28:5 Blessed be your grain basket and your kneading bowl!
28:6 May you be blessed in your coming in, and blessed in your going out!
28:7 The will beat down before you the enemies that rise up against you; they will come out against you from one direction, and flee before you in seven.
28:8 The will affirm the blessing upon you, on your barns and on all your undertakings; he will bless you in the land that the , your God, is giving you.
28:9 The will establish you as a holy people, as he swore to you, if you keep the commandments of the , your God, and walk in his ways.
28:10 All the peoples of the earth will see that the name of the is proclaimed over you, and they will be afraid of you.
28:11 The will generously increase the fruit of your womb, the offspring of your livestock, and the produce of your soil, upon the land which the swore to your ancestors he would give you.
28:12 The will open up for you his rich storehouse, the heavens, to give your land rain in due season and to bless all the works of your hands. You will lend to many nations but borrow from none.
28:13 The will make you the head not the tail, the top not the bottom, if you obey the commandments of the , your God, which I am giving you today, observing them carefully,
28:14 not turning aside, either to the right or to the left, from any of the words which I am giving you today, following other gods and serving them.
28:15 But if you do not obey the voice of the , your God, carefully observing all his commandments and statutes which I give you today, all these curses shall come upon you and overwhelm you:
28:16 May you be cursed in the city, and cursed in the country!
28:17 Cursed be your grain basket and your kneading bowl!
28:18 Cursed be the fruit of your womb, the produce of your soil and the offspring of your livestock, the issue of your herds and the young of your flocks!
28:19 May you be cursed in your coming in, and cursed in your going out!
28:20 The will send on you a curse, panic, and frustration in everything you set your hand to, until you are speedily destroyed and perish for the evil you have done in forsaking me.
28:21 The will make disease cling to you until he has made an end of you from the land you are entering to possess.
28:22 The will strike you with consumption, fever, and inflammation, with fiery heat and drought, with blight and mildew, that will pursue you until you perish.
28:23 The heavens over your heads will be like bronze and the earth under your feet like iron.
28:24 For rain the will give your land powdery dust, which will come down upon you from the heavens until you are destroyed.
28:25 The will let you be beaten down before your enemies; though you advance against them from one direction, you will flee before them in seven, so that you will become an object of horror to all the kingdoms of the earth.
28:26 Your corpses will become food for all the birds of the air and for the beasts of the field, with no one to frighten them off.
28:27 The will strike you with Egyptian boils and with tumors, skin diseases and the itch, from none of which you can be cured.
28:28 And the will strike you with madness, blindness and panic,
28:29 so that even at midday you will grope in the dark as though blind, unable to find your way. You will be oppressed and robbed continually, with no one to come to your aid.
28:30 Though you betroth a wife, another will have her. Though you build a house, you will not live in it. Though you plant a vineyard, you will not pluck its fruits.
28:31 Your ox will be slaughtered before your eyes, but you will not eat its flesh. Your donkey will be stolen in your presence, but you will never get it back. Your flocks will be given to your enemies, with no one to come to your aid.
28:32 Your sons and daughters will be given to another people while you strain your eyes looking for them every day, having no power to do anything.
28:33 A people you do not know will consume the fruit of your soil and of all your labor, and you will be thoroughly oppressed and continually crushed,
28:34 until you are driven mad by what your eyes must look upon.
28:35 The will strike you with malignant boils of which you cannot be cured, on your knees and legs, and from the soles of your feet to the crown of your head.
28:36 The will bring you, and your king whom you have set over you, to a nation which you and your ancestors have not known, and there you will serve other gods, of wood and stone,
28:37 and you will be a horror, a byword, a taunt among all the peoples to which the will drive you.
28:38 Though you take out seed to your field, you will harvest but little, for the locusts will devour it.
28:39 Though you plant and cultivate vineyards, you will not drink or store up the wine, for the worms will eat them.
28:40 Though you have olive trees throughout your country, you will have no oil for ointment, for your olives will drop off.
28:41 Though you beget sons and daughters, they will not remain with you, for they will go into captivity.
28:42 Buzzing insects will take possession of all your trees and the crops of your soil.
28:43 The resident aliens among you will rise above you higher and higher, while you sink lower and lower.
28:44 They will lend to you, not you to them. They will become the head, you the tail.
28:45 All these curses will come upon you, pursuing you and overwhelming you, until you are destroyed, because you would not obey the voice of the , your God, by keeping his commandments and statutes which he gave you.
28:46 They will be a sign and a wonder for you and your descendants for all time.
28:47 Since you would not serve the , your God, with heartfelt joy for abundance of every kind,
28:48 in hunger and thirst, in nakedness and utter want, you will serve the enemies whom the will send against you. He will put an iron yoke on your neck, until he destroys you.
28:49 The will raise up against you a nation from afar, from the end of the earth, that swoops down like an eagle, a nation whose language you do not understand,
28:50 a nation of fierce appearance, that shows neither respect for the aged nor mercy for the young.
28:51 They will consume the offspring of your livestock and the produce of your soil, until you are destroyed; they will leave you no grain or wine or oil, no issue of herd, no young of flock, until they have brought about your ruin.
28:52 They will besiege you in each of your communities, until the great, fortified walls, in which you trust, come tumbling down all over your land. They will besiege you in every community throughout the land which the , your God, has given you,
28:53 and because of the siege and the distress to which your enemy subjects you, you will eat the fruit of your womb, the flesh of your own sons and daughters whom the , your God, has given you.
28:54 The most refined and fastidious man among you will begrudge his brother and his beloved wife and his surviving children,
28:55 any share in the flesh of his children that he himself is using for food because nothing else is left him—such the siege and distress to which your enemy will subject you in all your communities.
28:56 The most fastidious woman among you, who would not venture to set the sole of her foot on the ground, so refined and fastidious is she, will begrudge her beloved husband and her son and daughter
28:57 the afterbirth that issues from her womb and the infants she brings forth because she secretly eats them for want of anything else—such the siege and distress to which your enemy will subject you in your communities.
28:58 If you are not careful to observe all the words of this law which is written in this book, and to fear this glorious and awesome name, the , your God,
28:59 the will bring upon you and your descendants wondrous calamities, severe and constant calamities, and malignant and constant sicknesses.
28:60 He will bring back upon you all the diseases of Egypt which you dread, and they will cling to you.
28:61 Even any sickness or calamity not written in this book of the law, that too the will bring upon you until you are destroyed.
28:62 You who were numerous as the stars of the heavens will be left few in number, because you would not obey the voice of the , your God.
28:63 Just as the once took delight in making you prosper and grow, so will the now take delight in ruining and destroying you, and you will be plucked out of the land you are now entering to possess.
28:64 The will scatter you among all the peoples from one end of the earth to the other, and there you will serve other gods, of wood and stone, which you and your ancestors have not known.
28:65 Among these nations you will find no rest, not even a resting place for the sole of your foot, for there the will give you an anguished heart and wearied eyes and a trembling spirit.
