28:66 Your life will hang in suspense and you will stand in dread both day and night, never sure of your life.
28:67 In the morning you will say, Would that it were evening! and in the evening you will say, Would that it were morning! because of the dread that your heart must feel and the sight that your eyes must see.
28:68 The will send you back in ships to Egypt, by a route which I told you that you would never see again; and there you will offer yourselves for sale to your enemies as male and female slaves, but there will be no buyer.
28:69 These are the words of the covenant which the commanded Moses to make with the Israelites in the land of Moab, in addition to the covenant he made with them at Horeb.
29:1 Moses summoned all Israel and said to them, You have seen with your own eyes all that the did in the land of Egypt to Pharaoh and all his servants and to all his land,
29:2 the great testings your own eyes have seen, and those great signs and wonders.
29:3 But the has not given you a heart to understand, or eyes to see, or ears to hear until this day.
29:4 I led you for forty years in the wilderness. Your clothes did not fall from you in tatters nor your sandals from your feet;
29:5 it was not bread that you ate, nor wine or beer that you drank—so that you might know that I, the , am your God.
29:6 When you came to this place, Sihon, king of Heshbon, and Og, king of Bashan, came out to engage us in battle, but we defeated them
29:7 and took their land, and gave it as a heritage to the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
29:8 Observe carefully the words of this covenant, therefore, in order that you may succeed in whatever you do.
29:9 You are standing today, all of you, in the presence of the , your God—your tribal heads, elders, and officials, all of the men of Israel,
29:10 your children, your wives, and the resident alien who lives in your camp, from those who cut wood to those who draw water for you—
29:11 to enter into the covenant of the , your God, which the , your God, is making with you today, with its curse,
29:12 so that he may establish you today as his people and he may be your God, as he promised you and as he swore to your ancestors, to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
29:13 But it is not with you alone that I am making this covenant, with its curse,
29:14 but with those who are standing here with us today in the presence of the , our God, and with those who are not here with us today.
29:15 You know that we lived in the land of Egypt and that we passed through the nations, that you too passed through
29:16 and saw the loathsome things and idols of wood and stone, of gold and silver, that they possess.
29:17 There may be among you a man or woman, or a clan or tribe, whose heart is now turning away from the , our God, to go and serve the gods of these nations; there may be among you a root bearing poison and wormwood;
29:18 if any such persons, after hearing the words of this curse, should congratulate themselves, saying in their hearts, I am safe, even though I walk in stubbornness of heart, thereby sweeping away moist and dry alike,
29:19 the will never consent to pardon them. Instead, the s burning wrath will flare up against them; every curse written in this book will pounce on them, and the will blot out their names from under the heavens.
29:20 The will single them out from all the tribes of Israel for doom, in keeping with all the curses of the covenant written in this book of the law.
29:21 Future generations, your descendants who will rise up after you, as well as the foreigners who will come here from distant lands, when they see the calamities of this land and the ills the has inflicted upon it—
29:22 all its soil burned out by sulphur and salt, unsown and unfruitful, without a blade of grass, like the catastrophe of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the overthrew in his furious wrath—
29:23 they and all the nations will ask, Why has the dealt thus with this land? Why this great outburst of wrath?
29:24 And they will say, Because they abandoned the covenant of the , the God of their ancestors, which he had made with them when he brought them out of the land of Egypt,
29:25 and they went and served other gods and bowed down to them, gods whom they did not know and whom he had not apportioned to them.
29:26 So the anger of the flared up against this land and brought on it every curse written in this book.
29:27 The uprooted them from their soil in anger, fury, and great wrath, and cast them out into another land, as they are today.
29:28 The hidden things belong to the our God, but the revealed things are for us and for our children forever, to observe all the words of this law.
30:1 When all these things, the blessing and the curse which I have set before you, come upon you, and you take them to heart in any of the nations where the , your God, has dispersed you,
30:2 and return to the , your God, obeying his voice, according to all that I am commanding you today, you and your children, with your whole heart and your whole being,
30:3 the , your God, will restore your fortunes and will have compassion on you; he will again gather you from all the peoples where the , your God, has scattered you.
30:4 Though you may have been dispersed to the farthest corner of the heavens, even from there will the , your God, gather you; even from there will he bring you back.
30:5 The , your God, will then bring you into the land your ancestors once possessed, that you may possess it; and he will make you more prosperous and numerous than your ancestors.
30:6 The , your God, will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, so that you will love the , your God, with your whole heart and your whole being, in order that you may live.
30:7 The , your God, will put all those curses on your enemies and the foes who pursued you.
30:8 You, however, shall again obey the voice of the and observe all his commandments which I am giving you today.
30:9 Then the , your God, will generously increase your undertakings, the fruit of your womb, the offspring of your livestock, and the produce of your soil; for the , your God, will again take delight in your prosperity, just as he took delight in your ancestors,
30:10 because you will obey the voice of the , your God, keeping the commandments and statutes that are written in this book of the law, when you return to the , your God, with your whole heart and your whole being.
30:11 For this command which I am giving you today is not too wondrous or remote for you.
30:12 It is not in the heavens, that you should say, Who will go up to the heavens to get it for us and tell us of it, that we may do it?
30:13 Nor is it across the sea, that you should say, Who will cross the sea to get it for us and tell us of it, that we may do it?
30:14 No, it is something very near to you, in your mouth and in your heart, to do it.
30:15 See, I have today set before you life and good, death and evil.
30:16 If you obey the commandments of the , your God, which I am giving you today, loving the , your God, and walking in his ways, and keeping his commandments, statutes and ordinances, you will live and grow numerous, and the , your God, will bless you in the land you are entering to possess.
30:17 If, however, your heart turns away and you do not obey, but are led astray and bow down to other gods and serve them,
30:18 I tell you today that you will certainly perish; you will not have a long life on the land which you are crossing the Jordan to enter and possess.
30:19 I call heaven and earth today to witness against you: I have set before you life and death, the blessing and the curse. Choose life, then, that you and your descendants may live,
30:20 by loving the , your God, obeying his voice, and holding fast to him. For that will mean life for you, a long life for you to live on the land which the swore to your ancestors, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, to give to them.
31:1 When Moses had finished speaking these words to all Israel,
31:2 he said to them, I am now one hundred and twenty years old and am no longer able to go out and come in; besides, the has said to me, Do not cross this Jordan.
31:3 It is the , your God, who will cross before you; he will destroy these nations before you, that you may dispossess them. (It is Joshua who will cross before you, as the promised.)
31:4 The will deal with them just as he dealt with Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, and with their country, when he destroyed them.
31:5 When, therefore, the delivers them up to you, you shall deal with them according to the whole commandment which I have given you.
31:6 Be strong and steadfast; have no fear or dread of them, for it is the , your God, who marches with you; he will never fail you or forsake you.
31:7 Then Moses summoned Joshua and in the presence of all Israel said to him, Be strong and steadfast, for you shall bring this people into the land which the swore to their ancestors he would give them; it is you who will give them possession of it.
31:8 It is the who goes before you; he will be with you and will never fail you or forsake you. So do not fear or be dismayed.
31:9 When Moses had written down this law, he gave it to the levitical priests who carry the ark of the covenant of the , and to all the elders of Israel.
31:10 Moses commanded them, saying, On the feast of Booths, at the prescribed time in the year for remission which comes at the end of every seven-year period,
31:11 when all Israel goes to appear before the , your God, in the place which he will choose, you shall read this law aloud in the presence of all Israel.
31:12 Assemble the people—men, women and children, as well as the resident aliens who live in your communities—that they may hear and so learn to fear the , your God, and to observe carefully all the words of this law.
31:13 Their children also, who do not know it yet, shall hear and learn to fear the , your God, as long as you live on the land which you are about to cross the Jordan to possess.
31:14 The said to Moses, The time is now approaching for you to die. Summon Joshua, and present yourselves at the tent of meeting that I may commission him. So Moses and Joshua went and presented themselves at the tent of meeting.
31:15 And the appeared at the tent in a column of cloud; the column of cloud stood at the entrance of the tent.
31:16 The said to Moses, Soon you will be at rest with your ancestors, and then this people will prostitute themselves by following the foreign gods among whom they will live in the land they are about to enter. They will forsake me and break the covenant which I have made with them.
31:17 At that time my anger will flare up against them; I will forsake them and hide my face from them; they will become a prey to be devoured, and much evil and distress will befall them. At that time they will indeed say, Is it not because our God is not in our midst that these evils have befallen us?
31:18 Yet I will surely hide my face at that time because of all the evil they have done in turning to other gods.
31:19 Now, write out this song for yourselves. Teach it to the Israelites and have them recite it, so that this song may be a witness for me against the Israelites.
31:20 For when I have brought them into the land flowing with milk and honey which I promised on oath to their ancestors, and they have eaten and are satisfied and have grown fat, if they turn to other gods and serve them, despising me and breaking my covenant,
31:21 then, when great evil and distress befall them, this song will speak to them as a witness, for it will not be forgotten if their descendants recite it. For I know what they are inclined to do even at the present time, before I have brought them into the land which I promised on oath.
31:22 So Moses wrote this song that same day, and he taught it to the Israelites.
31:23 Then he commissioned Joshua, son of Nun, and said to him, Be strong and steadfast, for it is you who will bring the Israelites into the land which I promised them on oath. I myself will be with you.
31:24 When Moses had finished writing out on a scroll the words of this law in their entirety,
31:25 Moses gave the Levites who carry the ark of the covenant of the this order:
31:26 Take this book of the law and put it beside the ark of the covenant of the , your God, that there it may be a witness against you.
31:27 For I already know how rebellious and stiff-necked you will be. Why, even now, while I am alive among you, you have been rebels against the ! How much more, then, after I am dead!
31:28 Assemble all your tribal elders and your officials before me, that I may speak these words for them to hear and so may call heaven and earth to witness against them.
31:29 For I know that after my death you are sure to act corruptly and to turn aside from the way along which I commanded you, so that evil will befall you in time to come because you have done what is evil in the s sight, and provoked him by your deeds.
31:30 Then Moses recited the words of this song in their entirety, for the whole assembly of Israel to hear:
32:1 Give ear, O heavens, and let me speak; let the earth hear the words of my mouth!
32:2 May my teaching soak in like the rain, and my utterance drench like the dew, Like a downpour upon the grass, like a shower upon the crops.
32:3 For I will proclaim the name of the , praise the greatness of our God!
32:4 The Rock—how faultless are his deeds, how right all his ways! A faithful God, without deceit, just and upright is he!
32:5 Yet his degenerate children have treated him basely, a twisted and crooked generation!
32:6 Is this how you repay the , so foolish and unwise a people? Is he not your father who begot you, the one who made and established you?
32:7 Remember the days of old, consider the years of generations past. Ask your father, he will inform you, your elders, they will tell you:
32:8 When the Most High allotted each nation its heritage, when he separated out human beings, He set up the boundaries of the peoples after the number of the divine beings;
32:9 But the s portion was his people; his allotted share was Jacob.
32:10 He found them in a wilderness, a wasteland of howling desert. He shielded them, cared for them, guarded them as the apple of his eye.
32:11 As an eagle incites its nestlings, hovering over its young, So he spread his wings, took them, bore them upon his pinions.
32:12 The alone guided them, no foreign god was with them.
32:13 He had them mount the summits of the land, fed them the produce of its fields; He suckled them with honey from the crags and olive oil from the flinty rock;
32:14 Butter from cows and milk from sheep, with the best of lambs; Bashan bulls and goats, with the cream of finest wheat; and the foaming blood of grapes you drank.
32:15 So Jacob ate and was satisfied, Jeshurun grew fat and kicked; you became fat and gross and gorged. They forsook the God who made them and scorned the Rock of their salvation.
32:16 With strange gods they incited him, with abominations provoked him to anger.
32:17 They sacrificed to demons, to no-gods, to gods they had never known, Newcomers from afar, before whom your ancestors had never trembled.
32:18 You were unmindful of the Rock that begot you, you forgot the God who gave you birth.
32:19 The saw and was filled with loathing, provoked by his sons and daughters.
32:20 He said, I will hide my face from them, and see what becomes of them. For they are a fickle generation, children with no loyalty in them!
32:21 Since they have incited me with a no-god, and provoked me with their empty idols, I will incite them with a no-people; with a foolish nation I will provoke them.
32:22 For by my wrath a fire is kindled that has raged to the depths of Sheol, It has consumed the earth with its yield, and set on fire the foundations of the mountains.
32:23 I will heap evils upon them and exhaust all my arrows against them:
32:24 Emaciating hunger and consuming fever and bitter pestilence, And the teeth of wild beasts I will send among them, with the venom of reptiles gliding in the dust.
32:25 Out in the street the sword shall bereave, and at home the terror For the young man and the young woman alike, the nursing babe as well as the gray beard.
32:26 I said: I will make an end of them and blot out their name from human memory,
32:27 Had I not feared the provocation by the enemy, that their foes might misunderstand, And say, Our own hand won the victory; the had nothing to do with any of it.
32:28 For they are a nation devoid of reason, having no understanding.
32:29 If they had insight they would realize this, they would understand their end:
32:30 How could one rout a thousand, or two put ten thousand to flight, Unless it was because their Rock sold them, the delivered them up?
32:31 Indeed, their rock is not like our Rock; our enemies are fools.
32:32 For their vine is from the vine of Sodom, from the vineyards of Gomorrah. Their grapes are grapes of poison, and their clusters are bitter.
32:33 Their wine is the venom of serpents, the cruel poison of vipers.
32:34 Is not this stored up with me, sealed up in my storehouses?
32:35 Vengeance is mine and recompense, for the time they lose their footing; Because the day of their disaster is at hand and their doom is rushing upon them!
32:36 Surely, the will do justice for his people; on his servants he will have pity. When he sees their strength is gone, and neither bond nor free is left,
32:37 He will say, Where are their gods, the rock in whom they took refuge,
32:38 Who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their libations? Let them rise up now and help you! Let them be your protection!
32:39 See now that I, I alone, am he, and there is no god besides me. It is I who bring both death and life, I who inflict wounds and heal them, and from my hand no one can deliver.
32:40 For I raise my hand to the heavens and will say: As surely as I live forever,
32:41 When I sharpen my flashing sword, and my hand lays hold of judgment, With vengeance I will repay my foes and requite those who hate me.
32:42 I will make my arrows drunk with blood, and my sword shall devour flesh— With the blood of the slain and the captured, from the long-haired heads of the enemy.
32:43 Exult with him, you heavens, bow to him, all you divine beings! For he will avenge the blood of his servants, take vengeance on his foes; He will requite those who hate him, and purge his peoples land.
32:44 So Moses, together with Hoshea, son of Nun, went and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people.
32:45 When Moses had finished speaking all these words to all Israel,
32:46 he said to them, Take to heart all the words that I am giving in witness against you today, words you should command your children, that they may observe carefully every word of this law.
32:47 For this is no trivial matter for you, but rather your very life; by this word you will enjoy a long life on the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess.
32:48 On that very day the said to Moses,
32:49 Ascend this mountain of the Abarim, Mount Nebo in the land of Moab facing Jericho, and view the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the Israelites as a possession.
32:50 Then you shall die on the mountain you are about to ascend, and shall be gathered to your people, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and there was gathered to his people,
32:51 because both of you broke faith with me among the Israelites at the waters of Meribath-kadesh in the wilderness of Zin: you did not manifest my holiness among the Israelites.
32:52 You may indeed see the land from a distance, but you shall not enter that land which I am giving to the Israelites.
33:1 This is the blessing with which Moses, the man of God, blessed the Israelites before he died.
33:2 He said: The came from Sinai and dawned on his people from Seir; he shone forth from Mount Paran. With him were myriads of holy ones; at his right hand advanced the gods.
33:3 Indeed, lover of the peoples, all the holy ones are at your side; They follow at your heels, carry out your decisions.
33:4 Moses charged us with the law, as a possession for the assembly of Jacob.
33:5 A king arose in Jeshurun when the chiefs of the people assembled, and the tribes of Israel united.
33:6 May Reuben live and not die out, but let his numbers be few.
33:7 Of Judah he said this: Hear, , the voice of Judah, and bring him to his people. His own hands defend his cause; be a help against his foes.
33:8 Of Levi he said: Give to Levi your Thummim, your Urim to your faithful one; Him you tested at Massah, contended against him at the waters of Meribah.
33:9 He said of his father and mother, I have no regard for them; His brothers he would not acknowledge, and his own children he did not recognize. For they kept your words, and your covenant they upheld.
33:10 They teach your ordinances to Jacob, your law to Israel. They bring incense to your nostrils, and burnt offerings to your altar.
33:11 Bless, , his strength, be pleased with the work of his hands. Crush the loins of his adversaries and of his foes, that they may not rise.
33:12 Of Benjamin he said: The beloved of the , he abides in safety beside him; He shelters him all day long; the beloved abides at his breast.
33:13 Of Joseph he said: Blessed by the is his land with the best of heaven above and of the abyss crouching beneath;
33:14 With the best of the produce of the sun, and the choicest yield of the months;
33:15 With the finest gifts of the ancient mountains and the best from the everlasting hills;
33:16 With the best of the earth and its fullness, and the favor of the one who dwells on Sinai. Let these come upon the head of Joseph and upon the brow of the prince among his brothers.
33:17 His firstborn bull, majesty is his! His horns are the horns of a wild ox; With them he gores the peoples, attacks the ends of the earth. These are the myriads of Ephraim, and these the thousands of Manasseh.
33:18 Of Zebulun he said: Rejoice, Zebulun, in your expeditions, exult, Issachar, in your tents!
33:19 They invite peoples to the mountain where they offer right sacrifices, Because they suck up the abundance of the seas and the hidden treasures of the sand.
33:20 Of Gad he said: Blessed be the one who has made Gad so vast! He lies there like a lion; he tears the arm, the head as well.
33:21 He saw that the best should be his, for there the commanders portion was assigned; he came at the head of the people. He carried out the justice of the and his ordinances for Israel.
33:22 Of Dan he said: Dan is a lions cub, that springs away from a viper!
33:23 Of Naphtali he said: Naphtali, abounding with favor, filled with the blessing of the , take possession of the west and south.
33:24 Of Asher he said: Most blessed of sons be Asher! May he be the favorite among his brothers, and may he dip his foot in oil!
33:25 May the bolts of your gates be iron and bronze; may your strength endure through all your days!
33:26 There is none like the God of Jeshurun, who rides the heavens in his power, who rides the clouds in his majesty;
33:27 The God of old is a refuge; a support are the arms of the Everlasting. He drove the enemy out of your way and he said, Destroy!
33:28 Israel abides securely, Jacob dwells apart, In a land of grain and wine, where the heavens drip with dew.
33:29 Happy are you, Israel! Who is like you, a people delivered by the , Your help and shield, and the sword of your glory. Your enemies cringe before you; you stride upon their backs.
34:1 Then Moses went up from the plains of Moab to Mount Nebo, the peak of Pisgah which faces Jericho, and the showed him all the land—Gilead, and as far as Dan,
34:2 all Naphtali, the land of Ephraim and Manasseh, all the land of Judah as far as the Western Sea,
34:3 the Negeb, the plain (the valley of Jericho, the City of Palms), and as far as Zoar.
34:4 The then said to him, This is the land about which I promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, I will give it to your descendants. I have let you see it with your own eyes, but you shall not cross over.
34:5 So there, in the land of Moab, Moses, the servant of the , died as the had said;
34:6 and he was buried in a valley in the land of Moab, opposite Beth-peor; to this day no one knows the place of his burial.
34:7 Moses was one hundred and twenty years old when he died, yet his eyes were undimmed and his vigor unabated.
34:8 The Israelites wept for Moses in the plains of Moab for thirty days, till they had completed the period of grief and mourning for Moses.
34:9 Now Joshua, son of Nun, was filled with the spirit of wisdom, since Moses had laid his hands upon him; and so the Israelites gave him their obedience, just as the had commanded Moses.
34:10 Since then no prophet has arisen in Israel like Moses, whom the knew face to face,
34:11 in all the signs and wonders the sent him to perform in the land of Egypt against Pharaoh and all his servants and against all his land,
34:12 and all the great might and the awesome power that Moses displayed in the sight of all Israel.
JOSHUA
1:1 After Moses, the servant of the , had died, the said to Moses aide Joshua, son of Nun:
1:2 Moses my servant is dead. So now, you and the whole people with you, prepare to cross the Jordan to the land that I will give the Israelites.
1:3 Every place where you set foot I have given you, as I promised Moses.
1:4 All the land of the Hittites, from the wilderness and the Lebanon east to the great river Euphrates and west to the Great Sea, will be your territory.
1:5 No one can withstand you as long as you live. As I was with Moses, I will be with you: I will not leave you nor forsake you.
1:6 Be strong and steadfast, so that you may give this people possession of the land I swore to their ancestors that I would give them.
1:7 Only be strong and steadfast, being careful to observe the entire law which Moses my servant enjoined on you. Do not swerve from it either to the right or to the left, that you may succeed wherever you go.
1:8 Do not let this book of the law depart from your lips. Recite it by day and by night, that you may carefully observe all that is written in it; then you will attain your goal; then you will succeed.
1:9 I command you: be strong and steadfast! Do not fear nor be dismayed, for the , your God, is with you wherever you go.
1:10 So Joshua commanded the officers of the people:
1:11 Go through the camp and command the people, Prepare your provisions, for three days from now you shall cross the Jordan here, to march in and possess the land the , your God, is giving as your possession.
1:12 Joshua addressed the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh:
1:13 Remember what Moses, the servant of the , commanded you when he said, The , your God, is about to give you rest; he will give you this land.
1:14 Your wives, your children, and your livestock may remain in the land Moses gave you here beyond the Jordan. But all the warriors among you must cross over armed, ahead of your kindred, and you must help them
1:15 until the has settled your kindred, and they like you possess the land the , your God, is giving them. Afterward you may return and possess your own land, which Moses, the servant of the , has given you east of the Jordan.
1:16 They answered Joshua, We will do all you have commanded us, and we will go wherever you send us.
1:17 As completely as we obeyed Moses, we will obey you. Only, may the , your God, be with you as God was with Moses.
1:18 Anyone who rebels against your orders and does not obey all your commands shall be put to death. Only be strong and steadfast.
2:1 Then Joshua, son of Nun, secretly sent out two spies from Shittim, saying, Go, reconnoiter the land and Jericho. When the two reached Jericho, they went into the house of a prostitute named Rahab, where they lodged.
2:2 But a report was brought to the king of Jericho: Some men came here last night, Israelites, to spy out the land.
2:3 So the king of Jericho sent Rahab the order, Bring out the men who have come to you and entered your house, for they have come to spy out the entire land.
2:4 The woman had taken the two men and hidden them, so she said, True, the men you speak of came to me, but I did not know where they came from.
2:5 At dark, when it was time to close the gate, they left, and I do not know where they went. You will have to pursue them quickly to overtake them.
2:6 Now, she had led them to the roof, and hidden them among her stalks of flax spread out there.
2:7 But the pursuers set out along the way to the fords of the Jordan. As soon as they had left to pursue them, the gate was shut.
2:8 Before the spies lay down, Rahab went up to them on the roof
2:9 and said: I know that the has given you the land, that a dread of you has come upon us, and that all the inhabitants of the land tremble with fear because of you.
2:10 For we have heard how the dried up the waters of the Red Sea before you when you came out of Egypt, and what you did to Sihon and Og, the two kings of the Amorites beyond the Jordan, whom you destroyed under the ban.
2:11 We heard, and our hearts melted within us; everyone is utterly dispirited because of you, since the , your God, is God in heaven above and on earth below.
2:12 Now then, swear to me by the that, since I am showing kindness to you, you in turn will show kindness to my family. Give me a reliable sign
2:13 that you will allow my father and mother, brothers and sisters, and my whole family to live, and that you will deliver us from death.
2:14 We pledge our lives for yours, they answered her. If you do not betray our mission, we will be faithful in showing kindness to you when the gives us the land.
2:15 Then she let them down through the window with a rope; for she lived in a house built into the city wall.
2:16 Go up into the hill country, she said, that your pursuers may not come upon you. Hide there for three days, until they return; then you may go on your way.
2:17 They answered her, We are free of this oath that you made us take, unless,
2:18 when we come into the land, you tie this scarlet cord in the window through which you are letting us down. Gather your father and mother, your brothers, and all your family into your house.
2:19 Should any of them pass outside the doors of your house, their blood will be on their own heads, and we will be guiltless. But if anyone in your house is harmed, their blood will be on our heads.
2:20 If, however, you betray our mission, we will be free of the oath you have made us take.
2:21 Let it be as you say, she replied, and sent them away. When they were gone, she tied the scarlet cord in the window.
2:22 They went up into the hill country, where they stayed three days until their pursuers, who had sought them all along the road without finding them, returned.
2:23 Then the two came back down from the hills, crossed the Jordan to Joshua, son of Nun, and told him all that had happened to them.
2:24 They assured Joshua, The has given all this land into our power; indeed, all the inhabitants of the land tremble with fear because of us.
3:1 Early the next morning, Joshua and all the Israelites moved from Shittim and came to the Jordan, where they stayed before crossing over.
3:2 Three days later the officers went through the camp
3:3 and issued these commands to the people: When you see the ark of the covenant of the , your God, which the levitical priests will carry, you must break camp and follow it,
3:4 that you may know the way to take, for you have not gone over this road before. But let there be a space of two thousand cubits between you and the ark: do not come nearer to it.
3:5 Joshua also said to the people, Sanctify yourselves, for tomorrow the will perform wonders among you.
3:6 And he told the priests, Take up the ark of the covenant and cross ahead of the people; so they took up the ark of the covenant and went before the people.
3:7 Then the said to Joshua: Today I will begin to exalt you in the sight of all Israel, that they may know that, as I was with Moses, so I will be with you.
3:8 Now command the priests carrying the ark of the covenant, When you come to the edge of the waters of the Jordan, there take your stand.
3:9 So Joshua said to the Israelites, Come here and listen to the words of the , your God.
3:10 He continued: By this you will know that there is a living God in your midst: he will certainly dispossess before you the Canaanites, Hittites, Hivites, Perizzites, Girgashites, Amorites, and Jebusites.
3:11 The ark of the covenant of the Lord of the whole earth will cross the Jordan before you.
3:12 Now choose twelve men, one from each of the tribes of Israel.
3:13 When the soles of the feet of the priests carrying the ark of the , the Lord of the whole earth, touch the waters of the Jordan, it will cease to flow; the water flowing down from upstream will halt in a single heap.
3:14 The people set out from their tents to cross the Jordan, with the priests carrying the ark of the covenant ahead of them.
3:15 When those bearing the ark came to the Jordan and the feet of the priests bearing the ark were immersed in the waters of the Jordan—which overflows all its banks during the entire season of the harvest—
3:16 the waters flowing from upstream halted, standing up in a single heap for a very great distance indeed, from Adam, a city in the direction of Zarethan; those flowing downstream toward the Salt Sea of the Arabah disappeared entirely. Thus the people crossed over opposite Jericho.
3:17 The priests carrying the ark of the covenant of the stood on dry ground in the Jordan riverbed while all Israel crossed on dry ground, until the whole nation had completed the crossing of the Jordan.
4:1 After the entire nation had completed the crossing of the Jordan,
4:2 the said to Joshua: Choose twelve men from the people, one from each tribe,
4:3 and command them, Take up twelve stones from this spot in the Jordan riverbed where the priests have been standing. Carry them over with you, and place them where you are to stay tonight.
4:4 Summoning the twelve men he had selected from among the Israelites, one from each tribe,
4:5 Joshua said to them: Go to the Jordan riverbed in front of the ark of the , your God; lift to your shoulders one stone apiece, so that they will equal in number the tribes of the Israelites.
4:6 In the future, these are to be a sign among you. When your children ask you, What do these stones mean to you?
4:7 you shall answer them, The waters of the Jordan ceased to flow before the ark of the covenant of the when it crossed the Jordan. Thus these stones are to serve as a perpetual memorial to the Israelites.
4:8 The twelve Israelites did as Joshua had commanded: they took up twelve stones from the Jordan riverbed as the had said to Joshua, one for each of the tribes of the Israelites. They carried them along to the camp site, and there they placed them.
4:9 Joshua set up the twelve stones that had been in the Jordan riverbed on the spot where the priests stood who were carrying the ark of the covenant. They are there to this day.
4:10 The priests carrying the ark stood in the Jordan riverbed until everything had been done that the had commanded Joshua to tell the people, just as Moses had commanded Joshua. The people crossed over quickly,
4:11 and when all the people had completed the crossing, the ark of the also crossed; and the priests were now in front of them.
4:12 The Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh, armed, marched in the vanguard of the Israelites, as Moses had ordered.
4:13 About forty thousand troops, equipped for battle, crossed over before the to the plains of Jericho for war.
4:14 That day the exalted Joshua in the sight of all Israel, and so during his whole life they feared him as they had feared Moses.
4:15 Then the said to Joshua:
4:16 Command the priests carrying the ark of the covenant to come up from the Jordan.
4:17 Joshua commanded the priests, Come up from the Jordan,
4:18 and when the priests carrying the ark of the covenant of the had come up from the Jordan riverbed, as the soles of their feet regained the dry ground, the waters of the Jordan resumed their course and as before overflowed all its banks.
4:19 The people came up from the Jordan on the tenth day of the first month, and camped in Gilgal on the eastern limits of Jericho.
4:20 At Gilgal Joshua set up the twelve stones that had been taken from the Jordan,
4:21 saying to the Israelites, In the future, when your children ask their parents, What do these stones mean?
4:22 you shall inform them, Israel crossed the Jordan here on dry ground.
4:23 For the , your God, dried up the waters of the Jordan in front of you until you crossed over, just as the , your God, had done at the Red Sea, drying it up in front of us until we crossed over,
4:24 in order that all the peoples of the earth may know that the hand of the is mighty, and that you may fear the , your God, forever.
5:1 When all the kings of the Amorites to the west of the Jordan and all the kings of the Canaanites by the sea heard that the had dried up the waters of the Jordan before the Israelites until they crossed over, their hearts melted and they were utterly dispirited because of the Israelites.
5:2 On this occasion the said to Joshua: Make flint knives and circumcise Israel for the second time.
5:3 So Joshua made flint knives and circumcised the Israelites at Gibeath-haaraloth.
5:4 This was the reason for the circumcision: Of all the people who had come out of Egypt, every male of military age had died in the wilderness during the journey after they came out of Egypt.
5:5 Though all the men who came out were circumcised, none of those born in the wilderness during the journey after the departure from Egypt were circumcised.
5:6 Now the Israelites wandered forty years in the wilderness, until all the warriors among the people that came forth from Egypt died off because they had not listened to the voice of the . For the swore that he would not let them see the land he had sworn to their ancestors to give us, a land flowing with milk and honey.
5:7 It was the children God raised up in their stead whom Joshua circumcised, for these were yet with foreskins, not having been circumcised on the journey.
5:8 When the circumcision of the entire nation was complete, they remained in camp where they were, until they recovered.
5:9 Then the said to Joshua: Today I have removed the reproach of Egypt from you. Therefore the place is called Gilgal to the present day.
5:10 While the Israelites were encamped at Gilgal on the plains of Jericho, they celebrated the Passover on the evening of the fourteenth day of the month.
5:11 On the day after the Passover they ate of the produce of the land in the form of unleavened cakes and parched grain. On that same day
5:12 after they ate of the produce of the land, the manna ceased. No longer was there manna for the Israelites, who that year ate of the yield of the land of Canaan.
5:13 While Joshua was near Jericho, he raised his eyes and saw one who stood facing him, drawn sword in hand. Joshua went up to him and asked, Are you one of us or one of our enemies?
5:14 He replied, Neither. I am the commander of the army of the : now I have come. Then Joshua fell down to the ground in worship, and said to him, What has my lord to say to his servant?
5:15 The commander of the army of the replied to Joshua, Remove your sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy. And Joshua did so.
6:1 Now Jericho was in a state of siege because of the presence of the Israelites. No one left or entered.
6:2 And to Joshua the said: I have delivered Jericho, its king, and its warriors into your power.
6:3 Have all the soldiers circle the city, marching once around it. Do this for six days,
6:4 with seven priests carrying rams horns ahead of the ark. On the seventh day march around the city seven times, and have the priests blow the horns.
6:5 When they give a long blast on the rams horns and you hear the sound of the horn, all the people shall shout aloud. The wall of the city will collapse, and the people shall attack straight ahead.
6:6 Summoning the priests, Joshua, son of Nun, said to them, Take up the ark of the covenant with seven of the priests carrying rams horns in front of the ark of the .
6:7 And he ordered the people, Proceed and surround the city, with the picked troops marching ahead of the ark of the .
6:8 When Joshua spoke to the people, the seven priests who carried the rams horns before the marched and blew their horns, and the ark of the covenant of the followed them.
6:9 In front of the priests with the horns marched the picked troops; the rear guard followed the ark, and the blowing of horns was kept up continually as they marched.
6:10 But Joshua had commanded the people, Do not shout or make any noise or outcry until I tell you, Shout! Then you must shout.
6:11 So he had the ark of the circle the city, going once around it, after which they returned to camp for the night.
6:12 Early the next morning, Joshua had the priests take up the ark of the .
6:13 The seven priests bearing the rams horns marched in front of the ark of the , blowing their horns. Ahead of these marched the picked troops, while the rear guard followed the ark of the , and the blowing of horns was kept up continually.
6:14 On this second day they again marched around the city once before returning to camp; and for six days in all they did the same.
6:15 On the seventh day, beginning at daybreak, they marched around the city seven times in the same manner; on that day only did they march around the city seven times.
6:16 The seventh time around, the priests blew the horns and Joshua said to the people, Now shout, for the has given you the city.
6:17 The city and everything in it is under the ban. Only Rahab the prostitute and all who are in the house with her are to live, because she hid the messengers we sent.
6:18 But be careful not to covet or take anything that is under the ban; otherwise you will bring upon the camp of Israel this ban and the misery of it.
6:19 All silver and gold, and the articles of bronze or iron, are holy to the . They shall be put in the treasury of the .
6:20 As the horns blew, the people began to shout. When they heard the sound of the horn, they raised a tremendous shout. The wall collapsed, and the people attacked the city straight ahead and took it.
6:21 They observed the ban by putting to the sword all living creatures in the city: men and women, young and old, as well as oxen, sheep and donkeys.
6:22 To the two men who had spied out the land, Joshua said, Go into the prostitutes house and bring out the woman with all her family, as you swore to her you would do.
6:23 The spies entered and brought out Rahab, with her father, mother, brothers, and all her family; her entire family they led forth and placed outside the camp of Israel.
6:24 The city itself they burned with all that was in it; but the silver, gold, and articles of bronze and iron they placed in the treasury of the house of the .
6:25 Because Rahab the prostitute had hidden the messengers whom Joshua had sent to reconnoiter Jericho, Joshua let her live, along with her fathers house and all her family, who dwell in the midst of Israel to this day.
6:26 On that occasion Joshua imposed the oath: Cursed before the be the man who attempts to rebuild this city, Jericho. At the cost of his firstborn will he lay its foundation, and at the cost of his youngest son will he set up its gates.
6:27 Thus the was with Joshua so that his fame spread throughout the land.
7:1 But the Israelites acted treacherously with regard to the ban; Achan, son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah of the tribe of Judah, took goods that were under the ban, and the anger of the flared up against the Israelites.
7:2 Joshua next sent men from Jericho to Ai, which is near Beth-aven and east of Bethel, with the order, Go up and reconnoiter the land. When they had explored Ai,
7:3 they returned to Joshua and advised, Do not send all the people up; if only about two or three thousand go up, they can attack and overcome Ai. You need not tire all the people: the enemy there are few.
7:4 About three thousand of the people made the attack, but they fled before the army at Ai,
7:5 who killed some thirty-six of them. They pursued them from the city gate to the Shebarim, and defeated them on the descent, so that the confidence of the people melted away like water.
7:6 Joshua, together with the elders of Israel, tore their garments and fell face down before the ark of the until evening; and they threw dust on their heads.
7:7 Alas, Lord , Joshua prayed, why did you ever allow this people to cross over the Jordan, delivering us into the power of the Amorites, that they might destroy us? Would that we had been content to dwell on the other side of the Jordan.
7:8 Please, Lord, what can I say, now that Israel has turned its back to its enemies?
7:9 When the Canaanites and the other inhabitants of the land hear of it, they will close in around us and efface our name from the earth. What will you do for your great name?
7:10 The replied to Joshua: Stand up. Why are you lying there?
7:11 Israel has sinned: they have transgressed the covenant which I enjoined on them. They have taken goods subject to the ban. They have stolen and lied, placing the goods in their baggage.
7:12 If the Israelites cannot stand up to their enemies, but must turn their back to them, it is because they are under the ban. I will not continue to be with you unless you remove that which is banned from among you.
7:13 Get up, sanctify the people. Tell them, Sanctify yourselves before tomorrow, for thus says the , the God of Israel: That which is banned is in your midst, Israel. You cannot stand up to your enemies until you remove it from among you.
7:14 In the morning you must come forward by tribes. The tribe which the designates shall come forward by clans; the clan which the designates shall come forward by families; the family which the designates shall come forward one by one.
7:15 Whoever is designated as having incurred the ban shall be destroyed by fire, with all that is his, because he has trangressed the covenant of the and has committed a shameful crime in Israel.
7:16 Early the next morning Joshua had Israel come forward by tribes, and the tribe of Judah was designated.
7:17 Then he had the clans of Judah come forward, and the clan of Zerah was designated. He had the clan of Zerah come forward by families, and Zabdi was designated.
7:18 Finally he had that family come forward one by one, and Achan, son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah of the tribe of Judah, was designated.
7:19 Joshua said to Achan, My son, give glory to the , the God of Israel, and praise him by telling me what you have done; do not hide it from me.
7:20 Achan answered Joshua, I have indeed sinned against the , the God of Israel. This is what I have done:
7:21 Among the spoils, I saw a beautiful Babylonian mantle, two hundred shekels of silver, and a bar of gold fifty shekels in weight; I coveted them and I took them. They are now hidden in the ground inside my tent, with the silver underneath.
7:22 Joshua sent messengers and they ran to the tent and there they were, hidden in the tent, with the silver underneath.
7:23 They took them from the tent, brought them to Joshua and all the Israelites, and spread them out before the .
7:24 Then Joshua and all Israel took Achan, son of Zerah, with the silver, the mantle, and the bar of gold, and with his sons and daughters, his ox, his donkey and his sheep, his tent, and all his possessions, and led them off to the Valley of Achor.
7:25 Joshua said, What misery have you caused us? May the bring misery upon you today! And all Israel stoned him to death. They burnt them with fire and they stoned them.
7:26 Over Achan they piled a great heap of stones, which remains to the present day. Then the turned from his anger. That is why the place is called the Valley of Achor to this day.
8:1 The then said to Joshua: Do not be afraid or dismayed. Take all the army with you and prepare to attack Ai. I have delivered the king of Ai into your power, with his people, city, and land.
8:2 Do to Ai and its king what you did to Jericho and its king—except that you may take its spoil and livestock as plunder. Set an ambush behind the city.
8:3 So Joshua and all the soldiers prepared to attack Ai. Picking out thirty thousand warriors, Joshua sent them off by night
8:4 with these orders: See that you ambush the city from the rear. Do not be very far from the city. All of you must be ready.
8:5 The rest of the people and I will come up to the city, and when they make a sortie against us as they did the last time, we will flee from them.
8:6 They will keep coming out after us until we have drawn them away from the city, for they will think, They are fleeing from us as they did the last time. When we flee,
8:7 then you rise from ambush and take possession of the city, which the , your God, will deliver into your power.
8:8 When you have taken the city, set it on fire in obedience to the s command. These are my orders to you.
8:9 Then Joshua sent them away. They went to the place of ambush, taking up their position to the west of Ai, toward Bethel. Joshua, however, spent that night with the army.
8:10 Early the next morning Joshua mustered the army and went up to Ai at its head, with the elders of Israel.
8:11 When all the troops he led were drawn up in position before the city, they pitched camp north of Ai, on the other side of the ravine.
8:12 He took about five thousand warriors and set them in ambush between Bethel and Ai, west of the city.
8:13 Thus the people took up their stations, with the main body north of the city and the ambush west of it, and Joshua waited overnight in the valley.
8:14 The king of Ai saw this, and he and all his army came out very early in the morning to engage Israel in battle at the place in front of the Arabah, not knowing that there was an ambush behind the city.
8:15 Joshua and the main body of the Israelites fled toward the wilderness, pretending defeat,
8:16 until the last of the soldiers in the city had been called out to pursue them. Since they were drawn away from the city, with everyone pursuing Joshua,
8:17 not a soldier remained in Ai or Bethel. They abandoned the city, leaving it open, as they pursued Israel.
8:18 Then the directed Joshua: Stretch out the javelin in your hand toward Ai, for I will deliver it into your power. Joshua stretched out the javelin in his hand toward the city,
8:19 and as soon as he did so, the men in ambush rose from their post, rushed in, captured the city, and immediately set it on fire.
8:20 By the time the army of Ai looked back, the smoke from the city was going up to the heavens. Escape in any direction was impossible, because the Israelites retreating toward the wilderness now turned on their pursuers;
8:21 for when Joshua and the main body of Israelites saw that the city had been taken by ambush and was going up in smoke, they struck back at the forces of Ai.
8:22 Since those in the city came out to intercept them, Ais army was hemmed in by Israelites on both sides, who cut them down without any fugitives or survivors
8:23 except the king, whom they took alive and brought to Joshua.
8:24 When Israel finished killing all the inhabitants of Ai in the open, who had pursued them into the wilderness, and all of them to the last man fell by the sword, then all Israel returned and put to the sword those inside the city.
8:25 There fell that day a total of twelve thousand men and women, the entire population of Ai.
8:26 Joshua kept the javelin in his hand stretched out until he had carried out the ban on all the inhabitants of Ai.
8:27 However, the Israelites took for themselves as plunder the livestock and the spoil of that city, according to the command of the issued to Joshua.
8:28 Then Joshua destroyed Ai by fire, reducing it to an everlasting mound of ruins, as it remains today.
8:29 He had the king of Ai hanged on a tree until evening; then at sunset Joshua ordered the body removed from the tree and cast at the entrance of the city gate, where a great heap of stones was piled up over it, which remains to the present day.
8:30 Later, on Mount Ebal, Joshua built to the , the God of Israel, an altar
8:31 of unhewn stones on which no iron tool had been used, just as Moses, the servant of the , had commanded the Israelites, as recorded in the book of the law. On this altar they sacrificed burnt offerings to the and made communion sacrifices.
8:32 There, in the presence of the Israelites, Joshua inscribed upon the stones a copy of the law written by Moses.
8:33 And all Israel, resident alien and native alike, with their elders, officers, and judges, stood on either side of the ark facing the levitical priests who were carrying the ark of the covenant of the . Half of them were facing Mount Gerizim and half Mount Ebal, just as Moses, the servant of the , had first commanded for the blessing of the people of Israel.
8:34 Then were read aloud all the words of the law, the blessings and the curses, exactly as written in the book of the law.
8:35 Every single word that Moses had commanded, Joshua read aloud to the entire assembly, including the women and children, and the resident aliens among them.
9:1 When the news reached all the kings west of the Jordan, in the mountain regions and in the Shephelah, and all along the coast of the Great Sea as far as the Lebanon: Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites,
9:2 they gathered together to launch a common attack against Joshua and Israel.
9:3 On hearing what Joshua had done to Jericho and Ai, the inhabitants of Gibeon
9:4 formed their own scheme. They chose provisions for a journey, making use of old sacks for their donkeys, and old wineskins, torn and mended.
9:5 They wore old, patched sandals and shabby garments; and all the bread they took was dry and crumbly.
9:6 Thus they journeyed to Joshua in the camp at Gilgal, where they said to him and to the Israelites, We have come from a far-off land; now, make a covenant with us.
9:7 But the Israelites replied to the Hivites, You may be living in land that is ours. How, then, can we make a covenant with you?
9:8 But they answered Joshua, We are your servants. Then Joshua asked them, Who are you? Where do you come from?
9:9 They answered him, Your servants have come from a far-off land, because of the fame of the , your God. For we have heard reports of all that he did in Egypt
9:10 and all that he did to the two kings of the Amorites beyond the Jordan, Sihon, king of Heshbon, and Og, king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth.
9:11 So our elders and all the inhabitants of our land said to us, Take along provisions for the journey and go to meet them. Say to them: We are your servants; now make a covenant with us.
9:12 This bread of ours was still warm when we brought it from home as provisions the day we left to come to you, but now it is dry and crumbly.
9:13 Here are our wineskins, which were new when we filled them, but now they are torn. Look at our garments and sandals; they are worn out from the very long journey.
9:14 Then the Israelite leaders partook of their provisions, without inquiring of the .
9:15 So Joshua made peace with them and made a covenant to let them live, which the leaders of the community sealed with an oath.
9:16 Three days after the covenant was made, the Israelites heard that these people were from nearby, and would be living in Israel.
9:17 The third day on the road, the Israelites came to their cities of Gibeon, Chephirah, Beeroth, and Kiriath-jearim,
9:18 but did not attack them, because the leaders of the community had sworn to them by the , the God of Israel. When the entire community grumbled against the leaders,
9:19 these all remonstrated with the community, We have sworn to them by the , the God of Israel, and so we cannot harm them.
9:20 Let us therefore let them live, and so deal with them that no wrath fall upon us because of the oath we have sworn to them.
9:21 Thus the leaders said to them, Let them live, and become hewers of wood and drawers of water for the entire community. So the community did as the leaders advised them.
9:22 Joshua summoned the Gibeonites and said to them, Why did you deceive us and say, We live far off from you?—You live among us!
9:23 Now are you accursed: every one of you shall always be a slave, hewers of wood and drawers of water, for the house of my God.
9:24 They answered Joshua, Your servants were fully informed of how the , your God, commanded Moses his servant that you be given the entire land and that all its inhabitants be destroyed before you. Since, therefore, at your advance, we were in great fear for our lives, we acted as we did.
9:25 And now that we are in your power, do with us what is good and right in your eyes.
9:26 Joshua did what he had decided: while he saved them from being killed by the Israelites,
9:27 on that day he made them, as they still are, hewers of wood and drawers of water for the community and for the altar of the , in the place the would choose.
10:1 Now when Adonizedek, king of Jerusalem, heard that Joshua had captured Ai and put it under the ban, and had done to that city and its king as he had done to Jericho and its king, and that the inhabitants of Gibeon had made their peace with Israel, remaining among them,
10:2 there was great fear abroad, because Gibeon was a great city, like one of the royal cities, greater even than Ai, and all its men were warriors.
10:3 So Adonizedek, king of Jerusalem, sent to Hoham, king of Hebron, Piram, king of Jarmuth, Japhia, king of Lachish, and Debir, king of Eglon, with this message:
10:4 Come and help me attack Gibeon, for it has made peace with Joshua and the Israelites.
10:5 The five Amorite kings, of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon, gathered with all their forces, and marched against Gibeon to make war on it.
10:6 Thereupon, the Gibeonites sent an appeal to Joshua in his camp at Gilgal: Do not abandon your servants. Come up here quickly and save us. Help us, because all the Amorite kings of the mountain country have joined together against us.
10:7 So Joshua marched up from Gilgal with all his army and all his warriors.
10:8 The said to Joshua: Do not fear them, for I have delivered them into your power. Not one of them will be able to withstand you.
10:9 After an all-night march from Gilgal, Joshua made a surprise attack upon them,
10:10 and the threw them into disorder before Israel. The Israelites inflicted a great slaughter on them at Gibeon and pursued them down the Beth-horon slope, attacking them as far as Azekah and Makkedah.
10:11 While they fled before Israel along the descent of Beth-horon, the hurled great stones from the heavens above them all the way to Azekah, killing many. More died from these hailstones than the Israelites killed with the sword.
10:12 It was then, when the delivered up the Amorites to the Israelites, that Joshua prayed to the , and said in the presence of Israel: Sun, stand still at Gibeon, Moon, in the valley of Aijalon!
10:13 The sun stood still, the moon stayed, while the nation took vengeance on its foes. This is recorded in the Book of Jashar. The sun halted halfway across the heavens; not for an entire day did it press on.
10:14 Never before or since was there a day like this, when the obeyed the voice of a man; for the fought for Israel.
10:15 Then Joshua and all Israel returned to the camp at Gilgal.
10:16 The five kings who had fled hid in the cave at Makkedah.
10:17 When Joshua was told, The five kings have been found, hiding in the cave at Makkedah,
10:18 he said, Roll large stones to the mouth of the cave and post guards over it.
10:19 But do not remain there yourselves. Pursue your enemies, and harry them in the rear. Do not allow them to reach their cities, for the , your God, has delivered them into your power.
10:20 Once Joshua and the Israelites had finally inflicted the last blows in this very great slaughter, and the survivors had escaped from them into the fortified cities,
10:21 all the army returned to Joshua and the camp at Makkedah in victory; no one uttered a sound against the Israelites.
10:22 Then Joshua said, Open the mouth of the cave and bring me those five kings from the cave.
10:23 They did so; they brought out to him from the cave the five kings, of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon.
10:24 When they brought the five kings out to Joshua, he summoned all the army of Israel and said to the commanders of the soldiers who had marched with him, Come forward and put your feet on the necks of these kings. They came forward and put their feet upon their necks.
10:25 Then Joshua said to them, Do not be afraid or dismayed, be firm and steadfast. This is what the will do to all the enemies against whom you fight.
10:26 Thereupon Joshua struck and killed the kings, and hanged them on five trees, where they remained hanging until evening.
10:27 At sunset Joshua commanded that they be taken down from the trees and be thrown into the cave where they had hidden; over the mouth of the cave large stones were placed, which remain until this very day.
10:28 Makkedah, too, Joshua captured and put to the sword at that time. He put the city, its king, and every person in it under the ban, leaving no survivors. Thus he did to the king of Makkedah what he had done to the king of Jericho.
10:29 Joshua then passed on with all Israel from Makkedah to Libnah, and attacked it,
10:30 and the delivered it, with its king, into the power of Israel. He put it to the sword with every person there, leaving no survivors. Thus he did to its king what he had done to the king of Jericho.
10:31 Joshua next passed on with all Israel from Libnah to Lachish, where they set up a camp during the attack.
10:32 The delivered Lachish into the power of Israel, so that on the second day Joshua captured it and put it to the sword with every person in it, just as he had done to Libnah.
10:33 At that time Horam, king of Gezer, came up to help Lachish, but Joshua defeated him and his people, leaving him no survivors.
10:34 From Lachish, Joshua passed on with all Israel to Eglon; encamping near it, they attacked it
10:35 and captured it the same day, putting it to the sword. On that day he put under the ban every person in it, just as he had done at Lachish.
10:36 From Eglon, Joshua went up with all Israel to Hebron, which they attacked
10:37 and captured. They put it to the sword with its king, all its cities, and every person there, leaving no survivors, just as Joshua had done to Eglon. He put it under the ban and every person in it.
10:38 Then Joshua and all Israel turned back to Debir and attacked it,
10:39 capturing it with its king and all its cities. They put them to the sword and put under the ban every person in it, leaving no survivors. Thus he did to Debir and its king what he had done to Hebron, as well as to Libnah and its king.
10:40 Joshua conquered the entire land; the mountain regions, the Negeb, the Shephelah, and the mountain slopes, with all their kings. He left no survivors, but put under the ban every living being, just as the , the God of Israel, had commanded.
10:41 Joshua conquered them from Kadesh-barnea to Gaza, and all the land of Goshen to Gibeon.
10:42 All these kings and their lands Joshua captured all at once, for the , the God of Israel, fought for Israel.
10:43 Thereupon Joshua with all Israel returned to the camp at Gilgal.
11:1 When Jabin, king of Hazor, learned of this, he sent a message to Jobab, king of Madon, to the king of Shimron, to the king of Achshaph,
11:2 and to the northern kings in the mountain regions and in the Arabah near Chinneroth, in the Shephelah, and in Naphath-dor to the west.
11:3 These were Canaanites to the east and west, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, and Jebusites in the mountain regions, and Hivites at the foot of Hermon in the land of Mizpah.
11:4 They came out with all their troops, an army numerous as the sands on the seashore, and with a multitude of horses and chariots.
11:5 All these kings made a pact and together they marched to the waters of Merom, where they encamped to fight against Israel.
11:6 The said to Joshua, Do not fear them, for by this time tomorrow I will present them slain to Israel. You must hamstring their horses and burn their chariots.
11:7 Joshua with his whole army came upon them suddenly at the waters of Merom and fell upon them.
11:8 The delivered them into the power of the Israelites, who defeated them and pursued them to Greater Sidon, to Misrephoth-maim, and eastward to the valley of Mizpeh. They struck them all down, leaving no survivors.
11:9 Joshua did to them as the had commanded: he hamstrung their horses and burned their chariots.
11:10 At that time Joshua, turning back, captured Hazor and struck down its king with the sword; for Hazor formerly was the chief of all those kingdoms.
11:11 He also struck down with the sword every person there, carrying out the ban, till none was left alive. Hazor itself he burned.
11:12 All the cities of those kings, and the kings themselves, Joshua captured and put to the sword, carrying out the ban on them, as Moses, the servant of the , had commanded.
11:13 However, Israel did not destroy by fire any of the cities built on their mounds, except Hazor, which Joshua burned.
11:14 All the spoil and livestock of these cities the Israelites took as plunder; but the people they put to the sword, until they had destroyed the last of them, leaving none alive.
11:15 As the had commanded his servant Moses, so Moses commanded Joshua, and Joshua acted accordingly. He left nothing undone that the had commanded Moses should be done.
11:16 So Joshua took all this land: the mountain regions, the entire Negeb, all the land of Goshen, the Shephelah, the Arabah, as well as the mountain regions and Shephelah of Israel,
11:17 from Mount Halak that rises toward Seir as far as Baal-gad in the Lebanon valley at the foot of Mount Hermon. All their kings he captured and put to death.
11:18 Joshua waged war against all these kings for a long time.
11:19 With the exception of the Hivites who lived in Gibeon, no city made peace with the Israelites; all were taken in battle.
11:20 For it was the s doing to make their hearts obstinate to meet Israel in battle, that they might be put under the ban without mercy, and be destroyed as the had commanded Moses.
11:21 At that time Joshua penetrated the mountain regions and exterminated the Anakim in Hebron, Debir, Anab, the entire mountain region of Judah, and the entire mountain region of Israel. Joshua put them and their cities under the ban,
11:22 so that no Anakim were left in the land of the Israelites. However, some survived in Gaza, in Gath, and in Ashdod.
11:23 Thus Joshua took the whole land, just as the had said to Moses. Joshua gave it to Israel as their heritage, apportioning it among the tribes. And the land had rest from war.
12:1 These are the kings of the land whom the Israelites conquered and whose lands they occupied, east of the Jordan, from the River Arnon to Mount Hermon, including all the eastern section of the Arabah:
12:2 First, Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon. His domain extended from Aroer, which is on the bank of the Wadi Arnon, to include the wadi itself, and the land northward through half of Gilead to the Wadi Jabbok at the border with the Ammonites,
12:3 as well as the Arabah from the eastern side of the Sea of Chinnereth, as far south as the eastern side of the Salt Sea of the Arabah in the direction of Beth-jeshimoth, southward under the slopes of Pisgah.
12:4 Secondly, the border of Og, king of Bashan, a survivor of the Rephaim, who lived at Ashtaroth and Edrei.
12:5 He ruled over Mount Hermon, Salecah, and all Bashan as far as the boundary of the Geshurites and Maacathites, and over half of Gilead as far as the territory of Sihon, king of Heshbon.
12:6 It was Moses, the servant of the , and the Israelites who conquered them; Moses, the servant of the , gave possession of their land to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
12:7 This is a list of the kings of the land whom Joshua and the Israelites conquered west of the Jordan, from Baal-gad in the Lebanon valley to Mount Halak which rises toward Seir; Joshua apportioned their land and gave possession of it to the tribes of Israel;
12:8 it included the mountain regions and Shephelah, the Arabah, the slopes, the wilderness, and the Negeb, belonging to the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites:
12:9 The king of Jericho, one; the king of Ai, which is near Bethel, one;
12:10 the king of Jerusalem, one; the king of Hebron, one;
12:11 the king of Jarmuth, one; the king of Lachish, one;
12:12 the king of Eglon, one; the king of Gezer, one;
12:13 the king of Debir, one; the king of Geder, one;
12:14 the king of Hormah, one; the king of Arad, one;
12:15 the king of Libnah, one; the king of Adullam, one;
12:16 the king of Makkedah, one; the king of Bethel, one;
12:17 the king of Tappuah, one; the king of Hepher, one;
12:18 the king of Aphek, one; the king of Lasharon, one;
12:19 the king of Madon, one; the king of Hazor, one;
12:20 the king of Shimron, one; the king of Achshaph, one;
12:21 the king of Taanach, one; the king of Megiddo, one;
12:22 the king of Kedesh, one; the king of Jokneam, at Carmel, one;
12:23 the king of Dor, in Naphath-dor, one; the king of Goyim at Gilgal, one;
12:24 and the king of Tirzah, one—thirty-one kings in all.
13:1 When Joshua was old and advanced in years, the said to him: Though now you are old and advanced in years, a very large part of the land still remains to be possessed.
13:2 This is the remaining land: all Geshur and all the districts of the Philistines
13:3 (from the stream adjoining Egypt to the boundary of Ekron in the north is reckoned Canaanite territory, though held by the five lords of the Philistines in Gaza, Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron);
13:4 also where the Avvim are in the south; all the land of the Canaanites from Mearah of the Sidonians to Aphek, and the boundaries of the Amorites;
13:5 and the Gebalite territory; and all the Lebanon on the east, from Baal-gad at the foot of Mount Hermon to Lebo-hamath.
13:6 All the inhabitants of the mountain regions between Lebanon and Misrephoth-maim, all Sidonians, I will drive out before the Israelites; at least include these areas in the division of the Israelite heritage, just as I have commanded you.
13:7 Now, therefore, apportion among the nine tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh the land which is to be their heritage.
13:8 Now the other half of the tribe of Manasseh, as well as the Reubenites and Gadites, had taken as their heritage what Moses, the servant of the , had given them east of the Jordan:
13:9 from Aroer on the bank of the Wadi Arnon and the city in the wadi itself, through the tableland of Medeba and Dibon,
13:10 with the rest of the cities of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon, to the boundary of the Ammonites;
13:11 also Gilead and the territory of the Geshurites and Maacathites, all Mount Hermon, and all Bashan as far as Salecah,
13:12 the entire kingdom in Bashan of Og, who was king at Ashtaroth and Edrei (he was a holdover from the remnant of the Rephaim). These Moses defeated and dispossessed.
13:13 But the Israelites did not dispossess the Geshurites and Maacathites, so that Geshur and Maacath dwell in the midst of Israel to this day.
13:14 However, Moses assigned no heritage to the tribe of Levi; the , the God of Israel, is their heritage, as the had promised them.
13:15 This is what Moses gave to the tribe of the Reubenites by their clans:
13:16 Their territory reached from Aroer, on the bank of the Wadi Arnon, and the city in the wadi itself, through the tableland about Medeba,
13:17 to include Heshbon and all its towns on the tableland, Dibon, Bamoth-baal, Beth-baal-meon,
13:18 Jahaz, Kedemoth, Mephaath,
13:19 Kiriathaim, Sibmah, Zereth-shahar on the knoll within the valley,
13:20 Beth-peor, the slopes of Pisgah, Beth-jeshimoth,
13:21 and the other cities of the tableland and of the whole kingdom of Sihon. This Amorite king, who reigned in Heshbon, Moses had defeated, with the princes of Midian, vassals of Sihon who were settled in the land: Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba;
13:22 Balaam, son of Beor, the diviner, the Israelites killed with the sword, together with those they struck down.
13:23 The boundary of the Reubenites was the Jordan. These cities and their villages were the heritage of the Reubenites by their clans.
13:24 This is what Moses gave to the tribe of the Gadites by their clans:
13:25 Their territory included Jazer, all the cities of Gilead, and half the land of the Ammonites as far as Aroer, toward Rabbah
13:26 (that is, from Heshbon to Ramath-mizpeh and Betonim, and from Mahanaim to the boundary of Lo-debar);
13:27 and in the Jordan valley: Beth-haram, Beth-nimrah, Succoth, Zaphon, the other part of the kingdom of Sihon, king of Heshbon, with the bank of the Jordan to the southeastern tip of the Sea of Chinnereth.
13:28 These cities and their villages were the heritage of the clans of the Gadites.
13:29 This is what Moses gave to the half-tribe of Manasseh; the half-tribe of the Manassites, by their clans, had
13:30 territory including Mahanaim, all of Bashan, the entire kingdom of Og, king of Bashan, and all the villages of Jair, which are sixty cities in Bashan.
13:31 Half of Gilead, with Ashtaroth and Edrei, royal cities of Og in Bashan, fell to the descendants of Machir, son of Manasseh, to half the Machirites, by their clans.
13:32 These are the heritages which Moses gave when he was in the plains of Moab, beyond the Jordan east of Jericho.
13:33 But Moses gave no heritage to the tribe of Levi: the , the God of Israel, is their heritage, as he had promised them.
14:1 These are the portions which the Israelites received as heritage in the land of Canaan. Eleazar the priest, Joshua, son of Nun, and the heads of families in the tribes of the Israelites determined
14:2 their heritage by lot, as the had commanded through Moses concerning the remaining nine and a half tribes.
14:3 To two and a half tribes Moses had already given a heritage beyond the Jordan; to the Levites he had given no heritage among them:
14:4 the descendants of Joseph formed two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim. But the Levites were given no share of the land except cities to live in, with their pasture lands for the herds and flocks.
14:5 As the had commanded Moses, so the Israelites did: they apportioned the land.
14:6 When the Judahites approached Joshua in Gilgal, the Kenizzite Caleb, son of Jephunneh, said to him: You know the word the spoke to Moses, the man of God, concerning you and concerning me in Kadesh-barnea.
14:7 I was forty years old when Moses, the servant of the , sent me from Kadesh-barnea to reconnoiter the land; and I brought back to him a frank report.
14:8 My fellow scouts who went up with me made the peoples confidence melt away, but I was completely loyal to the , my God.
14:9 On that occasion Moses swore this oath, The land where you have set foot shall become your heritage and that of your descendants forever, because you have been completely loyal to the , my God.
14:10 Now, as he promised, the has preserved me these forty-five years since the spoke thus to Moses while Israel journeyed in the wilderness; and now I am eighty-five years old,
14:11 but I am still as strong today as I was the day Moses sent me forth, with no less vigor whether it be for war or for any other tasks.
14:12 Now give me this mountain region which the promised me that day, as you yourself heard. True, the Anakim are there, with large fortified cities, but if the is with me I shall be able to dispossess them, as the promised.
14:13 Joshua blessed Caleb, son of Jephunneh, and gave him Hebron as his heritage.
14:14 Therefore Hebron remains the heritage of the Kenizzite Caleb, son of Jephunneh, to the present day, because he was completely loyal to the , the God of Israel.
14:15 Hebron was formerly called Kiriath-arba, for Arba, the greatest among the Anakim. And the land had rest from war.
15:1 The lot for the tribe of Judah by their clans fell toward the boundary of Edom, the wilderness of Zin in the Negeb, in the extreme south.
15:2 Their southern boundary ran from the end of the Salt Sea, from the tongue of land that faces the Negeb,
15:3 and went southward below the pass of Akrabbim, across through Zin, up to a point south of Kadesh-barnea, across to Hezron, and up to Addar; from there, looping around Karka,
15:4 it crossed to Azmon and then joined the Wadi of Egypt before coming out at the sea. (This is your southern boundary.)
15:5 The eastern boundary was the Salt Sea as far as the mouth of the Jordan. The northern boundary climbed northward from the tongue of the sea, toward the mouth of the Jordan,
15:6 up to Beth-hoglah, and ran north of Beth-arabah, up to Eben-Bohan-ben-Reuben.
15:7 Thence the boundary climbed to Debir, north of the Valley of Achor, in the direction of the Gilgal that faces the pass of Adummim, on the south side of the wadi; from there it crossed to the waters of En-shemesh and emerged at En-rogel.
15:8 Climbing again to the Valley of Ben-hinnom on the southern flank of the Jebusites (that is, Jerusalem), the boundary rose to the top of the mountain at the northern end of the Valley of Rephaim, which bounds the Valley of Hinnom on the west.
15:9 From the top of the mountain it ran to the fountain of waters of Nephtoah, extended to the cities of Mount Ephron, and continued to Baalah, or Kiriath-jearim.
15:10 From Baalah the boundary curved westward to Mount Seir and passed north of the ridge of Mount Jearim (that is, Chesalon); it descended to Beth-shemesh, and ran across to Timnah.
15:11 It then extended along the northern flank of Ekron, continued through Shikkeron, and across to Mount Baalah, from there to include Jabneel, before it came out at the sea.
15:12 The western boundary was the Great Sea and its coast. This was the complete boundary of the Judahites by their clans.
15:13 As the had commanded, Joshua gave Caleb, son of Jephunneh, a portion among the Judahites, namely, Kiriath-arba (Arba was the father of Anak), that is, Hebron.
15:14 And Caleb dispossessed from there the three Anakim, the descendants of Anak: Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
15:15 From there he marched up against the inhabitants of Debir, which was formerly called Kiriath-sepher.
15:16 Caleb said, To the man who attacks Kiriath-sepher and captures it, I will give my daughter Achsah in marriage.
15:17 Othniel captured it, the son of Calebs brother Kenaz; so Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah in marriage.
15:18 When she came to him, she induced him to ask her father for some land. Then, as she alighted from the donkey, Caleb asked her, What do you want?
15:19 She answered, Give me a present! Since you have assigned to me land in the Negeb, give me also pools of water. So he gave her the upper and the lower pools.

15:47 Ashdod and its towns and villages; Gaza and its towns and villages, as far as the Wadi of Egypt and the coast of the Great Sea.

15:56 Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah,
15:57 Kain, Gibbeah, and Timnah; ten cities and their villages.
15:58 Halhul, Beth-zur, Gedor,
