15:59 Maarath, Beth-anoth, and Eltekon; six cities and their villages. Tekoa, Ephrathah (that is, Bethlehem), Peor, Etam, Kulom, Tatam, Zores, Karim, Gallim, Bether, and Manoko; eleven cities and their villages.
15:60 Kiriath-baal (that is, Kiriath-jearim) and Rabbah; two cities and their villages.
15:61 In the wilderness: Beth-arabah, Middin, Secacah,
15:62 Nibshan, Ir-hamelah, and En-gedi; six cities and their villages.
15:63 But the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem the Judahites could not dispossess; so the Jebusites dwell in Jerusalem beside the Judahites to the present day.
16:1 The lot that fell to the Josephites extended from the Jordan at Jericho to the waters of Jericho east of the wilderness; then the boundary went up from Jericho to the heights at Bethel.
16:2 Leaving Bethel for Luz, it crossed the ridge to the border of the Archites at Ataroth,
16:3 and descended westward to the border of the Japhletites, to that of the Lower Beth-horon, and to Gezer, and from there to the sea.
16:4 Within the heritage of Manasseh and Ephraim, sons of Joseph,
16:5 the dividing line for the heritage of the Ephraimites by their clans ran from east of Ataroth-addar to Upper Beth-horon
16:6 and thence to the sea. From Michmethath on the north, their boundary curved eastward around Taanath-shiloh, and continued east of it to Janoah;
16:7 from there it descended to Ataroth and Naarah, and reaching Jericho, it ended at the Jordan.
16:8 From Tappuah the boundary ran westward to the Wadi Kanah and ended at the sea. This was the heritage of the Ephraimites by their clans,
16:9 including the villages that belonged to each city set aside for the Ephraimites within the heritage of the Manassites.
16:10 But they did not dispossess the Canaanites living in Gezer; they live within Ephraim to the present day, though they have been put to forced labor.
17:1 Now as for the lot that fell to the tribe of Manasseh as the firstborn of Joseph: since Manassehs eldest son, Machir, the father of Gilead, was a warrior, who had already obtained Gilead and Bashan,
17:2 the allotment was now made to the rest of the Manassites by their clans: the descendants of Abiezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Hepher, and Shemida; these are the other male children of Manasseh, son of Joseph, by their clans.
17:3 Furthermore, Zelophehad, son of Hepher, son of Gilead, son of Machir, son of Manasseh, had no sons, but only daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
17:4 These presented themselves to Eleazar the priest, to Joshua, son of Nun, and to the leaders, saying, The commanded Moses to give us a heritage among our relatives. So in accordance with the command of the a heritage was given them among their fathers relatives.
17:5 Thus ten shares fell to Manasseh apart from the land of Gilead and Bashan beyond the Jordan,
17:6 since these female descendants of Manasseh received each a portion among his sons. The land of Gilead fell to the rest of the Manassites.
17:7 Manasseh bordered on Asher. From Michmethath, near Shechem, another boundary ran southward to include the inhabitants of En-Tappuah,
17:8 because the district of Tappuah belonged to Manasseh, although Tappuah itself was an Ephraimite city on the border of Manasseh.
17:9 This same boundary continued down to the Wadi Kanah. The cities that belonged to Ephraim from among the cities in Manasseh were those to the south of that wadi; thus the territory of Manasseh ran north of the wadi and ended at the sea.
17:10 The land on the south belonged to Ephraim and that on the north to Manasseh; with the sea as their common boundary, they reached Asher on the north and Issachar on the east.
17:11 Moreover, in Issachar and in Asher Manasseh was awarded Beth-shean and its towns, Ibleam and its towns, the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, the inhabitants of Endor and its towns, the inhabitants of Taanach and its towns, the inhabitants of Megiddo and its towns (the third is Naphath-dor).
17:12 Since the Manassites were not able to dispossess these cities, the Canaanites continued to inhabit this region.
17:13 When the Israelites grew stronger they put the Canaanites to forced labor, but they did not dispossess them.
17:14 The descendants of Joseph said to Joshua, Why have you given us only one lot and one share as our heritage? Our people are too many, because of the extent to which the has blessed us.
17:15 Joshua answered them, If you are too many, go up to the forest and clear out a place for yourselves there in the land of the Perizzites and Rephaim, since the mountain regions of Ephraim are so narrow.
17:16 For the Josephites said, Our mountain regions are not enough for us; on the other hand, the Canaanites living in the valley region all have iron chariots, in particular those in Beth-shean and its towns, and those in the valley of Jezreel.
17:17 Joshua therefore said to Ephraim and Manasseh, the house of Joseph, You are a numerous people and very strong. You shall not have merely one share,
17:18 for the mountain region which is now forest shall be yours when you clear it. Its adjacent land shall also be yours if, despite their strength and iron chariots, you dispossess the Canaanites.
18:1 The whole community of the Israelites assembled at Shiloh, where they set up the tent of meeting; and the land was subdued before them.
18:2 There remained seven tribes among the Israelites that had not yet received their heritage.
18:3 Joshua therefore said to the Israelites, How much longer will you put off taking steps to possess the land which the , the God of your ancestors, has given you?
18:4 Choose three representatives from each of your tribes; I will send them to go throughout the land and describe it for purposes of acquiring their heritage. When they return to me
18:5 you shall divide it into seven parts. Judah is to retain its territory in the south, and the house of Joseph its territory in the north.
18:6 You shall bring to me here the description of the land in seven sections. I will then cast lots for you here before the , our God.
18:7 For the Levites have no share among you, because the priesthood of the is their heritage; while Gad, Reuben, and the half-tribe of Manasseh have already received the heritage east of the Jordan which Moses, the servant of the , gave them.
18:8 When those who were to describe the land were ready for their journey, Joshua commanded them, Go throughout the land and describe it; return to me and I will cast lots for you here before the in Shiloh.
18:9 So they went through the land, described its cities in writing in seven sections, and returned to Joshua in the camp at Shiloh.
18:10 Joshua then cast lots for them before the in Shiloh, and divided up the land for the Israelites into their separate shares.
18:11 One lot fell to the tribe of Benjaminites by their clans. The territory allotted them lay between the descendants of Judah and those of Joseph.
18:12 Their northern boundary began at the Jordan and went over the northern flank of Jericho, up westward into the mountains, until it reached the wilderness of Beth-aven.
18:13 From there it crossed over to the southern flank of Luz (that is, Bethel). Then it ran down to Ataroth-addar, on the mountaintop south of Lower Beth-horon.
18:14 For the western border, the boundary line swung south from the mountaintop opposite Beth-horon until it reached Kiriath-baal (that is, Kiriath-jearim; this city belonged to the Judahites). This was the western boundary.
18:15 The southern boundary began at the limits of Kiriath-jearim and projected to the spring at Nephtoah.
18:16 It went down to the edge of the mountain on the north of the Valley of Rephaim, where it faces the Valley of Ben-hinnom; and continuing down the Valley of Hinnom along the southern flank of the Jebusites, reached En-rogel.
18:17 Inclining to the north, it extended to En-shemesh, and thence to Geliloth, opposite the pass of Adummim. Then it dropped to Eben-Bohan-ben-Reuben,
18:18 across the northern flank of the Arabah overlook, down into the Arabah.
18:19 From there the boundary continued across the northern flank of Beth-hoglah and extended northward to the tongue of the Salt Sea, toward the southern end of the Jordan. This was the southern boundary.
18:20 The Jordan bounded it on the east. This was how the heritage of the Benjaminites by their clans was bounded on all sides.
18:21 Now the cities belonging to the tribe of the Benjaminites by their clans were: Jericho, Beth-hoglah, Emek-keziz,
18:22 Beth-arabah, Zemaraim, Bethel,
18:23 Avvim, Parah, Ophra,
18:24 Chephar-ammoni, Ophni, and Geba; twelve cities and their villages.
18:25 Also Gibeon, Ramah, Beeroth,
18:26 Mizpeh, Chephirah, Mozah,
18:27 Rekem, Irpeel, Taralah,
18:28 Zela, Haeleph, the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem), Gibeah, and Kiriath; fourteen cities and their villages. This was the heritage of the clans of Benjaminites.
19:1 The second lot fell to Simeon. The heritage of the tribe of Simeonites by their clans lay within that of the Judahites.
19:2 For their heritage they received Beer-sheba, Shema, Moladah,
19:3 Hazar-shual, Balah, Ezem,
19:4 Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah,
19:5 Ziklag, Bethmar-caboth, Hazar-susah,
19:6 Beth-lebaoth, and Sharuhen; thirteen cities and their villages.
19:7 Also Ain, Rimmon, Ether, and Ashan; four cities and their villages,
19:8 besides all the villages around these cities as far as Baalath-beer (that is, Ramoth-negeb). This was the heritage of the tribe of the Simeonites by their clans.
19:9 This heritage of the Simeonites was within the confines of the Judahites; for since the portion of the latter was too large for them, the Simeonites obtained their heritage within it.
19:10 The third lot fell to the Zebulunites by their clans. The boundary of their heritage was at Sarid.
19:11 Their boundary went up west and through Mareal, reaching Dabbesheth and the wadi that is near Jokneam.
19:12 From Sarid eastward it ran to the district of Chisloth-tabor, on to Daberath, and up to Japhia.
19:13 From there it continued eastward to Gath-hepher and to Eth-kazin, extended to Rimmon, and turned to Neah.
19:14 Skirting north of Hannathon, the boundary ended at the valley of Iphtahel.
19:15 Thus, with Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem, there were twelve cities and their villages.
19:16 This was the heritage of the Zebulunites by their clans, these cities and their villages.
19:17 The fourth lot fell to Issachar. The territory of the Issacharites by their clans
19:18 included Jezreel, Chesulloth, Shunem,
19:19 Hapharaim, Shion, Anaharath,
19:20 Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
19:21 Remeth, En-gannim, En-haddah, and Beth-pazzez.
19:22 The boundary reached Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth-shemesh, ending at the Jordan: sixteen cities and their villages.
19:23 This was the heritage of the Issacharites by their clans, these cities and their villages.
19:24 The fifth lot fell to the Asherites by their clans.
19:25 Their territory included Helkath, Hali, Beten, Achshaph,
19:26 Allammelech, Amad, and Mishal, and reached Carmel on the west, and Shihor-libnath.
19:27 In the other direction, it ran eastward of Beth-dagon, reached Zebulun and the valley of Iphtahel; then north of Beth-emek and Neiel, it extended northward to Cabul,
19:28 Ebron, Rehob, Hammon, and Kanah, near Greater Sidon.
19:29 Then the boundary turned back to Ramah and to the fortress city of Tyre; thence it cut back to Hosah and ended at the sea. Thus, with Mahalab, Achzib,
19:30 Ummah, Acco, Aphek, and Rehob, there were twenty-two cities and their villages.
19:31 This was the heritage of the tribe of the Asherites by their clans, these cities and their villages.
19:32 The sixth lot fell to the Naphtalites.
19:33 Their boundary extended from Heleph, from the oak at Zaanannim, including Adami-nekeb and Jabneel, to Lakkum, and ended at the Jordan.
19:34 In the opposite direction, westerly, it ran through Aznoth-tabor and from there extended to Hukkok; it reached Zebulun on the south, Asher on the west, and the Jordan on the east.
19:35 The fortified cities were Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Chinnereth,
19:36 Adamah, Ramah, Hazor,
19:37 Kedesh, Edrei, En-hazor,
19:38 Yiron, Migdal-el, Horem, Beth-anath, and Beth-shemesh; nineteen cities and their villages.
19:39 This was the heritage of the tribe of the Naphtalites by their clans, these cities and their villages.
19:40 The seventh lot fell to the tribe of Danites by their clans.
19:41 Their heritage was the territory of Zorah, Eshtaol, Ir-shemesh,
19:42 Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Ithlah,
19:43 Elon, Timnah, Ekron,
19:44 Eltekoh, Gibbethon, Baalath,
19:45 Jehud, Bene-berak, Gath-rimmon,
19:46 Me-jarkon, and Rakkon, with the coast at Joppa.
19:47 But the territory of the Danites was too small for them; so the Danites marched up and attacked Leshem, which they captured and put to the sword. Once they had taken possession of Leshem, they dwelt there and named it after their ancestor Dan.
19:48 This was the heritage of the tribe of the Danites by their clans, these cities and their villages.
19:49 When the last of them had received the portions of the land they were to inherit, the Israelites assigned a heritage in their midst to Joshua, son of Nun.
19:50 According to the command of the , they gave him the city he requested, Timnah-serah in the mountain region of Ephraim. He rebuilt the city and made it his home.
19:51 These are the heritages which Eleazar the priest, Joshua, son of Nun, and the heads of families in the tribes of the Israelites apportioned by lot in the presence of the , at the door of the tent of meeting in Shiloh. Thus they finished dividing the land.
20:1 The said to Joshua:
20:2 Tell the Israelites: Designate for yourselves the cities of refuge of which I spoke to you through Moses,
20:3 to which anyone guilty of inadvertent and unintentional homicide may flee for asylum from the avenger of blood.
20:4 To one of these cities the killer shall flee, and standing at the entrance of the city gate, shall plead his case in the hearing of the elders of the city, who must receive him and assign him a place in which to live among them.
20:5 Though the avenger of blood pursues him, they shall not deliver up to him the one who killed a neighbor unintentionally, when there had been no hatred previously.
20:6 Once he has stood judgment before the community, he shall live on in that city until the death of the high priest who is in office at the time. Then the killer may return home to the city from where he originally fled.
20:7 So they set apart Kedesh in Galilee in the mountain region of Naphtali, Shechem in the mountain region of Ephraim, and Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron) in the mountain region of Judah.
20:8 And beyond the Jordan east of Jericho they designated Bezer in the wilderness on the tableland in the tribe of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead in the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashan in the tribe of Manasseh.
20:9 These are the designated cities to which any Israelite or alien residing among them who had killed a person unintentionally might flee to escape death at the hand of the avenger of blood, until the killer could appear before the community.
21:1 The heads of the Levite families approached Eleazar the priest, Joshua, son of Nun, and the heads of families of the other tribes of the Israelites
21:2 at Shiloh in the land of Canaan, and said to them, The commanded, through Moses, that cities be given us to dwell in, with pasture lands for our livestock.
21:3 Out of their own heritage, according to the command of the , the Israelites gave the Levites the following cities with their pasture lands.
21:4 When the first lot among the Levites fell to the clans of the Kohathites, the descendants of Aaron the priest obtained by lot from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, thirteen cities.
21:5 From the clans of the tribe of Ephraim, from the tribe of Dan, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh, the rest of the Kohathites obtained by lot ten cities.
21:6 From the clans of the tribe of Issachar, from the tribe of Asher, from the tribe of Naphtali, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh, the Gershonites obtained by lot thirteen cities.
21:7 From the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun, the clans of the Merarites obtained twelve cities.
21:8 These cities with their pasture lands the Israelites gave by lot to the Levites, as the had commanded through Moses.
21:9 From the tribes of the Judahites and Simeonites they gave the following cities
21:10 and assigned them to the descendants of Aaron in the Kohathite clan of the Levites, since the first lot fell to them:
21:11 first, Kiriath-arba (Arba was the father of Anak), that is, Hebron, in the mountain region of Judah, with the adjacent pasture lands,
21:12 although the open country and villages belonging to the city had been given to Caleb, son of Jephunneh, as his holding.
21:13 Thus to the descendants of Aaron the priest were given the city of refuge for homicides at Hebron, with its pasture lands; also, Libnah with its pasture lands,
21:14 Jattir with its pasture lands, Eshtemoa with its pasture lands,
21:15 Holon with its pasture lands, Debir with its pasture lands,
21:16 Ain with its pasture lands, Juttah with its pasture lands, and Beth-shemesh with its pasture lands: nine cities from these two tribes.
21:17 From the tribe of Benjamin they obtained Gibeon with its pasture lands, Geba with its pasture lands,
21:18 Anathoth with its pasture lands, and Almon with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:19 These cities which with their pasture lands belonged to the priestly descendants of Aaron, were thirteen in all.
21:20 The rest of the Kohathite clans among the Levites obtained by lot, from the tribe of Ephraim, four cities.
21:21 They were assigned, with its pasture lands, the city of refuge for homicides at Shechem in the mountain region of Ephraim; also Gezer with its pasture lands,
21:22 Kibzaim with its pasture lands, and Beth-horon with its pasture lands.
21:23 From the tribe of Dan they obtained Elteke with its pasture lands, Gibbethon with its pasture lands,
21:24 Aijalon with its pasture lands, and Gath-rimmon with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:25 From the half-tribe of Manasseh, Taanach with its pasture lands, and Gath-rimmon with its pasture lands: two cities.
21:26 These cities which with their pasture lands belonged to the rest of the Kohathite clans were ten in all.
21:27 The Gershonite clan of the Levites received from the half-tribe of Manasseh the city of refuge for homicides at Golan in Bashan, with its pasture lands; and also Beth-Astharoth with its pasture lands: two cities.
21:28 From the tribe of Issachar they obtained Kishion with its pasture lands, Daberath with its pasture lands,
21:29 Jarmuth with its pasture lands, and En-gannim with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:30 From the tribe of Asher, Mishal with its pasture lands, Abdon with its pasture lands,
21:31 Helkath with its pasture lands, and Rehob with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:32 From the tribe of Naphtali, the city of refuge for homicides at Kedesh in Galilee, with its pasture lands; also Hammath with its pasture lands, and Kartan with its pasture lands: three cities.
21:33 The cities which belonged to the Gershonite clans, with their pasture lands, were thirteen in all.
21:34 The Merarite clans, the last of the Levites, received, from the tribe of Zebulun, Jokneam with its pasture lands, Kartah with its pasture lands,
21:35 Dimnah with its pasture lands, and Nahalal with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:36 Also, across the Jordan, from the tribe of Reuben, the city of refuge for homicides at Bezer with its pasture lands, Jahaz with its pasture lands,
21:37 Kedemoth with its pasture lands, and Mephaath with its pasture lands: four cities.
21:38 From the tribe of Gad, the city of refuge for homicides at Ramoth in Gilead with its pasture lands, Mahanaim with its pasture lands,
21:39 Heshbon with its pasture lands, and Jazer with its pasture lands: four cities in all.
21:40 The cities allotted to the Merarite clans, the last of the Levites, were therefore twelve in all.
21:41 Thus the total number of cities within the territory of the Israelites which, with their pasture lands, belonged to the Levites, was forty-eight.
21:42 With each and every one of these cities went the pasture lands round about it.
21:43 And so the gave Israel the entire land he had sworn to their ancestors he would give them. Once they had taken possession of it, and dwelt in it,
21:44 the gave them peace on every side, just as he had promised their ancestors. Not one of their enemies could withstand them; the gave all their enemies into their power.
21:45 Not a single word of the blessing that the had promised to the house of Israel failed; it all came true.
22:1 At that time Joshua summoned the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh
22:2 and said to them: You have observed all that Moses, the servant of the , commanded you, and have listened to my voice in everything I commanded you.
22:3 For many years now, even until today, you have not abandoned your allies, but have taken care to observe the commands of the , your God.
22:4 Now that the , your God, has settled your allies as he promised them, you may return to your tents, to your own land, which Moses, the servant of the , gave you, across the Jordan.
22:5 But be very careful to observe the commandment and the law which Moses, the servant of the , commanded you: love the , your God, follow him in all his ways, keep his commandments, hold fast to him, and serve him with your whole heart and your whole self.
22:6 Joshua then blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their tents.
22:7 (For, to half of the tribe of Manasseh Moses had assigned land in Bashan; and to the other half Joshua had given a portion along with their allies west of the Jordan.) When Joshua sent them away to their tents and blessed them,
22:8 he said, Now that you are returning to your own tents with great wealth, with abundant livestock, with silver, gold, bronze and iron, and with a very large supply of clothing, divide these spoils of your enemies with your allies there.
22:9 So the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh left the other Israelites at Shiloh in the land of Canaan and returned to the land of Gilead, their own land, which they had received according to the s command through Moses.
22:10 When the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh came to the region of the Jordan in the land of Canaan, they built an altar there at the Jordan, an impressively large altar.
22:11 The other Israelites heard the report: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh have built an altar in the region of the Jordan facing the land of Canaan, across from the Israelites.
22:12 When the Israelites heard this, they assembled at Shiloh, as the entire Israelite community to take military action against them.
22:13 The Israelites sent Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest, to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead,
22:14 and with him ten leaders, one from each tribe of Israel, each one the head of an ancestral house among the clans of Israel.
22:15 When these came to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead, they said to them:
22:16 Thus says the whole community of the : What act of treachery is this you have committed against the God of Israel? This day you have turned from following the ; by building an altar of your own you have rebelled against the this day.
22:17 Is the iniquity of Peor not enough, by which we made ourselves impure, even to this day, and a plague came upon the community of the ?
22:18 If today you turn away from following the , and rebel against the , tomorrow he will be angry with the whole community of Israel!
22:19 If you consider the land you now possess unclean, cross over to the land the possesses, where the tabernacle of the stands, and share that with us. But do not rebel against the , nor involve us in rebellion, by building an altar of your own in addition to the altar of the , our God.
22:20 When Achan, son of Zerah, acted treacherously by violating the ban, was it not upon the entire community of Israel that wrath fell? Though he was but a single man, he did not perish alone for his guilt!
22:21 The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh replied to the heads of the Israelite clans:
22:22 The is the God of gods. The , the God of gods, knows and Israel shall know. If now we have acted out of rebellion or treachery against the , our God, do not try to save us this day,
22:23 and if we have built an altar of our own to turn from following the , or to sacrifice burnt offerings, grain offerings, or communion sacrifices upon it, the himself will exact the penalty.
22:24 We did it rather out of our anxious concern lest in the future your children should say to our children: What have you to do with the , the God of Israel?
22:25 For the has placed the Jordan as a boundary between you and us, you Reubenites and Gadites. You have no share in the . Thus your children would prevent ours from revering the .
22:26 So we thought, Let us act for ourselves by building this altar of our own—not for burnt offerings or sacrifice,
22:27 but as witness between us and you and our descendants, that we have the right to provide for the service of the in his presence with our burnt offerings, sacrifices, and communion sacrifices. Now in the future your children cannot say to our children, You have no share in the .
22:28 Our thought was that, if in the future they should speak thus to us or to our descendants, we could answer: Look at the copy of the altar of the which our ancestors made, not for burnt offerings or for sacrifices, but to witness between you and us.
22:29 Far be it from us to rebel against the or to turn now from following the by building an altar for burnt offering, grain offering, or sacrifice in addition to the altar of the , our God, which stands before his tabernacle.
22:30 When Phinehas the priest and the leaders of the community, the heads of the Israelite clans, heard what the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the Manassites had to say, they were satisfied.
22:31 Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest, said to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the Manassites, Today we know that the is in our midst. Since you have not rebelled against the by this act of treachery, you have delivered the Israelites from the hand of the .
22:32 Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest, and the leaders returned from the Reubenites and the Gadites in the land of Gilead to the Israelites in the land of Canaan, and reported the matter to them.
22:33 The report satisfied the Israelites, who blessed God and decided not to take military action against the Reubenites and Gadites nor to ravage the land where they lived.
22:34 The Reubenites and the Gadites gave the altar its name as a witness among them that the is God.
23:1 Many years later, after the had given the Israelites rest from all their enemies round about them, and when Joshua was old and advanced in years,
23:2 he summoned all Israel, including their elders, leaders, judges, and officers, and said to them: I am old and advanced in years.
23:3 You have seen all that the , your God, has done for you against all these nations; for it has been the , your God, who fought for you.
23:4 See, I have apportioned among your tribes as their heritage the nations that survive, as well as those I destroyed, between the Jordan and the Great Sea in the west.
23:5 The , your God, will drive them out and dispossess them at your approach, so that you will take possession of their land as the , your God, promised you.
23:6 Therefore be strong and be careful to observe all that is written in the book of the law of Moses, never turning from it right or left,
23:7 or mingling with these nations that survive among you. You must not invoke their gods by name, or swear by them, or serve them, or bow down to them,
23:8 but you must hold fast to the , your God, as you have done up to this day.
23:9 At your approach the has dispossessed great and strong nations; not one has withstood you up to this day.
23:10 One of you puts to flight a thousand, because it is the , your God, himself who fights for you, as he promised you.
23:11 As for you, take great care to love the , your God.
23:12 For if you ever turn away from him and join with the remnant of these nations that survive among you, by intermarrying and intermingling with them,
23:13 know for certain that the , your God, will no longer dispossess these nations at your approach. Instead they will be a snare and a trap for you, a scourge for your sides and thorns for your eyes, until you perish from this good land which the , your God, has given you.
23:14 Today, as you see, I am going the way of all the earth. So now acknowledge with your whole heart and soul that not one of all the promises the , your God, made concerning you has failed. Every one has come true for you; not one has failed.
23:15 But just as every promise the , your God, made to you has come true for you, so will he bring upon you every threat, even so far as to exterminate you from this good land which the , your God, has given you.
23:16 If you transgress the covenant of the , your God, which he enjoined on you, to go and serve other gods and bow down to them, the anger of the will flare up against you and you will quickly perish from the good land he has given you.
24:1 Joshua gathered together all the tribes of Israel at Shechem, summoning the elders, leaders, judges, and officers of Israel. When they stood in ranks before God,
24:2 Joshua addressed all the people: Thus says the , the God of Israel: In times past your ancestors, down to Terah, father of Abraham and Nahor, lived beyond the River and served other gods.
24:3 But I brought your father Abraham from the region beyond the River and led him through the entire land of Canaan. I made his descendants numerous, and gave him Isaac.
24:4 To Isaac I gave Jacob and Esau. To Esau I assigned the mountain region of Seir to possess, while Jacob and his children went down to Egypt.
24:5 Then I sent Moses and Aaron, and struck Egypt with the plagues and wonders that I wrought in her midst. Afterward I led you out.
24:6 And when I led your ancestors out of Egypt, you came to the sea, and the Egyptians pursued your ancestors to the Red Sea with chariots and charioteers.
24:7 When they cried out to the , he put darkness between you and the Egyptians, upon whom he brought the sea so that it covered them. Your eyes saw what I did to Egypt. After you dwelt a long time in the wilderness,
24:8 I brought you into the land of the Amorites who lived east of the Jordan. They fought against you, but I delivered them into your power. You took possession of their land, and I destroyed them at your approach.
24:9 Then Balak, son of Zippor, king of Moab, prepared to war against Israel. He summoned Balaam, son of Beor, to curse you,
24:10 but I would not listen to Balaam. Instead, he had to bless you, and I delivered you from his power.
24:11 Once you crossed the Jordan and came to Jericho, the citizens of Jericho fought against you, but I delivered them also into your power.
24:12 And I sent the hornets ahead of you which drove them—the Amorites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hittites, Girgashites, Hivites, and Jebusites—out of your way; it was not your sword or your bow.
24:13 I gave you a land you did not till and cities you did not build, to dwell in; you ate of vineyards and olive groves you did not plant.
24:14 Now, therefore, fear the and serve him completely and sincerely. Cast out the gods your ancestors served beyond the River and in Egypt, and serve the .
24:15 If it is displeasing to you to serve the , choose today whom you will serve, the gods your ancestors served beyond the River or the gods of the Amorites in whose country you are dwelling. As for me and my household, we will serve the .
24:16 But the people answered, Far be it from us to forsake the to serve other gods.
24:17 For it was the , our God, who brought us and our ancestors up out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery. He performed those great signs before our very eyes and protected us along our entire journey and among all the peoples through whom we passed.
24:18 At our approach the drove out all the peoples, including the Amorites who dwelt in the land. Therefore we also will serve the , for he is our God.
24:19 Joshua in turn said to the people, You may not be able to serve the , for he is a holy God; he is a passionate God who will not forgive your transgressions or your sins.
24:20 If you forsake the and serve strange gods, he will then do evil to you and destroy you, after having done you good.
24:21 But the people answered Joshua, No! We will serve the .
24:22 Joshua therefore said to the people, You are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen to serve the . They replied, We are witnesses!
24:23 Now, therefore, put away the foreign gods that are among you and turn your hearts to the , the God of Israel.
24:24 Then the people promised Joshua, We will serve the , our God, and will listen to his voice.
24:25 So Joshua made a covenant with the people that day and made statutes and ordinances for them at Shechem.
24:26 Joshua wrote these words in the book of the law of God. Then he took a large stone and set it up there under the terebinth that was in the sanctuary of the .
24:27 And Joshua said to all the people, This stone shall be our witness, for it has heard all the words which the spoke to us. It shall be a witness against you, should you wish to deny your God.
24:28 Then Joshua dismissed the people, each to their own heritage.
24:29 After these events, Joshua, son of Nun, servant of the , died at the age of a hundred and ten,
24:30 and they buried him within the borders of his heritage at Timnath-serah in the mountain region of Ephraim north of Mount Gaash.
24:31 Israel served the during the entire lifetime of Joshua, and of those elders who outlived Joshua and who knew all the work the had done for Israel.
24:32 The bones of Joseph, which the Israelites had brought up from Egypt, were buried in Shechem in the plot of ground Jacob had bought from the sons of Hamor, father of Shechem, for a hundred pieces of money. This was a heritage of the descendants of Joseph.
24:33 When Eleazar, son of Aaron, also died, he was buried on the hill which had been given to his son Phinehas in the mountain region of Ephraim.
JUDGES
1:1 After the death of Joshua the Israelites consulted the , asking, Who shall be first among us to attack the Canaanites and to do battle with them?
1:2 The answered: Judah shall attack: I have delivered the land into his power.
1:3 Judah then said to his brother Simeon, Come up with me into the territory allotted to me, and let us do battle with the Canaanites. I will likewise go with you into the territory allotted to you. So Simeon went with him.
1:4 When Judah attacked, the delivered the Canaanites and Perizzites into their power, and they struck down ten thousand of them in Bezek.
1:5 They came upon Adonibezek in Bezek and fought against him. When they struck down the Canaanites and Perizzites,
1:6 Adonibezek fled. They pursued him, and when they caught him, they cut off his thumbs and big toes.
1:7 Seventy kings, said Adonibezek, used to pick up scraps under my table with their thumbs and big toes cut off. As I have done, so has God repaid me. He was brought to Jerusalem, and he died there.
1:8 The Judahites fought against Jerusalem, captured it, and put it to the sword, setting the city itself on fire.
1:9 Afterward the Judahites went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the mountain region, in the Negeb, and in the foothills.
1:10 Judah also marched against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron, which was formerly called Kiriath-arba, and defeated Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
1:11 They marched from there against the inhabitants of Debir, which was formerly called Kiriath-sepher.
1:12 Caleb said, To the man who attacks Kiriath-sepher and captures it, I will give my daughter Achsah in marriage.
1:13 Othniel captured it, the son of Calebs younger brother Kenaz; so Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah in marriage.
1:14 When she came to him, she induced him to ask her father for some land. Then, as she alighted from the donkey, Caleb asked her, What do you want?
1:15 She answered, Give me a present. Since you have put me in the land of the Negeb, give me pools of water. So Caleb gave her what she wanted, both the upper and the lower pool.
1:16 The descendants of Hobab the Kenite, Moses father-in-law, came up with the Judahites from the City of Palms to the wilderness of Arad, which is in the Negeb, and they settled among the Amalekites.
1:17 Then Judah went with his brother Simeon, and they defeated the Canaanites who lived in Zephath. They put the city under the ban and renamed it Hormah.
1:18 Judah captured Gaza with its territory, Ashkelon with its territory, Ekron with its territory, and Ashdod with its territory.
1:19 The was with Judah, so they gained possession of the mountain region. But they could not dispossess those who lived on the plain, because they had iron chariots.
1:20 As Moses had commanded, they gave Hebron to Caleb, who then drove the three sons of Anak away from there.
1:21 As for the Jebusites dwelling in Jerusalem, the Benjaminites did not dispossess them, so that the Jebusites live with the Benjaminites in Jerusalem to the present day.
1:22 The house of Joseph, too, went up against Bethel, and the was with them.
1:23 The house of Joseph reconnoitered Bethel, which formerly was called Luz.
1:24 The scouts saw a man coming out of the city and said to him, Tell us the way into the city, and we will show you mercy.
1:25 He showed them the way into the city, and they put the city to the sword; but they let the man and his whole clan go free.
1:26 The man then went to the land of the Hittites, where he built a city and called it Luz, which is its name to this day.
1:27 Manasseh did not take possession of Beth-shean with its towns or of Taanach with its towns. Nor did they dispossess the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, those of Ibleam and its towns, or those of Megiddo and its towns. The Canaanites continued to live in this district.
1:28 When Israel grew stronger, they conscripted the Canaanites as laborers, but did not actually drive them out.
1:29 Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, and so the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.
1:30 Nor did Zebulun dispossess the inhabitants of Kitron or those of Nahalol; the Canaanites lived among them and became forced laborers.
1:31 Nor did Asher dispossess the inhabitants of Acco or those of Sidon, or take possession of Mahaleb, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.
1:32 So the Asherites settled among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, for they had not dispossessed them.
1:33 Nor did Naphtali drive out the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh or those of Beth-anath. They settled among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land and the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh and Beth-anath became forced laborers for them.
1:34 The Amorites hemmed in the Danites in the mountain region, not permitting them to come down onto the plain.
1:35 So the Amorites continued to live in Harheres, Aijalon, and Shaalbim, but as the power of the house of Joseph grew, they were conscripted as laborers.
1:36 The territory of the Amorites extended from the Akrabbim pass, from Sela and upward.
2:1 A messenger of the went up from Gilgal to Bochim and said, I brought you up from Egypt and led you into the land which I promised on oath to your ancestors. I said, I will never break my covenant with you,
2:2 but you must not make a covenant with the inhabitants of this land; you must pull down their altars. But you did not listen to me. Look what you have done!
2:3 For I also said, I will not clear them out of your way; they will become traps for you, and their gods a snare for you.
2:4 When the messenger of the had spoken these things to all the Israelites, the people wept aloud.
2:5 They named that place Bochim, and they offered sacrifice there to the .
2:6 Then Joshua dismissed the people, and the Israelites went, each to their own heritage, to take possession of the land.
2:7 The people served the during the entire lifetime of Joshua, and of those elders who outlived Joshua and who had seen all the great work the had done for Israel.
2:8 Joshua, son of Nun, the servant of the , died at the age of a hundred and ten,
2:9 and they buried him within the borders of his heritage at Timnath-heres in the mountain region of Ephraim north of Mount Gaash.
2:10 When the rest of that generation were also gathered to their ancestors, and a later generation arose that did not know the or the work he had done for Israel,
2:11 the Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the . They served the Baals,
2:12 and abandoned the , the God of their ancestors, the one who had brought them out of the land of Egypt. They followed other gods, the gods of the peoples around them, and bowed down to them, and provoked the .
2:13 Because they had abandoned the and served Baal and the Astartes,
2:14 the anger of the flared up against Israel, and he delivered them into the power of plunderers who despoiled them. He sold them into the power of the enemies around them, and they were no longer able to withstand their enemies.
2:15 Whenever they marched out, the hand of the turned against them, as the had said, and as the had sworn to them; and they were in great distress.
2:16 But the raised up judges to save them from the power of their plunderers;
2:17 but they did not listen to their judges either, for they prostituted themselves by following other gods, bowing down to them. They were quick to stray from the way their ancestors had taken, who obeyed the commandments of the ; but these did not.
2:18 When the raised up judges for them, he would be with the judge and save them from the power of their enemies as long as the judge lived. The would change his mind when they groaned in their affliction under their oppressors.
2:19 But when the judge died, they would again do worse than their ancestors, following other gods, serving and bowing down to them, relinquishing none of their evil practices or stubborn ways.
2:20 The anger of the flared up against Israel, and he said: Because this nation has transgressed my covenant, which I enjoined on their ancestors, and has not listened to me,
2:21 I for my part will not clear away for them any more of the nations Joshua left when he died.
2:22 They will be made to test Israel, to see whether or not they will keep to the way of the and continue in it as their ancestors did.
2:23 Therefore the allowed these nations to remain instead of expelling them immediately. He had not delivered them into the power of Joshua.
3:1 These are the nations the allowed to remain, so that through them he might test Israel, all those who had not experienced any of the Canaanite wars—
3:2 to teach warfare to those generations of Israelites who had never experienced it:
3:3 the five lords of the Philistines, and all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites who lived in the mountain region of the Lebanon between Baal-hermon and Lebo-hamath.
3:4 These served as a test for Israel, to know whether they would obey the commandments the had enjoined on their ancestors through Moses.
3:5 So the Israelites settled among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
3:6 They took their daughters in marriage, and gave their own daughters to their sons in marriage, and served their gods.
3:7 Then the Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the ; they forgot the , their God, and served the Baals and the Asherahs,
3:8 and the anger of the flared up against them. He sold them into the power of Cushan-rishathaim, king of Aram Naharaim; and the Israelites served Cushan-rishathaim for eight years.
3:9 But when the Israelites cried out to the , he raised up a savior for them, to save them. It was Othniel, son of Calebs younger brother Kenaz.
3:10 The spirit of the came upon him, and he judged Israel. When he marched out to war, the delivered Cushan-rishathaim, king of Aram, into his power, and his hold on Cushan-rishathaim was firm.
3:11 So the land was at rest for forty years, until Othniel, son of Kenaz, died.
3:12 Again the Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the , so he strengthened Eglon, king of Moab, against Israel because they did what was evil in the sight of the .
3:13 Taking the Ammonites and Amalek as allies, he went and defeated Israel, taking possession of the City of Palms.
3:14 So the Israelites served Eglon, king of Moab, for eighteen years.
3:15 But when the Israelites cried out to the , he raised up for them a savior, Ehud, son of Gera, a Benjaminite who was left-handed. The Israelites would send their tribute to Eglon, king of Moab, by him.
3:16 Ehud made himself a two-edged dagger a foot long, and strapped it under his clothes on his right thigh.
3:17 He presented the tribute to Eglon, king of Moab; now Eglon was a very fat man.
3:18 When he had finished presenting the tribute, he dismissed the troops who had carried the tribute.
3:19 But he himself turned back at the sculptured stones near Gilgal, and said, I have a secret message for you, O king. And the king said, Silence! Then when all his attendants had left his presence,
3:20 Ehud went in to him where he sat alone in his cool upper room. Ehud said, I have a word from God for you. So the king rose from his throne.
3:21 Then Ehud with his left hand drew the dagger from his right thigh, and thrust it into Eglons belly.
3:22 The hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade because he did not withdraw the dagger from the body.
3:23 Then Ehud went out onto the porch, shutting the doors of the upper room on Eglon and locking them.
3:24 When Ehud had left and the servants had come, they saw that the doors of the upper room were locked, and thought, He must be easing himself in the cool chamber.
3:25 They waited until they were at a loss when he did not open the doors of the upper room. So they took the key and opened them, and there was their lord lying on the floor, dead.
3:26 During their delay Ehud escaped and, passing the sculptured stones, took refuge in Seirah.
3:27 On his arrival he sounded the horn in the mountain region of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down from the mountains with him as their leader.
3:28 Follow me, he said to them, for the has delivered your enemies the Moabites into your power. So they followed him down and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites, permitting no one to cross.
3:29 On that occasion they slew about ten thousand Moabites, all of them strong warriors. Not one escaped.
3:30 So Moab was brought under the power of Israel at that time; and the land had rest for eighty years.
3:31 After him there was Shamgar, son of Anath, who slew six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad. He, too, was a savior for Israel.
4:1 The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the ; Ehud was dead.
4:2 So the sold them into the power of the Canaanite king, Jabin, who reigned in Hazor. The general of his army was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-ha-goiim.
4:3 But the Israelites cried out to the ; for with his nine hundred iron chariots Jabin harshly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years.
4:4 At that time the prophet Deborah, wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel.
4:5 She used to sit under Deborahs palm tree, between Ramah and Bethel in the mountain region of Ephraim, where the Israelites came up to her for judgment.
4:6 She had Barak, son of Abinoam, summoned from Kedesh of Naphtali. She said to him, This is what the , the God of Israel, commands: Go, march against Mount Tabor, and take with you ten thousand men from Naphtali and Zebulun.
4:7 I will draw Sisera, the general of Jabins army, out to you at the Wadi Kishon, together with his chariots and troops, and I will deliver them into your power.
4:8 But Barak answered her, If you come with me, I will go; if you do not come with me, I will not go.
4:9 I will certainly go with you, she replied, but you will not gain glory for the expedition on which you are setting out, for it is into a womans power that the is going to sell Sisera. So Deborah arose and went with Barak and journeyed with him to Kedesh.
4:10 Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and ten thousand men followed him. Deborah also went up with him.
4:11 Now Heber the Kenite had detached himself from Cain, the descendants of Hobab, Moses father-in-law, and had pitched his tent by the terebinth of Zaanannim, which was near Kedesh.
4:12 It was reported to Sisera that Barak, son of Abinoam, had gone up to Mount Tabor.
4:13 So Sisera called out all nine hundred of his iron chariots and all his forces from Harosheth-ha-goiim to the Wadi Kishon.
4:14 Deborah then said to Barak, Up! This is the day on which the has delivered Sisera into your power. The marches before you. So Barak went down Mount Tabor, followed by his ten thousand men.
4:15 And the threw Sisera and all his chariots and forces into a panic before Barak. Sisera himself dismounted from his chariot and fled on foot,
4:16 but Barak pursued the chariots and the army as far as Harosheth-ha-goiim. The entire army of Sisera fell beneath the sword, not even one man surviving.
4:17 Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between Jabin, king of Hazor, and the family of Heber the Kenite.
4:18 Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, Turn aside, my lord, turn aside with me; do not be afraid. So he went into her tent, and she covered him with a rug.
4:19 He said to her, Please give me a little water to drink. I am thirsty. So she opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and then covered him.
4:20 Stand at the entrance of the tent, he said to her. If anyone comes and asks, Is there someone here? say, No!
4:21 Jael, wife of Heber, got a tent peg and took a mallet in her hand. When Sisera was in a deep sleep from exhaustion, she approached him stealthily and drove the peg through his temple and down into the ground, and he died.
4:22 Then when Barak came in pursuit of Sisera, Jael went out to meet him and said to him, Come, I will show you the man you are looking for. So he went in with her, and there lay Sisera dead, with the tent peg through his temple.
4:23 Thus on that day God humbled the Canaanite king, Jabin, before the Israelites;
4:24 their power weighed ever more heavily on him, until at length they finished off the Canaanite king, Jabin.
5:1 On that day Deborah sang this song—and Barak, son of Abinoam:
5:2 When uprising broke out in Israel, when the people rallied for duty—bless the !
5:3 Hear, O kings! Give ear, O princes! I will sing, I will sing to the , I will make music to the , the God of Israel.
5:4 , when you went out from Seir, when you marched from the plains of Edom, The earth shook, the heavens poured, the clouds poured rain,
5:5 The mountains streamed, before the , the One of Sinai, before the , the God of Israel.
5:6 In the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, in the days of Jael, caravans ceased: Those who traveled the roads now traveled by roundabout paths.
5:7 Gone was freedom beyond the walls, gone indeed from Israel. When I, Deborah, arose, when I arose, a mother in Israel.
5:8 New gods were their choice; then war was at the gates. No shield was to be found, no spear, among forty thousand in Israel!
5:9 My heart is with the leaders of Israel, with the dedicated ones of the people—bless the ;
5:10 Those who ride on white donkeys, seated on saddle rugs, and those who travel the road, Sing of them
5:11 to the sounds of musicians at the wells. There they recount the just deeds of the , his just deeds bringing freedom to Israel.
5:12 Awake, awake, Deborah! Awake, awake, strike up a song! Arise, Barak! Take captive your captors, son of Abinoam!
5:13 Then down went Israel against the mighty, the army of the went down for him against the warriors.
5:14 From Ephraim, their base in the valley; behind you, Benjamin, among your troops. From Machir came down commanders, from Zebulun wielders of the marshals staff.
5:15 The princes of Issachar were with Deborah, Issachar, faithful to Barak; in the valley they followed at his heels. Among the clans of Reuben great were the searchings of heart!
5:16 Why did you stay beside your hearths listening to the lowing of the herds? Among the clans of Reuben great were the searchings of heart!
5:17 Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan; Why did Dan spend his time in ships? Asher remained along the shore, he stayed in his havens.
5:18 Zebulun was a people who defied death, Naphtali, too, on the open heights!
5:19 The kings came and fought; then they fought, those kings of Canaan, At Taanach by the waters of Megiddo; no spoil of silver did they take.
5:20 From the heavens the stars fought; from their courses they fought against Sisera.
5:21 The Wadi Kishon swept them away; the wadi overwhelmed them, the Wadi Kishon. Trample down the strong!
5:22 Then the hoofs of the horses hammered, the galloping, galloping of steeds.
5:23 Curse Meroz, says the messenger of the , curse, curse its inhabitants! For they did not come when the helped, the help of the against the warriors.
5:24 Most blessed of women is Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, blessed among tent-dwelling women!
5:25 He asked for water, she gave him milk, in a princely bowl she brought him curds.
5:26 With her hand she reached for the peg, with her right hand, the workmans hammer. She hammered Sisera, crushed his head; she smashed, pierced his temple.
5:27 At her feet he sank down, fell, lay still; down at her feet he sank and fell; where he sank down, there he fell, slain.
5:28 From the window she looked down, the mother of Sisera peered through the lattice: Why is his chariot so long in coming? why are the hoofbeats of his chariots delayed?
5:29 The wisest of her princesses answers her; she even replies to herself,
5:30 They must be dividing the spoil they took: a slave woman or two for each man, Spoil of dyed cloth for Sisera, spoil of ornate dyed cloth, a pair of ornate dyed cloths for my neck in the spoil.
5:31 So perish all your enemies, O ! But may those who love you be like the sun rising in its might! And the land was at rest for forty years.
6:1 The Israelites did what was evil in the sight of the , who therefore delivered them into the power of Midian for seven years,
6:2 so that Midian held Israel subject. From fear of Midian the Israelites made dens in the mountains, the caves, and the strongholds.
6:3 For it used to be that whenever the Israelites had completed sowing their crops, Midian, Amalek, and the Kedemites would come up,
6:4 encamp against them, and lay waste the produce of the land as far as the outskirts of Gaza, leaving no sustenance in Israel, and no sheep, ox, or donkey.
6:5 For they would come up with their livestock, and their tents would appear as thick as locusts. They would be too many to count when they came into the land to lay it waste.
6:6 Israel was reduced to utter poverty by Midian, and so the Israelites cried out to the .
6:7 When Israel cried out to the because of Midian,
6:8 the sent a prophet to the Israelites who said to them: Thus says the , the God of Israel: I am the one who brought you up from Egypt; I brought you out of the house of slavery.
6:9 I rescued you from the power of Egypt and all your oppressors. I drove them out before you and gave you their land.
6:10 And I said to you: I, the , am your God; you shall not fear the gods of the Amorites in whose land you are dwelling. But you did not listen to me.
6:11 Then the messenger of the came and sat under the terebinth in Ophrah that belonged to Joash the Abiezrite. Joashs son Gideon was beating out wheat in the wine press to save it from the Midianites,
6:12 and the messenger of the appeared to him and said: The is with you, you mighty warrior!
6:13 My lord, Gideon said to him, if the is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are his wondrous deeds about which our ancestors told us when they said, Did not the bring us up from Egypt? For now the has abandoned us and has delivered us into the power of Midian.
6:14 The turned to him and said: Go with the strength you have, and save Israel from the power of Midian. Is it not I who send you?
6:15 But he answered him, Please, my Lord, how can I save Israel? My family is the poorest in Manasseh, and I am the most insignificant in my fathers house.
6:16 The said to him: I will be with you, and you will cut down Midian to the last man.
6:17 He answered him, If you look on me with favor, give me a sign that you are the one speaking with me.
6:18 Please do not depart from here until I come to you and bring out my offering and set it before you. He answered: I will await your return.
6:19 So Gideon went off and prepared a young goat and an ephah of flour in the form of unleavened cakes. Putting the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot, he brought them out to him under the terebinth and presented them.
6:20 The messenger of God said to him: Take the meat and unleavened cakes and lay them on this rock; then pour out the broth. When he had done so,
6:21 the messenger of the stretched out the tip of the staff he held. When he touched the meat and unleavened cakes, a fire came up from the rock and consumed the meat and unleavened cakes. Then the messenger of the disappeared from sight.
6:22 Gideon, now aware that it had been the messenger of the , said, Alas, Lord , that I have seen the messenger of the face to face!
6:23 The answered him: You are safe. Do not fear. You shall not die.
6:24 So Gideon built there an altar to the and called it Yahweh-shalom. To this day it is still in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
6:25 That same night the said to him: Take your fathers bull, the bull fattened for seven years, and pull down your fathers altar to Baal. As for the asherah beside it, cut it down
6:26 and build an altar to the , your God, on top of this stronghold with the pile of wood. Then take the fattened bull and offer it as a whole-burnt sacrifice on the wood from the asherah you have cut down.
6:27 So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the had commanded him. But he was too afraid of his family and of the townspeople to do it by day; he did it at night.
6:28 Early the next morning the townspeople found that the altar of Baal had been dismantled, the asherah beside it cut down, and the fattened bull offered on the altar that was built.
6:29 They asked one another, Who did this? They inquired and searched until they were told, Gideon, son of Joash, did it.
6:30 So the townspeople said to Joash, Bring out your son that he may die, for he has dismantled the altar of Baal and cut down the asherah that was beside it.
6:31 But Joash replied to all who were standing around him, Is it for you to take action for Baal, or be his savior? Anyone who takes action for him shall be put to death by morning. If he is a god, let him act for himself, since his altar has been dismantled!
6:32 So on that day Gideon was called Jerubbaal, because of the words, Let Baal take action against him, since he dismantled his altar.
6:33 Then all Midian and Amalek and the Kedemites mustered and crossed over into the valley of Jezreel, where they encamped.
6:34 And Gideon was clothed with the spirit of the , and he blew the horn summoning Abiezer to follow him.
6:35 He sent messengers throughout Manasseh, and they, too, were summoned to follow him; he also sent messengers throughout Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they advanced to meet the others.
6:36 Gideon said to God, If indeed you are going to save Israel through me, as you have said,
6:37 I am putting this woolen fleece on the threshing floor, and if dew is on the fleece alone, while all the ground is dry, I shall know that you will save Israel through me, as you have said.
6:38 That is what happened. Early the next morning when he wrung out the fleece, he squeezed enough dew from it to fill a bowl.
6:39 Gideon then said to God, Do not be angry with me if I speak once more. Let me make just one more test with the fleece. Let the fleece alone be dry, but let there be dew on all the ground.
6:40 That is what God did that night: the fleece alone was dry, but there was dew on all the ground.
7:1 Early the next morning Jerubbaal (that is, Gideon) encamped by the spring of Harod with all his soldiers. The camp of Midian was north of him, beside the hill of Moreh in the valley.
7:2 The said to Gideon: You have too many soldiers with you for me to deliver Midian into their power, lest Israel vaunt itself against me and say, My own power saved me.
7:3 So announce in the hearing of the soldiers, If anyone is afraid or fearful, let him leave! Let him depart from Mount Gilead! Twenty-two thousand of the soldiers left, but ten thousand remained.
7:4 The said to Gideon: There are still too many soldiers. Lead them down to the water and I will test them for you there. If I tell you that a certain man is to go with you, he must go with you. But no one is to go if I tell you he must not.
7:5 When Gideon led the soldiers down to the water, the said to him: Everyone who laps up the water as a dog does with its tongue you shall set aside by himself; and everyone who kneels down to drink raising his hand to his mouth you shall set aside by himself.
7:6 Those who lapped up the water with their tongues numbered three hundred, but all the rest of the soldiers knelt down to drink the water.
7:7 The said to Gideon: By means of the three hundred who lapped up the water I will save you and deliver Midian into your power. So let all the other soldiers go home.
7:8 They took up such supplies as the soldiers had with them, as well as their horns, and Gideon sent the rest of the Israelites to their tents, but kept the three hundred men. Now the camp of Midian was below him in the valley.
7:9 That night the said to Gideon: Go, descend on the camp, for I have delivered it into your power.
7:10 If you are afraid to attack, go down to the camp with your aide Purah
7:11 and listen to what they are saying. After that you will have the courage to descend on the camp. So he went down with his aide Purah to the outposts of the armed men in the camp.
7:12 The Midianites, Amalekites, and all the Kedemites were lying in the valley, thick as locusts. Their camels could not be counted, for they were as many as the sands on the seashore.
7:13 When Gideon arrived, one man was telling another about a dream. I had a dream, he said, that a round loaf of barley bread was rolling into the camp of Midian. It came to a certain tent and struck it and turned it upside down, and the tent collapsed.
7:14 This can only be the sword of the Israelite Gideon, son of Joash, the other replied. God has delivered Midian and all the camp into his power.
7:15 When Gideon heard the account of the dream and its explanation, he bowed down. Then returning to the camp of Israel, he said, Arise, for the has delivered the camp of Midian into your power.
7:16 He divided the three hundred men into three companies, and provided them all with horns and with empty jars and torches inside the jars.
7:17 Watch me and follow my lead, he told them. I shall go to the edge of the camp, and as I do, you must do also.
7:18 When I and those with me blow horns, you too must blow horns all around the camp and cry out, For the and for Gideon!
7:19 So Gideon and the hundred men who were with him came to the edge of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, just after the posting of the guards. They blew the horns and broke the jars they were holding.
7:20 When the three companies had blown their horns and broken their jars, they took the torches in their left hands, and in their right the horns they had been blowing, and cried out, A sword for the and for Gideon!
7:21 They all remained standing in place around the camp, while the whole camp began to run and shout and flee.
7:22 When they blew the three hundred horns, the set the sword of one against another throughout the camp, and they fled as far as Beth-shittah in the direction of Zeredah, near the border of Abel-meholah at Tabbath.
7:23 The Israelites were called to arms from Naphtali, from Asher, and from all Manasseh, and they pursued Midian.
7:24 Gideon also sent messengers throughout the mountain region of Ephraim to say, Go down to intercept Midian, and seize the water courses against them as far as Beth-barah, as well as the Jordan. So all the Ephraimites were called to arms, and they seized the water courses as far as Beth-barah, and the Jordan as well.
7:25 They captured the two princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb, killing Oreb at the rock of Oreb and Zeeb at the wine press of Zeeb. Then they pursued Midian, but they had the heads of Oreb and Zeeb brought to Gideon beyond the Jordan.
8:1 But the Ephraimites said to him, What have you done to us, not summoning us when you went to fight against Midian? And they quarreled bitterly with him.
8:2 But he answered them, What have I done in comparison with you? Is not the gleaning of Ephraim better than the vintage of Abiezer?
8:3 It was into your power God delivered the princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb. What have I been able to do in comparison with you? When he said this, their anger against him subsided.
8:4 When Gideon reached the Jordan and crossed it, he and his three hundred men were exhausted and famished.
8:5 So he said to the people of Succoth, Will you give my followers some loaves of bread? They are exhausted, and I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, kings of Midian.
8:6 But the princes of Succoth replied, Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your possession, that we should give food to your army?
8:7 Gideon said, Very well; when the has delivered Zebah and Zalmunna into my power, I will thrash your bodies with desert thorns and briers.
8:8 He went up from there to Penuel and made the same request of them, but the people of Penuel answered him as had the people of Succoth.
8:9 So to the people of Penuel, too, he said, When I return in peace, I will demolish this tower.
8:10 Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with their force of about fifteen thousand men; these were all who were left of the whole Kedemite army, a hundred and twenty thousand swordsmen having fallen.
8:11 Gideon went up by the route of the tent-dwellers east of Nobah and Jogbehah, and attacked the force when it felt secure.
8:12 Zebah and Zalmunna fled and Gideon pursued them. He captured the two kings of Midian, Zebah and Zalmunna, terrifying the entire force.
8:13 Then Gideon, son of Joash, returned from battle by the pass of Heres.
8:14 He captured a young man of Succoth and questioned him, and he wrote down for him the seventy-seven princes and elders of Succoth.
8:15 So he went to the princes of Succoth and said, Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, with whom you taunted me, Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your possession, that we should give food to your weary men?
8:16 He seized the elders of the city, and with desert thorns and briers he thrashed the people of Succoth.
8:17 He also demolished the tower of Penuel and killed the people of the city.
8:18 Then he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, What about the men you killed at Tabor? They were all like you, they replied. They appeared to be princes.
8:19 They were my brothers, my mothers sons, he said. As the lives, if you had spared their lives, I would not kill you.
8:20 Then he said to his firstborn, Jether, Go, kill them. But the boy did not draw his sword, for he was afraid, for he was still a boy.
8:21 Zebah and Zalmunna said, Come, kill us yourself, for as a man is, so is his strength. So Gideon stepped forward and killed Zebah and Zalmunna. He also took the crescents that were on the necks of their camels.
8:22 The Israelites then said to Gideon, Rule over us—you, your son, and your sons son—for you saved us from the power of Midian.
8:23 But Gideon answered them, I will not rule over you, nor shall my son rule over you. The must rule over you.
8:24 Gideon went on to say, Let me make a request of you. Give me, each of you, a ring from his spoils. (Since they were Ishmaelites, the enemy had gold rings.)
8:25 We will certainly give them, they replied, and they spread out a cloak into which everyone threw a ring from his spoils.
8:26 The gold rings he had requested weighed seventeen hundred gold shekels, apart from the crescents and pendants, the purple garments worn by the kings of Midian, and apart from the trappings that were on the necks of their camels.
8:27 Gideon made an ephod out of the gold and placed it in his city, Ophrah. All Israel prostituted themselves there, and it became a snare to Gideon and his household.
8:28 Midian was brought into subjection by the Israelites; they no longer held their heads high, and the land had rest for forty years, during the lifetime of Gideon.
8:29 Then Jerubbaal, son of Joash, went to live in his house.
8:30 Now Gideon had seventy sons, his own offspring, for he had many wives.
8:31 His concubine who lived in Shechem also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelech.
8:32 At a good old age Gideon, son of Joash, died and was buried in the tomb of Joash his father in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
8:33 But after Gideon was dead, the Israelites again prostituted themselves by following the Baals, making Baal-berith their god.
8:34 The Israelites did not remember the , their God, who had delivered them from the power of their enemies all around them.
8:35 Nor were they loyal to the house of Jerubbaal (Gideon) for all the good he had done for Israel.
9:1 Abimelech, son of Jerubbaal, went to his mothers kin in Shechem, and said to them and to the whole clan to which his mothers family belonged,
9:2 Put this question to all the lords of Shechem: Which is better for you: that seventy men, all Jerubbaals sons, rule over you, or that one man rule over you? You must remember that I am your own flesh and bone.
9:3 When his mothers kin repeated these words on his behalf to all the lords of Shechem, they set their hearts on Abimelech, thinking, He is our kin.
9:4 They also gave him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baal-berith, with which Abimelech hired worthless men and outlaws as his followers.
9:5 He then went to his fathers house in Ophrah, and killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerubbaal, on one stone. Only the youngest son of Jerubbaal, Jotham, escaped, for he was hidden.
9:6 Then all the lords of Shechem and all Beth-millo came together and made Abimelech king by the terebinth at the memorial pillar in Shechem.
9:7 When this was reported to Jotham, he went and stood at the top of Mount Gerizim and cried out in a loud voice: Hear me, lords of Shechem, and may God hear you!
9:8 One day the trees went out to anoint a king over themselves. So they said to the olive tree, Reign over us.
9:9 But the olive tree answered them, Must I give up my rich oil, whereby gods and human beings are honored, and go off to hold sway over the trees?
9:10 Then the trees said to the fig tree, Come; you reign over us!
9:11 But the fig tree answered them, Must I give up my sweetness and my sweet fruit, and go off to hold sway over the trees?
9:12 Then the trees said to the vine, Come you, reign over us.
9:13 But the vine answered them, Must I give up my wine that cheers gods and human beings, and go off to hold sway over the trees?
9:14 Then all the trees said to the buckthorn, Come; you reign over us!
9:15 The buckthorn answered the trees, If you are anointing me in good faith, to make me king over you, come, and take refuge in my shadow. But if not, let fire come from the buckthorn and devour the cedars of Lebanon.
9:16 Now then, if you have acted in good faith and integrity in appointing Abimelech your king, if you have acted with good will toward Jerubbaal and his house, and if you have treated him as he deserved—
9:17 for my father fought for you at the risk of his life when he delivered you from the power of Midian,
9:18 but you have risen against my fathers house today and killed his seventy sons upon one stone and made Abimelech, the son of his maidservant, king over the lords of Shechem, because he is your kin—
9:19 if, then, you have acted in good faith and integrity toward Jerubbaal and his house today, then rejoice in Abimelech and may he in turn rejoice in you!
9:20 But if not, let fire come forth from Abimelech and devour the lords of Shechem and Beth-millo, and let fire come forth from the lords of Shechem and Beth-millo and devour Abimelech.
9:21 Then Jotham fled and escaped to Beer, where he remained for fear of his brother Abimelech.
9:22 When Abimelech had ruled Israel for three years,
9:23 God put an evil spirit between Abimelech and the lords of Shechem, and the lords of Shechem broke faith with the house of Abimelech.
9:24 This was to repay the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal and to avenge their blood upon their brother Abimelech, who killed them, and upon the lords of Shechem, who encouraged him to kill his brothers.
9:25 The lords of Shechem then set men in ambush for him on the mountaintops, and they robbed all who passed them on the road. It was reported to Abimelech.
9:26 Now Gaal, son of Ebed, and his kin came, and when they passed through Shechem, the lords of Shechem put their trust in him.
9:27 They went out into the fields, harvested the grapes from their vineyards, trod them out, and held a festival. Then they went to the temple of their god, where they ate and drank and cursed Abimelech.
9:28 Gaal, son of Ebed, said, Who is Abimelech? And who is Shechem that we should serve him? Did not the son of Jerubbaal and his lieutenant Zebul serve the men of Hamor, father of Shechem? So why should we serve him?
9:29 Would that these troops were entrusted to my command! I would depose Abimelech. I would say to Abimelech, Get a larger army and come out!
9:30 When Zebul, the ruler of the city, heard what Gaal, son of Ebed, had said, he was angry
9:31 and sent messengers to Abimelech in Arumah to say, Gaal, son of Ebed, and his kin have come to Shechem and are stirring up the city against you.
9:32 So take action tonight, you and the troops who are with you, and set an ambush in the fields.
9:33 Promptly at sunrise tomorrow morning, make a raid on the city. When he and the troops who are with him come out against you, deal with him as best you can.
9:34 During the night Abimelech went into action with all his soldiers and set up an ambush outside of Shechem in four companies.
9:35 Gaal, son of Ebed, went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate. When Abimelech and his soldiers rose from their place of ambush,
9:36 Gaal saw the soldiers and said to Zebul, There are soldiers coming down from the mountaintops! But Zebul answered him, It is the shadow of the hills that you see as men.
9:37 But Gaal went on to say, Soldiers are coming down from the region of Tabbur-haarez, and one company is coming by way of Elon-meonenim.
9:38 Zebul said to him, Where now is your boast, when you said, Who is Abimelech that we should serve him? Are these not the troops for whom you expressed contempt? Go out now and fight with them.
9:39 So Gaal went out at the head of the lords of Shechem to fight against Abimelech;
9:40 but when Abimelech went after him, he fled from him. Many fell slain right up to the entrance of the gate.
9:41 Abimelech returned to Arumah, and Zebul drove Gaal and his kin away so that they could no longer remain at Shechem.
9:42 The next day, the army marched out into the field, and it was reported to Abimelech.
9:43 He divided the troops he had into three companies, and set up an ambush in the fields. He watched until he saw the army leave the city and then went on the attack against them.
9:44 Abimelech and the company with him rushed in and stood by the entrance of the city gate, while the other two companies rushed upon all who were in the field and attacked them.
9:45 That entire day Abimelech fought against the city. He captured it, killed the people who were in it, and demolished the city itself, sowing it with salt.
9:46 When they heard of this, all the lords of the Migdal-shechem went into the crypt of the temple of El-berith.
9:47 It was reported to Abimelech that all the lords of the Migdal-shechem were gathered together.
9:48 So he went up Mount Zalmon with all his soldiers, took his ax in his hand, and cut down some brushwood. This he lifted to his shoulder, then said to the troops with him, Hurry! Do just as you have seen me do.
9:49 So all the soldiers likewise cut down brushwood and, following Abimelech, placed it against the crypt. Then they set the crypt on fire over them, so that every one of the people of the Migdal-shechem, about a thousand men and women, perished.
9:50 Abimelech proceeded to Thebez, encamped, and captured it.
9:51 Now there was a strong tower in the middle of the city, and all the men and women and all the lords of the city fled there, shutting themselves in and going up to the roof of the tower.
9:52 Abimelech came up to the tower and fought against it. When he came close to the entrance of the tower to set it on fire,
9:53 a certain woman cast the upper part of a millstone down on Abimelechs head, and it fractured his skull.
9:54 He immediately called his armor-bearer and said to him, Draw your sword and put me to death so they will not say about me, A woman killed him. So his attendant ran him through and he died.
9:55 When the Israelites saw that Abimelech was dead, they all left for their homes.
9:56 Thus did God repay the evil that Abimelech had done to his father in killing his seventy brothers.
9:57 God also brought all the wickedness of the people of Shechem back on their heads, for the curse of Jotham, son of Jerubbaal, overtook them.
10:1 After Abimelech, Tola, son of Puah, son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, rose up to save Israel; he lived in Shamir in the mountain region of Ephraim.
10:2 When he had judged Israel twenty-three years, he died and was buried in Shamir.
10:3 Jair the Gileadite came after him and judged Israel twenty-two years.
10:4 He had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkeys and possessed thirty cities in the land of Gilead (these are called Havvoth-jair to the present day).
10:5 Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
10:6 The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the , serving the Baals and Ashtarts, the gods of Aram, the gods of Sidon, the gods of Moab, the gods of the Ammonites, and the gods of the Philistines. Since they had abandoned the and would not serve him,
10:7 the became angry with Israel and he sold them into the power of the Philistines and the Ammonites.
10:8 For eighteen years they afflicted and oppressed the Israelites in Bashan, and all the Israelites in the Amorite land beyond the Jordan in Gilead.
10:9 The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin and the house of Ephraim, so that Israel was in great distress.
10:10 Then the Israelites cried out to the , We have sinned against you, for we have abandoned our God and served the Baals.
10:11 The answered the Israelites: Did not the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
10:12 the Sidonians, the Amalekites, and the Midianites oppress you? Yet when you cried out to me, and I saved you from their power,
10:13 you still abandoned me and served other gods. Therefore I will save you no more.
