7:6 When they had gathered at Mizpah, they drew water and poured it out on the ground before the , and they fasted that day, saying, We have sinned against the . It was at Mizpah that Samuel began to judge the Israelites.
7:7 When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah, their leaders went up against Israel. Hearing this, the Israelites became afraid of the Philistines
7:8 and appealed to Samuel, Do not stop crying out to the our God for us, to save us from the hand of the Philistines.
7:9 Samuel therefore took an unweaned lamb and offered it whole as a burnt offering to the . He cried out to the for Israel, and the answered him.
7:10 While Samuel was sacrificing the burnt offering, the Philistines drew near for battle with Israel. That day, however, the thundered loudly against the Philistines, and threw them into such confusion that they were defeated by Israel.
7:11 Thereupon the Israelites rushed out from Mizpah and pursued the Philistines, striking them down even beyond Beth-car.
7:12 Samuel then took a stone and placed it between Mizpah and Jeshanah; he named it Ebenezer, explaining, As far as this place the has been our help.
7:13 Thus were the Philistines subdued, never again to enter the territory of Israel, for the hand of the was against them as long as Samuel lived.
7:14 The cities from Ekron to Gath which the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to them. Israel also freed the territory of these cities from Philistine domination. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
7:15 Samuel judged Israel as long as he lived.
7:16 He made a yearly circuit, passing through Bethel, Gilgal and Mizpah and judging Israel at each of these places.
7:17 Then he used to return to Ramah, for that was his home. There, too, he judged Israel and built an altar to the .
8:1 In his old age Samuel appointed his sons judges over Israel.
8:2 His firstborn was named Joel, his second son, Abijah; they judged at Beer-sheba.
8:3 His sons did not follow his example, but looked to their own gain, accepting bribes and perverting justice.
8:4 Therefore all the elders of Israel assembled and went to Samuel at Ramah
8:5 and said to him, Now that you are old, and your sons do not follow your example, appoint a king over us, like all the nations, to rule us.
8:6 Samuel was displeased when they said, Give us a king to rule us. But he prayed to the .
8:7 The said: Listen to whatever the people say. You are not the one they are rejecting. They are rejecting me as their king.
8:8 They are acting toward you just as they have acted from the day I brought them up from Egypt to this very day, deserting me to serve other gods.
8:9 Now listen to them; but at the same time, give them a solemn warning and inform them of the rights of the king who will rule them.
8:10 Samuel delivered the message of the in full to those who were asking him for a king.
8:11 He told them: The governance of the king who will rule you will be as follows: He will take your sons and assign them to his chariots and horses, and they will run before his chariot.
8:12 He will appoint from among them his commanders of thousands and of hundreds. He will make them do his plowing and harvesting and produce his weapons of war and chariotry.
8:13 He will use your daughters as perfumers, cooks, and bakers.
8:14 He will take your best fields, vineyards, and olive groves, and give them to his servants.
8:15 He will tithe your crops and grape harvests to give to his officials and his servants.
8:16 He will take your male and female slaves, as well as your best oxen and donkeys, and use them to do his work.
8:17 He will also tithe your flocks. As for you, you will become his slaves.
8:18 On that day you will cry out because of the king whom you have chosen, but the will not answer you on that day.
8:19 The people, however, refused to listen to Samuels warning and said, No! There must be a king over us.
8:20 We too must be like all the nations, with a king to rule us, lead us in warfare, and fight our battles.
8:21 Samuel listened to all the concerns of the people and then repeated them to the .
8:22 The said: Listen to them! Appoint a king to rule over them. Then Samuel said to the people of Israel, Return, each one of you, to your own city.
9:1 There was a powerful man from Benjamin named Kish, who was the son of Abiel, son of Zeror, son of Becorath, son of Aphiah, a Benjaminite.
9:2 He had a son named Saul, who was a handsome young man. There was no other Israelite more handsome than Saul; he stood head and shoulders above the people.
9:3 Now the donkeys of Sauls father, Kish, had wandered off. Kish said to his son Saul, Take one of the servants with you and go out and hunt for the donkeys.
9:4 So they went through the hill country of Ephraim, and through the land of Shalishah. Not finding them there, they continued through the land of Shaalim without success. They also went through the land of Benjamin, but they failed to find the animals.
9:5 When they came to the land of Zuph, Saul said to the servant who was with him, Come, let us turn back, lest my father forget about the donkeys and become anxious about us.
9:6 The servant replied, Listen! There is a man of God in this city, a man held in high esteem; everything he says comes true. Let us go there now! Perhaps he can advise us about the journey we have undertaken.
9:7 But Saul said to his servant, If we go, what can we offer the man? The food in our bags has run out; we have no present to give the man of God. What else do we have?
9:8 Again the servant answered Saul, I have a quarter shekel of silver. If I give that to the man of God, he will advise us about the journey.
9:9 (In former times in Israel, anyone who went to consult God used to say, Come, let us go to the seer. For the one who is now called prophet was formerly called seer.)
9:10 Saul then said to his servant, You are right! Come on, let us go! So they headed toward the city where the man of God lived.
9:11 As they were going up the path to the city, they met some young women coming out to draw water and they asked them, Is the seer in town?
9:12 The young women answered, Yes, there—straight ahead. Hurry now; just today he came to the city, because the people have a sacrifice today on the high place.
9:13 When you enter the city, you may reach him before he goes up to the high place to eat. The people will not eat until he arrives; only after he blesses the sacrifice will the invited guests eat. Go up immediately, for you should find him right now.
9:14 So they went up to the city. As they entered it—there was Samuel coming toward them on his way to the high place.
9:15 The day before Sauls arrival, the had revealed to Samuel:
9:16 At this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin whom you are to anoint as ruler of my people Israel. He shall save my people from the hand of the Philistines. I have looked upon my people; their cry has come to me.
9:17 When Samuel caught sight of Saul, the assured him: This is the man I told you about; he shall govern my people.
9:18 Saul met Samuel in the gateway and said, Please tell me where the seer lives.
9:19 Samuel answered Saul: I am the seer. Go up ahead of me to the high place and eat with me today. In the morning, before letting you go, I will tell you everything on your mind.
9:20 As for your donkeys that were lost three days ago, do not worry about them, for they have been found. Whom should Israel want if not you and your fathers family?
9:21 Saul replied: Am I not a Benjaminite, from the smallest of the tribes of Israel, and is not my clan the least among the clans of the tribe of Benjamin? Why say such things to me? 
9:22 Samuel then took Saul and his servant and brought them into the room. He seated them at the head of the guests, of whom there were about thirty.
9:23 He said to the cook, Bring the portion I gave you and told you to put aside.
9:24 So the cook took up the leg and what went with it, and placed it before Saul. Samuel said: This is a reserved portion that is set before you. Eat, for it was kept for you until this time; I explained that I was inviting some guests. Thus Saul dined with Samuel that day.
9:25 When they came down from the high place into the city, a mattress was spread for Saul on the roof,
9:26 and he slept there. At daybreak Samuel called to Saul on the roof, Get up, and I will send you on your way. Saul got up, and he and Samuel went outside the city together.
9:27 As they were approaching the edge of the town, Samuel said to Saul, Tell the servant to go on ahead of us, but you stay here for a moment, that I may give you a word from God.
10:1 Then, from a flask he had with him, Samuel poured oil on Sauls head and kissed him, saying: The anoints you ruler over his people Israel. You are the one who will govern the s people and save them from the power of their enemies all around them. This will be the sign for you that the has anointed you ruler over his heritage:
10:2 When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachels tomb at Zelzah in the territory of Benjamin. They will say to you, The donkeys you went to look for have been found. Now your father is no longer worried about the donkeys, but is anxious about you and says: What shall I do about my son?
10:3 Farther on, when you arrive at the oak of Tabor, three men will meet you as they go up to God at Bethel; one will be bringing three young goats, another three loaves of bread, and the third a skin of wine.
10:4 They will greet you and offer you two elevated offerings of bread, which you should accept from them.
10:5 After that you will come to Gibeath-elohim, where the Philistine garrison is located. As you enter that city, you will meet a band of prophets coming down from the high place. They will be preceded by lyres, tambourines, flutes, and harps, and will be in prophetic ecstasy.
10:6 The spirit of the will rush upon you, and you will join them in their prophetic ecstasy and will become a changed man.
10:7 When these signs have come to pass, do whatever lies to hand, because God is with you.
10:8 Now go down ahead of me to Gilgal, for I shall come down to you, to offer burnt offerings and to sacrifice communion offerings. Wait seven days until I come to you; I shall then tell you what you must do.
10:9 As Saul turned to leave Samuel, God changed his heart. That very day all these signs came to pass.
10:10 From there they arrived at Gibeah, where a band of prophets met Saul, and the spirit of God rushed upon him, so that he joined them in their prophetic ecstasy.
10:11 When all who had known him previously saw him in a prophetic state among the prophets, they said to one another, What has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?
10:12 And someone from that district responded, And who is their father? Thus the saying arose, Is Saul also among the prophets?
10:13 When he came out of the prophetic ecstasy, he went home.
10:14 Sauls uncle asked him and his servant, Where have you been? Saul replied, Looking for the donkeys. When we could not find them, we went to Samuel.
10:15 Sauls uncle said, Tell me, then, what Samuel said to you.
10:16 Saul said to his uncle, He assured us that the donkeys had been found. But Saul told him nothing about what Samuel had said about the kingship.
10:17 Samuel called the people together to the at Mizpah
10:18 and addressed the Israelites: Thus says the , the God of Israel: It was I who brought Israel up from Egypt and delivered you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.
10:19 But today you have rejected your God, who saves you from all your evils and calamities, by saying, No! You must appoint a king over us. Now, therefore, take your stand before the according to your tribes and families.
10:20 So Samuel had all the tribes of Israel come forward, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
10:21 Next he had the tribe of Benjamin come forward by clans, and the clan of Matri was chosen, and finally Saul, son of Kish, was chosen. But when they went to look for him, he was nowhere to be found.
10:22 Again they consulted the , Is there still someone else to come forward? The answered: He is hiding among the baggage.
10:23 They ran to bring him from there; when he took his place among the people, he stood head and shoulders above all the people.
10:24 Then Samuel addressed all the people, Do you see the man whom the has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people! Then all the people shouted out, Long live the king!
10:25 Samuel next explained to the people the rules of the monarchy, wrote them in a book, and placed them before the presence of the . Samuel then sent the people back to their own homes.
10:26 Saul also went home to Gibeah, accompanied by warriors whose hearts the had touched.
10:27 But some worthless people said, How can this fellow save us? They despised him and brought him no tribute.
11:1 About a month later, Nahash the Ammonite went up and besieged Jabesh-gilead. All the people of Jabesh begged Nahash, Make a treaty with us, and we will serve you.
11:2 But Nahash the Ammonite replied, This is my condition for making a treaty with you: I will gouge out the right eye of every man, and thus bring shame on all Israel.
11:3 The elders of Jabesh said to him: Give us seven days to send messengers throughout the territory of Israel. If there is no one to save us, we will surrender to you.
11:4 When the messengers arrived at Gibeah of Saul and reported the news in the peoples hearing, they all wept aloud.
11:5 Just then Saul came in from the field, behind his oxen. Why are the people weeping? he asked. They repeated the message of the inhabitants of Jabesh for him.
11:6 As he listened to this report, the spirit of God rushed upon him and he became very angry.
11:7 Taking a yoke of oxen, he cut them into pieces and sent them throughout the territory of Israel by messengers saying, If anyone does not come out to follow Saul and Samuel, the same thing will be done to his oxen! The dread of the came upon the people and they went forth as one.
11:8 When Saul reviewed them in Bezek, there were three hundred thousand Israelites and seventy thousand Judahites.
11:9 To the messengers who had come he said, Tell the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead that tomorrow, when the sun grows hot, they will be saved. The messengers went and reported this to the inhabitants of Jabesh, and they rejoiced.
11:10 The men of Jabesh said to Nahash, Tomorrow we will surrender to you, and you may do with us whatever you want.
11:11 The next day, Saul arranged his troops in three companies and invaded the camp during the dawn watch. They slaughtered Ammonites until the day had gotten hot; by then the survivors were so scattered that no two of them were left together.
11:12 The people then said to Samuel: Who questioned whether Saul should rule over us? Hand them over and we will put them to death.
11:13 But Saul objected, No one will be put to death this day, for today the has rescued Israel.
11:14 Samuel said to the people, Come, let us go to Gilgal to renew the kingship there.
11:15 So all the people went to Gilgal, and there they made Saul king in the s presence. They also sacrificed communion offerings there before the , and Saul and all the Israelites rejoiced greatly.
12:1 Samuel addressed all Israel: I have granted your request in every respect, he said. I have set a king over you
12:2 and now the king will lead you. As for me, I am old and gray, and my sons are among you. I was your leader from my youth to the present day.
12:3 Here I stand! Answer me in the presence of the and the s anointed. Whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Whom have I cheated? Whom have I wronged? From whom have I accepted a bribe and shut my eyes because of it? I will make restitution to you.
12:4 They replied, You have neither cheated us, nor oppressed us, nor accepted anything from anyone.
12:5 So he said to them, The is witness against you this day, and the s anointed is witness, that you have found nothing in my possession. The is witness, they said.
12:6 Samuel continued: The is witness, who appointed Moses and Aaron and brought your ancestors up from the land of Egypt.
12:7 Now take your stand, that I may judge you in the presence of the according to all the gracious acts that the has done for you and your ancestors.
12:8 When Jacob and his sons went to Egypt and the Egyptians oppressed them, your ancestors cried out to the . The then sent Moses and Aaron to bring them out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
12:9 But they forgot the their God; and so the sold them into the power of Sisera, the captain of the army of Hazor, the power of the Philistines, and the power of the king of Moab, who made war against them.
12:10 They cried out to the and said, We have sinned because we abandoned the and served the Baals and Astartes. Now deliver us from the power of our enemies, and we will serve you.
12:11 The sent Jerubbaal, Barak, Jephthah, and Samuel; he delivered you from the power of your enemies on every side, so that you could live in security.
12:12 Yet, when you saw Nahash, king of the Ammonites, advancing against you, you said to me, No! A king must rule us, even though the your God is your king.
12:13 Now here is the king you chose. See! The has given you a king.
12:14 If you fear and serve the , if you listen to the voice of the and do not rebel against the s command, if both you and the king, who rules over you, follow the your God—well and good.
12:15 But if you do not listen to the voice of the and if you rebel against the s command, the hand of the will be against you and your king.
12:16 Now then, stand ready to witness the great marvel the is about to accomplish before your eyes.
12:17 Are we not in the harvest time for wheat? Yet I will call upon the , and he will send thunder and rain. Thus you will see and understand how great an evil it is in the eyes of the that you have asked for a king.
12:18 Samuel called upon the , and the sent thunder and rain that day. Then all the people feared the and Samuel.
12:19 They said to Samuel, Pray to the your God for us, your servants, that we may not die for having added to all our other sins the evil of asking for a king.
12:20 Do not fear, Samuel answered them. You have indeed committed all this evil! Yet do not turn from the , but serve him with your whole heart.
12:21 Do not turn aside to gods who are nothing, who cannot act and deliver. They are nothing.
12:22 For the sake of his own great name the will not abandon his people, since the has decided to make you his people.
12:23 As for me, far be it from me to sin against the by ceasing to pray for you and to teach you the good and right way.
12:24 But you must fear the and serve him faithfully with all your heart, for you have seen the great things the has done among you.
12:25 If instead you continue to do evil, both you and your king shall be swept away.
13:1 [Saul wasyears old when he became king and he reigned-two years over Israel.]
13:2 Saul chose three thousand of Israel, of whom two thousand remained with him in Michmash and in the hill country of Bethel, and one thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin. He sent the rest of the army back to their tents.
13:3 Now Jonathan struck the Philistine garrison in Gibeah, and the Philistines got word of it. Then Saul sounded the horn throughout the land, saying, Let the Hebrews hear!
13:4 Then all Israel heard the report, Saul has struck the garrison of the Philistines! Israel has become odious to the Philistines! Then the army was called up to Saul in Gilgal.
13:5 The Philistines also assembled for battle against Israel, with thirty thousand chariots, six thousand horsemen, and foot soldiers as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They came up and encamped in Michmash, east of Beth-aven.
13:6 When the soldiers saw they were in danger because the army was hardpressed, they hid themselves in caves, thickets, rocks, caverns, and cisterns.
13:7 Other Hebrews crossed the Jordan into the land of Gad and Gilead. Saul, however, held out in Gilgal, all his army trembling in fear behind him.
13:8 He waited seven days, until the appointed time Samuel had set, but Samuel did not come, and the army deserted Saul.
13:9 He then said, Bring me the burnt offering and communion offerings! Then he sacrificed the burnt offering.
13:10 As he finished sacrificing the burnt offering, there came Samuel! So Saul went out toward him in order to greet him.
13:11 Samuel asked him, What have you done? Saul explained: When I saw that the army was deserting me and you did not come on the appointed day, and that the Philistines were assembling at Michmash,
13:12 I said to myself, Now the Philistines will come down against me at Gilgal, and I have not yet sought the s blessing. So I thought I should sacrifice the burnt offering.
13:13 Samuel replied to Saul: You have acted foolishly! Had you kept the command the your God gave you, the would now establish your kingship in Israel forever;
13:14 but now your kingship shall not endure. The has sought out a man after his own heart to appoint as ruler over his people because you did not observe what the commanded you.
13:15 Then Samuel set out from Gilgal and went his own way; but what was left of the army went up after Saul to meet the soldiers, going from Gilgal to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul then counted the soldiers he had with him, about six hundred.
13:16 Saul, his son Jonathan, and the soldiers they had with them were now occupying Geba of Benjamin, and the Philistines were encamped at Michmash.
13:17 Meanwhile, raiders left the camp of the Philistines in three bands. One band took the Ophrah road toward the district of Shual;
13:18 another turned in the direction of Beth-horon; and the third took the road for Geba that overlooks the Valley of the Hyenas toward the desert. 
13:19 Not a single smith was to be found anywhere in Israel, for the Philistines had said, Otherwise the Hebrews will make swords or spears.
13:20 All Israel, therefore, had to go down to the Philistines to sharpen their plowshares, mattocks, axes, and sickles.
13:21 The price for the plowshares and mattocks was two thirds of a shekel, and a third of a shekel for sharpening the axes and for setting the ox-goads.
13:22 And so on the day of battle neither sword nor spear could be found in the hand of any of the soldiers with Saul or Jonathan. Only Saul and his son Jonathan had them.
13:23 An outpost of the Philistines had pushed forward to the pass of Michmash.
14:1 One day Jonathan, son of Saul, said to his armor-bearer, Come, let us go over to the Philistine outpost on the other side. But he did not inform his father—
14:2 Saul was sitting under the pomegranate tree in Migron on the outskirts of Gibeah; with him were about six hundred men.
14:3 Ahijah, son of Ahitub, brother of Ichabod, the son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the priest of the at Shiloh, was wearing the ephod—nor did the soldiers know that Jonathan had gone.
14:4 Flanking the ravine through which Jonathan intended to cross to the Philistine outpost were rocky crags on each side, one named Bozez and the other Seneh.
14:5 One crag was to the north, toward Michmash; the other to the south, toward Geba.
14:6 Jonathan said to his armor-bearer: Come, let us go over to that outpost of the uncircumcised. Perhaps the will help us, because it is no more difficult for the to grant victory by means of a few than it is by means of many.
14:7 His armor-bearer replied, Do whatever you think best; I am with you in whatever you decide.
14:8 Jonathan continued: When we cross over to those men, we will be visible to them.
14:9 If they say to us, Stay there until we can come to you, we will stop where we are; we will not go up to them.
14:10 But if they say, Come up to us, we will go up, because the has delivered them into our hand. That will be our sign.
14:11 When the two of them came into the view of the Philistine outpost, the Philistines remarked, Look, some Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they have been hiding.
14:12 The men of the outpost called to Jonathan and his armor-bearer. Come up here, they said, and we will teach you a lesson. So Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, Climb up after me, for the has delivered them into the hand of Israel.
14:13 Jonathan clambered up with his armor-bearer behind him. As the Philistines fell before Jonathan, his armor-bearer, who followed him, would finish them off.
14:14 In this first attack Jonathan and his armor-bearer killed about twenty men within half a furlong.
14:15 Then terror spread through the camp and the countryside; all the soldiers in the outpost and in the raiding parties shuddered in terror. The earth shook with an awesome shuddering.
14:16 Sauls sentinels in Gibeah of Benjamin saw that the enemy camp had scattered and were running in all directions.
14:17 Saul said to those around him, Count the troops and find out if any of us are missing. When they had taken the count, they found Jonathan and his armor-bearer missing.
14:18 Saul then said to Ahijah, Bring the ephod here. (Ahijah was wearing the ephod before the Israelites at that time.)
14:19 While Saul was speaking to the priest, the uproar in the Philistine camp kept increasing. So he said to the priest, Withdraw your hand.
14:20 And Saul and all his men rallied and rushed into the fight, where the Philistines, wholly confused, were thrusting swords at one another.
14:21 The Hebrews who had previously sided with the Philistines and had gone up with them to their camp turned to join the Israelites under Saul and Jonathan.
14:22 Likewise, all the Israelites who were hiding in the hill country of Ephraim, hearing that the Philistines were fleeing, kept after them in the battle.
14:23 Thus the saved Israel that day. The battle continued past Beth-aven.
14:24 Even though the Israelites were exhausted that day, Saul laid an oath on them, saying, Cursed be the one who takes food before evening, before I am able to avenge myself on my enemies. So none of the people tasted food.
14:25 Now there was a honeycomb lying on the ground,
14:26 and when the soldiers came to the comb the honey was flowing; yet no one raised a hand from it to his mouth, because the people feared the oath.
14:27 Jonathan, who had not heard that his father had put the people under oath, thrust out the end of the staff he was holding and dipped it into the honeycomb. Then he raised it to his mouth and his eyes brightened.
14:28 At this, one of the soldiers spoke up: Your father put the people under a strict oath, saying, Cursed be the one who takes food today! As a result the people are weakened.
14:29 Jonathan replied: My father brings trouble to the land. Look how bright my eyes are because I had this little taste of honey.
14:30 What is more, if the army had eaten freely of the enemys plunder when they came across it today, surely the slaughter of the Philistines would have been the greater by now!
14:31 After the Philistines were routed that day from Michmash to Aijalon, the people were completely exhausted.
14:32 So the army pounced upon the plunder and took sheep, oxen, and calves, slaughtering them on the ground and eating the meat with the blood in it.
14:33 Informed that the army was sinning against the by eating the meat with blood in it, Saul said: You have broken faith. Roll a large stone here for me.
14:34 He continued: Mingle with the people and tell each of them, Bring an ox or sheep to me. Slaughter them here and then eat. But you must not sin against the by eating meat with blood in it. So that night they all brought whatever oxen they had seized, and they slaughtered them there;
14:35 and Saul built an altar to the —this was the first time he built an altar to the .
14:36 Then Saul said, Let us go down in pursuit of the Philistines by night, to plunder them until daybreak and leave no one alive. They replied, Do what you think best. But the priest said, Let us consult God.
14:37 So Saul inquired of God: Shall I go down in pursuit of the Philistines? Will you deliver them into the hand of Israel? But he received no answer on this occasion.
14:38 All officers of the army, Saul announced, come forward. Find out how this sin was committed today.
14:39 As the lives who has given victory to Israel, even if my son Jonathan has committed it, he shall surely die! But none of the people answered him.
14:40 So he said to all Israel, Stand on one side, and my son Jonathan and I will stand on the other. The people responded, Do what you think best.
14:41 And Saul said to the , the God of Israel: Why did you not answer your servant this time? If the blame for this resides in me or my son Jonathan, , God of Israel, respond with Urim; but if this guilt is in your people Israel, respond with Thummim. Jonathan and Saul were designated, and the people went free.
14:42 Saul then said, Cast lots between me and my son Jonathan. And Jonathan was designated.
14:43 Saul said to Jonathan, Tell me what you have done. Jonathan replied, I only tasted a little honey from the end of the staff I was holding. Am I to die for this?
14:44 Saul declared, May God do thus to me, and more, if you do not indeed die, Jonathan!
14:45 But the soldiers protested to Saul: Is Jonathan to die, the man who won this great victory for Israel? This must not be! As the lives, not a single hair of his head shall fall to the ground, for God was with him in what he did today! Thus the soldiers rescued Jonathan and he did not die.
14:46 After that Saul gave up the pursuit of the Philistines, who returned to their own territory.
14:47 After taking possession of the kingship over Israel, Saul waged war on its enemies all around—Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he was successful
14:48 and fought bravely. He defeated Amalek and delivered Israel from the hand of those who were plundering them.
14:49 The sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchishua; the name of his firstborn daughter was Merob; the name of the younger was Michal.
14:50 The name of Sauls wife was Ahinoam, daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of his general was Abner, son of Ner, Sauls uncle;
14:51 Kish, Sauls father, and Ner, Abners father, were sons of Abiel.
14:52 There was heavy fighting with the Philistines during Sauls lifetime. Whenever Saul saw any strong or brave man, he took him into his service.
15:1 Samuel said to Saul: It was I the sent to anoint you king over his people Israel. Now, therefore, listen to the message of the .
15:2 Thus says the of hosts: I will punish what Amalek did to the Israelites when he barred their way as they came up from Egypt.
15:3 Go, now, attack Amalek, and put under the ban everything he has. Do not spare him; kill men and women, children and infants, oxen and sheep, camels and donkeys.
15:4 Saul alerted the army, and at Telaim reviewed two hundred thousand foot soldiers and ten thousand men of Judah.
15:5 Saul went to the city of Amalek and set up an ambush in the wadi.
15:6 He warned the Kenites: Leave Amalek, turn aside and come down so I will not have to destroy you with them, for you were loyal to the Israelites when they came up from Egypt. After the Kenites left,
15:7 Saul routed Amalek from Havilah to the approaches of Shur, on the frontier of Egypt.
15:8 He took Agag, king of Amalek, alive, but the rest of the people he destroyed by the sword, putting them under the ban.
15:9 He and his troops spared Agag and the best of the fat sheep and oxen, and the lambs. They refused to put under the ban anything that was worthwhile, destroying only what was worthless and of no account.
15:10 Then the word of the came to Samuel:
15:11 I regret having made Saul king, for he has turned from me and has not kept my command. At this Samuel grew angry and cried out to the all night.
15:12 Early in the morning he went to meet Saul, but was informed that Saul had gone to Carmel, where he set up a monument in his own honor, and that on his return he had gone down to Gilgal.
15:13 When Samuel came to him, Saul greeted him: The bless you! I have kept the command of the .
15:14 But Samuel asked, What, then, is this bleating of sheep that comes to my ears, the lowing of oxen that I hear?
15:15 Saul replied: They were brought from Amalek. The people spared the best sheep and oxen to sacrifice to the , your God; but the rest we destroyed, putting them under the ban.
15:16 Samuel said to Saul: Stop! Let me tell you what the said to me last night. Speak! he replied.
15:17 Samuel then said: Though little in your own eyes, are you not chief of the tribes of Israel? The anointed you king of Israel
15:18 and sent you on a mission, saying: Go and put the sinful Amalekites under a ban of destruction. Fight against them until you have exterminated them.
15:19 Why then have you disobeyed the ? You have pounced on the spoil, thus doing what was evil in the s sight.
15:20 Saul explained to Samuel: I did indeed obey the and fulfill the mission on which the sent me. I have brought back Agag, the king of Amalek, and, carrying out the ban, I have destroyed the Amalekites.
15:21 But from the spoil the army took sheep and oxen, the best of what had been banned, to sacrifice to the your God in Gilgal.
15:22 But Samuel said: Does the delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obedience to the s command? Obedience is better than sacrifice, to listen, better than the fat of rams.
15:23 For a sin of divination is rebellion, and arrogance, the crime of idolatry. Because you have rejected the word of the , the in turn has rejected you as king.
15:24 Saul admitted to Samuel: I have sinned, for I have transgressed the command of the and your instructions. I feared the people and obeyed them.
15:25 Now forgive my sin, and return with me, that I may worship the .
15:26 But Samuel said to Saul, I will not return with you, because you rejected the word of the and the has rejected you as king of Israel.
15:27 As Samuel turned to go, Saul seized a loose end of his garment, and it tore off.
15:28 So Samuel said to him: The has torn the kingdom of Israel from you this day, and has given it to a neighbor of yours, who is better than you.
15:29 The Glory of Israel neither deceives nor repents, for he is not a mortal who repents.
15:30 But Saul answered: I have sinned, yet honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel. Return with me that I may worship the your God.
15:31 And so Samuel returned with him, and Saul worshiped the .
15:32 Afterward Samuel commanded, Bring Agag, king of Amalek, to me. Agag came to him struggling and saying, So it is bitter death!
15:33 And Samuel said, As your sword has made women childless, so shall your mother be childless among women. Then he cut Agag to pieces before the in Gilgal.
15:34 Samuel departed for Ramah, while Saul went up to his home in Gibeah of Saul.
15:35 Never again, as long as he lived, did Samuel see Saul. Yet he grieved over Saul, because the repented that he had made him king of Israel.
16:1 The said to Samuel: How long will you grieve for Saul, whom I have rejected as king of Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and be on your way. I am sending you to Jesse of Bethlehem, for from among his sons I have decided on a king.
16:2 But Samuel replied: How can I go? Saul will hear of it and kill me. To this the answered: Take a heifer along and say, I have come to sacrifice to the .
16:3 Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I myself will tell you what to do; you are to anoint for me the one I point out to you.
16:4 Samuel did as the had commanded him. When he entered Bethlehem, the elders of the city came trembling to meet him and asked, Is your visit peaceful, O seer?
16:5 He replied: Yes! I have come to sacrifice to the . So purify yourselves and celebrate with me today. He also had Jesse and his sons purify themselves and invited them to the sacrifice.
16:6 As they came, he looked at Eliab and thought, Surely the anointed is here before the .
16:7 But the said to Samuel: Do not judge from his appearance or from his lofty stature, because I have rejected him. God does not see as a mortal, who sees the appearance. The looks into the heart.
16:8 Then Jesse called Abinadab and presented him before Samuel, who said, The has not chosen him.
16:9 Next Jesse presented Shammah, but Samuel said, The has not chosen this one either.
16:10 In the same way Jesse presented seven sons before Samuel, but Samuel said to Jesse, The has not chosen any one of these.
16:11 Then Samuel asked Jesse, Are these all the sons you have? Jesse replied, There is still the youngest, but he is tending the sheep. Samuel said to Jesse, Send for him; we will not sit down to eat until he arrives here.
16:12 Jesse had the young man brought to them. He was ruddy, a youth with beautiful eyes, and good looking. The said: There—anoint him, for this is the one!
16:13 Then Samuel, with the horn of oil in hand, anointed him in the midst of his brothers, and from that day on, the spirit of the rushed upon David. Then Samuel set out for Ramah.
16:14 The spirit of the had departed from Saul, and he was tormented by an evil spirit from the .
16:15 So the servants of Saul said to him: Look! An evil spirit from God is tormenting you.
16:16 If your lordship will order it, we, your servants here attending to you, will look for a man skilled in playing the harp. When the evil spirit from God comes upon you, he will play and you will feel better.
16:17 Saul then told his servants, Find me a good harpist and bring him to me.
16:18 One of the servants spoke up: I have observed that a son of Jesse of Bethlehem is a skillful harpist. He is also a brave warrior, an able speaker, and a handsome young man. The is certainly with him.
16:19 Accordingly, Saul dispatched messengers to ask Jesse to send him his son David, who was with the flock.
16:20 Then Jesse took five loaves of bread, a skin of wine, and a young goat, and sent them to Saul with his son David.
16:21 Thus David came to Saul and entered his service. Saul became very fond of him and made him his armor-bearer.
16:22 Saul sent Jesse the message, Let David stay in my service, for he meets with my approval.
16:23 Whenever the spirit from God came upon Saul, David would take the harp and play, and Saul would be relieved and feel better, for the evil spirit would leave him.
17:1 The Philistines rallied their forces for battle at Socoh in Judah and camped between Socoh and Azekah at Ephes-dammim.
17:2 Saul and the Israelites rallied and camped in the valley of the Elah, drawing up their battle line to meet the Philistines.
17:3 The Philistines were stationed on one hill and the Israelites on an opposite hill, with a valley between them.
17:4 A champion named Goliath of Gath came out from the Philistine camp; he was six cubits and a span tall.
17:5 He had a bronze helmet on his head and wore a bronze breastplate of scale armor weighing five thousand shekels,
17:6 bronze greaves, and had a bronze scimitar slung from his shoulders.
17:7 The shaft of his javelin was like a weavers beam, and its iron head weighed six hundred shekels. His shield-bearer went ahead of him.
17:8 He stood and shouted to the ranks of Israel: Why come out in battle formation? I am a Philistine, and you are Sauls servants. Choose one of your men, and have him come down to me.
17:9 If he beats me in combat and kills me, we will be your vassals; but if I beat him and kill him, you shall be our vassals and serve us.
17:10 The Philistine continued: I defy the ranks of Israel today. Give me a man and let us fight together.
17:11 When Saul and all Israel heard this challenge of the Philistine, they were stunned and terrified. 
17:12 David was the son of an Ephrathite named Jesse from Bethlehem in Judah who had eight sons. In the days of Saul Jesse was old and well on in years.
17:13 The three oldest sons of Jesse had followed Saul to war; the names of these three sons who had gone off to war were Eliab the firstborn; Abinadab the second; and Shammah the third.
17:14 David was the youngest. While the three oldest had joined Saul,
17:15 David would come and go from Sauls presence to tend his fathers sheep at Bethlehem.
17:16 Meanwhile the Philistine came forward and took his stand morning and evening for forty days.
17:17 Now Jesse said to his son David: Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves for your brothers, and bring them quickly to your brothers in the camp.
17:18 Also take these ten cheeses for the field officer. Greet your brothers and bring home some token from them.
17:19 Saul and your brothers, together with all Israel, are at war with the Philistines in the valley of the Elah.
17:20 Early the next morning, having left the flock with a shepherd, David packed up and set out, as Jesse had commanded him. He reached the barricade of the camp just as the army, on their way to the battleground, were shouting their battle cry.
17:21 The Israelites and the Philistines drew up opposite each other in battle array.
17:22 David entrusted what he had brought to the keeper of the baggage and hastened to the battle line, where he greeted his brothers.
17:23 While he was talking with them, the Philistine champion, by name Goliath of Gath, came up from the ranks of the Philistines and spoke as before, and David listened.
17:24 When the Israelites saw the man, they all retreated before him, terrified.
17:25 The Israelites had been saying: Do you see this man coming up? He comes up to insult Israel. The king will make whoever kills him a very wealthy man. He will give his daughter to him and declare his fathers family exempt from taxes in Israel.
17:26 David now said to the men standing near him: How will the man who kills this Philistine and frees Israel from disgrace be rewarded? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should insult the armies of the living God?
17:27 They repeated the same words to him and said, That is how the man who kills him will be rewarded.
17:28 When Eliab, his oldest brother, heard him speaking with the men, he grew angry with David and said: Why did you come down? With whom have you left those sheep in the wilderness? I know your arrogance and dishonest heart. You came down to enjoy the battle!
17:29 David protested, What have I done now? I was only talking.
17:30 He turned from him to another and asked the same question; and everyone gave him the same answer as before.
17:31 The words that David had spoken were overheard and reported to Saul, who sent for him.
17:32 Then David spoke to Saul: My lord should not lose heart. Let your servant go and fight this Philistine.
17:33 But Saul answered David, You cannot go up against this Philistine and fight with him, for you are only a youth, while he has been a warrior from his youth.
17:34 Then David told Saul: Your servant used to tend his fathers sheep, and whenever a lion or bear came to carry off a sheep from the flock,
17:35 I would chase after it, attack it, and snatch the prey from its mouth. If it attacked me, I would seize it by the throat, strike it, and kill it.
17:36 Your servant has killed both a lion and a bear. This uncircumcised Philistine will be as one of them, because he has insulted the armies of the living God.
17:37 David continued: The same who delivered me from the claws of the lion and the bear will deliver me from the hand of this Philistine. Saul answered David, Go! the will be with you.
17:38 Then Saul dressed David in his own tunic, putting a bronze helmet on his head and arming him with a coat of mail.
17:39 David also fastened Sauls sword over the tunic. He walked with difficulty, however, since he had never worn armor before. He said to Saul, I cannot go in these, because I am not used to them. So he took them off.
17:40 Then, staff in hand, David selected five smooth stones from the wadi and put them in the pocket of his shepherds bag. With his sling in hand, he approached the Philistine.
17:41 With his shield-bearer marching before him, the Philistine advanced closer and closer to David.
17:42 When he sized David up and saw that he was youthful, ruddy, and handsome in appearance, he began to deride him.
17:43 He said to David, Am I a dog that you come against me with a staff? Then the Philistine cursed David by his gods
17:44 and said to him, Come here to me, and I will feed your flesh to the birds of the air and the beasts of the field.
17:45 David answered him: You come against me with sword and spear and scimitar, but I come against you in the name of the of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel whom you have insulted.
17:46 Today the shall deliver you into my hand; I will strike you down and cut off your head. This very day I will feed your dead body and the dead bodies of the Philistine army to the birds of the air and the beasts of the field; thus the whole land shall learn that Israel has a God.
17:47 All this multitude, too, shall learn that it is not by sword or spear that the saves. For the battle belongs to the , who shall deliver you into our hands.
17:48 The Philistine then moved to meet David at close quarters, while David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet the Philistine.
17:49 David put his hand into the bag and took out a stone, hurled it with the sling, and struck the Philistine on the forehead. The stone embedded itself in his brow, and he fell on his face to the ground.
17:50 Thus David triumphed over the Philistine with sling and stone; he struck the Philistine dead, and did it without a sword in his hand.
17:51 Then David ran and stood over him; with the Philistines own sword which he drew from its sheath he killed him, and cut off his head. When the Philistines saw that their hero was dead, they fled.
17:52 Then the men of Israel and Judah sprang up with a battle cry and pursued them to the approaches of Gath and to the gates of Ekron, and Philistines fell wounded along the road from Shaaraim as far as Gath and Ekron.
17:53 When they returned from their pursuit of the Philistines, the Israelites looted their camp.
17:54 David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem; but he kept Goliaths armor in his own tent.
17:55 As Saul watched David go out to meet the Philistine, he asked his general Abner, Abner, whose son is that young man? Abner replied, On your life, O king, I have no idea.
17:56 And the king said, Find out whose son the lad is.
17:57 So when David returned from slaying the Philistine, Abner escorted him into Sauls presence. David was still holding the Philistines head.
17:58 Saul then asked him, Whose son are you, young man? David replied, I am the son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem.
18:1 By the time David finished speaking with Saul, Jonathans life became bound up with Davids life; he loved him as his very self.
18:2 Saul retained David on that day and did not allow him to return to his fathers house.
18:3 Jonathan and David made a covenant, because Jonathan loved him as his very self.
18:4 Jonathan took off the cloak he was wearing and handed it over to David, along with his military dress, even his sword, bow, and belt.
18:5 David then carried out successfully every mission on which Saul sent him. So Saul put him in charge of his soldiers; this met with the approval of the whole army, even Sauls officers.
18:6 At the approach of Saul and David, on Davids return after striking down the Philistine, women came out from all the cities of Israel to meet Saul the king, singing and dancing, with tambourines, joyful songs, and stringed instruments.
18:7 The women played and sang: Saul has slain his thousands, David his tens of thousands.
18:8 Saul was very angry and resentful of the song, for he thought: They give David tens of thousands, but only thousands to me. All that remains for him is the kingship.
18:9 From that day on, Saul kept a jealous eye on David.
18:10 The next day an evil spirit from God rushed upon Saul, and he raged in his house. David was in attendance, playing the harp as at other times, while Saul was holding his spear.
18:11 Saul poised the spear, thinking, I will nail David to the wall! But twice David escaped him.
18:12 Saul then began to fear David because the was with him but had turned away from Saul.
18:13 Saul sent him out of his presence and appointed him a field officer. So David led the people on their military expeditions
18:14 and prospered in all his ways, for the was with him.
18:15 Seeing how he prospered, Saul feared David.
18:16 But all Israel and Judah loved David, since he led them on their expeditions.
18:17 Saul said to David, Look, I will give you my older daughter, Merob, in marriage if you become my warrior and fight the battles of the . Saul thought, I will not lay a hand on him. Let the hand of the Philistines strike him.
18:18 But David answered Saul: Who am I? And who are my kindred or my fathers clan in Israel that I should become the kings son-in-law?
18:19 But when the time came for Sauls daughter Merob to be given to David, she was given as wife to Adriel the Meholathite instead.
18:20 Now Sauls daughter Michal loved David. When this was reported to Saul, he was pleased.
18:21 He thought, I will offer her to him as a trap, so that the hand of the Philistines may strike him. So for the second time Saul said to David, You shall become my son-in-law today.
18:22 Saul then ordered his servants, Speak to David privately and say: The king favors you, and all his officers love you. You should become son-in-law to the king.
18:23 But when Sauls servants mentioned this to David, he said: Is becoming the kings son-in-law a trivial matter in your eyes? I am poor and insignificant.
18:24 When his servants reported Davids answer to him,
18:25 Saul commanded them, Say this to David: The king desires no other price for the bride than the foreskins of one hundred Philistines, that he may thus take vengeance on his enemies. Saul intended to have David fall into the hands of the Philistines.
18:26 When the servants reported this offer to David, he was pleased with the prospect of becoming the kings son-in-law. Before the year was up,
18:27 David arose and went with his men and slew two hundred Philistines. He brought back their foreskins and counted them out before the king that he might become the kings son-in-law. So Saul gave him his daughter Michal as wife.
18:28 Then Saul realized that the was with David and that his own daughter Michal loved David.
18:29 So Saul feared David all the more and was his enemy ever after.
18:30 The Philistine chiefs continued to make forays, but each time they took the field, David was more successful against them than any of Sauls other officers, and his name was held in great esteem.
19:1 Saul discussed his intention to kill David with his son Jonathan and with all his servants. But Sauls son Jonathan, who was very fond of David,
19:2 told him: My father Saul is trying to kill you. Therefore, please be on your guard tomorrow morning; stay out of sight and remain in hiding.
19:3 I, however, will go out and stand beside my father in the countryside where you are, and will speak to him about you. If I learn anything, I will let you know.
19:4 Jonathan then spoke well of David to his father Saul, telling him: The king should not harm his servant David. He has not harmed you, but has helped you very much by his deeds.
19:5 When he took his life in his hands and killed the Philistine, and the won a great victory for all Israel, you were glad to see it. Why, then, should you become guilty of shedding innocent blood by killing David without cause?
19:6 Saul heeded Jonathans plea and swore, As the lives, he shall not be killed.
19:7 So Jonathan summoned David and repeated the whole conversation to him. He then brought David to Saul, and David served him as before.
19:8 When war broke out again, David went out to fight against the Philistines and inflicted such a great defeat upon them that they fled from him.
19:9 Then an evil spirit from the came upon Saul as he was sitting in his house with spear in hand while David was playing the harp nearby.
19:10 Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the spear, but David eluded Saul, and the spear struck only the wall, while David got away safely.
19:11 The same night, Saul sent messengers to Davids house to guard it, planning to kill him in the morning. Davids wife Michal informed him, Unless you run for your life tonight, tomorrow you will be killed.
19:12 Then Michal let David down through a window, and he made his escape in safety.
19:13 Michal took the teraphim and laid it in the bed, putting a tangle of goats hair at its head and covering it with a blanket.
19:14 When Saul sent officers to arrest David, she said, He is sick.
19:15 Saul, however, sent the officers back to see David and commanded them, Bring him up to me in his bed, that I may kill him.
19:16 But when the messengers entered, they found the teraphim in the bed, with the tangle of goats hair at its head.
19:17 Saul asked Michal: Why did you lie to me like this? You have helped my enemy to get away! Michal explained to Saul: He threatened me, saying Let me go or I will kill you.
19:18 When David got safely away, he went to Samuel in Ramah, informing him of all that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went to stay in Naioth.
19:19 When Saul was told that David was at Naioth in Ramah,
19:20 he sent officers to arrest David. But when they saw the band of prophets presided over by Samuel in a prophetic state, the spirit of God came upon them and they too fell into the prophetic ecstasy.
19:21 Informed of this, Saul sent other messengers, who also fell into the prophetic ecstasy. For the third time Saul sent messengers, but they too fell into a prophetic ecstasy.
19:22 Finally Saul went to Ramah himself. Arriving at the large cistern in Secu, he asked, Where are Samuel and David? Someone answered, At Naioth in Ramah.
19:23 As he walked from there to Naioth in Ramah, the spirit of God came upon him also, and he continued on, acting like a prophet until he reached Naioth in Ramah.
19:24 Then he, too, stripped himself of his garments and remained in a prophetic state in the presence of Samuel; all that day and night he lay naked. That is why they say, Is Saul also among the prophets?
20:1 David fled from Naioth in Ramah, and went to Jonathan. What have I done? he asked him. What crime or what offense does your father hold against me that he seeks my life?
20:2 Jonathan answered him: Heaven forbid that you should die! My father does nothing, great or small, without telling me. Why, then, should my father conceal this from me? It cannot be true!
20:3 But David replied: Your father is well aware that I am favored with your friendship, so he has decided, Jonathan must not know about this or he will be grieved. Nevertheless, as the lives and as you live, there is only a step between me and death.
20:4 Jonathan then said to David, I will do whatever you say.
20:5 David answered: Tomorrow is the new moon, when I should in fact dine with the king. Let me go and hide in the open country until evening.
20:6 If it turns out that your father misses me, say, David urged me to let him go on short notice to his city Bethlehem, because his whole clan is holding its seasonal sacrifice there.
20:7 If he says, Very well, your servant is safe. But if he becomes quite angry, you can be sure he has planned some harm.
20:8 Do this kindness for your servant because of the s covenant into which you brought us: if I am guilty, kill me yourself! Why should you give me up to your father?
20:9 But Jonathan answered: Not I! If ever I find out that my father is determined to harm you, I will certainly let you know.
20:10 David then asked Jonathan, Who will tell me if your father gives you a harsh answer?
20:11 Jonathan replied to David, Come, let us go out into the field. When they were out in the open country together,
20:12 Jonathan said to David: As the , the God of Israel, lives, I will sound out my father about this time tomorrow. Whether he is well disposed toward David or not, I will inform you.
20:13 Should it please my father to bring any harm upon you, may the do thus to Jonathan and more, if I do not inform you of it and send you on your way in peace. May the be with you even as he was with my father.
20:14 Only this: if I am still alive, may you show me the kindness of the . But if I die,
20:15 never cut off your kindness from my house. And when the cuts off all the enemies of David from the face of the land,
20:16 the name of Jonathan must never be cut off from the family of David, or the will make you answer for it.
20:17 And in his love for David, Jonathan renewed his oath to him, because he loved him as he loved himself.
20:18 Jonathan then said to him: Tomorrow is the new moon; you will be missed, since your place will be vacant.
20:19 On the third day you will be missed all the more. Go to the spot where you hid on the other occasion and wait near the mound there.
20:20 On the third day of the month I will shoot arrows to the side of it, as though aiming at a target.
20:21 I will then send my attendant to recover the arrows. If in fact I say to him, Look, the arrow is this side of you; pick it up, come, for you are safe. As the lives, there will be nothing to fear.
20:22 But if I say to the boy, Look, the arrow is beyond you, go, for the sends you away.
20:23 However, in the matter which you and I have discussed, the shall be between you and me forever.
20:24 So David hid in the open country. On the day of the new moon, when the king sat down at the feast to dine,
20:25 he took his usual place against the wall. Jonathan sat facing him, while Abner sat at the kings side. Davids place was vacant.
20:26 Saul, however, said nothing that day, for he thought, He must have become unclean by accident.
20:27 On the next day, the second day of the month, Davids place was still vacant. So Saul asked his son Jonathan, Why has the son of Jesse not come to table yesterday or today?
20:28 Jonathan explained to Saul: David pleaded with me to let him go to Bethlehem.
20:29 Please let me go, he begged, for we are having a clan sacrifice in our city, and my brothers insist on my presence. Now then, if you think well of me, give me leave to visit my brothers. That is why he has not come to the kings table.
20:30 But Saul grew angry with Jonathan and said to him: Son of a rebellious woman, do I not know that, to your own disgrace and to the disgrace of your mothers nakedness, you are the companion of Jesses son?
20:31 For as long as the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, you cannot make good your claim to the kingship! Now send for him, and bring him to me, for he must die.
20:32 But Jonathan argued with his father Saul: Why should he die? What has he done?
20:33 At this Saul brandished his spear to strike him, and thus Jonathan learned that his father was determined to kill David.
20:34 Jonathan sprang up from the table in a rage and ate nothing that second day of the month, because he was grieved on Davids account, and because his father had humiliated him.
20:35 The next morning Jonathan, accompanied by a young boy, went out into the field for his appointment with David.
20:36 There he said to the boy, Run and find the arrows. And as the boy ran, he shot an arrow past him.
20:37 When the boy made for the spot where Jonathan had shot the arrow, Jonathan called after him, The arrow is farther on!
20:38 Again he called to the boy, Hurry, be quick, dont delay! Jonathans boy picked up the arrow and brought it to his master.
20:39 The boy suspected nothing; only Jonathan and David knew what was meant.
20:40 Then Jonathan gave his weapons to his boy and said to him, Go, take them to the city.
20:41 When the boy had gone, David rose from beside the mound and fell on his face to the ground three times in homage. They kissed each other and wept aloud together.
20:42 At length Jonathan said to David, Go in peace, in keeping with what the two of us have sworn by the name of the : The shall be between you and me, and between your offspring and mine forever.
21:1 Then David departed on his way, while Jonathan went back into the city.
21:2 David went to Ahimelech, the priest of Nob, who came trembling to meet him. He asked, Why are you alone? Is there no one with you?
21:3 David answered the priest: The king gave me a commission and told me, Do not let anyone know anything about the business on which I have sent you or the commission I have given you. For that reason I have arranged a particular meeting place with my men.
21:4 Now what do you have on hand? Give me five loaves, or whatever you can find.
21:5 But the priest replied to David, I have no ordinary bread on hand, only holy bread; if the men have abstained from women, you may eat some of that.
21:6 David answered the priest: We have indeed stayed away from women. In the past whenever I went out on a campaign, all the young men were consecrated—even for an ordinary campaign. All the more so are they consecrated with their weapons today!
21:7 So the priest gave him holy bread, for no other bread was on hand except the showbread which had been removed from before the and replaced by fresh bread when it was taken away.
21:8 One of Sauls servants was there that day, detained before the ; his name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of Sauls shepherds.
21:9 David then asked Ahimelech: Do you have a spear or a sword on hand? I brought along neither my sword nor my weapons, because the kings business was urgent.
21:10 The priest replied: The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here wrapped in a garment behind an ephod. If you wish to take it, do so; there is no sword here except that one. There is none like it, David cried, give it to me!
21:11 That same day David fled from Saul, going to Achish, king of Gath.
21:12 But the servants of Achish said to him, Is this not David, the king of the land? Is it not for him that during their dances they sing out, Saul has slain his thousands, David his tens of thousands?
21:13 David took note of these remarks and became very much afraid of Achish, king of Gath.
21:14 So, he feigned insanity in front of them and acted like a madman in their custody, drumming on the doors of the gate and drooling onto his beard.
21:15 Finally Achish said to his servants: You see the man is mad. Why did you bring him to me?
21:16 Do I not have enough madmen, that you bring this one to rant in my presence? Should this fellow come into my house?
22:1 David left Gath and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and the rest of his family heard about it, they came down to him there.
22:2 He was joined by all those in difficulties or in debt, or embittered, and became their leader. About four hundred men were with him.
22:3 From there David went to Mizpeh of Moab and said to the king of Moab, Let my father and mother stay with you, until I learn what God will do for me.
22:4 He left them with the king of Moab; they stayed with him as long as David remained in the stronghold.
22:5 But Gad the prophet said to David: Do not remain in the stronghold! Leave! Go to the land of Judah. And so David left and went to the forest of Hereth.
22:6 Now Saul heard that David and his men had been located. At the time he was sitting in Gibeah under a tamarisk tree on the high place, holding his spear, while all his servants stood by him.
22:7 So he said to them: Listen, men of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse give all of you fields and vineyards? Will he appoint any of you an officer over a thousand or a hundred men?
22:8 Is that why you have all conspired against me? Why no one told me that my son had made a pact with the son of Jesse? None of you has shown compassion for me by revealing to me that my son has incited my servant to ambush me, as is the case today.
22:9 Then Doeg the Edomite, who was standing with Sauls officers, spoke up: I saw the son of Jesse come to Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, in Nob.
22:10 He consulted the for him, furnished him with provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.
22:11 So the king summoned Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub, and all his family, the priests in Nob. They all came to the king.
22:12 Listen, son of Ahitub! Saul declared. Yes, my lord, he replied.
22:13 Saul questioned him, Why have you conspired against me with the son of Jesse by giving him food and a sword and by consulting God for him, that he might rise up against me in ambush, as is the case today?
22:14 Ahimelech answered the king: Who among all your servants is as loyal as David, the kings son-in-law, captain of your bodyguard, and honored in your own house?
22:15 Is this the first time I have consulted God for him? No indeed! Let not the king accuse his servant or anyone in my family of such a thing. Your servant knows nothing at all, great or small, about the whole matter.
22:16 But the king said, You shall certainly die, Ahimelech, with all your family.
22:17 The king then commanded his guards standing by him: Turn and kill the priests of the , for they gave David a hand. They knew he was a fugitive and yet failed to inform me. But the kings servants refused to raise a hand to strike the priests of the .
22:18 The king therefore commanded Doeg, You, turn and kill the priests! So Doeg the Edomite himself turned and killed the priests that day—eighty-five who wore the linen ephod.
22:19 Saul also put the priestly city of Nob to the sword, including men and women, children and infants, and oxen, donkeys and sheep.
22:20 One son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled to David.
22:21 When Abiathar told David that Saul had slain the priests of the ,
22:22 David said to him: I knew that day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would certainly tell Saul. I am responsible for the slaughter of all your family.
22:23 Stay with me. Do not be afraid; whoever seeks your life must seek my life also. You are under my protection.
23:1 David was informed that the Philistines were attacking Keilah and plundering the threshing floors.
23:2 So he consulted the , asking, Shall I go and attack these Philistines? The answered, Go, attack them, and free Keilah.
23:3 But Davids men said to him: Even in Judah we have reason to fear. How much more so if we go to Keilah against the forces of the Philistines!
23:4 Again David consulted the , who answered: Go down to Keilah, for I will deliver the Philistines into your power.
23:5 So David went with his men to Keilah and fought against the Philistines. He drove off their cattle and inflicted a severe defeat on them, and freed the inhabitants of Keilah.
23:6 Abiathar, son of Ahimelech, who had fled to David, went down with David to Keilah, taking the ephod with him.
23:7 When Saul was told that David had entered Keilah, he thought: God has put him in my hand, for he has boxed himself in by entering a city with gates and bars.
23:8 Saul then called all the army to war, in order to go down to Keilah and besiege David and his men.
23:9 When David found out that Saul was planning to harm him, he said to the priest Abiathar, Bring the ephod here.
23:10 God of Israel, David prayed, your servant has heard that Saul plans to come to Keilah, to destroy the city on my account.
23:11 Will they hand me over? Will Saul come down as your servant has heard? God of Israel, tell your servant. The answered: He will come down.
23:12 David then asked, Will the citizens of Keilah deliver me and my men into the hand of Saul? The answered: They will deliver you.
23:13 So David and his men, about six hundred in number, left Keilah and wandered from place to place. When Saul was informed that David had fled from Keilah, he did not go forth.
23:14 David now lived in the strongholds in the wilderness, or in the barren hill country near Ziph. Though Saul sought him continually, the did not deliver David into his hand.
23:15 While David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh he was afraid that Saul had come out to seek his life.
23:16 Then Sauls son, Jonathan, came down to David at Horesh and encouraged him in the .
23:17 He said to him: Have no fear, my father Saul shall not lay a hand to you. You shall be king of Israel and I shall be second to you. Even my father Saul knows this.
23:18 The two of them made a covenant before the in Horesh, where David remained, while Jonathan returned to his home.
23:19 Some of the Ziphites went up to Saul in Gibeah and said, David is hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh on the hill of Hachilah, south of Jeshimon.
23:20 Therefore, whenever the king wishes to come down, let him do so. It will be our task to deliver him into the kings hand.
23:21 Saul replied: The bless you for your compassion toward me.
23:22 Go now and make sure once more! Take note of the place where he sets foot for I am told that he is very cunning.
23:23 Look around and learn in which of all the various hiding places he is holding out. Then come back to me with reliable information, and I will go with you. If he is in the region, I will track him down out of all the families of Judah.
23:24 So they went off to Ziph ahead of Saul. At this time David and his men were in the wilderness below Maon, in the Arabah south of the wasteland.
23:25 When Saul and his men came looking for him, David got word of it and went down to the gorge in the wilderness below Maon. Saul heard of this and pursued David into the wilderness below Maon.
23:26 As Saul moved along one side of the gorge, David and his men took to the other. David was anxious to escape Saul, while Saul and his men were trying to outflank David and his men in order to capture them.
23:27 Then a messenger came to Saul, saying, Come quickly, because the Philistines have invaded the land.
23:28 Saul interrupted his pursuit of David and went to meet the Philistines. This is how that place came to be called the Rock of Divisions.
24:1 David then went up from there and stayed in the strongholds of Engedi.
24:2 When Saul returned from the pursuit of the Philistines, he was told that David was in the desert near Engedi.
24:3 So Saul took three thousand of the best men from all Israel and went in search of David and his men in the direction of the wild goat crags.
24:4 When he came to the sheepfolds along the way, he found a cave, which he entered to relieve himself. David and his men were occupying the inmost recesses of the cave.
24:5 Davids servants said to him, This is the day about which the said to you: I will deliver your enemy into your hand; do with him as you see fit. So David moved up and stealthily cut off an end of Sauls robe.
24:6 Afterward, however, David regretted that he had cut off an end of Sauls robe.
24:7 He said to his men, The forbid that I should do such a thing to my master, the s anointed, to lay a hand on him, for he is the s anointed.
24:8 With these words David restrained his men and would not permit them to attack Saul. Saul then left the cave and went on his way.
24:9 David also stepped out of the cave, calling to Saul, My lord the king! When Saul looked back, David bowed, his face to the ground in homage,
24:10 and asked Saul: Why do you listen to those who say, David is trying to harm you?
24:11 You see for yourself today that the just now delivered you into my hand in the cave. I was told to kill you, but I took pity on you instead. I decided, I will not raise a hand against my master, for he is the s anointed.
24:12 Look here, my father. See the end of your robe which I hold. I cut off an end of your robe and did not kill you. Now see and be convinced that I plan no harm and no rebellion. I have done you no wrong, though you are hunting me down to take my life.
24:13 May the judge between me and you. May the exact justice from you in my case. I shall not lay a hand on you.
24:14 As the old proverb says, From the wicked comes wickedness. Thus I will not lay a hand on you.
24:15 What is the king of Israel attacking? What are you pursuing? A dead dog! A single flea!
24:16 The will be the judge to decide between us. May the see this, defend my cause, and give me justice against you!
24:17 When David finished saying these things to Saul, Saul answered, Is that your voice, my son David? And he wept freely.
24:18 Saul then admitted to David: You are more in the right than I am. You have treated me graciously, while I have treated you badly.
24:19 You have declared this day how you treated me graciously: the delivered me into your hand and you did not kill me.
24:20 For if someone comes upon an enemy, do they send them graciously on their way? So may the reward you graciously for what you have done this day.
24:21 And now, since I know that you will certainly become king and that the kingship over Israel shall come into your possession,
24:22 swear to me by the that you will not cut off my descendants and that you will not blot out my name from my fathers house.
24:23 David gave Saul his oath and Saul returned home, while David and his men went up to the stronghold.
25:1 Samuel died, and all Israel gathered to mourn him; they buried him at his home in Ramah. Then David went down to the wilderness of Paran.
25:2 There was a man of Maon who had property in Carmel; he was very wealthy, owning three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. At the time, he was present for the shearing of his flock in Carmel.
25:3 The mans name was Nabal and his wife was Abigail. The woman was intelligent and attractive, but Nabal, a Calebite, was harsh and bad-mannered.
25:4 While in the wilderness, David heard that Nabal was shearing his flock,
25:5 so he sent ten young men, instructing them: Go up to Carmel. Pay Nabal a visit and greet him in my name.
25:6 Say to him, Peace be with you, my brother, and with your family, and with all who belong to you.
25:7 I have just heard that shearers are with you. Now, when your shepherds were with us, we did them no injury, neither did they miss anything while they were in Carmel.
25:8 Ask your servants and they will tell you. Look kindly on these young men, since we come at a festival time. Please give your servants and your son David whatever you can.
25:9 When Davids young men arrived, they delivered the entire message to Nabal in Davids name, and then waited.
25:10 But Nabal answered the servants of David: Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? Nowadays there are many servants who run away from their masters.
25:11 Must I take my bread, my wine, my meat that I have slaughtered for my own shearers, and give them to men who come from who knows where?
25:12 So Davids young men retraced their steps and on their return reported to him all that had been said.
25:13 Thereupon David said to his men, Let everyone strap on his sword. And everyone did so, and David put on his own sword. About four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred remained with the baggage.
25:14 Abigail, Nabals wife, was informed of this by one of the servants, who said: From the wilderness David sent messengers to greet our master, but he screamed at them.
25:15 Yet these men were very good to us. We were not harmed, neither did we miss anything all the while we were living among them during our stay in the open country.
25:16 Day and night they were a wall of protection for us, the whole time we were pasturing the sheep near them.
25:17 Now, see what you can do, for you must realize that otherwise disaster is in store for our master and for his whole house. He is such a scoundrel that no one can talk to him.
25:18 Abigail quickly got together two hundred loaves, two skins of wine, five dressed sheep, five seahs of roasted grain, a hundred cakes of pressed raisins, and two hundred cakes of pressed figs, and loaded them on donkeys.
25:19 She then said to her servants, Go on ahead; I will follow you. But to her husband Nabal she said nothing.
25:20 Hidden by the mountain, she came down riding on a donkey, as David and his men were coming down from the opposite direction. When she met them,
25:21 David had just been saying: Indeed, it was in vain that I guarded all this mans possessions in the wilderness, so that nothing of his was missing. He has repaid good with evil.
25:22 May God do thus to David, and more, if by morning I leave a single male alive among all those who belong to him.
25:23 As soon as Abigail saw David, she dismounted quickly from the donkey and, falling down, bowed low to the ground before David in homage.
25:24 As she fell at his feet she said: My lord, let the blame be mine. Please let your maidservant speak to you; listen to the words of your maidservant.
25:25 My lord, do not pay any attention to that scoundrel Nabal, for he is just like his name. His name means fool, and he acts the fool. I, your maidservant, did not see the young men whom my lord sent.
25:26 Now, therefore, my lord, as the lives, and as you live, the has kept you from shedding blood and from avenging yourself by your own hand. May your enemies and those who seek to harm my lord become as Nabal!
25:27 Accept this gift, then, which your maidservant has brought for my lord, and let it be given to the young men who follow my lord.
25:28 Please forgive the offense of your maidservant, for the shall certainly establish a lasting house for my lord, because my lord fights the battles of the . Let no evil be found in you your whole life long.
25:29 If any adversary pursues you to seek your life, may the life of my lord be bound in the bundle of the living in the care of the your God; may God hurl out the lives of your enemies as from the hollow of a sling.
25:30 And when the fulfills for my lord the promise of success he has made concerning you, and appoints you as ruler over Israel,
25:31 you shall not have any regrets or burdens on your conscience, my lord, for having shed innocent blood or for having rescued yourself. When the bestows good on my lord, remember your maidservant.
25:32 David said to Abigail: Blessed is the , the God of Israel, who sent you to meet me today.
25:33 Blessed is your good judgment and blessed are you yourself. Today you have prevented me from shedding blood and rescuing myself with my own hand.
25:34 Otherwise, as the , the God of Israel, lives, who has kept me from harming you, if you had not come so promptly to meet me, by dawn Nabal would not have had so much as one male left alive.
25:35 David then took from her what she had brought him and said to her: Go to your home in peace! See, I have listened to your appeal and have granted your request.
25:36 When Abigail came to Nabal, he was hosting a banquet in his house like that of a king, and Nabal was in a festive mood and very drunk. So she said not a word to him until daybreak the next morning.
25:37 But then, when Nabal was sober, his wife told him what had happened. At this his heart died within him, and he became like a stone.
25:38 About ten days later the struck Nabal and he died.
25:39 Hearing that Nabal was dead, David said: Blessed be the , who has defended my cause against the insult from Nabal, and who restrained his servant from doing evil, but has repaid Nabal for his evil deeds. David then sent a proposal of marriage to Abigail.
25:40 When Davids servants came to Abigail in Carmel, they said to her, David has sent us to make his proposal of marriage to you.
25:41 Rising and bowing to the ground, she answered, Let your maidservant be the slave who washes the feet of my lords servants.
25:42 She got up immediately, mounted a donkey, and followed Davids messengers, with her five maids attending her. She became his wife.
25:43 David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel. Thus both of them were his wives.
