25:44 But Saul gave Davids wife Michal, Sauls own daughter, to Palti, son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
26:1 Men from Ziph came to Saul in Gibeah, reporting that David was hiding on the hill of Hachilah at the edge of Jeshimon.
26:2 So Saul went down to the wilderness of Ziph with three thousand of the best warriors of Israel, to search for David in the wilderness of Ziph.
26:3 Saul camped beside the road on the hill of Hachilah, at the edge of Jeshimon. David, who was living in the wilderness, saw that Saul had come into the wilderness after him
26:4 and sent out scouts, who confirmed Sauls arrival.
26:5 David then went to the place where Saul was encamped and saw the spot where Saul and his general, Abner, son of Ner, had their sleeping quarters. Saul was lying within the camp, and all his soldiers were bivouacked around him.
26:6 David asked Ahimelech the Hittite, and Abishai, son of Zeruiah and brother of Joab, Who will go down into the camp with me to Saul? Abishai replied, I will.
26:7 So David and Abishai reached Sauls soldiers by night, and there was Saul lying asleep within the camp, his spear thrust into the ground at his head and Abner and his troops sleeping around him.
26:8 Abishai whispered to David: God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Let me nail him to the ground with one thrust of the spear; I will not need to strike him twice!
26:9 But David said to Abishai, Do not harm him, for who can lay a hand on the s anointed and remain innocent?
26:10 As the lives, David declared, only the can strike him: either when the time comes for him to die, or when he goes out and perishes in battle.
26:11 But the forbid that I lay a hand on the s anointed! Now take the spear at his head and the water jug, and let us be on our way.
26:12 So David took the spear and the water jug from their place at Sauls head, and they withdrew without anyone seeing or knowing or awakening. All remained asleep, because a deep slumber from the had fallen upon them.
26:13 Crossing over to an opposite slope, David stood on a distant hilltop. With a great distance between them
26:14 David called to the army and to Abner, son of Ner, Will you not answer, Abner? Then Abner shouted back, Who is it that calls me?
26:15 David said to Abner: Are you not a man? Who in Israel is your equal? Why were you not guarding your lord the king when one of his subjects came to assassinate the king, your lord?
26:16 What you have done is not right. As the lives, you people deserve death because you have not guarded your lord, the anointed of the . Go, look: where are the kings spear and the water jug that was at his head?
26:17 Saul recognized Davids voice and asked, Is that your voice, David my son? David answered, Yes, my lord the king.
26:18 He continued: Why does my lord pursue his servant? What have I done? What evil am I planning?
26:19 Please, now, let my lord the king listen to the words of his servant. If the has incited you against me, may an offering please the . But if it is the people who have done so, may they be cursed before the . They have driven me away so that today I have no share in the s heritage, but am told: Go serve other gods!
26:20 Do not let my blood spill on the ground far from the presence of the . For the king of Israel has come out to seek a single flea as if he were hunting partridge in the mountains.
26:21 Then Saul said: I have done wrong. Come back, David, my son! I will not harm you again, because you considered my life precious today even though I have been a fool and have made a serious mistake.
26:22 But David answered: Here is the kings spear. Let an attendant come over to get it.
26:23 The repays everyones righteousness and faithfulness. Although the delivered you into my hands today, I could not lay a hand on the s anointed.
26:24 Just as I regarded your life as precious today, so may the regard my life as precious and deliver me from all dangers.
26:25 Then Saul said to David: Blessed are you, my son David! You shall certainly succeed in whatever you undertake. David went his way, and Saul returned to his place.
27:1 David said to himself: I shall perish some day at the hand of Saul. I have no choice but to escape to the land of the Philistines; then Saul will give up his continual search for me throughout the land of Israel, and I will be out of his reach.
27:2 Accordingly, David departed with his six hundred soldiers and went over to Achish, son of Maoch, king of Gath.
27:3 David and his men lived in Gath with Achish; each one had his family, and David had his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.
27:4 When Saul learned that David had fled to Gath, he no longer searched for him.
27:5 David said to Achish: If I meet with your approval, let me have a place to live in one of the country towns. Why should your servant live with you in the royal city?
27:6 That same day Achish gave him Ziklag, which has, therefore, belonged to the kings of Judah up to the present time.
27:7 In all, David lived a year and four months in Philistine territory.
27:8 David and his men went out on raids against the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites—peoples living in the land between Telam, on the approach to Shur, and the land of Egypt.
27:9 In attacking the land David would not leave a man or woman alive, but would carry off sheep, oxen, donkeys, camels, and clothes. Then he would return to Achish,
27:10 who would ask, Against whom did you raid this time? David would reply, Against the Negeb of Judah, or Against the Negeb of Jerahmeel, or Against the Negeb of the Kenites.
27:11 David never left a man or woman alive to be brought to Gath. He thought, They will betray us and say, This is what David did. This was his custom as long as he lived in Philistine territory.
27:12 Achish trusted David, thinking, His people Israel must certainly detest him. I shall have him as my vassal forever.
28:1 In those days the Philistines mustered their military forces to fight against Israel. So Achish said to David, You realize, of course, that you and your warriors must march out for battle with me.
28:2 David answered Achish, Good! Now you shall learn what your servant can do. Then Achish said to David, I shall appoint you as my permanent bodyguard.
28:3 Now, Samuel was dead. All Israel had mourned him and buried him in his city, Ramah. Meanwhile Saul had driven mediums and diviners out of the land.
28:4 The Philistines rallied and, coming to Shunem, they encamped. Saul, too, mustered all Israel; they camped on Gilboa.
28:5 When Saul saw the Philistine camp, he grew afraid and lost heart completely.
28:6 He consulted the ; but the gave no answer, neither in dreams nor by Urim nor through prophets.
28:7 Then Saul said to his servants, Find me a medium through whom I can seek counsel. His servants answered him, There is a woman in Endor who is a medium.
28:8 So he disguised himself, putting on other clothes, and set out with two companions. They came to the woman at night, and Saul said to her, Divine for me; conjure up the spirit I tell you.
28:9 But the woman answered him, You know what Saul has done, how he expelled the mediums and diviners from the land. Then why are you trying to entrap me and get me killed?
28:10 But Saul swore to her by the , As the lives, you shall incur no blame for this.
28:11 Whom do you want me to conjure up? the woman asked him. Conjure up Samuel for me, he replied.
28:12 When the woman saw Samuel, she shrieked at the top of her voice and said to Saul, Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!
28:13 But the king said to her, Do not be afraid. What do you see? I see a god rising from the earth, she replied.
28:14 What does he look like? asked Saul. An old man is coming up wrapped in a robe, she replied. Saul knew that it was Samuel, and so he bowed his face to the ground in homage.
28:15 Samuel then said to Saul, Why do you disturb me by conjuring me up? Saul replied: I am in great distress, for the Philistines are waging war against me and God has turned away from me. Since God no longer answers me through prophets or in dreams, I have called upon you to tell me what I should do.
28:16 To this Samuel said: But why do you ask me, if the has abandoned you for your neighbor?
28:17 The has done to you what he declared through me: he has torn the kingdom from your hand and has given it to your neighbor David.
28:18 Because you disobeyed the s directive and would not carry out his fierce anger against Amalek, the has done this to you today.
28:19 Moreover, the will deliver Israel, and you as well, into the hands of the Philistines. By tomorrow you and your sons will be with me, and the will have delivered the army of Israel into the hands of the Philistines.
28:20 Immediately Saul fell full length on the ground, in great fear because of Samuels message. He had no strength left, since he had eaten nothing all that day and night.
28:21 Then the woman came to Saul and, seeing that he was quite terror-stricken, said to him: Remember, your maidservant obeyed you: I took my life in my hands and carried out the request you made of me.
28:22 Now you, in turn, please listen to your maidservant. Let me set out a bit of food for you to eat, so that you are strong enough to go on your way.
28:23 But he refused, saying, I will not eat. However, when his servants joined the woman in urging him, he listened to their entreaties, got up from the ground, and sat on a couch.
28:24 The woman had a stall-fed calf in the house, which she now quickly slaughtered. Then taking flour, she kneaded it and baked unleavened bread.
28:25 She set the meal before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they got up and left the same night.
29:1 Now the Philistines had mustered all their forces in Aphek, and the Israelites were encamped at the spring in Jezreel.
29:2 As the Philistine lords were marching their units of a hundred and a thousand, David and his warriors were marching in the rear guard with Achish.
29:3 The Philistine commanders asked, What are those Hebrews doing here? Achish answered them: Why, that is David, the officer of Saul, king of Israel. He has been with me for a year or two, and from the day he came over to me until now I have never found fault in him.
29:4 But the Philistine commanders were angered at this and said to him: Send that man back! Let him return to the place you picked out for him. He must not go down into battle with us; during the battle he might become our enemy. For how else can he win back his masters favor, if not at the expense of our soldiers?
29:5 Is this not the David for whom they sing during their dances, Saul has slain his thousands, David his tens of thousands?
29:6 So Achish summoned David and said to him: As the lives, you are honest, and I would want you with me in all my battles. To this day I have found nothing wrong with you since you came to me. But in the view of the chiefs you are not welcome.
29:7 Leave peacefully, now, and do nothing that might displease the Philistine chiefs.
29:8 But David said to Achish: What have I done? What fault have you found in your servant from the day I entered your service until today, that I cannot go to fight against the enemies of my lord the king?
29:9 I recognize, Achish answered David, that you are trustworthy, like an angel of God. But the Philistine commanders are saying, He must not go with us into battle.
29:10 So the first thing tomorrow, you and your lords servants who came with you, go to the place I picked out for you. Do not take to heart their worthless remarks; for you have been valuable in my service. But make an early morning start, as soon as it grows light, and be on your way.
29:11 So David and his warriors left early in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines, and the Philistines went on up to Jezreel.
30:1 Before David and his men reached Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had raided the Negeb and Ziklag. They stormed Ziklag, and set it on fire.
30:2 They took captive the women and all who were in the city, young and old, killing no one, and they herded them off when they left.
30:3 David and his men arrived at the city to find it burned to the ground and their wives, sons, and daughters taken captive.
30:4 Then David and those who were with him wept aloud until they could weep no more.
30:5 Davids two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel, had also been carried off.
30:6 Now David found himself in great danger, for the soldiers spoke of stoning him, so bitter were they over the fate of their sons and daughters. David took courage in the his God
30:7 and said to Abiathar, the priest, son of Ahimelech, Bring me the ephod! When Abiathar brought him the ephod,
30:8 David inquired of the , Shall I pursue these raiders? Can I overtake them? The answered him: Go in pursuit, for you will certainly overtake them and bring about a rescue.
30:9 So David went off with his six hundred as far as the Wadi Besor, where those who were to remain behind halted.
30:10 David continued the pursuit with four hundred, but two hundred were too exhausted to cross the Wadi Besor and remained behind.
30:11 An Egyptian was found in the open country and brought to David. They gave him food to eat and water to drink;
30:12 they also offered a cake of pressed figs and two cakes of pressed raisins. When he had eaten, he revived, for he had not taken food nor drunk water for three days and three nights.
30:13 Then David asked him, To whom do you belong? Where did you come from? I am an Egyptian, the slave of an Amalekite, he replied. My master abandoned me three days ago because I fell sick.
30:14 We raided the Negeb of the Cherethites, the territory of Judah, and the Negeb of Caleb; and we set Ziklag on fire.
30:15 David then asked him, Will you lead me down to these raiders? He answered, Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will lead you down to the raiders.
30:16 So he led them down, and there were the Amalekites lounging all over the ground, eating, drinking, and celebrating because of all the rich plunder they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
30:17 From dawn to sundown the next day David attacked them, allowing no one to escape except four hundred young men, who mounted their camels and fled.
30:18 David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, and he rescued his two wives.
30:19 Nothing was missing, small or great, plunder or sons or daughters, of all that the Amalekites had taken. David brought back everything.
30:20 Moreover, David took all the sheep and oxen, and as they drove these before him, they shouted, This is Davids plunder!
30:21 When David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow him, whom he had left behind at the Wadi Besor, they came out to meet David and the men with him. As David approached, he greeted them.
30:22 But all the greedy and worthless among those who had accompanied David said, Since they did not accompany us, we will not give them anything from the plunder, except for each mans wife and children.
30:23 But David said: You must not do this, my brothers, after what the has given us. The has protected us and delivered into our hands the raiders that came against us.
30:24 Who could agree with this proposal of yours? Rather, the share of the one who goes down to battle shall be the same as that of the one who remains with the baggage—they share alike.
30:25 And from that day forward he made this a law and a custom in Israel, as it still is today.
30:26 When David came to Ziklag, he sent part of the plunder to his friends, the elders of Judah, saying, This is a gift to you from the plunder of the enemies of the , namely,
30:27 to those in Bethel, Ramoth-negeb, Jattir,
30:28 Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
30:29 Racal, Jerahmeelite cities and Kenite cities,
30:30 Hormah, Borashan, Athach,
30:31 Hebron, and to all the places that David and his men had frequented.
31:1 Now the Philistines went to war against Israel, and the Israelites fled before them, and fell, slain on Mount Gilboa.
31:2 The Philistines pressed hard after Saul and his sons. When the Philistines had struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, sons of Saul,
31:3 the fury of the battle converged on Saul. Then the archers hit him, and he was severely wounded.
31:4 Saul said to his armor-bearer, Draw your sword and run me through; otherwise these uncircumcised will come and abuse me. But the armor-bearer, badly frightened, refused, so Saul took his own sword and fell upon it.
31:5 When the armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he too fell upon his sword and died with him.
31:6 Thus Saul, his three sons, and his armor-bearer died together on that same day.
31:7 When the Israelites on the slope of the valley and those along the Jordan saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled. Then the Philistines came and lived in those cities.
31:8 On the following day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
31:9 They cut off Sauls head and stripped him of his armor; these they sent throughout the land of the Philistines to bring the good news to the temple of their idols and to the people.
31:10 They put his armor in the temple of Astarte but impaled his body on the wall of Beth-shan.
31:11 When the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
31:12 all their warriors set out and traveled through the night; they removed the bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Beth-shan, and, returning to Jabesh, burned them.
31:13 Then they took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh, and fasted for seven days.
2 SAMUEL
1:1 After the death of Saul, David returned from his victory over the Amalekites and stayed in Ziklag two days.
1:2 On the third day a man came from the field of battle, one of Sauls people, with his garments torn and his head covered with dirt. Going to David, he fell to the ground in homage.
1:3 David asked him, Where have you come from? He replied, From the Israelite camp: I have escaped.
1:4 What happened? David said. Tell me. He answered that the soldiers had fled the battle and many of them had fallen and were dead; and that Saul and his son Jonathan were dead.
1:5 Then David said to the youth who was reporting to him, How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?
1:6 The youth reporting to him replied: I happened to find myself on Mount Gilboa and saw Saul leaning on his spear, with chariots and horsemen closing in on him.
1:7 He turned around and saw me, and called me to him. When I said, Here I am,
1:8 he asked me, Who are you? and I replied, An Amalekite.
1:9 Then he said to me, Stand over me, please, and put me to death, for I am in great suffering, but still alive.
1:10 So I stood over him and put him to death, for I knew that he could not survive his wound. I removed the crown from his head and the armlet from his arm and brought them here to my lord.
1:11 David seized his garments and tore them, and so did all the men who were with him.
1:12 They mourned and wept and fasted until evening for Saul and his son Jonathan, and for the people of the and the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
1:13 David said to the youth who had reported to him, Where are you from? He replied, I am the son of a resident alien, an Amalekite.
1:14 David said to him, How is it that you were not afraid to put forth your hand to desecrate the s anointed?
1:15 David then called one of the attendants and said to him, Come, strike him down; so he struck him and he died.
1:16 David said to him, Your blood is on your head, for you testified against yourself when you said, I put the s anointed to death.
1:17 Then David chanted this lament for Saul and his son Jonathan
1:18 (he commanded that it be taught to the Judahites; it is recorded in the Book of Jashar):
1:19 Alas! the glory of Israel, slain upon your heights! How can the warriors have fallen!
1:20 Do not report it in Gath, as good news in Ashkelons streets, Lest Philistine women rejoice, lest the women of the uncircumcised exult!
1:21 O mountains of Gilboa, upon you be neither dew nor rain, nor surging from the deeps! Defiled there the warriors shields, the shield of Saul—no longer anointed with oil!
1:22 From the blood of the slain, from the bodies of the warriors, The bow of Jonathan did not turn back, nor the sword of Saul return unstained.
1:23 Saul and Jonathan, beloved and dear, separated neither in life nor death, swifter than eagles, stronger than lions!
1:24 Women of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet and in finery, covered your clothing with ornaments of gold.
1:25 How can the warriors have fallen in the thick of battle! Jonathan—slain upon your heights!
1:26 I grieve for you, Jonathan my brother! Most dear have you been to me; More wondrous your love to me than the love of women.
1:27 How can the warriors have fallen, the weapons of war have perished!
2:1 After this, David inquired of the , Shall I go up into one of the cities of Judah? The replied to him: Go up. Then David asked, Where shall I go? He replied: To Hebron.
2:2 So David went up there, with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the wife of Nabal of Carmel.
2:3 David also brought up his men with their families, and they dwelt in the towns of Hebron.
2:4 Then the men of Judah came there and anointed David king over the house of Judah. A report reached David that the people of Jabesh-gilead had buried Saul.
2:5 So David sent messengers to the people of Jabesh-gilead and said to them: May you be blessed by the for having done this kindness to your lord Saul in burying him.
2:6 And now may the show you kindness and fidelity. For my part, I will show generosity to you for having done this.
2:7 So take courage and prove yourselves valiant, for though your lord Saul is dead, the house of Judah has anointed me king over them.
2:8 Abner, son of Ner, captain of Sauls army, took Ishbaal, son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim,
2:9 where he made him king over Gilead, the Asherites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and the rest of Israel.
2:10 Ishbaal, son of Saul, was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he reigned two years; but the house of Judah followed David.
2:11 In all, David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah seven years and six months.
2:12 Now Abner, son of Ner, and the servants of Ishbaal, Sauls son, set out from Mahanaim for Gibeon.
2:13 Joab, son of Zeruiah, and the servants of David also set out and encountered them at the pool of Gibeon. And they sat down, one group on one side of the pool and the other on the opposite side.
2:14 Then Abner said to Joab, Let the young men rise and perform for us. Joab replied, All right.
2:15 So they rose and were counted off: twelve of the Benjaminites of Ishbaal, son of Saul, and twelve of Davids servants.
2:16 Then each one grasped his opponents head and thrust his sword into his opponents side, and they all fell down together. And so that place was named the Field of the Sides; it is in Gibeon.
2:17 The battle that day was very fierce, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by Davids servants.
2:18 The three sons of Zeruiah were there—Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel, who was as fleet of foot as a gazelle in the open field,
2:19 set out after Abner, turning neither right nor left in his pursuit.
2:20 Abner turned around and said, Is that you, Asahel? He replied, Yes.
2:21 Abner said to him, Turn right or left; seize one of the young men and take what you can strip from him. But Asahel would not stop pursuing him.
2:22 Once more Abner said to Asahel: Stop pursuing me! Why must I strike you to the ground? How could I show my face to your brother Joab?
2:23 Still he refused to stop. So Abner struck him in the abdomen with the heel of his spear, and the weapon protruded from his back. He fell there and died on the spot. All who came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died, halted.
2:24 But Joab and Abishai continued the pursuit of Abner. The sun had gone down when they came to the hill of Ammah which lies east of the valley toward the wilderness near Geba.
2:25 Here the Benjaminites rallied around Abner, forming a single group, and made a stand on a hilltop.
2:26 Then Abner called to Joab and said: Must the sword devour forever? Do you not know that afterward there will be bitterness? How long before you tell the people to stop pursuing their brothers?
2:27 Joab replied, As God lives, if you had not spoken, it would be morning before the people would be stopped from pursuing their brothers.
2:28 Joab then sounded the horn, and all the people came to a halt, pursuing Israel no farther and fighting no more.
2:29 Abner and his men marched all night long through the Arabah, crossed the Jordan, marched all through the morning, and came to Mahanaim.
2:30 Joab, coming from the pursuit of Abner, assembled all the men. Nineteen other servants of David were missing, besides Asahel.
2:31 But Davids servants had struck down and killed three hundred and sixty men of Benjamin, followers of Abner.
2:32 They took up Asahel and buried him in his fathers tomb in Bethlehem. Joab and his men made an all-night march, and dawn found them in Hebron.
3:1 There followed a long war between the house of Saul and the house of David, in which David grew ever stronger, but the house of Saul ever weaker.
3:2 Sons were born to David in Hebron: his firstborn, Amnon, of Ahinoam from Jezreel;
3:3 the second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal of Carmel; the third, Absalom, son of Maacah, who was the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur;
3:4 the fourth, Adonijah, son of Haggith; the fifth, Shephatiah, son of Abital;
3:5 and the sixth, Ithream, by Davids wife Eglah. These were born to David in Hebron.
3:6 During the war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner was gaining power in the house of Saul.
3:7 Now Saul had had a concubine, Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah. And Ishbaal, son of Saul, said to Abner, Why have you slept with my fathers concubine?
3:8 Enraged at the words of Ishbaal, Abner said, Am I a dogs head from Judah? As of today, I have been loyal to the house of Saul your father, to his brothers and his friends, and I have kept you out of Davids clutches; and today you charge me with a crime involving a woman!
3:9 May God do thus to Abner, and more, if I do not carry out for David what the swore to him—
3:10 that is, take away the kingdom from the house of Saul and establish the throne of David over Israel as well as Judah, from Dan to Beer-sheba.
3:11 Ishbaal was no longer able to say a word to Abner, he feared him so.
3:12 Then Abner sent messengers to David in Telam, where he was at the moment, to say, Make a covenant with me, and you have me on your side, to bring all Israel over to you.
3:13 He replied, Good, I will make a covenant with you. But one thing I require of you. You must not appear before me unless you bring back Michal, Sauls daughter, when you come to present yourself to me.
3:14 At the same time David sent messengers to Ishbaal, son of Saul, to say, Give me my wife Michal, whom I betrothed by paying a hundred Philistine foreskins.
3:15 Ishbaal sent for her and took her away from her husband Paltiel, son of Laish,
3:16 who followed her weeping as far as Bahurim. But Abner said to him, Go back! So he turned back.
3:17 Abner then had a word with the elders of Israel: For some time you have been wanting David as your king.
3:18 Now take action, for the has said of David: By David my servant I will save my people Israel from the power of the Philistines and from the power of all their enemies.
3:19 Abner also spoke with Benjamin, and then went to speak with David in Hebron concerning all that would be agreeable to Israel and to the whole house of Benjamin.
3:20 When Abner, accompanied by twenty men, came to David in Hebron, David prepared a feast for Abner and for the men who were with him.
3:21 Then Abner said to David, I will now go to assemble all Israel for my lord the king, that they may make a covenant with you; you will then be king over all whom you wish to rule. So David let Abner go on his way in peace.
3:22 Just then Davids servants and Joab were coming in from an expedition, bringing much plunder with them. Abner, having been dismissed by David, was no longer with him in Hebron but had gone on his way in peace.
3:23 When Joab and the whole force he had with him arrived, he was informed, Abner, son of Ner, came to David, and he let him go on his way in peace.
3:24 So Joab went to the king and said: What have you done? Abner came to you! Why did you let him get away?
3:25 Dont you know Abner? He came to trick you, to learn your comings and goings, to learn everything you do.
3:26 Joab then left David and sent messengers after Abner to bring him back from the cistern of Sirah; but David did not know.
3:27 When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside within the city gate to speak with him privately. There he stabbed him in the abdomen, and he died for the blood of Asahel, Joabs brother.
3:28 Later David heard of it and said: Before the , I and my kingdom are forever innocent.
3:29 May the blood of Abner, son of Ner, be on the head of Joab and all his family. May Joabs family never be without one suffering from a discharge, or one with a skin disease, or a man who holds the distaff, or one falling by the sword, or one in need of food!
3:30 Joab and Abishai his brother had been lying in wait for Abner because he killed Asahel their brother in battle at Gibeon.
3:31 Then David said to Joab and to all the people who were with him, Tear your garments, put on sackcloth, and mourn over Abner. King David himself followed the bier.
3:32 When they had buried Abner in Hebron, the king wept aloud at the grave of Abner, and all the people wept.
3:33 And the king sang this lament over Abner: Should Abner have died like a fool?
3:34 Your hands were not bound with chains, nor your feet placed in fetters; As one falls before the wicked, you fell. And all the people continued to weep for him.
3:35 Then they went to console David with food while it was still day. But David swore, May God do thus to me, and more, if before the sun goes down I eat bread or anything else.
3:36 All the people noted this with approval, just as everything the king did met with their approval.
3:37 So on that day all the people and all Israel came to know that it was not the kings doing that Abner, son of Ner, was put to death.
3:38 The king then said to his servants: Do you not know that a prince, a great man, has fallen today in Israel.
3:39 Although I am the anointed king, I am weak this day, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too ruthless for me. May the repay the evildoer in accordance with his evil deed.
4:1 When Ishbaal, son of Saul, heard that Abner was dead in Hebron, he lost his resolve and all Israel was alarmed.
4:2 Ishbaal, son of Saul, had two company leaders named Baanah and Rechab, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, of the tribe of Benjamin—Beeroth, too, was ascribed to Benjamin:
4:3 the Beerothites fled to Gittaim, where they have been resident aliens to this day.
4:4 (Jonathan, son of Saul, had a son with crippled feet. He was five years old when the news about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel; his nurse took him and fled, but in their hasty flight, he fell and became lame. His name was Meribbaal.)
4:5 The sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, came into the house of Ishbaal during the heat of the day, while he was lying on his bed in the afternoon.
4:6 The gatekeeper of the house had dozed off while sifting wheat, and was asleep. So Rechab and his brother Baanah slipped past her
4:7 and entered the house while Ishbaal was lying asleep in his bedroom. They struck and killed him, and cut off his head. Then, taking the head, they traveled on the Arabah road all night long.
4:8 They brought the head of Ishbaal to David in Hebron and said to the king: This is the head of Ishbaal, son of your enemy Saul, who sought your life. Thus has the this day avenged my lord the king on Saul and his posterity.
4:9 But David replied to Rechab and his brother Baanah, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite: As the lives, who rescued me from every distress:
4:10 the man who reported to me, Saul is dead, and thought he was bringing good news, that man I seized and killed in Ziglag: that was the reward I gave him.
4:11 How much more now, when wicked men have slain an innocent man in bed at home, must I require his blood from you and purge you from the land!
4:12 So at Davids command, the young men killed them and cut off their hands and feet, hanging them up near the pool in Hebron. But he took the head of Ishbaal and buried it in Abners grave in Hebron.
5:1 All the tribes of Israel came to David in Hebron, and they said: Look! We are your bone and your flesh.
5:2 In days past, when Saul was still our king, you were the one who led Israel out in all its battles and brought it back. And the said to you: You shall shepherd my people Israel; you shall be ruler over Israel.
5:3 Then all the elders of Israel came to the king in Hebron, and at Hebron King David made a covenant with them in the presence of the ; and they anointed David king over Israel.
5:4 David was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned forty years:
5:5 in Hebron he was king over Judah seven years and six months, and in Jerusalem he was king thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah. 
5:6 Then the king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites who inhabited the land. They told David, You shall not enter here: the blind and the lame will drive you away! which was their way of saying, David shall not enter here.
5:7 David nevertheless captured the fortress of Zion, which is the City of David.
5:8 On that day David said: All who wish to strike at the Jebusites must attack through the water shaft. The lame and the blind shall be the personal enemies of David. That is why it is said, The blind and the lame shall not enter the palace.
5:9 David took up residence in the fortress which he called the City of David. David built up the city on all sides, from the Millo toward the center.
5:10 David became ever more powerful, for the of hosts was with him.
5:11 Hiram, king of Tyre, sent envoys to David along with cedar wood, and carpenters and masons, who built a house for David.
5:12 David now knew that the had truly established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
5:13 David took more concubines and wives in Jerusalem after he had come from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to him.
5:14 These are the names of those who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
5:15 Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
5:16 Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphelet.
5:17 When the Philistines had heard that David was anointed king over Israel, they marched out in force to come after him. When David heard this, he went down to the refuge.
5:18 Meanwhile the Philistines had come and deployed themselves in the valley of Rephaim.
5:19 David inquired of the , Shall I attack the Philistines, and will you deliver them into my power? The answered David: Attack, for I will surely deliver the Philistines into your power.
5:20 So David went to Baal-perazim, and he defeated them there. He said, The has broken through my enemies before me just as water breaks through a dam. Therefore that place was called Baal-perazim.
5:21 The Philistines abandoned their gods there, and David and his men carried them away.
5:22 Once again the Philistines came up and deployed themselves in the valley of Rephaim,
5:23 and again David inquired of the , who replied: Do not attack the front—circle behind them and come against them near the balsam trees.
5:24 When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, act decisively, for then the has already gone before you to strike the army of the Philistines.
5:25 David did as the commanded him, and routed the Philistines from Gibeon as far as Gezer.
6:1 David again assembled all the picked men of Israel, thirty thousand in number.
6:2 Then David and all the people who were with him set out for Baala of Judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which bears the name the of hosts enthroned above the cherubim.
6:3 They transported the ark of God on a new cart and took it away from the house of Abinadab on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, sons of Abinadab, were guiding the cart,
6:4 with Ahio walking before it,
6:5 while David and all the house of Israel danced before the with all their might, with singing, and with lyres, harps, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
6:6 As they reached the threshing floor of Nodan, Uzzah stretched out his hand to the ark of God and steadied it, for the oxen were tipping it.
6:7 Then the became angry with Uzzah; God struck him on that spot, and he died there in Gods presence.
6:8 David was angry because the s wrath had broken out against Uzzah. Therefore that place has been called Perez-uzzah even to this day.
6:9 David became frightened of the that day, and he said, How can the ark of the come to me?
6:10 So David was unwilling to take the ark of the with him into the City of David. David deposited it instead at the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
6:11 The ark of the remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months, and the blessed Obed-edom and all his household.
6:12 When it was reported to King David that the had blessed the household of Obed-edom and all that he possessed because of the ark of God, David went to bring up the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom into the City of David with joy.
6:13 As soon as the bearers of the ark of the had advanced six steps, he sacrificed an ox and a fatling.
6:14 Then David came dancing before the with abandon, girt with a linen ephod.
6:15 David and all the house of Israel were bringing up the ark of the with shouts of joy and sound of horn.
6:16 As the ark of the was entering the City of David, Michal, daughter of Saul, looked down from her window, and when she saw King David jumping and dancing before the , she despised him in her heart.
6:17 They brought in the ark of the and set it in its place within the tent which David had pitched for it. Then David sacrificed burnt offerings and communion offerings before the .
6:18 When David had finished sacrificing burnt offerings and communion offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the of hosts,
6:19 and distributed among all the people, the entire multitude of Israel, to every man and every woman, one loaf of bread, one piece of meat, and one raisin cake. Then all the people returned to their homes.
6:20 When David went home to bless his own house, Michal, the daughter of Saul, came out to meet him and said, How well the king of Israel has honored himself today, exposing himself to the view of the slave girls of his followers, as a commoner might expose himself!
6:21 But David replied to Michal: I was dancing before the . As the lives, who chose me over your father and all his house when he appointed me ruler over the s people, Israel, not only will I make merry before the ,
6:22 but I will demean myself even more. I will be lowly in your eyes, but in the eyes of the slave girls you spoke of I will be somebody.
6:23 Sauls daughter Michal was childless to the day she died.
7:1 After the king had taken up residence in his house, and the had given him rest from his enemies on every side,
7:2 the king said to Nathan the prophet, Here I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells in a tent!
7:3 Nathan answered the king, Whatever is in your heart, go and do, for the is with you.
7:4 But that same night the word of the came to Nathan:
7:5 Go and tell David my servant, Thus says the : Is it you who would build me a house to dwell in?
7:6 I have never dwelt in a house from the day I brought Israel up from Egypt to this day, but I have been going about in a tent or a tabernacle.
7:7 As long as I have wandered about among the Israelites, did I ever say a word to any of the judges whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel: Why have you not built me a house of cedar?
7:8 Now then, speak thus to my servant David, Thus says the of hosts: I took you from the pasture, from following the flock, to become ruler over my people Israel.
7:9 I was with you wherever you went, and I cut down all your enemies before you. And I will make your name like that of the greatest on earth.
7:10 I will assign a place for my people Israel and I will plant them in it to dwell there; they will never again be disturbed, nor shall the wicked ever again oppress them, as they did at the beginning,
7:11 and from the day when I appointed judges over my people Israel. I will give you rest from all your enemies. Moreover, the also declares to you that the will make a house for you:
7:12 when your days have been completed and you rest with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring after you, sprung from your loins, and I will establish his kingdom.
7:13 He it is who shall build a house for my name, and I will establish his royal throne forever.
7:14 I will be a father to him, and he shall be a son to me. If he does wrong, I will reprove him with a human rod and with human punishments;
7:15 but I will not withdraw my favor from him as I withdrew it from Saul who was before you.
7:16 Your house and your kingdom are firm forever before me; your throne shall be firmly established forever.
7:17 In accordance with all these words and this whole vision Nathan spoke to David.
7:18 Then King David went in and sat in the s presence and said, Who am I, Lord , and what is my house, that you should have brought me so far?
7:19 And yet even this is too little in your sight, Lord ! For you have made a promise regarding your servants house reaching into the future, and giving guidance to the people, Lord !
7:20 What more can David say to you? You know your servant, Lord !
7:21 For your servants sake and as you have had at heart, you have brought about this whole magnificent disclosure to your servant.
7:22 Therefore, great are you, Lord ! There is no one like you, no God but you, as we have always heard.
7:23 What other nation on earth is there like your people Israel? What god has ever led a nation, redeeming it as his people and making a name by great and awesome deeds, as you drove out the nations and their gods before your people, whom you redeemed for yourself from Egypt?
7:24 You have established for yourself your people Israel as your people forever, and you, , have become their God.
7:25 Now, God, confirm the promise that you have spoken concerning your servant and his house forever. Bring about what you have promised
7:26 so that your name may be forever great. People will say: The of hosts is God over Israel, when the house of your servant David is established in your presence.
7:27 Because you, of hosts, God of Israel, have revealed to your servant, I will build you a house, your servant now finds the courage to make this prayer before you.
7:28 Since you, Lord , are truly God and your words are truth and you have made this generous promise to your servant,
7:29 do, then, bless the house of your servant, that it may be in your presence forever—since you, Lord , have promised, and by your blessing the house of your servant shall be blessed forever.
8:1 After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them; and David took from the Philistines.
8:2 He also defeated Moab and measured them with a line. Making them lie down on the ground, he measured two lengths of line for death, and a full length for life. Thus the Moabites became subject to David, paying tribute.
8:3 David then defeated Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to re-establish his dominion at the River.
8:4 David captured from him one thousand seven hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David hamstrung all the chariot horses, but left one hundred for his chariots.
8:5 The Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer, king of Zobah, but David also defeated twenty-two thousand of them in Aram.
8:6 David then placed garrisons in the Damascus region of Aram, and the Arameans became Davids subjects, paying tribute. The brought David victory in all his undertakings.
8:7 David took the golden shields that were carried by Hadadezers attendants and brought them to Jerusalem. (These Shishak, king of Egypt, took away when he came to Jerusalem in the days of Rehoboam, son of Solomon.)
8:8 From Tebah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David removed a very large quantity of bronze.
8:9 When Toi, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
8:10 Toi sent his son Hadoram to wish King David well and to congratulate him on having waged a victorious war against Hadadezer; for Hadadezer had been at war with Toi. Hadoram also brought with him articles of silver, gold, and bronze.
8:11 These also King David consecrated to the along with the silver and gold that he had taken for this purpose from all the nations he had subdued:
8:12 from Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek, and from the spoils of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
8:13 On his return, David made a name for himself by defeating eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
8:14 He set up garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became Davids subjects. Thus the brought David victory in all his undertakings.
8:15 David was king over all Israel; he dispensed justice and right to all his people.
8:16 Joab, son of Zeruiah, was in command of the army. Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was chancellor.
8:17 Zadok, son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, were priests. Shavsha was scribe.
8:18 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and the Pelethites; and Davids sons were priests.
9:1 David asked, Is there any survivor of Sauls house to whom I may show kindness for the sake of Jonathan?
9:2 Now there was an official of the house of Saul named Ziba. He was summoned to David, and the king asked him, Are you Ziba? He replied, Your servant.
9:3 Then the king asked, Is there any survivor of Sauls house to whom I may show Gods kindness? Ziba answered the king, There is still Jonathans son, the one whose feet are crippled.
9:4 The king asked him, Where is he? and Ziba answered the king, He is in the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar.
9:5 So King David sent for him and had him brought from the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, from Lodebar.
9:6 When Meribbaal, son of Jonathan, son of Saul, came to David, he fell face down in homage. David said, Meribbaal, and he answered, Your servant.
9:7 Do not be afraid, David said to him, I will surely be kind to you for the sake of Jonathan your father. I will restore to you all the lands of Saul your grandfather, and you shall eat at my table always.
9:8 Bowing low, he answered, What am I, your servant, that you should pay attention to a dead dog like me?
9:9 The king then called Ziba, Sauls attendant, and said to him: All that belonged to Saul and to his entire house, I am giving to your lords son.
9:10 You and your sons and servants must till the land for him. You shall bring in the produce, which shall be food for your lords household to eat. But Meribbaal, your lords son, shall always eat at my table. Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
9:11 Ziba answered the king, Whatever my lord the king commands his servant, so shall your servant do. And so Meribbaal ate at Davids table like one of the kings sons.
9:12 Meribbaal had a young son whose name was Mica; and all the tenants of Zibas household worked for Meribbaal.
9:13 But Meribbaal lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the kings table. He was lame in both feet.
10:1 After this, the king of the Ammonites died, and Hanun his son succeeded him as king.
10:2 David said, I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, as his father showed kindness to me. Therefore David sent his servants to Hanun to console him concerning his father. But when Davids servants had entered the land of the Ammonites,
10:3 the Ammonite princes said to their lord Hanun, Do you think David is doing this—sending you these consolers—to honor your father? Is it not rather to explore the city, to spy on it, and to overthrow it, that David has sent his servants to you?
10:4 So Hanun seized Davids servants, shaved off half their beards, cut away the lower halves of their garments at the buttocks, and sent them away.
10:5 David was told of it and he sent word for them to be intercepted, for the men had been greatly disgraced. Remain at Jericho, the king told them, until your beards have grown again; then come back here.
10:6 When the Ammonites realized that they were in bad odor with David, they sent for and hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth-rehob and Zobah, as well as the king of Maacah with one thousand men, and twelve thousand men from Tob.
10:7 When David heard of this, he sent Joab and his whole army of warriors against them.
10:8 The Ammonites marched out and lined up for battle at the entrance of their city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah remained apart in the open field.
10:9 When Joab saw that there was a battle line both in front of and behind him, he chose some of the best fighters of Israel and lined them up against the Arameans;
10:10 the rest of the army he placed under the command of his brother Abishai and lined up to oppose the Ammonites.
10:11 And he said, If the Arameans prove too strong for me, you must come and save me; and if the Ammonites prove too strong for you, I will come to save you.
10:12 Hold firm and let us show ourselves courageous for the sake of our people and the cities of our God; and may the do what is good in his sight.
10:13 Joab therefore advanced with his men for battle with the Arameans, but they fled before him.
10:14 And when the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they too fled before Abishai, and reentered their city. Joab then ceased his attack on the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
10:15 Seeing themselves vanquished by Israel, the Arameans held a full muster of troops.
10:16 Hadadezer sent for and brought Arameans from beyond the River. They came to Helam, with Shobach, the captain of Hadadezers army, at their head.
10:17 When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel together, crossed the Jordan, and went to Helam. The Arameans drew up in formation against David and gave battle.
10:18 But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred of their chariot fighters and forty thousand of their foot soldiers. He struck down Shobach, commander of the army, and he died on the field.
10:19 When Hadadezers vassal kings saw themselves vanquished by Israel, they made peace with the Israelites and became their subjects. After this, the Arameans were afraid to give further aid to the Ammonites.
11:1 At the turn of the year, the time when kings go to war, David sent out Joab along with his officers and all Israel, and they laid waste the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. David himself remained in Jerusalem.
11:2 One evening David rose from his bed and strolled about on the roof of the kings house. From the roof he saw a woman bathing; she was very beautiful.
11:3 David sent people to inquire about the woman and was told, She is Bathsheba, daughter of Eliam, and wife of Uriah the Hittite, Joabs armor-bearer.
11:4 Then David sent messengers and took her. When she came to him, he took her to bed, at a time when she was just purified after her period; and she returned to her house.
11:5 But the woman had become pregnant; she sent a message to inform David, I am pregnant.
11:6 So David sent a message to Joab, Send me Uriah the Hittite. Joab sent Uriah to David.
11:7 And when he came, David asked him how Joab was, how the army was, and how the war was going, and Uriah answered that all was well.
11:8 David then said to Uriah, Go down to your house and bathe your feet. Uriah left the kings house, and a portion from the kings table was sent after him.
11:9 But Uriah slept at the entrance of the kings house with the other officers of his lord, and did not go down to his own house.
11:10 David was told, Uriah has not gone down to his house. So he said to Uriah, Have you not come from a journey? Why, then, did you not go down to your house?
11:11 Uriah answered David, The ark and Israel and Judah are staying in tents, and my lord Joab and my lords servants are encamped in the open field. Can I go home to eat and to drink and to sleep with my wife? As the lives and as you live, I will do no such thing.
11:12 Then David said to Uriah, Stay here today also, and tomorrow I will send you back. So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day. On the following day,
11:13 David summoned him, and he ate and drank with David, who got him drunk. But in the evening he went out to sleep on his bed among his lords servants, and did not go down to his house.
11:14 The next morning David wrote a letter to Joab which he sent by Uriah.
11:15 This is what he wrote in the letter: Place Uriah up front, where the fighting is fierce. Then pull back and leave him to be struck down dead.
11:16 So while Joab was besieging the city, he assigned Uriah to a place where he knew the defenders were strong.
11:17 When the men of the city made a sortie against Joab, some officers of Davids army fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.
11:18 Then Joab sent David a report of all the details of the battle,
11:19 instructing the messenger, When you have finished giving the king all the details of the battle,
11:20 the king may become angry and say to you: Why did you go near the city to fight? Did you not know that they would shoot from the wall above?
11:21 Who killed Abimelech, son of Jerubbaal? Was it not a woman who threw a millstone down on him from the wall above, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you go near the wall? Then you in turn are to say, Your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.
11:22 The messenger set out, and on his arrival he reported to David everything Joab had sent him to tell.
11:23 He told David: The men had the advantage over us and came out into the open against us, but we pushed them back to the entrance of the city gate.
11:24 Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall above, and some of the kings servants died; and your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.
11:25 David said to the messenger: This is what you shall say to Joab: Do not let this be a great evil in your sight, for the sword devours now here and now there. Strengthen your attack on the city and destroy it. Encourage him.
11:26 When the wife of Uriah heard that her husband had died, she mourned her lord.
11:27 But once the mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her into his house. She became his wife and bore him a son. But in the sight of the what David had done was evil.
12:1 The sent Nathan to David, and when he came to him, he said: Tell me how you judge this case: In a certain town there were two men, one rich, the other poor.
12:2 The rich man had flocks and herds in great numbers.
12:3 But the poor man had nothing at all except one little ewe lamb that he had bought. He nourished her, and she grew up with him and his children. Of what little he had she ate; from his own cup she drank; in his bosom she slept; she was like a daughter to him.
12:4 Now, a visitor came to the rich man, but he spared his own flocks and herds to prepare a meal for the traveler who had come to him: he took the poor mans ewe lamb and prepared it for the one who had come to him.
12:5 David grew very angry with that man and said to Nathan: As the lives, the man who has done this deserves death!
12:6 He shall make fourfold restitution for the lamb because he has done this and was unsparing.
12:7 Then Nathan said to David: You are the man! Thus says the God of Israel: I anointed you king over Israel. I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
12:8 I gave you your lords house and your lords wives for your own. I gave you the house of Israel and of Judah. And if this were not enough, I could count up for you still more.
12:9 Why have you despised the and done what is evil in his sight? You have cut down Uriah the Hittite with the sword; his wife you took as your own, and him you killed with the sword of the Ammonites.
12:10 Now, therefore, the sword shall never depart from your house, because you have despised me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
12:11 Thus says the : I will bring evil upon you out of your own house. I will take your wives before your very eyes, and will give them to your neighbor: he shall lie with your wives in broad daylight.
12:12 You have acted in secret, but I will do this in the presence of all Israel, in the presence of the sun itself.
12:13 Then David said to Nathan, I have sinned against the . Nathan answered David: For his part, the has removed your sin. You shall not die,
12:14 but since you have utterly spurned the by this deed, the child born to you will surely die.
12:15 Then Nathan returned to his house. The struck the child that the wife of Uriah had borne to David, and it became desperately ill.
12:16 David pleaded with God on behalf of the child. He kept a total fast, and spent the night lying on the ground clothed in sackcloth.
12:17 The elders of his house stood beside him to get him to rise from the ground; but he would not, nor would he take food with them.
12:18 On the seventh day, the child died. Davids servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said: When the child was alive, we spoke to him, but he would not listen to what we said. How can we tell him the child is dead? He may do some harm!
12:19 But David noticed his servants whispering among themselves and realized that the child was dead. He asked his servants, Is the child dead? They said, Yes.
12:20 Rising from the ground, David washed and anointed himself, and changed his clothes. Then he went to the house of the and worshiped. He returned to his own house and asked for food; they set it before him, and he ate.
12:21 His servants said to him: What is this you are doing? While the child was living, you fasted and wept and kept vigil; now that the child is dead, you rise and take food.
12:22 He replied: While the child was living, I fasted and wept, thinking, Who knows? The may grant me the childs life.
12:23 But now he is dead. Why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he will not return to me.
12:24 Then David consoled Bathsheba his wife. He went and slept with her; and she conceived and bore him a son, who was named Solomon. The loved him
12:25 and sent the prophet Nathan to name him Jedidiah, on behalf of the .
12:26 Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured that royal city.
12:27 He sent messengers to David to say: I have fought against Rabbah and have taken the water-city.
12:28 Therefore, assemble the rest of the soldiers, join the siege against the city, and capture it, lest I be the one to capture the city and mine be the name people mention, not yours.
12:29 So David assembled the rest of the soldiers, went to Rabbah, fought against it, and captured it.
12:30 He took the crown of Milcom from the idols head, a talent of gold in weight, with precious stones; this crown David wore on his own head. He also brought out a great amount of spoil from the city.
12:31 He deported the people of the city and set them to work with saws, iron picks, and iron axes, or put them to work at the brickmold. He dealt thus with all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and his whole army returned to Jerusalem.
13:1 After this, the following occurred. Davids son Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar, and Davids son Amnon loved her.
13:2 He was in such anguish over his sister Tamar that he became sick; she was a virgin, and Amnon thought it impossible to do anything to her.
13:3 Now Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, son of Davids brother Shimeah, who was very clever.
13:4 He asked him, Prince, why are you so dejected morning after morning? Why not tell me? So Amnon said to him, I am in love with Tamar, my brother Absaloms sister.
13:5 Then Jonadab replied, Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. When your father comes to visit you, say to him, Please let my sister Tamar come and encourage me to take food. If she prepares something in my presence, for me to see, I will eat it from her hand.
13:6 So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. When the king came to visit him, Amnon said to the king, Please let my sister Tamar come and prepare some fried cakes before my eyes, that I may take food from her hand.
13:7 David then sent home a message to Tamar, Please go to the house of your brother Amnon and prepare some food for him.
13:8 Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was in bed. Taking dough and kneading it, she twisted it into cakes before his eyes and fried the cakes.
13:9 Then she took the pan and set out the cakes before him. But Amnon would not eat; he said, Have everyone leave me. When they had all left him,
13:10 Amnon said to Tamar, Bring the food into the bedroom, that I may have it from your hand. So Tamar picked up the cakes she had prepared and brought them to her brother Amnon in the bedroom.
13:11 But when she brought them close to him so he could eat, he seized her and said to her, Come! Lie with me, my sister!
13:12 But she answered him, No, my brother! Do not force me! This is not done in Israel. Do not commit this terrible crime.
13:13 Where would I take my shame? And you would be labeled a fool in Israel. So please, speak to the king; he will not keep me from you.
13:14 But he would not listen to her; he was too strong for her: he forced her down and raped her.
13:15 Then Amnon felt intense hatred for her; the hatred he felt for her far surpassed the love he had had for her. Amnon said to her, Get up, leave.
13:16 She replied, No, brother, because sending me away would be far worse than this evil thing you have done to me. He would not listen to her,
13:17 but called the youth who was his attendant and said, Send this girl outside, away from me, and bar the door after her.
13:18 Now she had on a long tunic, for that is how virgin princesses dressed in olden days. When his attendant put her out and barred the door after her,
13:19 Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long tunic in which she was clothed. Then, putting her hands to her head, she went away crying loudly.
13:20 Her brother Absalom said to her: Has your brother Amnon been with you? Keep still now, my sister; he is your brother. Do not take this so to heart. So Tamar remained, devastated, in the house of her brother Absalom.
13:21 King David, when he heard of the whole affair, became very angry. He would not, however, antagonize Amnon, his high-spirited son; he loved him, because he was his firstborn.
13:22 And Absalom said nothing, good or bad, to Amnon; but Absalom hated Amnon for having humiliated his sister Tamar.
13:23 Two years went by. It was sheep-shearing time for Absalom in Baal-hazor near Ephraim, and Absalom invited all the kings sons.
13:24 Absalom went to the king and said: Your servant has hired the shearers. Please, may the king come with all his servants to your servant.
13:25 But the king said to Absalom, No, my son, all of us should not go lest we be a burden to you. And though Absalom urged him, he would not go but began to bid him good-bye.
13:26 Absalom then said, If not you, then please let my brother Amnon come with us. The king asked him, Why should he go with you?
13:27 But at Absaloms urging, the king sent Amnon and with him all his other sons. Absalom prepared a banquet fit for a king.
13:28 But Absalom had instructed his attendants: Now watch! When Amnon is merry with wine and I say to you, Kill Amnon, put him to death. Do not be afraid, for it is I who order you to do it. Be strong and act like warriors.
13:29 When the attendants did to Amnon as Absalom had commanded, all the kings other sons rose up, mounted their mules, and fled.
13:30 While they were still on the road, a report reached David: Absalom has killed all the kings sons and not one of them is left.
13:31 The king stood up, tore his garments, and lay on the ground. All his servants standing by him also tore their garments.
13:32 But Jonadab, son of Davids brother Shimeah, spoke up: Let not my lord think that all the young men, the kings sons, have been killed! Amnon alone is dead, for Absalom was set on this ever since Amnon humiliated his sister Tamar.
13:33 Now let my lord the king not take so to heart that report, All the kings sons are dead. Amnon alone is dead.
13:34 Meanwhile, Absalom had taken flight. Then the servant on watch looked out and saw a large group coming down the slope from the direction of Bahurim. He came in and reported this to the king: I saw some men coming down the mountainside from the direction of Bahurim.
13:35 So Jonadab said to the king: There! The kings sons have come. It is as your servant said.
13:36 No sooner had he finished speaking than the kings sons came in, weeping aloud. The king, too, and all his servants wept very bitterly.
13:37 But Absalom, who had taken flight, went to Talmai, son of Ammihud, king of Geshur,
13:38 and stayed in Geshur for three years.
13:39 All that time the king continued to mourn his son; but his intention of going out against Absalom abated as he was consoled over the death of Amnon.
14:1 Now Joab, son of Zeruiah, knew how the king felt toward Absalom.
14:2 Joab sent to Tekoa and brought from there a wise woman, to whom he said: Pretend to be in mourning. Put on mourning apparel and do not anoint yourself with oil, that you may appear to be a woman who has long been mourning someone dead.
14:3 Then go to the king and speak to him in this manner. And Joab told her what to say.
14:4 So the woman of Tekoa went to the king and fell to the ground in homage, saying, Help, O king!
14:5 The king said to her, What do you want? She replied: Alas, I am a widow; my husband is dead.
14:6 Your servant had two sons, who quarreled in the field, with no one to part them, and one of them struck his brother and killed him.
14:7 Then the whole clan confronted your servant and demanded: Give up the one who struck down his brother. We must put him to death for the life of his brother whom he has killed; we must do away with the heir also. Thus they will quench my remaining hope and leave my husband neither name nor posterity upon the earth.
14:8 The king then said to the woman: Go home. I will issue a command on your behalf.
14:9 The woman of Tekoa answered him, Upon me and my family be the blame, my lord king; the king and his throne are innocent.
14:10 Then the king said, If anyone says a word to you, have him brought to me, and he shall not touch you again.
14:11 But she said, Please, let the king remember the your God, that the avenger of blood may not go too far in destruction and that my son may not be done away with. He replied, As the lives, not a hair of your son shall fall to the ground.
14:12 But the woman continued, Please let your servant say still another word to my lord the king. He replied, Speak.
14:13 So the woman said: Why, then, do you think the way you do against the people of God? In pronouncing as he has, the king shows himself guilty, in not bringing back his own banished son.
14:14 We must indeed die; we are then like water that is poured out on the ground and cannot be gathered up. Yet, though God does not bring back to life, he does devise means so as not to banish anyone from him.
14:15 And now, if I have presumed to speak to the king of this matter, it is because the people have given me cause to fear. And so your servant thought: Let me speak to the king. Perhaps he will grant the petition of his servant.
14:16 For the king must surely listen and rescue his servant from the grasp of one who would destroy both me and my son from the heritage of God.
14:17 And your servant says, Let the word of my lord the king lead to rest; indeed, my lord the king is like an angel of God, discerning good and evil. The your God be with you.
14:18 The king answered the woman, Now do not conceal from me anything I may ask you! The woman said, Let my lord the king speak.
14:19 So the king asked, Is the hand of Joab with you in all this? And the woman answered: As you live, my lord the king, it is just as my lord has said, and not otherwise. It was your servant Joab who instructed me and told your servant all these things she was to say.
14:20 Your servant Joab did this in order to approach the matter in a roundabout way. But my lord is wise with the wisdom of an angel of God, knowing all things on earth.
14:21 Then the king said to Joab: I am granting this request. Go and bring back young Absalom.
14:22 Falling to the ground in homage and blessing the king, Joab said, This day your servant knows that I am in good favor with you, my lord king, since the king has granted the request of your servant.
14:23 Joab then went off to Geshur and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
14:24 But the king said, Let him go off to his own house; he shall not appear before me. So Absalom went off to his house and did not appear before the king.
14:25 In all Israel there was no man more praised for his beauty than Absalom, flawless from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
14:26 When he shaved his head—as he used to do at the end of every year, because his hair became too heavy for him—the hair weighed two hundred shekels according to the royal standard.
14:27 Absalom had three sons born to him, besides a daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.
14:28 Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years without appearing before the king.
14:29 Then he sent a message asking Joab to send him to the king, but Joab would not come to him. Although he asked him a second time, Joab would not come.
14:30 He therefore instructed his servants: You see Joabs field that borders mine, where he has barley. Go, set it on fire. And so Absaloms servants set the field on fire. Joabs farmhands came to him with torn garments and told him, Absaloms servants set your field on fire.
14:31 Joab went to Absalom in his house and asked him, Why have your servants set my field on fire?
14:32 Absalom answered Joab: I sent you a message: Come here, that I may send you to the king to say: Why did I come back from Geshur? I would be better off if I were still there! Now, let me appear before the king. If I am guilty, let him put me to death.
14:33 Joab went to the king and reported this. The king then called Absalom; he came to him and in homage fell on his face to the ground before the king. Then the king kissed Absalom.
15:1 After this, Absalom provided himself with chariots, horses, and a retinue of fifty.
15:2 Moreover, Absalom used to rise early and stand alongside the road leading to the gate. If someone had a lawsuit to be decided by the king, Absalom would call to him and say, From what city are you? And when he replied, Your servant is of such and such a tribe of Israel,
15:3 Absalom would say to him, Your case is good and just, but there is no one to hear you in the kings name.
15:4 And he would continue: If only I could be appointed judge in the land! Then everyone who has a lawsuit to be decided might come to me and I would render him justice.
15:5 Whenever a man approached him to show homage, he would extend his hand, hold him, and kiss him.
15:6 By behaving in this way toward all the Israelites who came to the king for judgment, Absalom was stealing the heart of Israel.
15:7 After a period of four years, Absalom said to the king: Please let me go to Hebron and fulfill a vow I made to the .
15:8 For while living in Geshur in Aram, your servant made this vow: If the ever brings me back to Jerusalem, I will worship him in Hebron.
15:9 The king said to him, Go in peace, and he went off to Hebron.
15:10 Then Absalom sent agents throughout the tribes of Israel to say, When you hear the sound of the horn, say, Absalom is king in Hebron!
15:11 Two hundred men had accompanied Absalom from Jerusalem. They had been invited and went in all innocence, knowing nothing.
15:12 Absalom also sent to Ahithophel the Gilonite, Davids counselor, an invitation to come from his town, Giloh, for the sacrifices he was about to offer. So the conspiracy gained strength, and the people with Absalom increased in numbers.
15:13 An informant came to David with the report, The Israelites have given their hearts to Absalom, and they are following him.
15:14 At this, David said to all his servants who were with him in Jerusalem: Get up, let us flee, or none of us will escape from Absalom. Leave at once, or he will quickly overtake us, and then bring disaster upon us, and put the city to the sword.
15:15 The kings servants answered him, Whatever our lord the king chooses to do, we are your servants.
15:16 Then the king set out, accompanied by his entire household, except for ten concubines whom he left behind to care for the palace.
15:17 As the king left the city, with all his officers accompanying him, they halted opposite the ascent of the Mount of Olives, at a distance,
15:18 while the whole army marched past him. As all the Cherethites and Pelethites, and the six hundred Gittites who had entered his service from that city, were passing in review before the king,
15:19 the king said to Ittai the Gittite: Why should you also go with us? Go back and stay with the king, for you are a foreigner and you, too, are an exile from your own country.
15:20 You came only yesterday, and today shall I have you wander off with us wherever I have to go? Return and take your brothers with you, and may the show you kindness and fidelity.
15:21 But Ittai answered the king, As the lives, and as my lord the king lives, your servant shall be wherever my lord the king is, whether for death or for life.
15:22 So the king said to Ittai, Go, then, march on. And Ittai the Gittite, with all his men and all the dependents that were with him, marched on.
15:23 The whole land wept aloud as the last of the soldiers went by, and the king crossed the Wadi Kidron with all the soldiers moving on ahead of him by way of the ascent of the Mount of Olives, toward the wilderness.
15:24 Zadok, too, and all the Levites bearing the ark of the covenant of God set down the ark of God until the whole army had finished marching out of the city; and Abiathar came up.
15:25 Then the king said to Zadok: Take the ark of God back to the city. If I find favor with the , he will bring me back and permit me to see it and its lodging place.
15:26 But if he should say, I am not pleased with you, I am ready; let him do to me as he sees fit.
15:27 The king also said to Zadok the priest: Look, you and Abiathar return to the city in peace, and both your sons with you, your own son Ahimaaz, and Abiathars son Jonathan.
15:28 Remember, I shall be waiting at the fords near the wilderness until a report from you comes to me.
15:29 So Zadok and Abiathar took the ark of God back to Jerusalem and remained there.
15:30 As David went up the ascent of the Mount of Olives, he wept without ceasing. His head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. All those who were with him also had their heads covered and were weeping as they went.
15:31 When David was told, Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom, he said, O , turn the counsel of Ahithophel to folly!
15:32 When David reached the top, where God was worshiped, Hushai the Archite was there to meet him, with garments torn and dirt upon his head.
15:33 David said to him: If you come with me, you will be a burden to me;
15:34 but if you return to the city and say to Absalom, Let me be your servant, O king; I was formerly your fathers servant, but now I will be yours, you will thwart for me the counsel of Ahithophel.
15:35 You will have the priests Zadok and Abiathar there with you. If you hear anything from the kings house, you shall report it to the priests Zadok and Abiathar,
15:36 who have there with them their two sons, Zadoks son Ahimaaz and Abiathars son Jonathan. Through them you shall send on to me whatever you hear.
15:37 So Davids friend Hushai went into the city, Jerusalem, as Absalom was about to enter it.
16:1 David went a little beyond the top and Ziba, the servant of Meribbaal, was there to meet him with saddled donkeys laden with two hundred loaves of bread, an ephah of cakes of pressed raisins, an ephah of summer fruits, and a skin of wine.
16:2 The king said to Ziba, What are you doing with all this? Ziba replied: The donkeys are for the kings household to ride on. The bread and summer fruits are for your servants to eat, and the wine to drink when they grow weary in the wilderness.
16:3 Then the king said, And where is your lords son? Ziba answered the king, He is staying in Jerusalem, for he said, Today the house of Israel will restore to me my fathers kingdom.
16:4 The king therefore said to Ziba, So! Everything Meribbaal had is yours. Then Ziba said: I pay you homage, my lord the king. May I find favor with you!
16:5 As King David was approaching Bahurim, there was a man coming out; he was of the same clan as the house of Saul, and his name was Shimei, son of Gera. He kept cursing as he came out,
16:6 and throwing stones at David and at all King Davids officers, even though all the soldiers, including the royal guard, were on Davids right and on his left.
16:7 Shimei was saying as he cursed: Get out! Get out! You man of blood, you scoundrel!
16:8 The has paid you back for all the blood shed from the family of Saul, whom you replaced as king, and the has handed over the kingdom to your son Absalom. And now look at you: you suffer ruin because you are a man of blood.
16:9 Abishai, son of Zeruiah, said to the king: Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and take off his head.
16:10 But the king replied: What business is it of mine or of yours, sons of Zeruiah, that he curses? Suppose the has told him to curse David; who then will dare to say, Why are you doing this?
16:11 Then David said to Abishai and to all his servants: If my own son, who came forth from my loins, is seeking my life, how much more might this Benjaminite do so! Let him alone and let him curse, for the has told him to.
16:12 Perhaps the will look upon my affliction and repay me with good for the curses he is uttering this day.
16:13 David and his men continued on the road, while Shimei kept up with them on the hillside, all the while cursing and throwing stones and dirt as he went.
16:14 The king and all the soldiers with him arrived at the Jordan tired out, and stopped there to rest.
16:15 In the meantime Absalom, with all the Israelites, entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
16:16 When Davids friend Hushai the Archite came to Absalom, he said to him: Long live the king! Long live the king!
16:17 But Absalom asked Hushai: Is this your devotion to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?
16:18 Hushai replied to Absalom: On the contrary, I am his whom the and all this people and all Israel have chosen, and with him I will stay.
16:19 Furthermore, as I was in attendance upon your father, so will I be before you. Whom should I serve, if not his son?
16:20 Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, Offer your counsel on what we should do.
