16:21 Ahithophel replied to Absalom: Go to your fathers concubines, whom he left behind to take care of the palace. When all Israel hears how odious you have made yourself to your father, all those on your side will take courage.
16:22 So a tent was pitched on the roof for Absalom, and Absalom went to his fathers concubines in view of all Israel.
16:23 Now the counsel given by Ahithophel at that time was as though one sought the word of God. Such was all the counsel of Ahithophel both to David and to Absalom.
17:1 Ahithophel went on to say to Absalom: Let me choose twelve thousand men and be off in pursuit of David tonight.
17:2 If I come upon him when he is weary and discouraged, I shall cause him panic, and all the people with him will flee, and I shall strike down the king alone.
17:3 Then I can bring back the rest of the people to you, as a bride returns to her husband. It is the death of only one man you are seeking; then all the people will be at peace.
17:4 This plan sounded good to Absalom and to all the elders of Israel.
17:5 Then Absalom said, Now call Hushai the Archite also; let us hear what he too has to say.
17:6 When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him: This is Ahithophels plan. Shall we follow his plan? If not, give your own.
17:7 Hushai replied to Absalom, This time Ahithophel has not given good counsel.
17:8 And he went on to say: You know that your father and his men are warriors, and that they are as fierce as a bear in the wild robbed of her cubs. Moreover, since your father is a skilled fighter, he will not spend the night with the army.
17:9 Even now he lies hidden in one of the caves or in one of his other places. And if some of our soldiers should fall at the first attack, whoever hears of it will say, Absaloms followers have been slaughtered.
17:10 Then even the brave man with the heart of a lion—his heart will melt. For all Israel knows that your father is a fighter and those who are with him are brave.
17:11 This is what I counsel: Let all Israel be assembled, from Dan to Beer-sheba, as numerous as the sands by the sea, and you yourself go with them.
17:12 We can then attack him wherever we find him, settling down upon him as dew alights on the ground. None shall survive—neither he nor any of his followers.
17:13 And if he retires into a city, all Israel shall bring ropes to that city and we can drag it into the gorge, so that not even a pebble of it can be found.
17:14 Then Absalom and all the Israelites said, The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel. For the had commanded that Ahithophels good counsel should be thwarted, so that he might bring Absalom to ruin.
17:15 Then Hushai said to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: This is the counsel Ahithophel gave Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is what I counseled.
17:16 So send a warning to David immediately: Do not spend the night at the fords near the wilderness, but cross over without fail. Otherwise the king and all the people with him will be destroyed.
17:17 Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En-rogel. A maidservant was to come with information for them, and they in turn were to go and report to King David. They could not risk being seen entering the city,
17:18 but an attendant did see them and informed Absalom. They hurried on their way and reached the house of a man in Bahurim who had a cistern in his courtyard. They let themselves down into it,
17:19 and the woman took the cover and spread it over the mouth of the cistern, strewing crushed grain on the cover so that nothing could be noticed.
17:20 When Absaloms servants came to the woman at the house, they asked, Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan? The woman replied, They went by a short while ago toward the water. They searched, but found no one, and so returned to Jerusalem.
17:21 As soon as they left, Ahimaaz and Jonathan came up out of the cistern and went on to report to King David. They said to him: Leave! Cross the water at once, for Ahithophel has given such and such counsel in regard to you.
17:22 So David and all his people moved on and crossed the Jordan. By daybreak, there was no one left who had not crossed.
17:23 When Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not acted upon, he saddled his donkey and departed, going to his home in his own city. Then, having left orders concerning his household, he hanged himself. And so he died and was buried in his fathers tomb.
17:24 Now David had arrived at Mahanaim while Absalom crossed the Jordan accompanied by all the Israelites.
17:25 Absalom had put Amasa in command of the army in Joabs place. Amasa was the son of an Ishmaelite named Ithra, who had married Abigail, daughter of Jesse and sister of Joabs mother Zeruiah.
17:26 Israel and Absalom encamped in the land of Gilead.
17:27 When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi, son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Machir, son of Ammiel from Lodebar, and Barzillai, the Gileadite from Rogelim,
17:28 brought beds and covers, basins and pottery, as well as wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
17:29 honey, and butter and cheese from the flocks and herds, for David and those who were with him to eat; for they said, The people will be hungry and tired and thirsty in the wilderness.
18:1 After mustering the troops he had with him, David placed officers in command of units of a thousand and units of a hundred.
18:2 David then divided the troops three ways, a third under Joab, a third under Abishai, son of Zeruiah and brother of Joab, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. The king said to the troops, I intend to go out with you myself.
18:3 But they replied: You must not come out with us. For if we flee, no one will care; even if half of us die, no one will care. But you are worth ten thousand of us. Therefore it is better that we have you to help us from the city.
18:4 The king said to them, I will do what you think best. So the king stood by the gate as all the soldiers marched out in units of a hundred and a thousand.
18:5 But the king gave this command to Joab, Abishai, and Ittai: Be gentle with young Absalom for my sake. All the soldiers heard as the king gave commands to the various leaders with regard to Absalom.
18:6 Davids army then took the field against Israel, and a battle was fought in the forest near Mahanaim.
18:7 The forces of Israel were defeated by Davids servants, and the casualties there that day were heavy—twenty thousand men.
18:8 The battle spread out over that entire region, and the forest consumed more combatants that day than did the sword.
18:9 Absalom unexpectedly came up against Davids servants. He was mounted on a mule, and, as the mule passed under the branches of a large oak tree, his hair caught fast in the tree. He hung between heaven and earth while the mule under him kept going.
18:10 Someone saw this and reported to Joab, I saw Absalom hanging from an oak tree.
18:11 Joab said to the man who told him this: If you saw him, why did you not strike him to the ground on the spot? Then it would have been my duty to give you fifty pieces of silver and a belt.
18:12 But the man replied to Joab: Even if I already held a thousand pieces of silver in my two hands, I would not lay a hand on the kings son, for in our hearing the king gave you and Abishai and Ittai a command: Protect the youth Absalom for my sake.
18:13 Had I been disloyal and killed him, it would all have come out before the king, and you would stand aloof.
18:14 Joab replied, I will not waste time with you in this way. And taking three pikes in hand, he thrust for the heart of Absalom. He was still alive in the tree.
18:15 When ten of Joabs young armor-bearers closed in on Absalom, and killed him with further blows,
18:16 Joab then sounded the horn, and the soldiers turned back from the pursuit of the Israelites, because Joab called them to halt.
18:17 They took Absalom and cast him into a deep pit in the forest, and built up a very large mound of stones over him. And all the Israelites fled to their own tents.
18:18 During his lifetime Absalom had taken a pillar and set it up for himself in the Kings Valley, for he said, I have no son to perpetuate my name. The pillar which he named for himself is called Absaloms Monument to the present day.
18:19 Then Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, said, Let me run to take the good news to the king that the has set him free from the power of his enemies.
18:20 But Joab said to him: You are not the man to bring the news today. On some other day you may take the good news, but today you would not be bringing good news, for in fact the kings son is dead.
18:21 Then Joab said to a Cushite, Go, tell the king what you have seen. The Cushite bowed to Joab and ran off.
18:22 But Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, said to Joab again, Come what may, permit me also to run after the Cushite. Joab replied: Why do you want to run, my son? You will receive no reward.
18:23 But he insisted, Come what may, I want to run. Joab said to him, Run. Ahimaaz took the way of the Jordan plain and outran the Cushite.
18:24 Now David was sitting between the two gates, and a lookout mounted to the roof of the gate above the city wall, where he looked out and saw a man running all alone.
18:25 The lookout shouted to inform the king, who said, If he is alone, he has good news to report. As he kept coming nearer,
18:26 the lookout spied another runner. From his place atop the gate he cried out, There is another man running by himself. And the king responded, He, too, is bringing good news.
18:27 Then the lookout said, I notice that the first one runs like Ahimaaz, son of Zadok. The king replied, He is a good man; he comes with good news.
18:28 Then Ahimaaz called out and greeted the king. With face to the ground he paid homage to the king and said, Blessed be the your God, who has delivered up the men who rebelled against my lord the king.
18:29 But the king asked, Is young Absalom safe? And Ahimaaz replied, I saw a great disturbance when the kings servant Joab sent your servant on, but I do not know what it was.
18:30 The king said, Step aside and remain in attendance here. So he stepped aside and remained there.
18:31 When the Cushite came in, he said, Let my lord the king receive the good news that this day the has freed you from the power of all who rose up against you.
18:32 But the king asked the Cushite, Is young Absalom all right? The Cushite replied, May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rebel against you with evil intent be as that young man!
19:1 The king was shaken, and went up to the room over the city gate and wept. He said as he wept, My son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!
19:2 Joab was told, The king is weeping and mourning for Absalom,
19:3 and that days victory was turned into mourning for the whole army when they heard, The king is grieving for his son.
19:4 The soldiers stole into the city that day like men shamed by flight in battle.
19:5 Meanwhile the king covered his face and cried out in a loud voice, My son Absalom! Absalom! My son, my son!
19:6 So Joab went to the kings residence and said: Though they saved your life and your sons and daughters lives, and the lives of your wives and your concubines, you have put all your servants to shame today
19:7 by loving those who hate you and hating those who love you. For you have announced today that officers and servants are nothing to you. Indeed I am now certain that if Absalom were alive today and all of us dead, that would be fine with you.
19:8 Now then, get up! Go out and speak kindly to your servants. I swear by the that if you do not go out, not a single man will remain with you overnight, and this will be a far greater disaster for you than any that has come upon you from your youth until now.
19:9 So the king got up and sat at the gate. When all the people were told, The king is sitting at the gate, they came into his presence. Now the Israelites had fled to their separate tents,
19:10 but throughout the tribes of Israel all the people were arguing among themselves, saying to one another: The king delivered us from the grasp of our enemies, and it was he who rescued us from the grasp of the Philistines. Now, he has fled the country before Absalom,
19:11 but Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in battle. Why, then, should you remain silent about restoring the king to his palace? When the talk of all Israel reached the king,
19:12 David sent word to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: Say to the elders of Judah: Why should you be last to restore the king to his palace?
19:13 You are my brothers, you are my bone and flesh. Why should you be last to restore the king?
19:14 Also say to Amasa: Are you not my bone and flesh? May God do thus to me, and more, if you do not become commander of my army permanently in place of Joab.
19:15 He won the hearts of the Judahites all together, and so they sent a message to the king: Return, with all your servants.
19:16 So the king returned, and when he reached the Jordan, Judah had come to Gilgal to meet him and to bring him across the Jordan.
19:17 Shimei, son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried down with the Judahites to meet King David,
19:18 accompanied by a thousand men from Benjamin. Ziba, too, the servant of the house of Saul, accompanied by his fifteen sons and twenty servants, hastened to the Jordan before the king.
19:19 They crossed over the ford to bring the kings household over and to do whatever he wished. When Shimei, son of Gera, crossed the Jordan, he fell down before the king
19:20 and said to him: May my lord not hold me guilty; do not remember or take to heart the wrong that your servant did the day my lord the king left Jerusalem.
19:21 For your servant knows that I have done wrong. But I now am the first of the whole house of Joseph to come down today to meet my lord the king.
19:22 But Abishai, son of Zeruiah, countered: Shimei must be put to death for this. He cursed the anointed of the .
19:23 David replied: What has come between you and me, sons of Zeruiah, that you would become my adversaries this day? Should anyone die today in Israel? Am I not aware that today I am king over Israel?
19:24 Then the king said to Shimei, You shall not die. And the king gave him his oath.
19:25 Meribbaal, son of Saul, also went down to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet nor trimmed his mustache nor washed his clothes from the day the king left until he returned safely.
19:26 When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, Why did you not go with me, Meribbaal?
19:27 He replied: My lord king, my servant deceived me. For your servant said to him, Saddle the donkey for me, that I may ride on it and go with the king; your servant is lame.
19:28 But he slandered your servant before my lord the king. But my lord the king is like an angel of God. Do whatever seems good to you.
19:29 For though my fathers entire house deserved only death from my lord the king, yet you placed your servant among those who eat at your table. What right do I still have to make further appeal to the king?
19:30 But the king said to him: Why do you go on talking? I say, You and Ziba shall divide the property.
19:31 Meribbaal answered the king, Indeed let him take it all, now that my lord the king has returned safely to his house.
19:32 Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim and escorted the king to the Jordan for his crossing, taking leave of him at the Jordan.
19:33 It was Barzillai, a very old man of eighty, who had provided for the king during his stay in Mahanaim; he was a very great man.
19:34 The king said to Barzillai, Cross over with me, and I will provide for your old age as my guest in Jerusalem.
19:35 But Barzillai answered the king: How much longer have I to live, that I should go up to Jerusalem with the king?
19:36 I am now eighty years old. Can I distinguish between good and evil? Can your servant taste what he eats and drinks, or still hear the voices of men and women singers? Why should your servant be any further burden to my lord the king?
19:37 In escorting the king across the Jordan, your servant is doing little enough! Why should the king give me this reward?
19:38 Please let your servant go back to die in my own city by the tomb of my father and mother. Here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. Do for him whatever seems good to you.
19:39 Then the king said to him, Chimham shall cross over with me, and for him I will do whatever seems good to you. And anything else you would like me to do for you, I will do.
19:40 Then all the people crossed over the Jordan but the king remained; he kissed Barzillai and bade him farewell as he returned to his own place.
19:41 Finally the king crossed over to Gilgal, accompanied by Chimham. All of the people of Judah and half of the people of Israel had escorted the king across.
19:42 But then all these Israelites began coming to the king and saying, Why did our brothers the Judahites steal you away and bring the king and his household across the Jordan, along with all Davids men?
19:43 All the Judahites replied to the men of Israel: Because the king is our relative. Why are you angry over this? Have we had anything to eat at the kings expense? Or have portions from his table been given to us?
19:44 The Israelites answered the Judahites: We have ten shares in the king. Also, we are the firstborn rather than you. Why do you slight us? Were we not first to speak of restoring our king? Then the Judahites in turn spoke even more fiercely than the Israelites.
20:1 Now a scoundrel named Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite, happened to be there. He sounded the horn and cried out, We have no share in David, nor any heritage in the son of Jesse. Everyone to your tents, O Israel!
20:2 So all the Israelites left David to follow Sheba, son of Bichri. But the Judahites, from the Jordan to Jerusalem, remained loyal to their king.
20:3 David came to his house in Jerusalem, and the king took the ten concubines whom he had left behind to care for the palace and placed them under guard. He provided for them, but never again saw them. And so they remained shut away to the day of their death, lifelong widows.
20:4 Then the king said to Amasa: Summon the Judahites for me within three days. Then present yourself here.
20:5 Accordingly Amasa set out to summon Judah, but delayed beyond the time set for him.
20:6 Then David said to Abishai: Sheba, son of Bichri, may now do us more harm than Absalom did. Take your lords servants and pursue him, lest he find fortified cities and take shelter while we look on.
20:7 So Joab and the Cherethites and Pelethites and all the warriors marched out behind Abishai from Jerusalem to campaign in pursuit of Sheba, son of Bichri.
20:8 They were at the great stone in Gibeon when Amasa met them. Now Joab had a belt over his tunic, from which was slung a sword in its sheath at his thigh; the sword would slide out downwards.
20:9 Joab asked Amasa, Is everything all right, my brother? and with his right hand held Amasas beard as if to kiss him.
20:10 And since Amasa was not on his guard against the sword in Joabs other hand, Joab stabbed him in the abdomen with it, so that his entrails burst forth to the ground, and he died; there was no second thrust. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued Sheba, son of Bichri.
20:11 One of Joabs attendants stood by Amasa and said, Let him who favors Joab and is for David follow Joab.
20:12 Amasa lay covered with blood in the middle of the highroad, and the man noticed that all the soldiers were stopping. So he rolled Amasa away from the road to the field and spread a garment over him, because he saw how all who came upon him were stopping.
20:13 When he had been removed from the road, everyone went on after Joab in pursuit of Sheba, son of Bichri.
20:14 Sheba had passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel Beth-maacah. Then all the Bichrites assembled and they too entered the city after him.
20:15 So all Joabs troops came and besieged him in Abel Beth-maacah. They built up a mound against the city, so that it stood against the rampart, and were battering the wall to knock it down.
20:16 Then a wise woman from the city called out, Listen, listen! Tell Joab, Come here, so I can speak with you.
20:17 When Joab had come near her, the woman said, Are you Joab? And he replied, Yes. She said to him, Listen to what your servant has to say. He replied, I am listening.
20:18 Then she went on to say: There is a saying from long ago, Let them ask if they will in Abel or in Dan whether loyalty is finished
20:19 or ended in Israel. You are seeking to batter down a city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you wish to swallow up the heritage of the ?
20:20 Joab answered, Not at all, not at all! I do not wish to swallow or batter anything.
20:21 That is not the case at all. A man from the hill country of Ephraim, whose name is Sheba, son of Bichri, has rebelled against King David. Give him up, just him, and I will withdraw from the city. Then the woman said to Joab, His head shall be thrown to you across the wall.
20:22 In her wisdom, the woman went to all the people, and they cut off the head of Sheba, son of Bichri, and threw it out to Joab. He then sounded the horn, and they scattered from the city to their own tents, while Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
20:23 Joab was in command of the whole army of Israel. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and Pelethites.
20:24 Adoram was in charge of the forced labor. Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the chancellor.
20:25 Shawsha was the scribe. Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
20:26 Ira the Jairite was also Davids priest.
21:1 In Davids time there was a famine for three years, year after year. David sought the presence of the , who said: There is bloodguilt on Saul and his family because he put the Gibeonites to death.
21:2 So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not Israelites, but survivors of the Amorites; and although the Israelites had given them their oath, Saul had sought to kill them off in his zeal for the Israelites and for Judah.)
21:3 David said to the Gibeonites, What must I do for you and how must I make atonement, that you may bless the heritage of the ?
21:4 The Gibeonites answered him, We have no claim against Saul and his house for silver or gold, nor is it our place to put anyone to death in Israel. Then he said, I will do for you whatever you propose.
21:5 They said to the king, As for the man who was exterminating us and who intended to destroy us that we might have no place in all the territory of Israel,
21:6 let seven men from among his descendants be given to us, that we may execute them before the in Gibeon, on the s mountain. The king replied, I will give them up.
21:7 The king, however, spared Meribbaal, son of Jonathan, son of Saul, because of the s oath that formed a bond between David and Sauls son Jonathan.
21:8 But the king took Armoni and Meribbaal, the two sons that Aiahs daughter Rizpah had borne to Saul, and the five sons of Sauls daughter Merob that she had borne to Adriel, son of Barzillai the Meholathite,
21:9 and delivered them into the power of the Gibeonites, who then executed them on the mountain before the . The seven fell at the one time; they were put to death during the first days of the harvest—that is, at the beginning of the barley harvest.
21:10 Then Rizpah, Aiahs daughter, took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on the rock from the beginning of the harvest until rain came down on them from the heavens, fending off the birds of the heavens from settling on them by day, and the wild animals by night.
21:11 When David was informed of what Rizpah, Aiahs daughter, the concubine of Saul, had done,
21:12 he went and obtained the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them away secretly from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hanged them at the time they defeated Saul on Gilboa.
21:13 When he had brought up from there the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan, the bones of those who had been executed were also gathered up.
21:14 Then the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan were buried in the land of Benjamin, at Zela, in the tomb of his father Kish. After all that the king commanded had been carried out, God granted relief to the land.
21:15 There was another battle between the Philistines and Israel. David went down with his servants and fought the Philistines, but David grew tired.
21:16 Dadu, a descendant of the Rephaim, whose bronze spear weighed three hundred shekels, was about to take him captive. Dadu was girt with a new sword and thought he would kill David,
21:17 but Abishai, son of Zeruiah, came to help him, and struck and killed the Philistine. Then Davids men swore to him, You must not go out to battle with us again, lest you quench the lamp of Israel.
21:18 After this, there was another battle with the Philistines, in Gob. On that occasion Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Saph, a descendant of the Rephaim.
21:19 There was another battle with the Philistines, in Gob, and Elhanan, son of Jair from Bethlehem, killed Goliath of Gath, whose spear shaft was like a weavers beam.
21:20 There was another battle, at Gath, and there was a giant, who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all. He too was descended from the Rephaim.
21:21 And when he insulted Israel, Jonathan, son of Davids brother Shimei, struck him down.
21:22 These four were descended from the Rephaim in Gath, and they fell at the hands of David and his servants.
22:1 David proclaimed the words of this song to the when the had rescued him from the grasp of all his enemies and from the grasp of Saul.
22:2 He said: O , my rock, my fortress, my deliverer,
22:3 my God, my rock of refuge! My shield, my saving horn, my stronghold, my refuge, my savior, from violence you keep me safe.
22:4 Praised be the , I exclaim! I have been delivered from my enemies.
22:5 The breakers of death surged round about me, the menacing floods terrified me;
22:6 The cords of Sheol tightened; the snares of death lay in wait for me.
22:7 In my distress I called out: ! I cried out to my God; From his temple he heard my voice, my cry reached his ears.
22:8 The earth rocked and shook; the foundations of the heavens trembled; they shook as his wrath flared up.
22:9 Smoke rose in his nostrils, a devouring fire from his mouth; it kindled coals into flame.
22:10 He parted the heavens and came down, a dark cloud under his feet.
22:11 Mounted on a cherub he flew, borne along on the wings of the wind.
22:12 He made darkness the cover about him, a mass of water, heavy thunderheads.
22:13 From the brightness of his presence coals were kindled to flame.
22:14 The thundered from heaven; the Most High made his voice resound.
22:15 He let fly arrows and scattered them; lightning, and dispersed them.
22:16 Then the bed of the sea appeared; the worlds foundations lay bare, At the roar of the , at the storming breath of his nostrils.
22:17 He reached down from on high and seized me, drew me out of the deep waters.
22:18 He rescued me from my mighty enemy, from foes too powerful for me.
22:19 They attacked me on a day of distress, but the came to my support.
22:20 He set me free in the open; he rescued me because he loves me.
22:21 The acknowledged my righteousness; rewarded my clean hands.
22:22 For I kept the ways of the ; I was not disloyal to my God.
22:23 His laws were all before me, his decrees I did not cast aside.
22:24 I was honest toward him; I was on guard against sin.
22:25 So the rewarded my righteousness, the cleanness of my hands in his sight.
22:26 Toward the faithful you are faithful; to the honest you are honest;
22:27 Toward the sincere you are sincere; but to the perverse you are devious.
22:28 Humble people you save, though on the haughty your eyes look down.
22:29 You are my lamp, O ! My God brightens the darkness about me.
22:30 With you I can rush an armed band, with my God to help I can leap a wall.
22:31 Gods way is unerring; the s promise is tried and true; he is a shield for all who trust in him.
22:32 Truly, who is God except the ? Who but our God is the rock?
22:33 This God who girded me with might, kept my way unerring,
22:34 Who made my feet swift as a deers, set me safe on the heights,
22:35 Who trained my hands for war, my arms to bend even a bow of bronze.
22:36 You have given me your protecting shield, and your help has made me great.
22:37 You gave me room to stride; my feet never stumbled.
22:38 I pursued my enemies and overtook them; I did not turn back till I destroyed them.
22:39 I struck them down, and they did not rise; they fell dead at my feet.
22:40 You girded me with strength for war; subdued adversaries at my feet.
22:41 My foes you put to flight before me; those who hated me I destroyed.
22:42 They cried for help, but no one saved them, cried to the but got no answer.
22:43 I ground them fine as the dust of the earth; like mud in the streets I trod them down.
22:44 You rescued me from the strife of my people; you made me head over nations. A people I had not known became my slaves;
22:45 Foreigners cringed before me; as soon as they heard of me they obeyed.
22:46 Their courage failed; they came trembling from their fortresses.
22:47 The lives! Blessed be my rock! Exalted be God, the rock of my salvation.
22:48 O God who granted me vindication, subdued peoples under me,
22:49 and helped me escape from my enemies, Truly you have exalted me above my adversaries, from the violent you have rescued me.
22:50 Thus I will proclaim you, , among the nations; I will sing the praises of your name.
22:51 You have given great victories to your king, and shown kindness to your anointed, to David and his posterity forever.
23:1 These are the last words of David: The oracle of David, son of Jesse; the oracle of the man God raised up, Anointed of the God of Jacob, favorite of the Mighty One of Israel.
23:2 The spirit of the spoke through me; his word was on my tongue.
23:3 The God of Israel spoke; of me the Rock of Israel said, One who rules over humankind with justice, who rules in the fear of God,
23:4 Is like the light at sunrise on a cloudless morning, making the lands vegetation glisten after rain.
23:5 Is not my house firm before God? He has made an eternal covenant with me, set forth in detail and secured. Will he not bring to fruition all my salvation and my every desire?
23:6 But the wicked are all like thorns to be cast away; they cannot be taken up by hand.
23:7 One wishing to touch them must be armed with iron or the shaft of a spear. They must be utterly consumed by fire.
23:8 These are the names of Davids warriors. Ishbaal, the son of Hachamoni, chief of the Three. He brandished his spear over eight hundred whom he had slain in a single encounter.
23:9 Next to him was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the Three warriors with David at Ephes-dammim, when they insulted the Philistines who had massed there for battle. The Israelites had retreated,
23:10 but he stood there and struck down the Philistines until his hand grew tired from clutching the sword. The brought about a great victory on that day; the army turned back to rejoin Eleazar, but only to strip the slain.
23:11 Next to him was Shammah, son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had assembled at Lehi, where there was a plot of land full of lentils. The people were fleeing before the Philistines,
23:12 but he took his stand in the middle of the plot, kept it safe, and cut down the Philistines. Thus the brought about a great victory. Such deeds as these the Three warriors performed.
23:13 Three of the Thirty chiefs went down to David in the cave of Adullam during the harvest, while a Philistine clan was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
23:14 David was then in the stronghold, and there was a garrison of Philistines in Bethlehem.
23:15 Now David had a craving and said, If only someone would give me a drink of water from the cistern by the gate of Bethlehem!
23:16 Thereupon the three warriors broke through the encampment of the Philistines, drew water from the cistern by the gate of Bethlehem, and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it, and instead poured it out to the ,
23:17 saying: The forbid that I do such a thing! Could I drink the blood of these men who went at the risk of their lives? So he refused to drink it.
23:18 Abishai, the brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was the chief of the Thirty; he brandished his spear over three hundred whom he had slain. He made a name among the Thirty,
23:19 but was more famous than any of the Thirty, becoming their leader. However, he did not attain to the Three.
23:20 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, a valiant man of mighty deeds, from Kabzeel, killed the two sons of Ariel of Moab. Also, he went down and killed the lion in the cistern on a snowy day.
23:21 He likewise slew an Egyptian, a huge man. The Egyptian carried a spear, but Benaiah came against him with a staff; he wrested the spear from the Egyptians hand, and killed him with that spear.
23:22 Such deeds as these Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, performed; and he made a name among the Thirty warriors
23:23 but was more famous than any of the Thirty. However, he did not attain to the Three. David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
23:24 Asahel, brother of Joab, was among the Thirty; Elhanan, son of Dodo, from Bethlehem;
23:25 Shammah, from En-harod; Elika, from En-harod;
23:26 Helez, from Beth-pelet; Ira, son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa;
23:27 Abiezer, from Anathoth; Sibbecai, from Husha;
23:28 Zalmon, from Ahoh; Maharai, from Netophah;
23:29 Heled, son of Baanah, from Netophah; Ittai, son of Ribai, from Gibeah of Benjamin;
23:30 Benaiah, from Pirathon; Hiddai, from the valley of Gaash;
23:31 Abibaal, from Beth-arabah; Azmaveth, from Bahurim;
23:32 Eliahba, from Shaalbon; Jashen the Gunite; Jonathan,
23:33 son of Shammah the Hararite; Ahiam, son of Sharar the Hararite;
23:34 Eliphelet, son of Ahasbai, from Beth-maacah; Eliam, son of Ahithophel, from Gilo;
23:35 Hezrai, from Carmel; Paarai the Arbite;
23:36 Igal, son of Nathan, from Zobah; Bani the Gadite;
23:37 Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai, from Beeroth, the armor-bearer of Joab, son of Zeruiah;
23:38 Ira, from Jattir; Gareb, from Jattir;
23:39 Uriah the Hittite—thirty-seven in all.
24:1 The s anger against Israel flared again, and he incited David against them: Go, take a census of Israel and Judah.
24:2 The king therefore said to Joab and the leaders of the army who were with him, Tour all the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba and register the people, that I may know their number.
24:3 But Joab replied to the king: May the your God increase the number of people a hundredfold for my lord the king to see it with his own eyes. But why does it please my lord to do a thing of this kind?
24:4 However, the kings command prevailed over Joab and the leaders of the army, so they left the kings presence in order to register the people of Israel.
24:5 Crossing the Jordan, they began near Aroer, south of the city in the wadi, and turned in the direction of Gad toward Jazer.
24:6 They continued on to Gilead and to the district below Mount Hermon. Then they proceeded to Dan; from there they turned toward Sidon,
24:7 going to the fortress of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and ending up in the Negeb of Judah, at Beer-sheba.
24:8 Thus they toured the whole land, reaching Jerusalem again after nine months and twenty days.
24:9 Joab then reported the census figures to the king: of men capable of wielding a sword, there were in Israel eight hundred thousand, and in Judah five hundred thousand.
24:10 Afterward, however, David regretted having numbered the people. David said to the : I have sinned grievously in what I have done. Take away, , your servants guilt, for I have acted very foolishly.
24:11 When David rose in the morning, the word of the came to the prophet Gad, Davids seer, saying:
24:12 Go, tell David: Thus says the : I am offering you three options; choose one of them, and I will give you that.
24:13 Gad then went to David to inform him. He asked: Should three years of famine come upon your land; or three months of fleeing from your enemy while he pursues you; or is it to be three days of plague in your land? Now consider well: what answer am I to give to him who sent me?
24:14 David answered Gad: I am greatly distressed. But let us fall into the hand of God, whose mercy is great, rather than into human hands.
24:15 Thus David chose the plague. At the time of the wheat harvest it broke out among the people. The sent plague over Israel from morning until the time appointed, and from Dan to Beer-sheba seventy thousand of the people died.
24:16 But when the angel stretched forth his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the changed his mind about the calamity, and said to the angel causing the destruction among the people: Enough now! Stay your hand. The angel of the was then standing at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
24:17 When David saw the angel who was striking the people, he said to the : It is I who have sinned; it is I, the shepherd, who have done wrong. But these sheep, what have they done? Strike me and my fathers family!
24:18 On the same day Gad went to David and said to him, Go and set up an altar to the on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
24:19 According to Gads word, David went up as the had commanded.
24:20 Now Araunah looked down and saw the king and his servants coming toward him while he was threshing wheat. So he went out and bowed down before the king, his face to the ground.
24:21 Then Araunah asked, Why does my lord the king come to his servant? David replied, To buy the threshing floor from you, to build an altar to the , that the plague may be withdrawn from the people.
24:22 But Araunah said to David: Let my lord the king take it and offer up what is good in his sight. See, here are the oxen for burnt offerings, and the threshing sledges and the yokes of oxen for wood.
24:23 All this does Araunah give to the king. Araunah then said to the king, May the your God accept your offering.
24:24 The king, however, replied to Araunah, No, I will buy it from you at the proper price, for I cannot sacrifice to the my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing. So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty silver shekels.
24:25 Then David built an altar to the there, and sacrificed burnt offerings and communion offerings. The granted relief to the land, and the plague was withdrawn from Israel.
1 KINGS
1:1 When King David was old and advanced in years, though they covered him with blankets he could not get warm.
1:2 His servants therefore said to him, Let a young virgin be sought to attend my lord the king, and to nurse him. If she sleeps with you, my lord the king will be warm.
1:3 So they sought for a beautiful girl throughout the territory of Israel, and found Abishag the Shunamite. So they brought her to the king.
1:4 The girl was very beautiful indeed, and she nursed the king and took care of him. But the king did not have relations with her.
1:5 Adonijah, son of Haggith, boasted, I shall be king! and he provided himself with chariots, horses, and a retinue of fifty to go before him.
1:6 Yet his father would never antagonize him by asking, Why are you doing this? Adonijah was also very handsome, and next in age to Absalom by the same mother.
1:7 He consulted with Joab, son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest, and they became Adonijahs supporters.
1:8 However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei and Rei, and Davids warriors did not support Adonijah.
1:9 Adonijah slaughtered sheep, oxen, and fatlings at the stone Zoheleth near En-rogel and invited all his brothers, the kings sons, and all the royal officials of Judah;
1:10 but he did not invite Nathan the prophet, or Benaiah, or the warriors, or Solomon his brother.
1:11 Then Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomons mother: Have you not heard that Adonijah, son of Haggith, has become king, and our lord David does not know?
1:12 Come now, let me advise you so that you may save your life and the life of your son Solomon.
1:13 Go, visit King David, and say to him, Did you not, my lord king, swear to your handmaid: Your son Solomon shall be king after me; it is he who shall sit upon my throne? Why, then, has Adonijah become king?
1:14 And while you are still there speaking to the king, I will come in after you and confirm your words.
1:15 So Bathsheba visited the king in his room. The king was very old, and Abishag the Shunamite was caring for the king.
1:16 Bathsheba bowed in homage to the king. The king said to her, What do you wish?
1:17 She answered him: My lord, you swore to your servant by the , your God, Solomon your son will be king after me; it is he who shall sit upon my throne.
1:18 But now Adonijah has become king, and you, my lord king, do not know it.
1:19 He has sacrificed bulls, fatlings, and sheep in great numbers; he has invited all the kings sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab, the commander of the army, but not your servant Solomon.
1:20 Now, my lord king, all Israel is looking to you to declare to them who is to sit upon the throne of my lord the king after him.
1:21 If this is not done, when my lord the king rests with his ancestors, I and my son Solomon will be considered criminals.
1:22 While she was still speaking to the king, Nathan the prophet came in.
1:23 They told the king, Nathan the prophet is here. He entered the kings presence and did him homage, bowing to the floor.
1:24 Then Nathan said: My lord king, did you say, Adonijah shall be king after me and shall sit upon my throne?
1:25 For today he went down and sacrificed bulls, fatlings, and sheep in great numbers; he invited all the kings sons, the commanders of the army, and Abiathar the priest, and even now they are eating and drinking in his company and saying, Long live King Adonijah!
1:26 But me, your servant, he did not invite; nor Zadok the priest, nor Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, nor your servant Solomon.
1:27 If this was done by order of my lord the king, you did not tell me, your servant, who is to sit upon the throne of my lord the king after him.
1:28 King David answered, Call Bathsheba here. When she entered the kings presence and stood before him,
1:29 the king swore, As the lives, who has redeemed my life from all distress,
1:30 this very day I will fulfill the oath I swore to you by the , the God of Israel, Your son Solomon shall be king after me and shall sit upon my throne in my place.
1:31 Bowing to the floor in homage to the king, Bathsheba said, May my lord, King David, live forever!
1:32 Then King David said, Call Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah, son of Jehoiada. When they had entered the kings presence,
1:33 he said to them: Take with you the royal officials. Mount my son Solomon upon my own mule and escort him down to Gihon.
1:34 There Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet shall anoint him king over Israel, and you shall blow the rams horn and cry, Long live King Solomon!
1:35 When you come back up with him, he is to go in and sit upon my throne. It is he that shall be king in my place: him I designate ruler of Israel and of Judah.
1:36 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, answered the king: So be it! May the , the God of my lord the king, so decree!
1:37 As the has been with my lord the king, so may he be with Solomon, and make his throne even greater than that of my lord, King David!
1:38 So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and Pelethites went down, and mounting Solomon on King Davids mule, escorted him to Gihon.
1:39 Then Zadok the priest took the horn of oil from the tent and anointed Solomon. They blew the rams horn and all the people shouted, Long live King Solomon!
1:40 Then all the people went up after him, playing flutes and rejoicing so much the earth split with their shouting.
1:41 Adonijah and all the guests who were with him heard it, just as they ended their banquet. When Joab heard the sound of the rams horn, he asked, Why this uproar in the city?
1:42 As he was speaking, Jonathan, son of Abiathar the priest, arrived. Adonijah said, Come, you are a man of worth and must bring good news.
1:43 Jonathan answered Adonijah, Hardly! Our lord, King David, has made Solomon king.
1:44 The king sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and Pelethites, and they mounted him upon the kings own mule.
1:45 Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anointed him king at Gihon, and they went up from there rejoicing, so that the city is in an uproar. That is the noise you hear.
1:46 Moreover, Solomon has taken his seat on the royal throne,
1:47 and moreover the kings servants have come to pay their respects to our lord, King David, saying, May your God make Solomons name more famous than your name, his throne greater than your throne! And the king in his bed did homage.
1:48 This is what the king said: Blessed be the , the God of Israel, who has this day provided one to sit upon my throne, so that I see it with my own eyes.
1:49 All the guests of Adonijah got up trembling, and went each their way,
1:50 but Adonijah, in fear of Solomon, got up and went to grasp the horns of the altar.
1:51 It was reported to Solomon: Adonijah, in fear of King Solomon, is clinging to the horns of the altar and saying, Let King Solomon first swear that he will not kill me, his servant, with the sword.
1:52 Solomon answered, If he proves worthy, not a hair of his shall fall to the ground. But if evil is found in him, he shall die.
1:53 King Solomon sent to have him brought down from the altar, and he came and paid homage to King Solomon. Solomon then said to him, Go to your house.
2:1 When the time of Davids death drew near, he gave these instructions to Solomon his son:
2:2 I am going the way of all the earth. Be strong and be a man!
2:3 Keep the mandate of the , your God, walking in his ways and keeping his statutes, commands, ordinances, and decrees as they are written in the law of Moses, that you may succeed in whatever you do, and wherever you turn,
2:4 and that the may fulfill the word he spoke concerning me: If your sons so conduct themselves that they walk before me in faithfulness with their whole heart and soul, there shall never be wanting someone of your line on the throne of Israel.
2:5 You yourself know what Joab, son of Zeruiah, did to me—what he did to the two commanders of Israels armies, Abner, son of Ner, and Amasa, son of Jether: he killed them and brought the blood of war into a time of peace, and put the blood of war on the belt about his waist and the sandal on his foot.
2:6 Act with all the wisdom you possess; do not let his gray head go down to Sheol in peace.
2:7 But be true to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and have them among those who eat at your table. For they were loyal to me when I was fleeing from your brother Absalom.
2:8 You also have with you Shimei, son of Gera, the Benjaminite of Bahurim, who cursed me bitterly the day I was going to Mahanaim. When he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the : I will not kill you by the sword.
2:9 But you must not let him go unpunished. You are wise; you will know what to do to send his gray head down to Sheol in blood.
2:10 David rested with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David.
2:11 David was king over Israel for forty years: he was king seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem. 
2:12 Then Solomon sat on the throne of David his father, and his kingship was established.
2:13 Adonijah, son of Haggith, came to Bathsheba, the mother of Solomon. Do you come in peace? she asked. In peace, he answered,
2:14 and he added, I have something to say to you. She replied, Speak.
2:15 So he said: You know that the kingship was mine, and all Israel expected me to be king. But the kingship passed me by and went to my brother; by the s will it went to him.
2:16 But now there is one favor I would ask of you. Do not refuse me. And she said, Speak on.
2:17 He said, Please ask King Solomon, who will not refuse you, to give me Abishag the Shunamite to be my wife.
2:18 Bathsheba replied, Very well, I will speak to the king for you.
2:19 Then Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him for Adonijah, and the king stood up to meet her and paid her homage. Then he sat down upon his throne, and a throne was provided for the kings mother, who sat at his right.
2:20 She said, There is one small favor I would ask of you. Do not refuse me. The king said to her, Ask it, my mother, for I will not refuse you.
2:21 So she said, Let Abishag the Shunamite be given to your brother Adonijah to be his wife.
2:22 King Solomon answered his mother, And why do you ask that Abishag the Shunamite be given to Adonijah? Ask the kingship for him as well, for he is my older brother! Ask for him, for Abiathar the priest, for Joab, son of Zeruiah!
2:23 And King Solomon swore by the : May God do thus to me and more, if Adonijah has not spoken this word at the cost of his life.
2:24 And now, as the lives, who has established me and set me on the throne of David my father and made for me a house as he promised, this day shall Adonijah be put to death.
2:25 Then King Solomon sent Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, who struck him dead.
2:26 The king said to Abiathar the priest: Go to your estate in Anathoth. Though you deserve to die, I will not put you to death at this time, because you carried the ark of the Lord before David my father and shared in all the hardships my father endured.
2:27 So Solomon dismissed Abiathar from the office of priest of the , thus fulfilling the word the had spoken in Shiloh against the house of Eli.
2:28 When the news came to Joab, since he had sided with Adonijah, though not with Absalom, he fled to the tent of the and clung to the horns of the altar.
2:29 King Solomon was told, Joab has fled to the tent of the and is by the altar. He sent Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, with the order, Go, strike him down.
2:30 Benaiah went to the tent of the and said to him, The king says, Come out. But he answered, No! I will die here. Benaiah reported to the king, This is what Joab said to me in reply.
2:31 The king answered him: Do as he has said. Strike him down and bury him, and remove from me and from my fathers house the blood which Joab shed without provocation.
2:32 The will bring blood upon his own head, because he struck down two men better and more just than himself, and slew them with the sword without my father Davids knowledge: Abner, son of Ner, commander of Israels army, and Amasa, son of Jether, commander of Judahs army.
2:33 Their blood will be upon the head of Joab and his descendants. But upon David and his descendants, upon his house and his throne, there shall be peace forever from the .
2:34 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, went back, struck him down and killed him; he was buried in his house in the wilderness.
2:35 The king appointed Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, over the army in his place; Zadok the priest the king put in place of Abiathar.
2:36 Then the king summoned Shimei and said to him: Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and stay there. Do not go anywhere else.
2:37 For the day you leave, and cross the Wadi Kidron, be certain you shall surely die. Your blood shall be upon your own head.
2:38 Shimei answered the king: I accept. Your servant will do just as my lord the king has said. So Shimei stayed in Jerusalem for a long time.
2:39 But three years later, two of Shimeis servants ran away to Achish, son of Maacah, king of Gath, and Shimei was told, Your servants are in Gath.
2:40 So Shimei rose, saddled his donkey, and went to Achish in Gath in search of his servants; and Shimei returned from Gath with his servants.
2:41 When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath, and had returned,
2:42 the king summoned Shimei and said to him: Did I not have you swear by the and warn you clearly, The day you leave and go anywhere else, be certain you shall surely die? And you answered, I accept and obey.
2:43 Why, then, have you not kept the oath of the and the command that I gave you?
2:44 And the king said to Shimei: In your heart you know very well the evil that you did to David my father. Now the is bringing your own evil upon your head.
2:45 But King Solomon shall be blessed, and Davids throne shall be established before the forever.
2:46 The king then gave the order to Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, who went out and struck him dead. And the royal power was established in Solomons hand.
3:1 Solomon allied himself by marriage with Pharaoh, king of Egypt. He married the daughter of Pharaoh and brought her to the City of David, until he should finish building his own house, and the house of the , and the wall around Jerusalem.
3:2 The people were sacrificing on the high places, however, for up to that time no house had been built for the name of the .
3:3 Although Solomon loved the , walking in the statutes of David his father, he offered sacrifice and burned incense on the high places.
3:4 The king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, because that was the great high place. Upon its altar Solomon sacrificed a thousand burnt offerings.
3:5 In Gibeon the appeared to Solomon in a dream at night. God said: Whatever you ask I shall give you.
3:6 Solomon answered: You have shown great kindness to your servant, David my father, because he walked before you with fidelity, justice, and an upright heart; and you have continued this great kindness toward him today, giving him a son to sit upon his throne.
3:7 Now, , my God, you have made me, your servant, king to succeed David my father; but I am a mere youth, not knowing at all how to act—
3:8 I, your servant, among the people you have chosen, a people so vast that it cannot be numbered or counted.
3:9 Give your servant, therefore, a listening heart to judge your people and to distinguish between good and evil. For who is able to give judgment for this vast people of yours?
3:10 The Lord was pleased by Solomons request.
3:11 So God said to him: Because you asked for this—you did not ask for a long life for yourself, nor for riches, nor for the life of your enemies—but you asked for discernment to know what is right—
3:12 I now do as you request. I give you a heart so wise and discerning that there has never been anyone like you until now, nor after you will there be anyone to equal you.
3:13 In addition, I give you what you have not asked for: I give you such riches and glory that among kings there will be no one like you all your days.
3:14 And if you walk in my ways, keeping my statutes and commandments, as David your father did, I will give you a long life.
3:15 Solomon awoke; it was a dream! He went to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the covenant of the Lord, sacrificed burnt offerings and communion offerings, and gave a feast for all his servants. 
3:16 Later, two prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
3:17 One woman said: By your leave, my lord, this woman and I live in the same house, and I gave birth in the house while she was present.
3:18 On the third day after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were alone; no one else was in the house with us; only the two of us were in the house.
3:19 This womans son died during the night when she lay on top of him.
3:20 So in the middle of the night she got up and took my son from my side, as your servant was sleeping. Then she laid him in her bosom and laid her dead son in my bosom.
3:21 I rose in the morning to nurse my son, and he was dead! But when I examined him in the morning light, I saw it was not the son I had borne.
3:22 The other woman answered, No! The living one is my son, the dead one is yours. But the first kept saying, No! the dead one is your son, the living one is mine! Thus they argued before the king.
3:23 Then the king said: One woman claims, This, the living one, is my son, the dead one is yours. The other answers, No! The dead one is your son, the living one is mine.
3:24 The king continued, Get me a sword. When they brought the sword before the king,
3:25 he said, Cut the living child in two, and give half to one woman and half to the other.
3:26 The woman whose son was alive, because she was stirred with compassion for her son, said to the king, Please, my lord, give her the living baby—do not kill it! But the other said, It shall be neither mine nor yours. Cut it in two!
3:27 The king then answered, Give her the living baby! Do not kill it! She is the mother.
3:28 When all Israel heard the judgment the king had given, they were in awe of him, because they saw that the king had in him the wisdom of God for giving right judgment.
4:1 Solomon was king over all Israel,
4:2 and these were the officials he had in his service: Azariah, son of Zadok, the priest;
4:3 Elihoreph and Ahijah, sons of Shisha, scribes; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, the chancellor;
4:4 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, in charge of the army; Zadok and Abiathar, priests;
4:5 Azariah, son of Nathan, in charge of the governors; Zabud, son of Nathan, priest and companion to the king;
4:6 Ahishar, master of the palace; and Adoniram, son of Abda, in charge of the forced labor.
4:7 Solomon had twelve governors over all Israel who supplied food for the king and his household, each having to provide for one month in the year.
4:8 Their names were: the son of Hur in the hill country of Ephraim;
4:9 the son of Deker in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-shemesh, and Elon Beth-hanan;
4:10 the son of Hesed in Arubboth, as well as in Socoh and the whole region of Hepher;
4:11 the son of Abinadab, in all Naphath-dor; he was married to Taphath, Solomons daughter;
4:12 Baana, son of Ahilud, in Taanach and Megiddo and all Beth-shean near Zarethan below Jezreel, from Beth-shean to Abel-meholah to beyond Jokmeam;
4:13 the son of Geber in Ramoth-gilead, having charge of the villages of Jair, son of Manasseh, in Gilead; and of the district of Argob in Bashan—sixty large walled cities with gates barred with bronze;
4:14 Ahinadab, son of Iddo, in Mahanaim;
4:15 Ahimaaz, in Naphtali; he was married to Basemath, another daughter of Solomon;
4:16 Baana, son of Hushai, in Asher and Aloth;
4:17 Jehoshaphat, son of Paruah, in Issachar;
4:18 Shimei, son of Ela, in Benjamin;
4:19 Geber, son of Uri, in the land of Gilead, the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, and of Og, king of Bashan. There was one governor besides, in the land of Judah.
4:20 Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sands by the sea; they ate and drank and rejoiced.
5:1 Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the River to the land of the Philistines, down to the border of Egypt; they paid Solomon tribute and served him as long as he lived.
5:2 Solomons provisions for each day were thirty kors of fine flour, sixty kors of meal,
5:3 ten fatted oxen, twenty pasture-fed oxen, and a hundred sheep, not counting harts, gazelles, roebucks, and fatted fowl.
5:4 He had dominion over all the land west of the River, from Tiphsah to Gaza, and all its kings, and he had peace on all his borders round about.
5:5 Thus Judah and Israel lived in security, everyone under their own vine and fig tree from Dan to Beer-sheba, as long as Solomon lived.
5:6 Solomon had forty thousand stalls for horses for chariots and twelve thousand horsemen.
5:7 The governors, one for each month, provided food for King Solomon and for all the guests at King Solomons table. They left nothing unprovided.
5:8 For the chariot horses and draft animals also, each brought his quota of barley and straw to the required place.
5:9 Moreover, God gave Solomon wisdom, exceptional understanding, and knowledge, as vast as the sand on the seashore.
5:10 Solomons wisdom surpassed that of all the peoples of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.
5:11 He was wiser than anyone else—wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, or Heman, Chalcol, and Darda, the musicians—and his fame spread throughout the neighboring peoples.
5:12 Solomon also uttered three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered a thousand and five.
5:13 He spoke of plants, from the cedar on Lebanon to the hyssop growing out of the wall, and he spoke about beasts, birds, reptiles, and fishes.
5:14 People from all nations came to hear Solomons wisdom, sent by all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom. 
5:15 When Hiram, king of Tyre, heard that Solomon had been anointed king in place of his father, he sent an embassy to him; for Hiram had always been Davids friend.
5:16 Solomon sent back this message to Hiram:
5:17 You know that David my father, because of the wars that beset him, could not build a house for the name of the his God until such time as the should put his enemies under the soles of his feet.
5:18 But now the , my God, has given me rest on all sides, without adversary or misfortune.
5:19 So I intend to build a house for the name of the , my God, as the said to David my father: Your son whom I will put upon your throne in your place shall build the house for my name.
5:20 Give orders, then, to have cedars from the Lebanon cut down for me. My servants shall accompany yours, and I will pay you whatever you say for your servants wages. For you know that there is no one among us who is skilled in cutting timber like the Sidonians.
5:21 When Hiram had heard the words of Solomon, he was overjoyed, and said, Blessed be the this day, who has given David a wise son over this numerous people.
5:22 Hiram then sent word to Solomon, I have heard the proposal you sent me, and I will provide all the cedars and fir trees you desire.
5:23 My servants shall bring them down from the Lebanon to the sea, and I will arrange them into rafts in the sea and bring them wherever you say. There I will break up the rafts, and you shall take the lumber. You, for your part, shall furnish the provisions I desire for my household.
5:24 So Hiram continued to provide Solomon with all the cedars and fir trees he desired,
5:25 while Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand kors of wheat to provide for his household, and twenty kors of hand-pressed oil. Solomon gave Hiram all this every year.
5:26 The gave Solomon wisdom as he promised him. So there was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and the two of them made a covenant.
5:27 King Solomon raised thirty thousand forced laborers from all Israel.
5:28 He sent them to the Lebanon for a month in relays of ten thousand, so that they spent one month in the Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram was in charge of the forced labor.
5:29 Solomon had seventy thousand carriers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the mountain,
5:30 in addition to three thousand three hundred overseers answerable to Solomon, who were in charge of the work and directed the people engaged in the work.
5:31 By order of the king, fine, large blocks of stone were quarried to give the house a foundation of hewn stone.
5:32 Solomons and Hirams builders, along with others from Gebal, shaped them, and prepared the wood and stones for building the house.
6:1 In the four hundred and eightieth year after the Israelites went forth from the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomons reign over Israel, in the month of Ziv (the second month), he began to build the house of the .
6:2 The house which King Solomon built for the was sixty cubits long, twenty wide, and thirty high.
6:3 The porch in front of the nave of the house was twenty cubits from side to side along the width of the house, and ten cubits deep in front of the house.
6:4 Windows with closed lattices were made for the house,
6:5 and adjoining the wall of the house he built a substructure around its walls that enclosed the nave and the inner sanctuary, and he made side chambers all around.
6:6 The lowest story was five cubits wide, the middle one six cubits wide, the third seven cubits wide, because he put recesses along the outside of the house to avoid fastening anything into the walls of the house.
6:7 The house was built of stone dressed at the quarry, so that no hammer or ax, no iron tool, was to be heard in the house during its construction.
6:8 The entrance to the middle story was on the south side of the house; stairs led up to the middle story and from the middle story to the third.
6:9 When he had finished building the house, it was roofed in with rafters and boards of cedar.
6:10 He built the substructure five cubits high all along the outside of the house, to which it was joined by cedar beams.
6:11 The word of the came to Solomon:
6:12 As to this house you are building—if you walk in my statutes, carry out my ordinances, and observe all my commands, walking in them, I will fulfill toward you my word which I spoke to David your father.
6:13 I will dwell in the midst of the Israelites and will not forsake my people Israel.
6:14 When Solomon finished building the house,
6:15 its inside walls were lined with cedar paneling: he covered the interior with wood from floor to ceiling, and he covered its floor with fir planking.
6:16 At the rear of the house a space of twenty cubits was set off by cedar panels from the floor to the ceiling, enclosing the inner sanctuary, the holy of holies.
6:17 The house was forty cubits long, that is, the nave, the part in front.
6:18 The cedar in the interior of the house was carved in the form of gourds and open flowers; all was of cedar, and no stone was to be seen.
6:19 In the innermost part of the house he set up the inner sanctuary to house the ark of the s covenant.
6:20 In front of the inner sanctuary (it was twenty cubits long, twenty wide, and twenty high, and he covered it with pure gold), he made an altar of cedar.
6:21 Solomon covered the interior of the house with pure gold, and he drew golden chains across in front of the inner sanctuary, and covered it with gold.
6:22 He covered the whole house with gold, until the whole house was done, and the whole altar that belonged to the inner sanctuary he covered with gold.
6:23 In the inner sanctuary he made two cherubim, each ten cubits high, made of pine.
6:24 Each wing of a cherub was five cubits so that the span from wing tip to wing tip was ten cubits.
6:25 The second cherub was also ten cubits: the two cherubim were identical in size and shape;
6:26 the first cherub was ten cubits high, and so was the second.
6:27 He placed the cherubim in the inmost part of the house; the wings of the cherubim were spread wide, so that one wing of the first touched the side wall and the wing of the second touched the other wall; the wings pointing to the middle of the room touched each other.
6:28 He overlaid the cherubim with gold.
6:29 The walls of the house on all sides of both the inner and the outer rooms had carved figures of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers.
6:30 The floor of the house of both the inner and the outer rooms was overlaid with gold.
6:31 At the entrance of the inner sanctuary, doors of pine were made; the doorframes had five-sided posts.
6:32 The two doors were of pine, with carved figures of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers. The doors were overlaid with gold, and the cherubim and the palm trees were also covered with beaten gold.
6:33 He did the same at the entrance to the nave, where the doorposts were of pine and were four-sided.
6:34 The two doors were of fir wood, each door consisting of two panels hinged together;
6:35 and he carved cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, and plated them with gold.
6:36 He walled off the inner court with three courses of hewn stones and one course of cedar beams.
6:37 The foundations of the s house were laid in the month of Ziv in the fourth year,
6:38 and it was finished, in all particulars, exactly according to plan, in the month of Bul, the eighth month, in the eleventh year. Thus Solomon built it in seven years.
7:1 To finish the building of his own house Solomon took thirteen years.
7:2 He built the House of the Forest of Lebanon one hundred cubits long, fifty wide, and thirty high; it was supported by four rows of cedar columns, with cedar beams upon the columns.
7:3 Moreover, it had a ceiling of cedar above the rafters resting on the columns; these rafters numbered forty-five, fifteen to a row.
7:4 There were lattices in three rows, each row facing the next,
7:5 and all the openings and doorposts were squared with lintels, each facing across from the next.
7:6 He also made the Porch of Columns, fifty cubits long and thirty wide. The porch extended across the front, and there were columns with a canopy in front of them.
7:7 He also made the Porch of the Throne where he gave judgment—that is, the Porch of Judgment; it was paneled with cedar from floor to ceiling beams.
7:8 The house in which he lived was in another court, set in deeper than the Porch and of the same construction. (Solomon made a house like this Porch for Pharaohs daughter, whom he had married.)
7:9 All these buildings were of fine stones, hewn to size and trimmed front and back with a saw, from the foundation to the bonding course and outside as far as the great court.
7:10 The foundation was made of fine, large blocks, some ten cubits and some eight cubits.
7:11 Above were fine stones hewn to size, and cedar wood.
7:12 The great court had three courses of hewn stones all around and a course of cedar beams. So also were the inner court of the house of the and its porch.
7:13 King Solomon brought Hiram from Tyre.
7:14 He was a bronze worker, the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali; his father had been from Tyre. He was endowed with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge for doing any work in bronze. He came to King Solomon and did all his metal work.
7:15 He fashioned two bronze columns, each eighteen cubits high and twelve cubits in circumference.
7:16 He also made two capitals cast in bronze, to be placed on top of the columns, each of them five cubits high.
7:17 There were meshes made like netting and braid made like chains for the capitals on top of the columns, seven for each capital.
7:18 He also cast pomegranates, two rows around each netting to cover the capital on top of the columns.
7:19 The capitals on top of the columns (in the porch) were made like lilies, four cubits high.
7:20 And the capitals on the two columns, both above and adjoining the bulge where it crossed out of the netting, had two hundred pomegranates in rows around each capital.
7:21 He set up the columns at the temple porch; one he set up to the south, and called it Jachin, and the other to the north, and called it Boaz.
7:22 The top of the columns was made like a lily. Thus the work on the columns was completed.
7:23 Then he made the molten sea; it was made with a circular rim, and measured ten cubits across, five in height, and thirty in circumference.
7:24 Under the brim, gourds encircled it for ten cubits around the compass of the sea; the gourds were in two rows and were cast in one mold with the sea.
7:25 This rested on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east, with their haunches all toward the center; upon them was set the sea.
7:26 It was a handbreadth thick, and its brim resembled that of a cup, being lily-shaped. Its capacity was two thousand baths.
7:27 He also made ten stands of bronze, each four cubits long, four wide, and three high.
7:28 When these stands were constructed, panels were set within the framework.
7:29 On the panels within the frames there were lions, oxen, and cherubim; and on the frames likewise, above and below the lions and oxen, there were wreaths in hammered relief.
7:30 Each stand had four bronze wheels and bronze axles. The four legs of each stand had cast braces, which were under the basin; they had wreaths on each side.
7:31 The mouth of the basin was inside, and a cubit above, the crown, whose opening was round, made like a receptacle, a cubit and a half in depth. There was carved work at the opening, on panels that were square, not circular.
7:32 The four wheels were below the paneling, and the axletrees of the wheels and the stand were of one piece. Each wheel was a cubit and a half high.
7:33 The wheels were constructed like chariot wheels; their axletrees, rims, spokes, and hubs were all cast.
7:34 The four braces reached the four corners of each stand, and formed part of the stand.
7:35 At the top of the stand there was a raised collar half a cubit high, and the handles and panels on top of the stand formed part of it.
7:36 On the flat ends of the handles and on the panels, wherever there was a bare space, cherubim, lions, and palm trees were carved, as well as wreaths all around.
7:37 This was how he made the ten stands, all of the same casting, the same size, the same shape.
7:38 He made ten bronze basins, each four cubits in diameter with a capacity of forty baths, one basin atop each of the ten stands.
7:39 He placed the stands, five on the south side of the house and five on the north. The sea he placed off to the southeast from the south side of the house.
7:40 When Hiram had made the pots, shovels, and bowls, he finished all his work for King Solomon in the house of the :
7:41 two columns; two nodes for the capitals on top of the columns; two pieces of netting covering the two nodes for the capitals on top of the columns;
7:42 four hundred pomegranates in double rows on both pieces of netting that covered the two nodes of the capitals on top of the columns;
7:43 ten stands; ten basins on the stands;
7:44 one sea; twelve oxen supporting the sea;
7:45 pots, shovels, and bowls. All these articles which Hiram made for King Solomon in the house of the were of burnished bronze.
7:46 The king had them cast in the neighborhood of the Jordan, between Succoth and Zarethan, in thick clay molds.
7:47 Solomon did not weigh all the articles because they were so numerous; the weight of the bronze, therefore, was not determined.
7:48 Solomon made all the articles that were for the house of the : the golden altar; the table on which the showbread lay;
7:49 the lampstands of pure gold, five to the right and five to the left before the inner sanctuary; their flowers, lamps, and tongs of gold;
7:50 basins, snuffers, bowls, cups, and firepans of pure gold; hinges of gold for the doors of the innermost part of the house, or holy of holies, and for the doors of the outer room, the nave.
7:51 When all the work undertaken by King Solomon in the house of the was completed, he brought in the votive offerings of his father David, and put the silver, gold, and other articles in the treasuries of the house of the .
8:1 Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel and all the heads of the tribes, the princes in the ancestral houses of the Israelites. They came to King Solomon in Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the s covenant from the city of David (which is Zion).
8:2 All the people of Israel assembled before King Solomon during the festival in the month of Ethanim (the seventh month).
8:3 When all the elders of Israel had arrived, the priests took up the ark;
8:4 and they brought up the ark of the and the tent of meeting with all the sacred vessels that were in the tent. The priests and Levites brought them up.
8:5 King Solomon and the entire community of Israel, gathered for the occasion before the ark, sacrificed sheep and oxen too many to number or count.
8:6 The priests brought the ark of the covenant of the to its place, the inner sanctuary of the house, the holy of holies, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
8:7 The cherubim had their wings spread out over the place of the ark, sheltering the ark and its poles from above.
8:8 The poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the holy place in front of the inner sanctuary. They cannot be seen from outside, but they remain there to this day.
8:9 There was nothing in the ark but the two stone tablets which Moses had put there at Horeb, when the made a covenant with the Israelites after they went forth from the land of Egypt.
8:10 When the priests left the holy place, the cloud filled the house of the
8:11 so that the priests could no longer minister because of the cloud, since the glory of the had filled the house of the .
8:12 Then Solomon said, The intends to dwell in the dark cloud;
8:13 I have indeed built you a princely house, the base for your enthronement forever.
8:14 The king turned and blessed the whole assembly of Israel, while the whole assembly of Israel stood.
8:15 He said: Blessed be the , the God of Israel, who with his own mouth spoke a promise to David my father and by his hand fulfilled it, saying:
8:16 Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city out of any tribe of Israel for the building of a house, that my name might be there; but I have chosen David to rule my people Israel.
8:17 When David my father wished to build a house for the name of the , the God of Israel,
8:18 the said to him: In wishing to build a house for my name, you did well.
8:19 But it is not you who will build the house, but your son, who comes from your loins; he shall build the house for my name.
8:20 Now the has fulfilled the word he spoke: I have succeeded David my father, and I sit on the throne of Israel, as the has spoken, and I have built this house for the name of the , the God of Israel.
8:21 I have provided there a place for the ark in which is the covenant of the that he made with our ancestors when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
8:22 Solomon stood before the altar of the in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel, and stretching forth his hands toward heaven,
8:23 he said, , God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven above or on earth below; you keep covenant and love toward your servants who walk before you with their whole heart,
8:24 the covenant that you kept toward your servant, David my father, what you promised him; your mouth has spoken and your hand has fulfilled this very day.
8:25 And now, , God of Israel, keep toward your servant, David my father, what you promised: There shall never be wanting someone from your line to sit before me on the throne of Israel, provided that your descendants keep to their way, walking before me as you have.
8:26 Now, God of Israel, may the words you spoke to your servant, David my father, be confirmed.
8:27 Is God indeed to dwell on earth? If the heavens and the highest heavens cannot contain you, how much less this house which I have built!
8:28 Regard kindly the prayer and petition of your servant, , my God, and listen to the cry of supplication which I, your servant, utter before you this day.
8:29 May your eyes be open night and day toward this house, the place of which you said, My name shall be there; listen to the prayer your servant makes toward this place.
8:30 Listen to the petition of your servant and of your people Israel which they offer toward this place. Listen, from the place of your enthronement, heaven, listen and forgive.
8:31 If someone sins in some way against a neighbor and is required to take an oath sanctioned by a curse, and comes and takes the oath before your altar in this house,
8:32 listen in heaven; act and judge your servants. Condemn the wicked, requiting their ways; acquit the just, rewarding their justice.
8:33 When your people Israel are defeated by an enemy because they sinned against you, and then they return to you, praise your name, pray to you, and entreat you in this house,
8:34 listen in heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land you gave their ancestors.
