19:18 They gave their gods to the fire—they were not gods at all, but the work of human hands—wood and stone, they destroyed them.
19:19 Therefore, , our God, save us from this mans power, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone, , are God.
19:20 Then Isaiah, son of Amoz, sent this message to Hezekiah: Thus says the , the God of Israel, to whom you have prayed concerning Sennacherib, king of Assyria: I have listened!
19:21 This is the word the has spoken concerning him: She despises you, laughs you to scorn, the virgin daughter Zion! Behind you she wags her head, daughter Jerusalem.
19:22 Whom have you insulted and blasphemed, at whom have you raised your voice And lifted up your eyes on high? At the Holy One of Israel!
19:23 Through the mouths of your messengers you insulted the Lord when you said, With my many chariots I went up to the tops of the peaks, to the recesses of Lebanon, To cut down its lofty cedars, its choice cypresses; I reached to the farthest shelter, the forest ranges.
19:24 I myself dug wells and drank foreign waters, Drying up all the rivers of Egypt beneath the soles of my feet.
19:25 Have you not heard? A long time ago I prepared it, from days of old I planned it. Now I have brought it about: You are here to reduce fortified cities to heaps of ruins,
19:26 Their people powerless, dismayed and distraught. They are plants of the field, green growth, thatch on the rooftops, Grain scorched by the east wind.
19:27 I know when you stand or sit, when you come or go and how you rage against me.
19:28 Because you rage against me, and your smugness has reached my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, And make you leave by the way you came.
19:29 This shall be a sign for you: This year you shall eat the aftergrowth, next year, what grows of itself; But in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit!
19:30 The remaining survivors of the house of Judah shall again strike root below and bear fruit above.
19:31 For out of Jerusalem shall come a remnant, and from Mount Zion, survivors. The zeal of the of hosts shall do this.
19:32 Therefore, thus says the about the king: He shall not come as far as this city, nor shoot there an arrow, nor confront it with a shield, Nor cast up a siege-work against it.
19:33 By the way he came he shall leave, never coming as far as this city, oracle of the .
19:34 I will shield and save this city for my own sake and the sake of David my servant.
19:35 That night the angel of the went forth and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand men in the Assyrian camp. Early the next morning, there they were, dead, all those corpses!
19:36 So Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, broke camp, departed, returned home, and stayed in Nineveh.
19:37 When he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword and fled into the land of Ararat. His son Esarhaddon reigned in his place.
20:1 In those days, when Hezekiah was mortally ill, the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, came and said to him: Thus says the : Put your house in order, for you are about to die; you shall not recover.
20:2 He turned his face to the wall and prayed to the :
20:3 Ah, , remember how faithfully and wholeheartedly I conducted myself in your presence, doing what was good in your sight! And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
20:4 Before Isaiah had left the central courtyard, the word of the came to him:
20:5 Go back and tell Hezekiah, the leader of my people: Thus says the , the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Now I am healing you. On the third day you shall go up to the house of the .
20:6 I will add to your life fifteen years. I will rescue you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria; I will be a shield to this city for my own sake and the sake of David my servant.
20:7 Then Isaiah said, Bring a poultice of figs and apply it to the boil for his recovery.
20:8 Hezekiah asked Isaiah, What is the sign that the will heal me and that I shall go up to the house of the on the third day?
20:9 Isaiah replied, This will be the sign for you from the that he will carry out the word he has spoken: Shall the shadow go forward or back ten steps?
20:10 It is easy for the shadow to advance ten steps, Hezekiah answered. Rather, let it go back ten steps.
20:11 So Isaiah the prophet invoked the . He made the shadow go back the ten steps it had descended on the staircase to the terrace of Ahaz.
20:12 At that time, Berodach-baladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and gifts to Hezekiah when he heard that he had been ill.
20:13 Hezekiah listened to the envoys and then showed off his whole treasury: his silver, gold, spices and perfumed oil, his armory, and everything in his storerooms; there was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
20:14 Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and asked him: What did these men say to you? Where did they come from? Hezekiah replied, They came from a distant land, from Babylon.
20:15 He asked, What did they see in your house? Hezekiah answered, They saw everything in my house. There is nothing in my storerooms that I did not show them.
20:16 Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah: Hear the word of the :
20:17 The time is coming when all that is in your house, everything that your ancestors have stored up until this day, shall be carried off to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the .
20:18 Some of your own descendants, your offspring, your progeny, shall be taken and made attendants in the palace of the king of Babylon.
20:19 Hezekiah replied to Isaiah, The word of the which you have spoken is good. For he thought, There will be peace and stability in my lifetime.
20:20 The rest of the acts of Hezekiah, with all his valor, and how he constructed the pool and conduit and brought water into the city, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
20:21 Hezekiah rested with his ancestors, and his son Manasseh succeeded him as king.
21:1 Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Hephzibah.
21:2 He did what was evil in the s sight, following the abominable practices of the nations whom the had dispossessed before the Israelites.
21:3 He rebuilt the high places which Hezekiah his father had destroyed. He set up altars to Baal and also made an asherah, as Ahab, king of Israel, had done. He bowed down to the whole host of heaven and served them.
21:4 He built altars in the house of the , of which the had said: In Jerusalem I will set my name.
21:5 And he built altars for the whole host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the .
21:6 He immolated his child by fire. He practiced soothsaying and divination, and reintroduced the consulting of ghosts and spirits. He did much evil in the s sight and provoked him to anger.
21:7 The Asherah idol he had made, he placed in the s house, of which the had said to David and to his son Solomon: In this house and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I shall set my name forever.
21:8 I will no longer make Israel step out of the land I gave their ancestors, provided that they are careful to observe all I have commanded them and the entire law which Moses my servant enjoined upon them.
21:9 But they did not listen. Manasseh misled them into doing even greater evil than the nations the had destroyed at the coming of the Israelites.
21:10 Then the spoke through his servants the prophets:
21:11 Because Manasseh, king of Judah, has practiced these abominations, and has done greater evil than all that was done by the Amorites before him, and has led Judah into sin by his idols,
21:12 therefore, thus says the , the God of Israel: I am about to bring such evil on Jerusalem and Judah that, when any hear of it, their ears shall ring:
21:13 I will measure Jerusalem with the same cord as I did Samaria, and with the plummet I used for the house of Ahab. I will wipe Jerusalem clean as one wipes a dish, wiping it inside and out.
21:14 I will cast off the survivors of my inheritance. I will deliver them into enemy hands, to become prey and booty for all their enemies,
21:15 because they have done what is evil in my sight and provoked me from the day their ancestors came forth from Egypt until this very day.
21:16 Manasseh shed so much innocent blood that it filled the length and breadth of Jerusalem, in addition to the sin he caused Judah to commit by doing what was evil in the s sight.
21:17 The rest of the acts of Manasseh, with all that he did and the sin he committed, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
21:18 Manasseh rested with his ancestors; he was buried in his palace garden, the garden of Uzza, and his son Amon succeeded him as king.
21:19 Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Meshullemeth, daughter of Haruz, from Jotbah.
21:20 He did what was evil in the s sight, as his father Manasseh had done.
21:21 He walked in all the ways of his father; he served the idols his father had served, and bowed down to them.
21:22 He abandoned the , the God of his ancestors, and did not walk in the way of the .
21:23 Officials of Amon plotted against him and killed the king in his palace,
21:24 but the people of the land then slew all who had plotted against King Amon, and the people of the land made his son Josiah king in his stead.
21:25 The rest of the acts of Amon, which he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
21:26 He was buried in his own grave in the garden of Uzza, and his son Josiah succeeded him as king.
22:1 Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Jedidah, daughter of Adaiah, from Bozkath.
22:2 He did what was right in the s sight, walking in the way of David his father, not turning right or left.
22:3 In his eighteenth year, King Josiah sent the scribe Shaphan, son of Azaliah, son of Meshullam, to the house of the with these orders:
22:4 Go to the high priest Hilkiah and have him calculate the valuables that have been brought to the house of the , which the doorkeepers have collected from the people.
22:5 Then have him turn them over to the master workers in the house of the , and have them give them to the ordinary workers who are in the house of the to repair its breaches:
22:6 to the carpenters, the builders, and the masons, and to purchase wood and hewn stone.
22:7 No reckoning shall be asked of them regarding the funds provided to them, because they hold positions of trust.
22:8 The high priest Hilkiah informed the scribe Shaphan, I have found the book of the law in the temple of the . Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, who read it.
22:9 Then the scribe Shaphan went to the king and reported, Your servants have smelted down the silver deposited in the temple and have turned it over to the master workers in the house of the .
22:10 The scribe Shaphan also informed the king, Hilkiah the priest has given me a book, and then Shaphan read it in the presence of the king.
22:11 When the king heard the words of the book of the law, he tore his garments.
22:12 The king then issued this command to Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, son of Shaphan, Achbor, son of Micaiah, Shaphan the scribe, and Asaiah the kings servant:
22:13 Go, consult the for me, for the people, and for all Judah, about the words of this book that has been found, for the rage of the has been set furiously ablaze against us, because our ancestors did not obey the words of this book, nor do what is written for us.
22:14 So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to Huldah the prophet, wife of Shallum, son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe; she lived in Jerusalem, in the Second Quarter. When they had spoken to her,
22:15 she said to them, Thus says the , the God of Israel: Say to the man who sent you to me,
22:16 Thus says the : I am about to bring evil upon this place and upon its inhabitants—all the words of the book which the king of Judah has read.
22:17 Because they have abandoned me and have burned incense to other gods, provoking me by all the works of their hands, my rage is ablaze against this place and it cannot be extinguished.
22:18 But to the king of Judah who sent you to consult the , give this response: Thus says the , the God of Israel: As for the words you have heard,
22:19 because you were heartsick and have humbled yourself before the when you heard what I have spoken concerning this place and its inhabitants, that they would become a desolation and a curse; and because you tore your garments and wept before me, I in turn have heard, oracle of the .
22:20 I will therefore gather you to your ancestors; you shall go to your grave in peace, and your eyes shall not see all the evil I am about to bring upon this place. This they reported to the king.
23:1 The king then had all the elders of Judah and of Jerusalem summoned before him.
23:2 The king went up to the house of the with all the people of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem: priests, prophets, and all the people, great and small. He read aloud to them all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the house of the .
23:3 The king stood by the column and made a covenant in the presence of the to follow the and to observe his commandments, statutes, and decrees with his whole heart and soul, and to re-establish the words of the covenant written in this book. And all the people stood by the covenant.
23:4 Then the king commanded the high priest Hilkiah, his assistant priests, and the doorkeepers to remove from the temple of the all the objects that had been made for Baal, Asherah, and the whole host of heaven. These he burned outside Jerusalem on the slopes of the Kidron; their ashes were carried to Bethel.
23:5 He also put an end to the idolatrous priests whom the kings of Judah had appointed to burn incense on the high places in the cities of Judah and in the vicinity of Jerusalem, as well as those who burned incense to Baal, to the sun, moon, and signs of the zodiac, and to the whole host of heaven.
23:6 From the house of the he also removed the Asherah to the Wadi Kidron, outside Jerusalem; he burned it and beat it to dust, in the Wadi Kidron, and scattered its dust over the graveyard of the people of the land.
23:7 He tore down the apartments of the cult prostitutes in the house of the , where the women wove garments for the Asherah.
23:8 He brought in all the priests from the cities of Judah, and then defiled, from Geba to Beer-sheba, the high places where they had offered incense. He also tore down the high places of the gates, which were at the entrance of the Gate of Joshua, governor of the city, north of the city gate.
23:9 (The priests of the high places could not function at the altar of the in Jerusalem; but they, along with their relatives, ate the unleavened bread.)
23:10 The king also defiled Topheth in the Valley of Ben-hinnom, so that there would no longer be any immolation of sons or daughters by fire in honor of Molech.
23:11 He did away with the horses which the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun; these were at the entrance of the house of the , near the chamber of Nathan-melech the official, which was in the large building. The chariots of the sun he destroyed by fire.
23:12 He also demolished the altars made by the kings of Judah on the roof (the roof terrace of Ahaz), and the altars made by Manasseh in the two courts of the s house. He pulverized them and threw the dust into the Wadi Kidron.
23:13 The king defiled the high places east of Jerusalem, south of the Mount of the Destroyer, which Solomon, king of Israel, had built in honor of Astarte, the Sidonian horror, of Chemosh, the Moabite horror, and of Milcom, the Ammonites abomination.
23:14 He broke to pieces the pillars, cut down the asherahs, and filled the places where they had been with human bones.
23:15 Likewise the altar which was at Bethel, the high place built by Jeroboam, son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin—this same altar and high place he tore down and burned, grinding the high place to powder and burning the asherah.
23:16 When Josiah turned and saw the graves there on the mountainside, he ordered the bones taken from the graves and burned on the altar, and thus defiled it, according to the s word proclaimed by the man of God as Jeroboam stood by the altar on the feast day. When the king looked up and saw the grave of the man of God who had proclaimed these words,
23:17 he asked, What is that marker I see? The people of the city replied, The grave of the man of God who came from Judah and proclaimed the very things you have done to the altar in Bethel.
23:18 Let him be, he said, let no one move his bones. So they left his bones undisturbed together with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
23:19 Josiah also removed all the temples on the high places in the cities of Samaria which the kings of Israel had built, provoking the ; he did the very same to them as he had done in Bethel.
23:20 He slaughtered upon the altars all the priests of the high places that were there, and burned human bones upon them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
23:21 The king issued a command to all the people: Observe the Passover of the , your God, as it is written in this book of the covenant.
23:22 No Passover such as this had been observed during the period when the judges ruled Israel, or during the entire period of the kings of Israel and the kings of Judah,
23:23 until the eighteenth year of King Josiah, when this Passover of the was kept in Jerusalem.
23:24 Further, Josiah purged the consultation of ghosts and spirits, with the household gods, idols, and all the other horrors to be seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem, so that he might carry out the words of the law that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest had found in the house of the .
23:25 Before him there had been no king who turned to the as he did, with his whole heart, his whole being, and his whole strength, in accord with the entire law of Moses; nor did any king like him arise after him.
23:26 Yet the did not turn from his fiercely burning anger against Judah, because of all the provocations that Manasseh had given.
23:27 The said: Even Judah will I put out of my sight as I did Israel. I will reject this city, Jerusalem, which I chose, and the house of which I said: There shall my name be.
23:28 The rest of the acts of Josiah, with all that he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
23:29 In his time Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, went up toward the Euphrates River against the king of Assyria. King Josiah set out to meet him, but was slain at Megiddo at the first encounter.
23:30 His servants brought his body on a chariot from Megiddo to Jerusalem, where they buried him in his own grave. Then the people of the land took Jehoahaz, son of Josiah, anointed him, and proclaimed him king to succeed his father.
23:31 Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
23:32 He did what was evil in the s sight, just as his ancestors had done.
23:33 Pharaoh Neco took him prisoner at Riblah in the land of Hamath, thus ending his reign in Jerusalem. He imposed a fine upon the land of a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
23:34 Pharaoh Neco then made Eliakim, son of Josiah, king in place of Josiah his father; he changed his name to Jehoiakim. Jehoahaz he took away with him to Egypt, where he died.
23:35 Jehoiakim gave the silver and gold to Pharaoh, but taxed the land to raise the amount Pharaoh demanded. He exacted the silver and gold from the people of the land, from each proportionately, to pay Pharaoh Neco.
23:36 Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Zebidah, daughter of Pedaiah, from Rumah.
23:37 He did what was evil in the s sight, just as his ancestors had done.
24:1 During Jehoiakims reign Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, attacked, and Jehoiakim became his vassal for three years. Then Jehoiakim turned and rebelled against him.
24:2 The loosed against him bands of Chaldeans, Arameans, Moabites, and Ammonites; he unleashed them against Judah to destroy him, according to the s word spoken through his servants the prophets.
24:3 This befell Judah because the had stated that he would put them out of his sight for the sins Manasseh had committed in all that he did,
24:4 and especially because of the innocent blood he shed; he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the would not forgive.
24:5 The rest of the acts of Jehoiakim, with all that he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
24:6 Jehoiakim rested with his ancestors, and his son Jehoiachin succeeded him as king.
24:7 The king of Egypt did not again leave his own land, for the king of Babylon had taken all that belonged to the king of Egypt from the wadi of Egypt to the Euphrates River.
24:8 Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Nehushta, daughter of Elnathan, from Jerusalem.
24:9 He did what was evil in the s sight, just as his father had done.
24:10 At that time officers of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, attacked Jerusalem, and the city came under siege.
24:11 Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, himself arrived at the city while his officers were besieging it.
24:12 Then Jehoiachin, king of Judah, together with his mother, his ministers, officers, and functionaries, surrendered to the king of Babylon, who, in the eighth year of his reign, took him captive.
24:13 He carried off all the treasures of the house of the and the treasures of the kings house, and broke up all the gold utensils that Solomon, king of Israel, had provided in the house of the , as the had decreed.
24:14 He deported all Jerusalem: all the officers and warriors of the army, ten thousand in number, and all the artisans and smiths. Only the lowliest of the people of the land were left.
24:15 He deported Jehoiachin to Babylon, and the kings mother, his wives, his functionaries, and the chiefs of the land he led captive from Jerusalem to Babylon.
24:16 All seven thousand soldiers of the army, and a thousand artisans and smiths, all of them trained warriors, these too the king of Babylon brought captive to Babylon.
24:17 In place of Jehoiachin the king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachins uncle, king; he changed his name to Zedekiah.
24:18 Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
24:19 He did what was evil in the sight of the , just as Jehoiakim had done.
24:20 This befell Jerusalem and Judah because the was so angry that he cast them out of his sight. Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
25:1 In the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiahs reign, on the tenth day of the month, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his whole army advanced against Jerusalem, encamped around it, and built siege walls on every side.
25:2 The siege of the city continued until the eleventh year of Zedekiah.
25:3 On the ninth day of the month, when famine had gripped the city, and the people of the land had no more food,
25:4 the city walls were breached. That night, all the soldiers came to the gate between the two walls near the kings garden (the Chaldeans had the city surrounded), while the king went toward the Arabah.
25:5 But the Chaldean army pursued the king and overtook him in the desert near Jericho, abandoned by his whole army.
25:6 The king was therefore arrested and brought to Riblah to the king of Babylon, who pronounced sentence on him.
25:7 They slew Zedekiahs sons before his eyes; then they put out his eyes, bound him with fetters, and brought him to Babylon.
25:8 On the seventh day of the fifth month (this was in the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon), Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, came to Jerusalem as the agent of the king of Babylon.
25:9 He burned the house of the , the house of the king, and all the houses of Jerusalem (every noble house); he destroyed them by fire.
25:10 The Chaldean troops who were with the captain of the guard tore down the walls that surrounded Jerusalem,
25:11 and Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, led into exile the last of the army remaining in the city, and those who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and the last of the commoners.
25:12 But some of the countrys poor the captain of the guard left behind as vinedressers and farmers.
25:13 The bronze columns that belonged to the house of the , and the stands and the bronze sea in the house of the , the Chaldeans broke into pieces; they carried away the bronze to Babylon.
25:14 They took also the pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the cups and all the bronze articles used for service.
25:15 The fire pans and the bowls that were of solid gold or silver the captain of the guard also carried off.
25:16 The two columns, the one bronze sea, and the stands, which Solomon had made for the house of the —the weight in bronze of all these articles was never calculated.
25:17 Each of the columns was eighteen cubits high; a bronze capital three cubits high surmounted each column, and a netting with pomegranates encircled the capital, all of bronze; and they were duplicated on the other column, on the netting.
25:18 The captain of the guard also took Seraiah, the chief priest, Zephaniah, an assistant priest, and the three doorkeepers.
25:19 And from the city he took one officer who was a commander of soldiers, five courtiers in the personal service of the king who were still in the city, the scribe in charge of the army who mustered the people of the land, and sixty of the people of the land still remaining in the city.
25:20 The captain of the guard, Nebuzaradan, arrested these and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah, and
25:21 the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death in Riblah, in the land of Hamath. And thus Judah went into exile from their native soil.
25:22 As for the people whom he had allowed to remain in the land of Judah, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, appointed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, over them.
25:23 Hearing that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah over them, all the army commanders and the troops came to him at Mizpah: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, Johanan, son of Kareah, Seraiah, son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah, son of the Maakite, each with his troops.
25:24 Gedaliah gave the commanders and their troops his oath. He said to them, Do not be afraid of the Chaldean officials. Remain in the country and serve the king of Babylon, so that all will be well with you.
25:25 But in the seventh month Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of royal descent, came with ten others, attacked Gedaliah and killed him, along with the Judahites and Chaldeans who were in Mizpah with him.
25:26 Then all the people, great and small, left with the army commanders and went to Egypt for fear of the Chaldeans.
25:27 In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, on the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month, Evil-merodach, king of Babylon, in the inaugural year of his own reign, raised up Jehoiachin, king of Judah, from prison.
25:28 He spoke kindly to him and gave him a throne higher than that of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
25:29 Jehoiachin took off his prison garb; he ate regularly in the kings presence as long as he lived;
25:30 and for his allowance the king granted him a regular allowance, in fixed daily amounts, for as long as he lived.
1 CHRONICLES
1:1 Adam, Seth, Enosh,
1:2 Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
1:3 Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
1:4 Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1:5 The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
1:6 The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
1:7 The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, the Kittim, and the Rodanim.
1:8 The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
1:9 The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. The sons of Raama were Sheba and Dedan.
1:10 Cush became the father of Nimrod, who was the first to be a warrior on the earth.
1:11 Mizraim became the father of the Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
1:12 Pathrusim, Casluhim, and Caphtorim, from whom the Philistines sprang.
1:13 Canaan became the father of Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth,
1:14 and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
1:15 the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
1:16 the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
1:17 The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram. The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
1:18 Arpachshad became the father of Shelah, and Shelah became the father of Eber.
1:19 Two sons were born to Eber; the first was named Peleg (for in his time the world was divided), and his brother was named Joktan.
1:20 Joktan became the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
1:21 Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
1:22 Ebal, Abimael, Sheba,
1:23 Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab; all these were the sons of Joktan.
1:24 Shem, Arpachshad, Shelah,
1:25 Eber, Peleg, Reu,
1:26 Serug, Nahor, Terah,
1:27 Abram, that is, Abraham.
1:28 The sons of Abraham were Isaac and Ishmael.
1:29 These were their generations: Nebaioth, the firstborn of Ishmael, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
1:30 Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
1:31 Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were the sons of Ishmael.
1:32 The sons of Keturah, Abrahams concubine: she bore Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. The sons of Jokshan were Sheba and Dedan.
1:33 The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the sons of Keturah.
1:34 Abraham begot Isaac. The sons of Isaac were Esau and Israel.
1:35 The descendants of Esau were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
1:36 The descendants of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.
1:37 The descendants of Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
1:38 The sons of Seir were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
1:39 The sons of Lotan were Hori and Homam; Timna was the sister of Lotan.
1:40 The sons of Shobal were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. The sons of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah.
1:41 The sons of Anah: Dishon. The sons of Dishon were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
1:42 The sons of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan. The sons of Dishan were Uz and Aran.
1:43 The kings who reigned in the land of Edom before the Israelites had kings were the following: Bela, son of Beor, the name of whose city was Dinhabah.
1:44 When Bela died, Jobab, son of Zerah, from Bozrah, succeeded him as king.
1:45 When Jobab died, Husham, from the land of the Temanites, succeeded him as king.
1:46 Husham died and Hadad, son of Bedad, succeeded him as king. He overthrew the Midianites on the Moabite plateau, and the name of his city was Avith.
1:47 Hadad died and Samlah of Masrekah succeeded him as king.
1:48 Samlah died and Shaul from Rehoboth on the Euphrates succeeded him as king.
1:49 When Shaul died, Baalhanan, son of Achbor, succeeded him as king.
1:50 Baalhanan died and Hadad succeeded him as king. The name of his city was Pai, and his wifes name was Mehetabel. She was the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Mezahab.
1:51 After Hadad died, there were chiefs in Edom: the chiefs of Timna, Aliah, Jetheth,
1:52 Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
1:53 Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
1:54 Magdiel, and Iram were the chiefs of Edom.
2:1 These were the sons of Israel: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
2:2 Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
2:3 The sons of Judah were: Er, Onan, and Shelah; these three Bathshua, a Canaanite woman, bore to him. But Judahs firstborn, Er, was wicked in the sight of the , so he took his life.
2:4 Judahs daughter-in-law Tamar bore him Perez and Zerah, so that he had five sons in all.
2:5 The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
2:6 The sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Darda—five in all.
2:7 The sons of Zimri: Carmi. The sons of Carmi: Achar, who brought trouble upon Israel by violating the ban.
2:8 The sons of Ethan: Azariah.
2:9 The sons born to Hezron were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.
2:10 Ram became the father of Amminadab, and Amminadab became the father of Nahshon, a prince of the Judahites.
2:11 Nahshon became the father of Salmah. Salmah became the father of Boaz.
2:12 Boaz became the father of Obed. Obed became the father of Jesse.
2:13 Jesse became the father of Eliab, his firstborn, of Abinadab, the second son, Shimea, the third,
2:14 Nethanel, the fourth, Raddai, the fifth,
2:15 Ozem, the sixth, and David, the seventh.
2:16 Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah had three sons: Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
2:17 Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.
2:18 By his wife Azubah, Caleb, son of Hezron, became the father of a daughter, Jerioth. Her sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
2:19 When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.
2:20 Hur became the father of Uri, and Uri became the father of Bezalel.
2:21 Then Hezron had relations with the daughter of Machir, the father of Gilead, whom he married when he was sixty years old. She bore him Segub.
2:22 Segub became the father of Jair, who possessed twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead.
2:23 Geshur and Aram took from them the villages of Jair, that is, Kenath and its towns, sixty cities in all, which had belonged to the sons of Machir, the father of Gilead.
2:24 After the death of Hezron, Caleb had relations with Ephrathah, the widow of his father Hezron, and she bore him Ashhur, the father of Tekoa.
2:25 The sons of Jerahmeel, the firstborn of Hezron, were Ram, the firstborn, then Bunah, Oren, and Ozem, his brothers.
2:26 Jerahmeel also had another wife, named Atarah, who was the mother of Onam.
2:27 The sons of Ram, the firstborn of Jerahmeel, were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
2:28 The sons of Onam were Shammai and Jada. The sons of Shammai were Nadab and Abishur.
2:29 Abishurs wife, who was named Abihail, bore him Ahban and Molid.
2:30 The sons of Nadab were Seled and Appaim. Seled died childless.
2:31 The sons of Appaim: Ishi. The sons of Ishi: Sheshan. The sons of Sheshan: Ahlai.
2:32 The sons of Jada, the brother of Shammai, were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died childless.
2:33 The sons of Jonathan were Peleth and Zaza. These were the sons of Jerahmeel.
2:34 Sheshan had no sons, only daughters; he had an Egyptian slave named Jarha.
2:35 Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his slave Jarha, and she bore him Attai.
2:36 Attai became the father of Nathan. Nathan became the father of Zabad.
2:37 Zabad became the father of Ephlal. Ephlal became the father of Obed.
2:38 Obed became the father of Jehu. Jehu became the father of Azariah.
2:39 Azariah became the father of Helez. Helez became the father of Eleasah.
2:40 Eleasah became the father of Sismai. Sismai became the father of Shallum.
2:41 Shallum became the father of Jekamiah. Jekamiah became the father of Elishama.
2:42 The sons of Caleb, the brother of Jerahmeel: Mesha his firstborn, who was the father of Ziph. Then the sons of Mareshah, who was the father of Hebron.
2:43 The sons of Hebron were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
2:44 Shema became the father of Raham, who was the father of Jorkeam. Rekem became the father of Shammai.
2:45 The son of Shammai: Maon, who was the father of Beth-zur.
2:46 Ephah, Calebs concubine, bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran became the father of Gazez.
2:47 The sons of Jahdai were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
2:48 Maacah, Calebs concubine, bore Sheber and Tirhanah.
2:49 She also bore Shaaph, the father of Madmannah, Sheva, the father of Machbenah, and the father of Gibea. Achsah was Calebs daughter.
2:50 These were sons of Caleb, sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah: Shobal, the father of Kiriath-jearim,
2:51 Salma, the father of Bethlehem, and Hareph, the father of Bethgader.
2:52 The sons of Shobal, the father of Kiriath-jearim, were Reaiah, half of the Manahathites,
2:53 and the clans of Kiriath-jearim: the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites. From these the Zorahites and the Eshtaolites derived.
2:54 The sons of Salma were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-Joab, half of the Manahathites, and the Zorites.
2:55 The clans of the Sopherim dwelling in Jabez were the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. They were the Kenites, who descended from Hammath, the ancestor of the Rechabites.
3:1 These were the sons of David born to him in Hebron: the firstborn, Amnon, by Ahinoam of Jezreel; the second, Daniel, by Abigail of Carmel;
3:2 the third, Absalom, son of Maacah, who was the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur; the fourth, Adonijah, son of Haggith;
3:3 the fifth, Shephatiah, by Abital; the sixth, Ithream, by his wife Eglah.
3:4 Six in all were born to him in Hebron, where he reigned seven years and six months. Then he reigned thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
3:5 In Jerusalem the following were born to him: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon—four by Bathsheba, the daughter of Ammiel;
3:6 Ibhar, Elishua, Eliphelet,
3:7 Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
3:8 Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet—nine.
3:9 All these were sons of David, in addition to other sons by concubines; and Tamar was their sister.
3:10 The son of Solomon was Rehoboam, whose son was Abijah, whose son was Asa, whose son was Jehoshaphat,
3:11 whose son was Joram, whose son was Ahaziah, whose son was Joash,
3:12 whose son was Amaziah, whose son was Azariah, whose son was Jotham,
3:13 whose son was Ahaz, whose son was Hezekiah, whose son was Manasseh,
3:14 whose son was Amon, whose son was Josiah.
3:15 The sons of Josiah were: the firstborn Johanan; the second, Jehoiakim; the third, Zedekiah; the fourth, Shallum.
3:16 The sons of Jehoiakim were: Jeconiah, his son; Zedekiah, his son.
3:17 The sons of Jeconiah the captive were: Shealtiel,
3:18 Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
3:19 The sons of Pedaiah were Zerubbabel and Shimei. The sons of Zerubbabel were Meshullam and Hananiah; Shelomith was their sister.
3:20 The sons of Meshullam were Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, Jushabhesed—five.
3:21 The sons of Hananiah were Pelatiah, Jeshaiah, Rephaiah, Arnan, Obadiah, and Shecaniah.
3:22 The sons of Shecaniah were Shemaiah, Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, Shaphat—six.
3:23 The sons of Neariah were Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam—three.
3:24 The sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani—seven.
4:1 The sons of Judah were: Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
4:2 Reaiah, the son of Shobal, became the father of Jahath, and Jahath became the father of Ahumai and Lahad. These were the clans of the Zorathites.
4:3 These were the sons of Hareph, the father of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash; their sister was named Hazzelelponi.
4:4 Penuel was the father of Gedor, and Ezer the father of Hushah. These were the sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah, the father of Bethlehem.
4:5 Ashhur, the father of Tekoa, had two wives, Helah and Naarah.
4:6 Naarah bore him Ahuzzam, Hepher, the Temenites, and the Ahashtarites. These were the sons of Naarah.
4:7 The sons of Helah were Zereth, Izhar, Ethnan, and Koz.
4:8 Koz became the father of Anub and Zobebah, as well as of the clans of Aharhel, son of Harum.
4:9 Jabez was the most distinguished of his brothers. His mother had named him Jabez, saying, I bore him with pain.
4:10 Jabez prayed to the God of Israel: Oh, that you may truly bless me and extend my boundaries! May your hand be with me and make me free of misfortune, without pain! And God granted his prayer.
4:11 Chelub, the brother of Shuhah, became the father of Mehir, who was the father of Eshton.
4:12 Eshton became the father of Bethrapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah, the father of the city of Nahash. These were the men of Recah.
4:13 The sons of Kenaz were Othniel and Seraiah. The sons of Othniel were Hathath and Meonothai;
4:14 Meonothai became the father of Ophrah. Seraiah became the father of Joab, the father of Geharashim, so called because they were artisans.
4:15 The sons of Caleb, son of Jephunneh, were Ir, Elah, and Naam. The sons of Elah: Kenaz.
4:16 The sons of Jehallelel were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
4:17 The sons of Ezrah were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Jether became the father of Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah, the father of Eshtemoa.
4:18 Mereds Egyptian wife bore Jered, the father of Gedor, Heber, the father of Soco, and Jekuthiel, the father of Zanoah. These were the sons of Bithiah, the daughter of Pharaoh, whom Mered married.
4:19 The sons of his Jewish wife, the sister of Naham, the father of Keilah, were Shimon the Garmite and Ishi the Maacathite.
4:20 The sons of Shimon were Amnon, Rinnah, Benhanan, and Tilon. The son of Ishi was Zoheth and the son of Zoheth.
4:21 The sons of Shelah, son of Judah, were: Er, the father of Lecah; Laadah, the father of Mareshah; the clans of the linen weavers guild in Bethashbea;
4:22 Jokim; the people of Cozeba; and Joash and Saraph, who held property in Moab, but returned to Bethlehem. (These are events of old.)
4:23 They were potters and inhabitants of Netaim and Gederah, where they lived in the kings service.
4:24 The sons of Simeon were Nemuel, Jamin, Jachin, Zerah, and Shaul,
4:25 whose son was Shallum, whose son was Mibsam, whose son was Mishma.
4:26 The sons of Mishma were his son Hammuel, whose son was Zaccur, whose son was Shimei.
4:27 Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters. His brothers, however, did not have many sons, and as a result all their clans did not equal the number of the Judahites.
4:28 They dwelt in Beer-sheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
4:29 Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad,
4:30 Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag,
4:31 Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Bethbiri, and Shaaraim. Until the reign of David, these were their cities
4:32 and their villages. Etam, also, and Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan—five cities,
4:33 together with all their outlying villages as far as Baal. Here is where they dwelt, and so it was inscribed of them in their family records.
4:34 Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah, son of Amaziah,
4:35 Joel, Jehu, son of Joshibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel,
4:36 Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
4:37 Ziza, son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah—
4:38 these just named were princes in their clans, and their ancestral houses spread out to such an extent
4:39 that they went to the approaches of Gedor, east of the valley, seeking pasture for their flocks.
4:40 They found abundant and good pastures, and the land was spacious, quiet, and peaceful—for the Hamites dwelt there formerly.
4:41 They who have just been listed by name set out during the reign of Hezekiah, king of Judah, and attacked their tents and also the Meunites who were there. They put them under the ban that is still in force to this day and dwelt in their place because they found pasture there for their flocks.
4:42 Five hundred of them (the Simeonites) went to Mount Seir, with Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel, sons of Ishi, at their head.
4:43 They attacked the surviving Amalekites who had escaped, and have lived there to the present day.
5:1 The sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel. (He was indeed the firstborn, but because he defiled the couch of his father his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph, son of Israel, so that he is not listed in the family records according to his birthright.
5:2 Judah, in fact, became powerful among his brothers, so that the ruler came from him, though the birthright had been Josephs.)
5:3 The sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
5:4 His son was Joel, whose son was Shemaiah, whose son was Gog, whose son was Shimei,
5:5 whose son was Micah, whose son was Reaiah, whose son was Baal,
5:6 whose son was Beerah, whom Tilgath-pileser, the king of Assyria, took into exile; he was a prince of the Reubenites.
5:7 His brothers who belonged to his clans, when they were listed in the family records according to their descendants, were: Jeiel, the chief, and Zechariah,
5:8 and Bela, son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel. The Reubenites lived in Aroer and as far as Nebo and Baal-meon;
5:9 toward the east they dwelt as far as the wilderness which extends from the Euphrates River, for they had much livestock in the land of Gilead.
5:10 In Sauls time they waged war with the Hagrites, and when they had defeated them they dwelt in their tents throughout the region east of Gilead.
5:11 The Gadites lived alongside them in the land of Bashan as far as Salecah.
5:12 Joel was chief, Shapham was second in command, and Janai was judge in Bashan.
5:13 Their brothers, according to their ancestral houses, were: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber—seven.
5:14 These were the sons of Abihail, son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.
5:15 Ahi, son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was the head of their ancestral houses.
5:16 They dwelt in Gilead, in Bashan and its towns, and in all the pasture lands of Sirion to the borders.
5:17 All were listed in the family records in the time of Jotham, king of Judah, and of Jeroboam, king of Israel.
5:18 The Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh were warriors, men who bore shield and sword and who drew the bow, trained in warfare—forty-four thousand seven hundred and sixty men fit for military service.
5:19 When they waged war against the Hagrites and against Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab,
5:20 they received help so that the Hagrites and all who were with them were delivered into their power. For during the battle they cried out to God, and he heard them because they had put their trust in him.
5:21 Along with one hundred thousand persons they also captured their livestock: fifty thousand camels, two hundred fifty thousand sheep, and two thousand donkeys.
5:22 Many were slain and fell; for From God the victory. They dwelt in their place until the time of the exile.
5:23 The half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land of Bashan as far as Baal-hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon; they were numerous.
5:24 The following were the heads of their ancestral houses: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel—men who were warriors, famous men, and heads over their ancestral houses.
5:25 However, they acted treacherously toward the God of their ancestors by prostituting themselves to follow the gods of the peoples of the land, whom God had destroyed before them.
5:26 Therefore the God of Israel stirred up against them the anger of Pul, king of Assyria, and the anger of Tilgath-pilneser [], king of Assyria, who deported the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh and brought them to Halah, Habor, and Hara, and to the river Gozan, where they have remained to this day. 
5:27 The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
5:28 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
5:29 The children of Amram were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
5:30 Eleazar became the father of Phinehas. Phinehas became the father of Abishua.
5:31 Abishua became the father of Bukki. Bukki became the father of Uzzi.
5:32 Uzzi became the father of Zerahiah. Zerahiah became the father of Meraioth.
5:33 Meraioth became the father of Amariah. Amariah became the father of Ahitub.
5:34 Ahitub became the father of Zadok. Zadok became the father of Ahimaaz.
5:35 Ahimaaz became the father of Azariah. Azariah became the father of Johanan.
5:36 Johanan became the father of Azariah, who served as priest in the temple Solomon built in Jerusalem.
5:37 Azariah became the father of Amariah. Amariah became the father of Ahitub.
5:38 Ahitub became the father of Zadok. Zadok became the father of Shallum.
5:39 Shallum became the father of Hilkiah. Hilkiah became the father of Azariah.
5:40 Azariah became the father of Seraiah. Seraiah became the father of Jehozadak.
5:41 Jehozadak was one of those who went into the exile which the inflicted on Judah and Jerusalem through Nebuchadnezzar.
6:1 The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
6:2 The sons of Gershon were named Libni and Shimei.
6:3 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
6:4 The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These were the clans of Levi, according to their ancestors.
6:5 Of Gershon: his son Libni, whose son was Jahath, whose son was Zimmah,
6:6 whose son was Joah, whose son was Iddo, whose son was Zerah, whose son was Jetherai.
6:7 The sons of Kohath: his son Amminadab, whose son was Korah, whose son was Assir,
6:8 whose son was Elkanah, whose son was Ebiasaph, whose son was Assir,
6:9 whose son was Tahath, whose son was Uriel, whose son was Uzziah, whose son was Shaul.
6:10 The sons of Elkanah were Amasai and Ahimoth,
6:11 whose son was Elkanah, whose son was Zophai, whose son was Nahath,
6:12 whose son was Eliab, whose son was Jeroham, whose son was Elkanah, whose son was Samuel.
6:13 The sons of Samuel were Joel, the firstborn, and Abijah, the second.
6:14 The sons of Merari: Mahli, whose son was Libni, whose son was Shimei, whose son was Uzzah,
6:15 whose son was Shimea, whose son was Haggiah, whose son was Asaiah.
6:16 The following were established by David for the service of song in the s house at the time when the ark had a resting place.
6:17 They served as singers before the tabernacle of the tent of meeting until Solomon built the house of the in Jerusalem, and they performed their services according to the order prescribed for them.
6:18 Those who so performed are the following, together with their sons. Among the Kohathites: Heman, the chanter, son of Joel, son of Samuel,
6:19 son of Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Toah,
6:20 son of Zuph, son of Elkanah, son of Mahath, son of Amasi,
6:21 son of Elkanah, son of Joel, son of Azariah, son of Zephaniah,
6:22 son of Tahath, son of Assir, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah,
6:23 son of Izhar, son of Kohath, son of Levi, son of Israel.
6:24 His brother Asaph stood at his right hand. Asaph was the son of Berechiah, son of Shimea,
6:25 son of Michael, son of Baaseiah, son of Malchijah,
6:26 son of Ethni, son of Zerah, son of Adaiah,
6:27 son of Ethan, son of Zimmah, son of Shimei,
6:28 son of Jahath, son of Gershon, son of Levi.
6:29 Their brothers, the Merarites, stood at the left: Ethan, son of Kishi, son of Abdi, son of Malluch,
6:30 son of Hashabiah, son of Amaziah, son of Hilkiah,
6:31 son of Amzi, son of Bani, son of Shemer,
6:32 son of Mahli, son of Mushi, son of Merari, son of Levi.
6:33 Their brother Levites were appointed to all the other services of the tabernacle of the house of God.
6:34 However, it was Aaron and his sons who made the sacrifice on the altar for burnt offerings and on the altar of incense; they alone had charge of the holy of holies and of making atonement for Israel, as Moses, the servant of God, had commanded.
6:35 These were the sons of Aaron: his son Eleazar, whose son was Phinehas, whose son was Abishua,
6:36 whose son was Bukki, whose son was Uzzi, whose son was Zerahiah,
6:37 whose son was Meraioth, whose son was Amariah, whose son was Ahitub,
6:38 whose son was Zadok, whose son was Ahimaaz.
6:39 The following were their dwelling places, by encampments in their territories. To the sons of Aaron who belonged to the clan of the Kohathites, since the lot fell to them,
6:40 was assigned Hebron in the land of Judah, with its adjacent pasture lands.
6:41 However, the open country and the villages belonging to the city had been given to Caleb, the son of Jephunneh.
6:42 There were assigned to the sons of Aaron: Hebron a city of refuge, Libnah with its pasture lands, Jattir with its pasture lands, Eshtemoa with its pasture lands,
6:43 Holon with its pasture lands, Debir with its pasture lands,
6:44 Ashan with its pasture lands, Jetta with its pasture lands, and Beth-shemesh with its pasture lands.
6:45 Also from the tribe of Benjamin: Gibeon with its pasture lands, Geba with its pasture lands, Almon with its pasture lands, Anathoth with its pasture lands. In all, they had thirteen cities with their pasture lands.
6:49 The Israelites assigned these cities with their pasture lands to the Levites,
6:50 designating them by name and assigning them by lot from the tribes of the Judahites, Simeonites, and Benjaminites.
6:46 The other Kohathites obtained ten cities by lot for their clans from the tribe of Ephraim, from the tribe of Dan, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh.
6:47 The clans of the Gershonites obtained thirteen cities from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, and Naphtali, and from the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan.
6:48 The clans of the Merarites obtained twelve cities by lot from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
6:51 The clans of the Kohathites obtained cities by lot from the tribe of Ephraim.
6:52 They were assigned cities of refuge: Shechem in the mountain region of Ephraim, with its pasture lands, Gezer with its pasture lands,
6:53 Kibzaim with its pasture lands, and Beth-horon with its pasture lands.
6:54 From the tribe of Dan: Elteke with its pasture lands, Gibbethon with its pasture lands, Aijalon with its pasture lands, and Gath-rimmon with its pasture lands.
6:55 From the half-tribe of Manasseh: Taanach with its pasture lands and Ibleam with its pasture lands. These belonged to the rest of the Kohathite clan.
6:56 The clans of the Gershonites received from the half-tribe of Manasseh: Golan in Bashan with its pasture lands and Ashtaroth with its pasture lands.
6:57 From the tribe of Issachar: Kedesh with its pasture lands, Daberath with its pasture lands,
6:58 Ramoth with its pasture lands, and Engannim with its pasture lands.
6:59 From the tribe of Asher: Mashal with its pasture lands, Abdon with its pasture lands,
6:60 Hilkath with its pasture lands, and Rehob with its pasture lands.
6:61 From the tribe of Naphtali: Kedesh in Galilee with its pasture lands, Hammon with its pasture lands, and Kiriathaim with its pasture lands.
6:62 The rest of the Merarites received from the tribe of Zebulun: Jokneam with its pasture lands, Kartah with its pasture lands, Rimmon with its pasture lands, and Tabor with its pasture lands.
6:63 Across the Jordan at Jericho (that is, east of the Jordan) they received from the tribe of Reuben: Bezer in the desert with its pasture lands, Jahzah with its pasture lands,
6:64 Kedemoth with its pasture lands, and Mephaath with its pasture lands.
6:65 From the tribe of Gad: Ramoth in Gilead with its pasture lands, Mahanaim with its pasture lands,
6:66 Heshbon with its pasture lands, and Jazer with its pasture lands.
7:1 The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron: four.
7:2 The sons of Tola were Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Shemuel, heads of the ancestral houses of Tola, mighty warriors in their generations. In the time of David they numbered twenty-two thousand six hundred.
7:3 The sons of Uzzi: Izarahiah. The sons of Izarahiah were Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah. All five of these were chiefs.
7:4 Along with them, in their generations, according to ancestral houses, were thirty-six thousand men in organized military troops, since they had more wives and children
7:5 than their fellow tribesmen. In all the clans of Issachar there was a total of eighty-seven thousand warriors listed in their family records.
7:6 The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, and Jediael—three.
7:7 The sons of Bela were Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri—five. They were heads of their ancestral houses and warriors. Their family records listed twenty-two thousand and thirty-four.
7:8 The sons of Becher were Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth—all these were sons of Becher.
7:9 Their family records listed twenty thousand two hundred of their kindred who were heads of their ancestral houses and warriors.
7:10 The sons of Jediael: Bilhan. The sons of Bilhan were Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.
7:11 All these were sons of Jediael, heads of ancestral houses and warriors. They numbered seventeen thousand two hundred men fit for military service
7:12 Shupham and Hupham. The sons of Dan: Hushim.
7:13 The sons of Naphtali were Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum. These were sons of Bilhah.
7:14 The sons of Manasseh, whom his Aramean concubine bore: she bore Machir, the father of Gilead.
7:15 Machir took a wife whose name was Maacah; his sisters name was Molecheth. Manassehs second son was named Zelophehad, who had only daughters.
7:16 Maacah, Machirs wife, bore a son whom she named Peresh. He had a brother named Sheresh, whose sons were Ulam and Rakem.
7:17 The sons of Ulam: Bedan. These were the sons of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh.
7:18 His sister Molecheth bore Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.
7:19 The sons of Shemida were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.
7:20 The sons of Ephraim: Shuthelah, whose son was Bered, whose son was Tahath, whose son was Eleadah, whose son was Tahath,
7:21 whose son was Zabad. Ephraims son Shuthelah, and Ezer and Elead, who were born in the land, were killed by the inhabitants of Gath because they had gone down to take away their livestock.
7:22 Their father Ephraim mourned a long time, but after his relatives had come and comforted him,
7:23 he had relations with his wife, who conceived and bore a son whom he named Beriah, since evil had befallen his house.
7:24 He had a daughter, Sheerah, who built Lower and Upper Beth-horon and Uzzen-sheerah.
7:25 Zabads son was Rephah, whose son was Resheph, whose son was Telah, whose son was Tahan,
7:26 whose son was Ladan, whose son was Ammihud, whose son was Elishama,
7:27 whose son was Nun, whose son was Joshua.
7:28 Their property and their dwellings were in Bethel and its towns, Naaran to the east, Gezer and its towns to the west, and also Shechem and its towns as far as Ayyah and its towns.
7:29 Manasseh, however, had possession of Beth-shean and its towns, Taanach and its towns, Megiddo and its towns, and Dor and its towns. In these dwelt the sons of Joseph, the son of Israel.
7:30 The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah; their sister was Serah.
7:31 Beriahs sons were Heber and Malchiel, who was the father of Birzaith.
7:32 Heber became the father of Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their sister Shua.
7:33 The sons of Japhlet were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath; these were the sons of Japhlet.
7:34 The sons of Shomer were Ahi, Rohgah, Jehubbah, and Aram.
7:35 The sons of his brother Hotham were Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.
7:36 The sons of Zophah were Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah,
7:37 Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, and Beera.
7:38 The sons of Jether were Jephunneh, Pispa, and Ara.
7:39 The sons of Ulla were Arah, Hanniel, and Rizia.
7:40 All these were sons of Asher, heads of ancestral houses, distinguished men, warriors, and chiefs among the princes. Their family records numbered twenty-six thousand men fit for military service.
8:1 Benjamin became the father of Bela, his firstborn, Ashbel, the second son, Aharah, the third,
8:2 Nohah, the fourth, and Rapha, the fifth.
8:3 The sons of Bela were Addar and Gera, the father of Ehud.
8:4 The sons of Ehud were Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
8:5 Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
8:6 These were the sons of Ehud, family heads over those who dwelt in Geba and were deported to Manahath.
8:7 Also Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera. The last, who led them into exile, became the father of Uzza and Ahihud.
8:8 Shaharaim became a father on the Moabite plateau after he had put away his wives Hushim and Baara.
8:9 By his wife Hodesh he begot Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
8:10 Jeuz, Sachia, and Mirmah. These were his sons, family heads.
8:11 By Hushim he begot Abitub and Elpaal.
8:12 The sons of Elpaal were Eber, Misham, Shemed (who built Ono and Lod with its nearby towns),
8:13 and Beriah, and Shema. They were family heads of those who dwelt in Aijalon, and they put the inhabitants of Gath to flight.
8:14 Their relatives were Elpaal, Shashak, and Jeremoth.
8:15 Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
8:16 Michael, Ishpah, and Joha were the sons of Beriah.
8:17 Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
8:18 Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab were the sons of Elpaal.
8:19 Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi,
8:20 Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,
8:21 Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath were the sons of Shimei.
8:22 Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
8:23 Abdon, Zichri, Hanan,
8:24 Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
8:25 Iphdeiah, and Penuel were the sons of Shashak.
8:26 Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
8:27 Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zichri were the sons of Jeroham.
8:28 These were family heads in their generations, chiefs who dwelt in Jerusalem.
8:29 In Gibeon dwelt Jeiel, the founder of Gibeon, whose wifes name was Maacah;
8:30 also his firstborn son, Abdon, and Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
8:31 Gedor, Ahio, Zecher, and Mikloth.
8:32 Mikloth became the father of Shimeah. These, too, dwelt with their relatives in Jerusalem, opposite their fellow tribesmen.
8:33 Ner became the father of Kish, and Kish became the father of Saul. Saul became the father of Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
8:34 The son of Jonathan was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal became the father of Micah.
8:35 The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
8:36 Ahaz became the father of Jehoaddah, and Jehoaddah became the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri became the father of Moza.
8:37 Moza became the father of Binea, whose son was Raphah, whose son was Eleasah, whose son was Azel.
8:38 Azel had six sons, whose names were Azrikam, his firstborn, Ishmael, Sheariah, Azariah, Obadiah, and Hanan; all these were the sons of Azel.
8:39 The sons of Eshek, his brother, were Ulam, his firstborn, Jeush, the second son, and Eliphelet, the third.
8:40 The sons of Ulam were warriors, skilled with the bow, and they had many sons and grandsons: one hundred and fifty. All these were the sons of Benjamin.
9:1 Thus all Israel was listed in family lists, and these are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel. Now Judah had been exiled to Babylon because of its treachery.
9:2 The first to settle again in their cities and dwell there were certain Israelites, the priests, the Levites, and the temple servants.
9:3 In Jerusalem lived Judahites and Benjaminites; also Ephraimites and Manassites.
9:4 Among the Judahites was Uthai, son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani, one of the sons of Perez, son of Judah.
9:5 Among the Shelanites were Asaiah, the firstborn, and his sons.
9:6 Among the Zerahites were Jeuel and six hundred and ninety of their relatives.
9:7 Among the Benjaminites were Sallu, son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah,
9:8 as well as Ibneiah, son of Jeroham; Elah, son of Uzzi, son of Michri; Meshullam, son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah.
9:9 Their kindred of various families were nine hundred and fifty-six. All those named were heads of their ancestral houses.
9:10 Among the priests were Jedaiah; Jehoiarib; Jachin;
9:11 Azariah, son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, the ruler of the house of God;
9:12 Adaiah, son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah; Maasai, son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer.
9:13 Their brothers, heads of their ancestral houses, were one thousand seven hundred and sixty, valiant in the work of the service of the house of God.
9:14 Among the Levites were Shemaiah, son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, one of the sons of Merari;
9:15 Bakbakkar; Heresh; Galal; Mattaniah, son of Mica, son of Zichri, a descendant of Asaph;
9:16 Obadiah, son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, a descendant of Jeduthun; and Berechiah, son of Asa, son of Elkanah, whose family lived in the villages of the Netophathites.
9:17 The gatekeepers were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their brothers; Shallum was the chief.
9:18 Previously they had stood guard at the kings gate on the east side; now they became gatekeepers for the encampments of the Levites.
9:19 Shallum, son of Kore, son of Ebiasaph, a descendant of Korah, and his brothers of the same ancestral house of the Korahites had as their assigned task the guarding of the threshold of the tent, just as their fathers had guarded the entrance to the encampment of the .
9:20 Phinehas, son of Eleazar, had been their chief in times past; the was with him.
9:21 Zechariah, son of Meshelemiah, guarded the gate of the tent of meeting.
9:22 In all, those who were chosen for gatekeepers at the threshold were two hundred and twelve. They were inscribed in the family records of their villages. David and Samuel the seer had established them in their position of trust.
9:23 Thus they and their sons kept guard over the gates of the house of the , the house which was then a tent.
9:24 The gatekeepers were stationed at the four sides, to the east, the west, the north, and the south.
9:25 Their brothers who lived in their own villages took turns in assisting them for seven-day periods,
9:26 while the four chief gatekeepers were on permanent duty. These were the Levites who also had charge of the chambers and treasures of the house of God.
9:27 They would spend the night near the house of God, for it was in their charge and they had the duty of opening it each morning.
9:28 Some of them had charge of the vessels used there, tallying them as they were brought in and taken out.
9:29 Others were appointed to take care of the utensils and all the sacred vessels, as well as the fine flour, the wine, the oil, the frankincense, and the spices.
9:30 It was the sons of priests, however, who mixed the spiced ointments.
9:31 Mattithiah, one of the Levites, the firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, was entrusted with preparing the cakes.
9:32 Benaiah the Kohathite, one of their brothers, was in charge of setting out the showbread each sabbath.
9:33 These were the singers and the gatekeepers, family heads over the Levites. They stayed in the chambers when free of duty, for day and night they had to be ready for service.
9:34 These were the levitical family heads by their generations, chiefs who dwelt in Jerusalem.
9:35 Jeiel, the founder of Gibeon, dwelt in Gibeon; his wifes name was Maacah.
9:36 His firstborn son was Abdon; then came Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
9:37 Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
9:38 Mikloth became the father of Shimeam. These, too, with their relatives, dwelt opposite their relatives in Jerusalem.
9:39 Ner became the father of Kish, and Kish became the father of Saul. Saul became the father of Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
9:40 The son of Jonathan was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal became the father of Micah.
9:41 The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
9:42 Ahaz became the father of Jehoaddah, and Jehoaddah became the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri became the father of Moza.
9:43 Moza became the father of Binea, whose son was Rephaiah, whose son was Eleasah, whose son was Azel.
9:44 Azel had six sons, whose names were Azrikam, his firstborn, Ishmael, Sheariah, Azariah, Obadiah, and Hanan; these were the sons of Azel.
10:1 Now the Philistines went to war against Israel, and Israel fled before them, and they fell, slain on Mount Gilboa.
10:2 The Philistines pressed hard after Saul and his sons. When the Philistines had struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, sons of Saul,
10:3 the fury of the battle converged on Saul. Then the archers hit him, and he was severely wounded.
10:4 Saul said to his armor-bearer, Draw your sword and run me through; otherwise these uncircumcised will come and abuse me. But the armor-bearer, badly frightened, refused, so Saul took his own sword and fell upon it.
10:5 When the armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he too fell upon his sword and died.
10:6 Thus Saul, and his three sons, his whole house, died together.
10:7 When all the Israelites in the valley saw that Saul and his sons had fled and that they had died, they abandoned their cities and fled. Then the Philistines came and lived in those cities.
10:8 On the following day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, they found Saul and his sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
10:9 They stripped him, and took his head and his armor; these they sent throughout the land of the Philistines to bring the good news to their idols and to the people.
10:10 They put his armor in the temple of their gods, but his skull they impaled at the temple of Dagon.
10:11 When all the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard all that the Philistines had done to Saul,
10:12 all their warriors set out, recovered the corpses of Saul and his sons, and brought them to Jabesh. They buried their bones under the oak of Jabesh, and fasted for seven days.
10:13 Thus Saul died because of his treason against the in disobeying his word, and also because he had sought counsel from a ghost,
10:14 rather than from the . Therefore the took his life, and turned his kingdom over to David, the son of Jesse.
11:1 Then all Israel gathered around David in Hebron, and they said: Look! We are your bone and your flesh.
11:2 In days past, when Saul was still the king, it was you who led Israel in all its battles. And now the , your God, has said to you: You shall shepherd my people Israel; you shall be ruler over my people Israel.
11:3 Then all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and at Hebron David made a covenant with them in the presence of the ; and they anointed David king over Israel, in accordance with the word of the given through Samuel.
11:4 Then David and all Israel went to Jerusalem, that is, Jebus, where the inhabitants of the land were called Jebusites.
11:5 The inhabitants of Jebus said to David, You shall not enter here. David nevertheless captured the fortress of Zion, which is the City of David.
11:6 David said, Whoever strikes the Jebusites first shall be made chief and captain. Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the first to attack; and so he became chief.
11:7 David took up residence in the fortress, which therefore was called the City of David.
11:8 He built up the city on all sides, from the Millo all the way around, while Joab restored the rest of the city.
11:9 David became ever more powerful, for the of hosts was with him.
11:10 These were Davids chief warriors who, together with all Israel, supported him in his reign in order to make him king, according to the s word concerning Israel.
11:11 Here is the list of Davids warriors: Ishbaal, the son of Hachamoni, chief of the Three. He brandished his spear over three hundred, whom he had slain in a single encounter.
11:12 Next to him was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the Three warriors.
11:13 He was with David at Pas-dammim, where the Philistines had massed for battle. There was a plot of land full of barley. The people were fleeing before the Philistines,
11:14 but he took his stand in the middle of the plot, kept it safe, and cut down the Philistines. Thus the brought about a great victory.
11:15 Three of the Thirty chiefs went down to the rock, to David, who was in the cave of Adullam while the Philistines were encamped in the valley of Rephaim.
11:16 David was then in the stronghold, and a Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
11:17 David had a strong craving, and said, If only someone would give me a drink of water from the cistern by the gate of Bethlehem!
11:18 Thereupon the Three broke through the encampment of the Philistines, drew water from the cistern by the gate of Bethlehem, and carried it back to David. But David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out to the ,
11:19 saying, God forbid that I should do such a thing! Could I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives? For at the risk of their lives they brought it. So he refused to drink it. Such deeds as these the Three warriors performed.
11:20 Abishai, the brother of Joab, was the chief of the Thirty; he brandished his spear over three hundred, whom he had slain. He made a name beside the Three,
11:21 but was twice as famous as any of the Thirty, becoming their leader. However, he did not attain to the Three.
11:22 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, a valiant man of mighty deeds, from Kabzeel, killed the two sons of Ariel of Moab. Also, he went down and killed the lion in the cistern on a snowy day.
11:23 He likewise slew the Egyptian, a huge man five cubits tall. The Egyptian carried a spear that was like a weavers beam, but Benaiah came against him with a staff; he wrested the spear from the Egyptians hand, and killed him with that spear.
11:24 Such deeds as these Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, performed, and he made a name beside the Three warriors,
11:25 but was more famous than any of the Thirty. However, he did not attain to the Three. David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
11:26 Also these warriors: Asahel, the brother of Joab; Elhanan, son of Dodo, from Bethlehem;
11:27 Shammoth, from En-harod; Helez, from Beth-pelet;
11:28 Ira, son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa; Abiezer, from Anathoth;
11:29 Sibbecai, from Husha; Ilai, from Ahoh;
11:30 Maharai, from Netophah; Heled, son of Baanah, from Netophah;
11:31 Ithai, son of Ribai, from Gibeah of Benjamin; Benaiah, from Pirathon;
11:32 Hurai, from Nahale-gaash; Abiel, from Beth-arabah;
11:33 Azmaveth, from Bahurim; Eliahba, from Shaalbon;
11:34 Jashen the Gunite; Jonathan, son of Shagee the Hararite;
11:35 Ahiam, son of Sachar the Hararite; Elipheleth, son of
11:36 Ahasbai, from Beth-maacah; Ahijah, from Gilo;
11:37 Hezro, from Carmel; Naarai, the son of Ezbai;
11:38 Joel, brother of Nathan, from Rehob, the Gadite;
11:39 Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai, from Beeroth, the armor-bearer of Joab, son of Zeruiah;
11:40 Ira, from Jattir; Gareb, from Jattir;
11:41 Uriah the Hittite; Zabad, son of Ahlai,
11:42 and, in addition to the Thirty, Adina, son of Shiza, the Reubenite, chief of the tribe of Reuben;
11:43 Hanan, son of Maacah; Joshaphat the Mithnite;
11:44 Uzzia, the Ashterathite; Shama and Jeiel, sons of Hotham, from Aroer;
11:45 Jediael, son of Shimri, and Joha, his brother, the Tizite;
11:46 Eliel the Mahavite; Jeribai and Joshaviah, sons of Elnaam; Ithmah, from Moab;
11:47 Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobian.
12:1 The following men came to David in Ziklag while he was still under banishment from Saul, son of Kish; they, too, were among the warriors who helped him in his battles.
12:2 They were archers who could use either the right or the left hand, both in slinging stones and in shooting arrows with the bow. They were some of Sauls kinsmen, from Benjamin.
12:3 Ahiezer was their chief, along with Joash, both sons of Shemaah of Gibeah; also Jeziel and Pelet, sons of Azmaveth; Beracah; Jehu, from Anathoth;
12:4 Ishmaiah the Gibeonite, a warrior among the Thirty, and over the Thirty;
12:5 Jeremiah; Jahaziel; Johanan; Jozabad from Gederah;
12:6 Eluzai; Jerimoth; Bealiah; Shemariah; Shephatiah the Haruphite;
12:7 Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam, who were Korahites;
12:8 Joelah and Zebadiah, sons of Jeroham, from Gedor.
12:9 Some of the Gadites also went over to David when he was at the stronghold in the wilderness. They were valiant warriors, experienced soldiers equipped with shield and spear, fearsome as lions, swift as gazelles on the mountains.
12:10 Ezer was their chief, Obadiah was second, Eliab third,
12:11 Mishmannah fourth, Jeremiah fifth,
12:12 Attai sixth, Eliel seventh,
12:13 Johanan eighth, Elzabad ninth,
12:14 Jeremiah tenth, and Machbannai eleventh.
12:15 These Gadites were army commanders, the lesser over hundreds and the greater over thousands.
12:16 It was they who crossed over the Jordan in the first month, when it was overflowing both its banks, and chased away all who were in the valleys to the east and to the west.
12:17 Some Benjaminites and Judahites also came to David at the stronghold.
12:18 David went out to meet them and addressed them in these words: If you come peacefully, to help me, I am of a mind to have you join me. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies though my hands have done no wrong, may the God of our ancestors see and punish you.
12:19 Then a spirit clothed Amasai, the chief of the Thirty, and he answered David: We are yours, O David, we are with you, son of Jesse. Peace, peace to you, and peace to him who helps you; may your God be your helper! So David received them and placed them among the leaders of his troops.
12:20 Men from Manasseh also deserted to David when he came with the Philistines to battle against Saul. However, he did not help the Philistines, for their lords took counsel and sent him home, saying, At the cost of our heads he will desert to his master Saul.
12:21 As he was returning to Ziklag, therefore, these deserted to him from Manasseh: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai, chiefs of thousands of Manasseh.
12:22 They helped David by taking charge of his troops, for they were all warriors and became commanders of his army.
12:23 And from day to day men kept coming to Davids help until there was a vast encampment, like Gods own encampment.
12:24 This is the muster of the detachments of armed troops that came to David at Hebron to bring Sauls kingdom over to him, as the had ordained.
12:25 Judahites bearing shields and spears: six thousand eight hundred armed troops.
12:26 Of the Simeonites, warriors fit for battle: seven thousand one hundred.
12:27 Of the Levites: four thousand six hundred,
12:28 along with Jehoiada, leader of the line of Aaron, with another three thousand seven hundred,
12:29 and Zadok, a young warrior, with twenty-two princes of his fathers house.
12:30 Of the Benjaminites, the kinsmen of Saul: three thousand—until this time, most of them had kept their allegiance to the house of Saul.
12:31 Of the Ephraimites: twenty thousand eight hundred warriors, men renowned in their ancestral houses.
12:32 Of the half-tribe of Manasseh: eighteen thousand, designated by name to come and make David king.
12:33 Of the Issacharites, their chiefs who were endowed with an understanding of the times and who knew what Israel had to do: two hundred chiefs, together with all their kinsmen under their command.
12:34 From Zebulun, men fit for military service, set in battle array with every kind of weapon for war: fifty thousand men rallying with a single purpose.
12:35 From Naphtali: one thousand captains, and with them, armed with shield and lance, thirty-seven thousand men.
12:36 Of the Danites, set in battle array: twenty-eight thousand six hundred.
12:37 From Asher, fit for military service and set in battle array: forty thousand.
12:38 From the other side of the Jordan, of the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, men equipped with every kind of weapon of war: one hundred and twenty thousand.
12:39 All these soldiers, drawn up in battle order, came to Hebron with the resolute intention of making David king over all Israel. The rest of Israel was likewise of one mind to make David king.
12:40 They remained with David for three days, eating and drinking, for their relatives had prepared for them.
