12:41 Moreover, their neighbors from as far as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali came bringing food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen—provisions in great quantity of meal, pressed figs, raisins, wine, oil, oxen, and sheep. For there was rejoicing in Israel.
13:1 After David had taken counsel with his commanders of thousands and of hundreds, that is, with every leader,
13:2 he said to the whole assembly of Israel: If it seems good to you, and is so decreed by the our God, let us send to the rest of our kindred from all the districts of Israel, and also the priests and the Levites from their cities with pasture lands, that they may join us;
13:3 and let us bring the ark of our God here among us, for in the days of Saul we did not consult it.
13:4 And the whole assembly agreed to do it, for it seemed right in the eyes of all the people.
13:5 Then David assembled all Israel, from Shihor of Egypt to Lebo-hamath, to bring the ark of God from Kiriath-jearim.
13:6 David and all Israel went up to Baalah, that is, to Kiriath-jearim, of Judah, to bring up from there the ark of God, which was known by the name enthroned upon the cherubim.
13:7 They transported the ark of God on a new cart from the house of Abinadab; Uzzah and Ahio were guiding the cart,
13:8 while David and all Israel danced before God with all their might, with singing, and with lyres, harps, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.
13:9 As they reached the threshing floor of Chidon, Uzzah stretched out his hand to steady the ark, for the oxen were tipping it.
13:10 Then the became angry with Uzzah and struck him, because he had laid his hand on the ark; he died there in Gods presence.
13:11 David was angry because the s anger had broken out against Uzzah. Therefore that place has been called Perez-uzzah even to this day.
13:12 David was afraid of God that day, and he said, How can I bring in the ark of God to me?
13:13 Therefore he did not take the ark with him into the City of David, but deposited it instead at the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
13:14 The ark of God remained in the house of Obed-edom with his family for three months, and the blessed Obed-edoms household and all that he possessed.
14:1 Hiram, king of Tyre, sent envoys to David along with cedar wood, and masons and carpenters to build him a house.
14:2 David now knew that the had truly established him as king over Israel, for his kingdom was greatly exalted for the sake of his people Israel.
14:3 David took other wives in Jerusalem and became the father of more sons and daughters.
14:4 These are the names of those who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
14:5 Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet,
14:6 Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
14:7 Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphelet.
14:8 When the Philistines had heard that David was anointed king over all Israel, they marched out in force looking for him. But when David heard of this, he went out against them.
14:9 Meanwhile the Philistines had come and raided the valley of Rephaim.
14:10 David inquired of God, Shall I attack the Philistines, and will you deliver them into my power? The answered him, Attack, for I have delivered them into your power.
14:11 So they attacked, at Baal-perazim, and David defeated them there. Then David said, By my hand God has broken through my enemies just as water breaks through a dam. Therefore that place was called Baal-perazim.
14:12 The Philistines abandoned their gods there, and David ordered them to be burnt.
14:13 Once again the Philistines raided the valley,
14:14 and again David inquired of God. But God answered him: Do not try to pursue them, but go around them and come against them near the balsam trees.
14:15 When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then go forth to battle, for God has already gone before you to strike the army of the Philistines.
14:16 David did as God commanded him, and they routed the Philistine army from Gibeon to Gezer.
14:17 Thus Davids fame was spread abroad through every land, and the put the fear of him on all the nations.
15:1 David built houses for himself in the City of David and prepared a place for the ark of God, pitching a tent for it there.
15:2 At that time he said, No one may carry the ark of God except the Levites, for the chose them to carry the ark of the and to minister to him forever.
15:3 Then David assembled all Israel to Jerusalem to bring up the ark of the to its place, which he had prepared for it.
15:4 David also convened the sons of Aaron and the Levites:
15:5 of the sons of Kohath, Uriel, their chief, and one hundred and twenty of his brothers;
15:6 of the sons of Merari, Asaiah, their chief, and two hundred and twenty of his brothers;
15:7 of the sons of Gershon, Joel, their chief, and one hundred and thirty of his brothers;
15:8 of the sons of Elizaphan, Shemaiah, their chief, and two hundred of his brothers;
15:9 of the sons of Hebron, Eliel, their chief, and eighty of his brothers;
15:10 of the sons of Uzziel, Amminadab, their chief, and one hundred and twelve of his brothers.
15:11 David summoned the priests Zadok and Abiathar, and the Levites Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab,
15:12 and said to them: You heads of the levitical houses, sanctify yourselves along with your brothers to bring up the ark of the , the God of Israel, to the place which I have prepared for it.
15:13 Because you were not with us the first time, the our God broke out against us, for we did not seek him aright.
15:14 Accordingly, the priests and the Levites sanctified themselves to bring up the ark of the , the God of Israel.
15:15 The Levites carried the ark of God on their shoulders with poles, as Moses had commanded according to the word of the .
15:16 David commanded the commanders of the Levites to appoint their brothers as singers and to play on musical instruments, harps, lyres, and cymbals, to make a loud sound of rejoicing.
15:17 Therefore the Levites appointed Heman, son of Joel, and, among his brothers, Asaph, son of Berechiah; and among the sons of Merari, their brothers, Ethan, son of Kushaiah;
15:18 and, together with these, their brothers of the second rank: the gatekeepers Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel.
15:19 The singers, Heman, Asaph, and Ethan, sounded brass cymbals.
15:20 Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah played on harps set to Alamoth.
15:21 But Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel led the song on lyres set to sheminith.
15:22 Chenaniah was the chief of the Levites in the singing; he directed the singing, for he was skillful.
15:23 Berechiah and Elkanah were gatekeepers before the ark.
15:24 The priests, Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer, sounded the trumpets before the ark of God. Obed-edom and Jeiel were also gatekeepers before the ark.
15:25 Thus David, the elders of Israel, and the commanders of thousands went to bring up the ark of the covenant of the with joy from the house of Obed-edom.
15:26 While God helped the Levites to carry the ark of the covenant of the , they sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams.
15:27 David was vested in a robe of fine linen, as were all the Levites who carried the ark, the singers, and Chenaniah, the leader of song; David was also wearing a linen ephod.
15:28 Thus all Israel brought up the ark of the covenant of the with joyful shouting, to the sound of horns, trumpets, and cymbals, and the music of harps and lyres.
15:29 But as the ark of the covenant of the was entering the City of David, Michal, daughter of Saul, looked down from her window, and when she saw King David leaping and dancing, she despised him in her heart.
16:1 They brought in the ark of God and set it within the tent which David had pitched for it. Then they sacrificed burnt offerings and communion offerings to God.
16:2 When David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and communion offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the ,
16:3 and distributed to every Israelite, to every man and every woman, a loaf of bread, a piece of meat, and a raisin cake.
16:4 He then appointed certain Levites to minister before the ark of the , to celebrate, thank, and praise the , the God of Israel.
16:5 Asaph was their chief, and second to him were Zechariah, Uzziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel. These were to play on harps and lyres, while Asaph was to sound the cymbals,
16:6 and the priests Benaiah and Jahaziel were to be the regular trumpeters before the ark of the covenant of God.
16:7 On that same day, David appointed Asaph and his brothers to sing for the first time these praises of the :
16:8 Give thanks to the , invoke his name; make known among the peoples his deeds.
16:9 Sing praise, play music; proclaim all his wondrous deeds.
16:10 Glory in his holy name; rejoice, O hearts that seek the !
16:11 Rely on the mighty ; constantly seek his face.
16:12 Recall the wondrous deeds he has done, his signs, and his words of judgment,
16:13 You sons of Israel, his servants, offspring of Jacob, the chosen ones!
16:14 The is our God; who rules the whole earth.
16:15 He remembers forever his covenant the pact imposed for a thousand generations—
16:16 Which was made with Abraham, confirmed by oath to Isaac,
16:17 And ratified as binding for Jacob, an everlasting covenant for Israel:
16:18 To you will I give the land of Canaan, your own allotted heritage.
16:19 When they were few in number, a handful, and strangers there,
16:20 Wandering from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another,
16:21 He let no one oppress them; for their sake he rebuked kings:
16:22 Do not touch my anointed, to my prophets do no harm.
16:23 Sing to the , all the earth, announce his salvation, day after day.
16:24 Tell his glory among the nations; among all peoples, his wondrous deeds.
16:25 For great is the and highly to be praised; to be feared above all gods.
16:26 For the gods of the nations all do nothing, but the made the heavens.
16:27 Splendor and majesty go before him; power and rejoicing are in his holy place.
16:28 Give to the , you families of nations, give to the glory and might;
16:29 Give to the the glory due his name! Bring gifts, and come before him; bow down to the , splendid in holiness.
16:30 Tremble before him, all the earth; the world will surely stand fast, never to be moved.
16:31 Let the heavens be glad and the earth rejoice; let them say among the nations: The is king.
16:32 Let the sea and what fills it resound; let the plains be joyful and all that is in them!
16:33 Then let all the trees of the forest exult before the , who comes, who comes to rule the earth.
16:34 Give thanks to the , who is good, whose love endures forever;
16:35 And say, Save us, O God, our savior, gather us and deliver us from among the nations, That we may give thanks to your holy name and glory in praising you.
16:36 Blessed be the , the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting! Let all the people say, Amen! Hallelujah.
16:37 Then David left Asaph and his brothers there before the ark of the covenant of the to minister before the ark regularly according to the daily ritual;
16:38 he also left there Obed-edom and sixty-eight of his brothers, including Obed-edom, son of Jeduthun, and Hosah, to be gatekeepers.
16:39 But the priest Zadok and his priestly brothers he left before the tabernacle of the on the high place at Gibeon,
16:40 to make burnt offerings to the on the altar for burnt offerings regularly, morning and evening, and to do all that is written in the law of the which he commanded Israel.
16:41 With them were Heman and Jeduthun and the others who were chosen and designated by name to give thanks to the , whose love endures forever,
16:42 with trumpets and cymbals for accompaniment, and instruments for sacred song. The sons of Jeduthun kept the gate.
16:43 Then all the people departed, each to their own homes, and David returned to bless his household.
17:1 After David had taken up residence in his house, he said to Nathan the prophet, See, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of the covenant of the is under tentcloth.
17:2 Nathan replied to David, Whatever is in your heart, go and do, for God is with you.
17:3 But that same night the word of God came to Nathan:
17:4 Go and tell David my servant, Thus says the : It is not you who are to build the house for me to dwell in.
17:5 For I have never dwelt in a house, from the day I brought Israel up, even to this day, but I have been lodging in tent or tabernacle.
17:6 As long as I have wandered about with all Israel, did I ever say a word to any of the judges of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people, Why have you not built me a house of cedar?
17:7 Now then, speak thus to my servant David, Thus says the of hosts: I took you from the pasture, from following the flock, to become ruler over my people Israel.
17:8 I was with you wherever you went, and I cut down all your enemies before you. I will make your name like that of the greatest on the earth.
17:9 I will assign a place for my people Israel and I will plant them in it to dwell there; they will never again be disturbed, nor shall the wicked ever again oppress them, as they did at the beginning,
17:10 and during all the time when I appointed judges over my people Israel. And I will subdue all your enemies. Moreover, I declare to you that the will build you a house:
17:11 when your days have been completed and you must join your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring after you who will be one of your own sons, and I will establish his kingdom.
17:12 He it is who shall build me a house, and I will establish his throne forever.
17:13 I will be a father to him, and he shall be a son to me, and I will not withdraw my favor from him as I withdrew it from the one who was before you;
17:14 but I will maintain him in my house and in my kingdom forever, and his throne shall be firmly established forever.
17:15 In accordance with all these words and this whole vision Nathan spoke to David.
17:16 Then King David came in and sat in the s presence, and said: Who am I, God, and what is my house, that you should have brought me so far?
17:17 And yet, even this is too little in your sight, O God! For you have made a promise regarding your servants house reaching into the future, and you have looked on me as henceforth the most notable of men, God.
17:18 What more can David say to you? You have known your servant.
17:19 , for your servants sake and in keeping with your purpose, you have done this great thing.
17:20 , there is no one like you, no God but you, just as we have always heard.
17:21 Is there, like your people Israel, whom you redeemed from Egypt, another nation on earth whom a god went to redeem as his people? You won for yourself a name for great and awesome deeds by driving out the nations before your people.
17:22 You made your people Israel your own forever, and you, , became their God.
17:23 Now, , may the promise that you have spoken concerning your servant and his house remain firm forever. Bring about what you have promised,
17:24 that your name, of hosts, God of Israel, may be great and abide forever, while the house of your servant is established in your presence.
17:25 Because you, my God, have revealed to your servant that you will build him a house, your servant dares to pray before you.
17:26 Since you, , are truly God and have made this generous promise to your servant,
17:27 do, then, bless the house of your servant, that it may be in your presence forever—since it is you, , who blessed it, it is blessed forever.
18:1 After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them; and he took Gath and its towns away from the Philistines.
18:2 He also defeated Moab, and the Moabites became Davids subjects, paying tribute.
18:3 David then defeated Hadadezer, king of Zobah, toward Hamath, who was on his way to set up his victory stele at the river Euphrates.
18:4 David captured from him one thousand chariots, seven thousand horsemen, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David hamstrung all the chariot horses, but left one hundred for his chariots.
18:5 The Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer, king of Zobah, but David also defeated twenty-two thousand of their men in Aram.
18:6 Then David set up garrisons in the Damascus region of Aram, and the Arameans became Davids subjects, paying tribute. Thus the made David victorious in all his campaigns.
18:7 David took the golden shields that were carried by Hadadezers attendants and brought them to Jerusalem.
18:8 David likewise took away from Tibhath and Cun, cities of Hadadezer, large quantities of bronze; Solomon later used it to make the bronze sea and the pillars and the vessels of bronze.
18:9 When Tou, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer, king of Zobah,
18:10 he sent his son Hadoram to wish King David well and to congratulate him on having waged a victorious war against Hadadezer; for Hadadezer had been at war with Tou. He also brought gold, silver and bronze articles of every sort.
18:11 These also King David consecrated to the along with all the silver and gold that he had taken from the nations: from Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek.
18:12 Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, also defeated eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
18:13 He set up garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became Davids subjects. Thus the brought David victory in all his undertakings.
18:14 David was king over all Israel; he dispensed justice and right to all his people.
18:15 Joab, son of Zeruiah, was in command of the army; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was chancellor;
18:16 Zadok, son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, were priests; Shavsha was scribe;
18:17 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and the Pelethites; and Davids sons were the chief assistants to the king.
19:1 Afterward Nahash, king of the Ammonites, died and his son succeeded him as king.
19:2 David said, I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, for his father showed kindness to me. Therefore he sent envoys to console him over his father. But when Davids servants had entered the land of the Ammonites to console Hanun,
19:3 the Ammonite princes said to Hanun, Do you think David is doing this—sending you these consolers—to honor your father? Have not his servants rather come to you to explore the land, spying it out for its overthrow?
19:4 So Hanun seized Davids servants and had them shaved and their garments cut off halfway at the hips. Then he sent them away.
19:5 David was told about the men, and he sent word for them to be intercepted, for the men had been greatly disgraced. Remain at Jericho, the king told them, until your beards have grown again; then come back here.
19:6 When the Ammonites realized that they had put themselves in bad odor with David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent a thousand talents of silver to hire chariots and horsemen from Aram Naharaim, from Aram-maacah, and from Zobah.
19:7 They hired thirty-two thousand chariots along with the king of Maacah and his army, who came and encamped before Medeba. The Ammonites also assembled from their cities and came out for war.
19:8 When David heard of this, he sent Joab and his whole army of warriors against them.
19:9 The Ammonites marched out and lined up for battle at the entrance of the city, while the kings who had come to their help remained apart in the open field.
19:10 When Joab saw that there was a battle line both in front of and behind him, he chose some of the best fighters among the Israelites and lined them up against the Arameans;
19:11 the rest of the army, which he placed under the command of his brother Abishai, then lined up to oppose the Ammonites.
19:12 And he said: If the Arameans prove too strong for me, you must come and save me; and if the Ammonites prove too strong for you, I will save you.
19:13 Hold firm and let us show ourselves courageous for the sake of our people and the cities of our God; and may the do what is good in his sight.
19:14 Joab therefore advanced with his men to engage the Arameans in battle; but they fled before him.
19:15 And when the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they too fled before his brother Abishai, and entered their city. Joab then came to Jerusalem.
19:16 Seeing themselves vanquished by Israel, the Arameans sent messengers to bring out the Arameans from beyond the Euphrates, with Shophach, the commander of Hadadezers army, at their head.
19:17 When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel together, crossed the Jordan, and met them. With the army of David drawn up to fight the Arameans, they gave battle.
19:18 But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven thousand of their chariot fighters and forty thousand of their foot soldiers; he also put to death Shophach, the commander of the army.
19:19 When the vassals of Hadadezer saw themselves vanquished by Israel, they made peace with David and became his subjects. After this, the Arameans refused to come to the aid of the Ammonites.
20:1 At the turn of the year, the time when kings go to war, Joab led the army out in force, laid waste the land of the Ammonites, and went on to besiege Rabbah; David himself remained in Jerusalem. When Joab had attacked Rabbah and destroyed it,
20:2 David took the crown of Milcom from the idols head. It was found to weigh a talent of gold, with precious stones on it; this crown David wore on his own head. He also brought out a great amount of spoil from the city.
20:3 He deported the people of the city and set them to work with saws, iron picks, and axes. David dealt thus with all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and his whole army returned to Jerusalem.
20:4 Afterward there was another battle with the Philistines, at Gezer. At that time, Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Sippai, one of the descendants of the Rephaim, and the Philistines were subdued.
20:5 There was another battle with the Philistines, and Elhanan, the son of Jair, slew Lahmi, the brother of Goliath of Gath, whose spear shaft was like a weavers beam.
20:6 There was another battle, at Gath, and there was a giant, who had six fingers to each hand and six toes to each foot; twenty-four in all. He too was descended from the Rephaim.
20:7 He defied Israel, and Jonathan, the son of Shimea, Davids brother, slew him.
20:8 These were the descendants of the Rephaim of Gath who died at the hands of David and his servants.
21:1 A satan rose up against Israel, and he incited David to take a census of Israel.
21:2 David therefore said to Joab and to the other generals of the army, Go, number the Israelites from Beer-sheba to Dan, and report back to me that I may know their number.
21:3 But Joab replied: May the increase his people a hundredfold! My lord king, are not all of them my lords subjects? Why does my lord seek to do this thing? Why should he bring guilt upon Israel?
21:4 However, the kings command prevailed over Joab, who departed and traversed all of Israel, and then returned to Jerusalem.
21:5 Joab reported the census figures to David: of men capable of wielding a sword, there were in all Israel one million one hundred thousand, and in Judah four hundred and seventy thousand.
21:6 Levi and Benjamin, however, he did not include in the census, for the kings command was repugnant to Joab.
21:7 This command was evil in the sight of God, and he struck Israel.
21:8 Then David said to God, I have sinned greatly in doing this thing. Take away your servants guilt, for I have acted very foolishly.
21:9 Then the spoke to Gad, Davids seer, in these words:
21:10 Go, tell David: Thus says the : I am laying out three options; choose one of them, and I will inflict it on you.
21:11 Accordingly, Gad went to David and said to him: Thus says the : Decide now—
21:12 will it be three years of famine; or three months of fleeing your enemies, with the sword of your foes ever at your back; or three days of the s own sword, a plague in the land, with the s destroying angel in every part of Israel? Now consider: What answer am I to give him who sent me?
21:13 Then David said to Gad: I am in serious trouble. But let me fall into the hand of the , whose mercy is very great, rather than into hands of men.
21:14 Therefore the sent a plague upon Israel, and seventy thousand Israelites died.
21:15 God also sent an angel to Jerusalem to destroy it; but as the angel was on the point of destroying it, the saw and changed his mind about the calamity, and said to the destroying angel, Enough now! Stay your hand! The angel of the was then standing by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
21:16 When David raised his eyes, he saw the angel of the standing between earth and heaven, drawn sword in hand stretched out against Jerusalem. David and the elders, clothed in sackcloth, fell face down,
21:17 and David prayed to God: Was it not I who ordered the census of the people? I am the one who sinned, I did this wicked thing. But these sheep, what have they done? O , my God, strike me and my fathers family, but do not afflict your people with this plague!
21:18 Then the angel of the commanded Gad to tell David to go up and set up an altar to the on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
21:19 David went up at the word of Gad, which he spoke in the name of the .
21:20 Ornan turned around and saw the king; his four sons who were with him hid themselves, but Ornan kept on threshing wheat.
21:21 But as David came toward Ornan, he looked up and saw that it was David, and left the threshing floor and bowed down before David, his face to the ground.
21:22 David said to Ornan: Sell me the site of this threshing floor, that I may build on it an altar to the . Sell it to me at its full price, that the plague may be withdrawn from the people.
21:23 But Ornan said to David: Take it as your own, and let my lord the king do what is good in his sight. See, I also give you the oxen for the burnt offerings, the threshing sledges for the wood, and the wheat for the grain offering. I give it all to you.
21:24 But King David replied to Ornan: No! I will buy it from you properly, at its full price. I will not take what is yours for the , nor bring burnt offerings that cost me nothing.
21:25 So David paid Ornan six hundred shekels of gold for the place.
21:26 David then built an altar there to the , and sacrificed burnt offerings and communion offerings. He called upon the , who answered him by sending down fire from heaven upon the altar for burnt offerings.
21:27 Then the gave orders to the angel to return his sword to its sheath.
21:28 Once David saw that the had answered him at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he continued to offer sacrifices there.
21:29 The tabernacle of the , which Moses had made in the wilderness, and the altar for burnt offerings were at that time on the high place at Gibeon.
21:30 But David could not go into his presence to inquire of God, for he was fearful of the sword of the angel of the .
22:1 Thus David said, This is the house of the God, and this is the altar for burnt offerings for Israel.
22:2 David then ordered that the resident aliens in the land of Israel should be brought together, and he appointed them stonecutters to hew out stone blocks for building the house of God.
22:3 David also laid up large stores of iron to make nails for the doors of the gates, and clamps, together with so much bronze that it could not be weighed,
22:4 and cedar trees without number. The Sidonians and Tyrians brought great stores of cedar logs to David.
22:5 David said: My son Solomon is young and inexperienced; but the house that is to be built for the must be made so magnificent that it will be renowned and glorious in all lands. Therefore I will make preparations for it. Thus before his death David laid up materials in abundance.
22:6 Then he summoned his son Solomon and commanded him to build a house for the , the God of Israel.
22:7 David said to Solomon: My son, it was my purpose to build a house myself for the name of the , my God.
22:8 But this word of the came to me: You have shed much blood, and you have waged great wars. You may not build a house for my name, because you have shed too much blood upon the earth in my sight.
22:9 However, a son will be born to you. He will be a peaceful man, and I will give him rest from all his enemies on every side. For Solomon shall be his name, and in his time I will bestow peace and tranquility on Israel.
22:10 It is he who shall build a house for my name; he shall be a son to me, and I will be a father to him, and I will establish the throne of his kingship over Israel forever.
22:11 Now, my son, the be with you, and may you succeed in building the house of the your God, as he has said you shall.
22:12 But may the give you prudence and discernment when he gives you command over Israel, so that you keep the law of the , your God.
22:13 Only then shall you succeed, if you are careful to observe the statutes and ordinances which the commanded Moses for Israel. Be strong and steadfast; do not fear or be dismayed.
22:14 See, with great effort I have laid up for the house of the a hundred thousand talents of gold, a million talents of silver, and bronze and iron in such great quantities that they cannot be weighed. I have also laid up wood and stones, to which you must add.
22:15 Moreover, you have available workers, stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and experts in every craft,
22:16 without number, skilled with gold, silver, bronze, and iron. Set to work, therefore, and the be with you!
22:17 David also commanded all of the officials of Israel to help his son Solomon:
22:18 Is not the your God with you? Has he not given you rest on every side? Indeed, he has delivered the inhabitants of the land into my power, and the land is subdued before the and his people.
22:19 Therefore, devote your hearts and souls to seeking the your God. Proceed to build the sanctuary of the God, that the ark of the covenant of the and Gods sacred vessels may be brought into the house built for the name of the .
23:1 When David had grown old and was near the end of his days, he made his son Solomon king over Israel.
23:2 He then gathered together all the officials of Israel, along with the priests and the Levites.
23:3 The Levites thirty years old and above were counted, and their total number was found to be thirty-eight thousand.
23:4 Of these, twenty-four thousand were to direct the service of the house of the , six thousand were to be officials and judges,
23:5 four thousand were to be gatekeepers, and four thousand were to praise the with the instruments which [David] had devised for praise.
23:6 David apportioned them into divisions according to the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
23:7 To the Gershonites belonged Ladan and Shimei.
23:8 The sons of Ladan: Jehiel the chief, then Zetham and Joel; three in all.
23:9 The sons of Shimei were Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran; three. These were the heads of the families of Ladan.
23:10 The sons of Shimei were Jahath, Zizah, Jeush, and Beriah; these were the sons of Shimei, four in all.
23:11 Jahath was the chief and Zizah was second to him; but Jeush and Beriah had few sons, and therefore they were classed as a single family, exercising a single office.
23:12 The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel; four in all.
23:13 The sons of Amram were Aaron and Moses. Aaron was set apart to be consecrated as most holy, he and his sons forever, to offer sacrifice before the , to minister to him, and to bless in his name forever.
23:14 As for Moses, however, the man of God, his sons were counted as part of the tribe of Levi.
23:15 The sons of Moses were Gershom and Eliezer.
23:16 The sons of Gershom: Shubael the chief.
23:17 The sons of Eliezer were Rehabiah the chief—Eliezer had no other sons, but the sons of Rehabiah were very numerous.
23:18 The sons of Izhar: Shelomith the chief.
23:19 The sons of Hebron: Jeriah, the chief, Amariah, the second, Jahaziel, the third, and Jekameam, the fourth.
23:20 The sons of Uzziel: Micah, the chief, and Isshiah, the second.
23:21 The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. The sons of Mahli: Eleazar and Kish.
23:22 Eleazar died leaving no sons, only daughters; the sons of Kish, their kinsmen, married them.
23:23 The sons of Mushi: Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth; three in all.
23:24 These were the sons of Levi according to their ancestral houses, the family heads as they were enrolled one by one according to their names. They performed the work of the service of the house of the beginning at twenty years of age.
23:25 David said: The , the God of Israel, has given rest to his people, and has taken up his dwelling in Jerusalem forever.
23:26 Henceforth the Levites need not carry the tabernacle or any of the equipment for its service.
23:27 For by Davids last words the Levites were enlisted from the time they were twenty years old.
23:28 Their duty is to assist the sons of Aaron in the service of the house of the , having charge of the courts, the chambers, and the preservation of everything holy: they take part in the service of the house of God.
23:29 They also have charge of the showbread, of the fine flour for the grain offering, of the wafers of unleavened bread, and of the baking and mixing, and of all measures of quantity and size.
23:30 They are to be present every morning to offer thanks and to praise the , and likewise in the evening;
23:31 and at every sacrifice of burnt offerings to the on sabbaths, new moons, and feast days, in such numbers as are prescribed, they must always be present before the
23:32 and observe what is prescribed for them concerning the tent of meeting, the sanctuary, and the sons of Aaron, their kinsmen, in the service of the house of the .
24:1 There were also divisions for the sons of Aaron. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
24:2 Nadab and Abihu died before their father, leaving no sons; therefore only Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.
24:3 David, with Zadok, a descendant of Eleazar, and Ahimelech, a descendant of Ithamar, apportioned them their offices in the priestly service.
24:4 But since the sons of Eleazar were found to be more numerous by male heads than those of Ithamar, the former were divided into sixteen groups, and the latter into eight groups, each under its family heads.
24:5 Their functions were assigned impartially by lot, for there were officers of the holy place, and officers of God, descended both from Eleazar and from Ithamar.
24:6 The scribe Shemaiah, son of Nethanel, a Levite, recorded them in the presence of the king, and of the officials, of Zadok the priest, and of Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, and of the heads of the ancestral houses of the priests and of the Levites, listing two successive family groups from Eleazar before each one from Ithamar.
24:7 The first lot fell to Jehoiarib, the second to Jedaiah,
24:8 the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim,
24:9 the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin,
24:10 the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah,
24:11 the ninth to Jeshua, the tenth to Shecaniah,
24:12 the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim,
24:13 the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Ishbaal,
24:14 the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer,
24:15 the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Happizzez,
24:16 the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezkel,
24:17 the twenty-first to Jachin, the twenty-second to Gamul,
24:18 the twenty-third to Delaiah, the twenty-fourth to Maaziah.
24:19 This was the appointed order of their service when they functioned in the house of the according to the precepts given them by Aaron, their father, as the , the God of Israel, had commanded him.
24:20 Of the remaining Levites, there were Shubael, of the sons of Amram, and Jehdeiah, of the sons of Shubael;
24:21 Isshiah, the chief, of the sons of Rehabiah;
24:22 Shelomith of the Izharites, and Jahath of the sons of Shelomith.
24:23 The sons of Hebron were Jeriah, the chief, Amariah, the second, Jahaziel, the third, Jekameam, the fourth.
24:24 The sons of Uzziel were Micah; Shamir, of the sons of Micah;
24:25 Isshiah, the brother of Micah; and Zechariah, a descendant of Isshiah.
24:26 The sons of Merari were Mahli, Mushi, and the sons of his son Uzziah.
24:27 The sons of Merari through his son Uzziah: Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
24:28 The sons of Mahli were Eleazar, who had no sons,
24:29 and Jerahmeel, of the sons of Kish.
24:30 The sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the sons of the Levites according to their ancestral houses.
24:31 They too, in the same manner as their kinsmen, the sons of Aaron, cast lots in the presence of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the heads of the priestly and levitical families; the more important family did so in the same way as the less important one.
25:1 David and the leaders of the liturgy set apart for the service the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, who prophesied to the accompaniment of lyres and harps and cymbals. This is the list of those who performed this service:
25:2 Of the sons of Asaph: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asharelah, sons of Asaph, under the direction of Asaph, who prophesied under the guidance of the king.

25:5 All these were the sons of Heman, the kings seer for divine matters; to exalt him God gave Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.

25:7 Their number, together with that of their kinsmen who were trained in singing to the , all of them skilled men, was two hundred and eighty-eight.
25:8 They cast lots for their functions equally, young and old, master and pupil alike.

26:1 As for the divisions of gatekeepers: Of the Korahites was Meshelemiah, the son of Kore, one of the sons of Abiasaph.
26:2 Meshelemiahs sons: Zechariah, the firstborn, Jediael, the second son, Zebadiah, the third, Jathniel, the fourth,
26:3 Elam, the fifth, Jehohanan, the sixth, Eliehoenai, the seventh.
26:4 Obed-edoms sons: Shemaiah, the firstborn, Jehozabad, a second son, Joah, the third, Sachar, the fourth, Nethanel, the fifth,
26:5 Ammiel, the sixth, Issachar, the seventh, Peullethai, the eighth, for God blessed him.
26:6 To his son Shemaiah were born sons who ruled over their family, for they were warriors.
26:7 The sons of Shemaiah were Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad; also his kinsmen who were men of substance, Elihu and Semachiah.
26:8 All these were the sons of Obed-edom, who, together with their sons and their kinsmen, were men of substance, fit for the service. Of Obed-edom, sixty-two.
26:9 Of Meshelemiah, eighteen sons and kinsmen, men of substance.
26:10 Hosah, a descendant of Merari, had these sons: Shimri, the chief (for though he was not the firstborn, his father made him chief),
26:11 Hilkiah, the second son, Tebaliah, the third, Zechariah, the fourth. All the sons and kinsmen of Hosah were thirteen.
26:12 To these divisions of the gatekeepers, by their chief men, were assigned watches for them to minister in the house of the , for each group in the same way.
26:13 They cast lots for each gate, small and large families alike.
26:14 When the lot was cast for the east side, it fell to Meshelemiah. Then they cast lots for his son Zechariah, a prudent counselor, and the north side fell to his lot.
26:15 To Obed-edom fell the south side, and to his sons the storehouse.
26:16 To Hosah fell the west side with the Shallecheth gate at the ascending highway. For each family, watches were established.
26:17 On the east, six watched each day, on the north, four each day, on the south, four each day, and at the storehouse they were two and two;
26:18 as for the large building on the west, there were four at the highway and two at the large building.
26:19 These were the classes of the gatekeepers, sons of Korah and Merari.
26:20 Their brother Levites had oversight of the treasuries of the house of God and the treasuries of votive offerings.
26:21 Among the sons of Ladan the Gershonite, the family heads were sons of Jehiel:
26:22 the sons of Jehiel, Zetham and his brother Joel, who oversaw the treasures of the house of the .
26:23 Of the Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites, and Uzzielites,
26:24 Shubael, son of Gershom, son of Moses, was principal overseer of the treasures.
26:25 His associate was of the line of Eliezer, whose son was Rehabiah, whose son was Jeshaiah, whose son was Joram, whose son was Zichri, whose son was Shelomith.
26:26 This Shelomith and his kinsmen oversaw all the treasures of the votive offerings dedicated by King David, the heads of the families, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and the commanders of the army;
26:27 what came from wars and from spoils, they dedicated for the support of the house of the .
26:28 Also, whatever Samuel the seer, Saul, son of Kish, Abner, son of Ner, Joab, son of Zeruiah, and all others had consecrated, was under the charge of Shelomith and his kinsmen.
26:29 Among the Izharites, Chenaniah and his sons were in charge of Israels civil affairs as officials and judges.
26:30 Among the Hebronites, Hashabiah and his kinsmen, one thousand seven hundred men of substance, had the administration of Israel on the western side of the Jordan for all the work of the and the service of the king.
26:31 Among the Hebronites, Jerijah was their chief according to their family records. In the fortieth year of Davids reign search was made, and there were found among them warriors at Jazer of Gilead.
26:32 His kinsmen were also men of substance, two thousand seven hundred heads of families. King David appointed them to the administration of the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh for everything pertaining to God and to the king.
27:1 This is the list of the Israelite family heads, commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and other officers who served the king in all that pertained to the divisions, of twenty-four thousand men each, that came and went month by month throughout the year.
27:2 Over the first division for the first month was Ishbaal, son of Zabdiel, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men;
27:3 a descendant of Perez, he was chief over all the commanders of the army for the first month.
27:4 Over the division of the second month was Eleazar, son of Dodo, from Ahoh, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:5 The third army commander, for the third month, was Benaiah, son of Jehoiada the chief priest, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:6 This Benaiah was a warrior among the Thirty and over the Thirty. His son Ammizabad was over his division.
27:7 Fourth, for the fourth month, was Asahel, brother of Joab, and after him his son Zebadiah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:8 Fifth, for the fifth month, was the commander Shamhuth, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:9 Sixth, for the sixth month, was Ira, son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:10 Seventh, for the seventh month, was Hellez, from Beth-pelet, of the Ephraimites, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:11 Eighth, for the eighth month, was Sibbecai the Hushathite, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:12 Ninth, for the ninth month, was Abiezer from Anathoth, of Benjamin, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:13 Tenth, for the tenth month, was Maharai from Netophah, a descendant of Zerah, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:14 Eleventh, for the eleventh month, was Benaiah the Pirathonite, of the Ephraimites, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:15 Twelfth, for the twelfth month, was Heldai the Netophathite, of the family of Othniel, and in his division were twenty-four thousand men.
27:16 Over the tribes of Israel, for the Reubenites the leader was Eliezer, son of Zichri; for the Simeonites, Shephatiah, son of Maacah;
27:17 for Levi, Hashabiah, son of Kemuel; for Aaron, Zadok;
27:18 for Judah, Eliab, one of Davids brothers; for Issachar, Omri, son of Michael;
27:19 for Zebulun, Ishmaiah, son of Obadiah; for Naphtali, Jeremoth, son of Azriel;
27:20 for the Ephraimites, Hoshea, son of Azaziah; for the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joel, son of Pedaiah;
27:21 for the half-tribe of Manasseh in Gilead, Iddo, son of Zechariah; for Benjamin, Jaasiel, son of Abner;
27:22 for Dan, Azarel, son of Jeroham. These were the commanders of the tribes of Israel.
27:23 David did not count those who were twenty years of age or younger, for the had promised to multiply Israel like the stars of the heavens.
27:24 Joab, son of Zeruiah, began to take the census, but he did not complete it, for because of it wrath fell upon Israel. Therefore the number was not recorded in the book of chronicles of King David.
27:25 Over the treasuries of the king was Azmaveth, the son of Adiel. Over the treasuries in the country, the cities, the villages, and the towers was Jonathan, son of Uzziah.
27:26 Over the farm workers who tilled the soil was Ezri, son of Chelub.
27:27 Over the vineyards was Shimei from Ramah, and over their produce for the wine cellars was Zabdi the Shiphmite.
27:28 Over the olive trees and sycamores of the Shephelah was Baalhanan the Gederite, and over the stores of oil was Joash.
27:29 Over the cattle that grazed in Sharon was Shitrai the Sharonite, and over the cattle in the valleys was Shaphat, the son of Adlai;
27:30 over the camels was Obil the Ishmaelite; over the donkeys was Jehdeiah the Meronothite;
27:31 and over the flocks was Jaziz the Hagrite. All these were the overseers of King Davids possessions.
27:32 Jonathan, Davids uncle and a man of intelligence, was counselor and scribe; he and Jehiel, the son of Hachmoni, attended the kings sons.
27:33 Ahithophel was also the kings counselor, and Hushai the Archite was the kings friend.
27:34 After Ahithophel came Jehoiada, the son of Benaiah, and Abiathar. The commander of the kings army was Joab.
28:1 David assembled at Jerusalem all the commanders of Israel, the tribal commanders, the commanders of the divisions who were in the service of the king, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, those in command of all the kings estates and possessions, and his sons, together with the courtiers, the warriors, and every person of substance.
28:2 King David rose to his feet and said: Hear me, my kinsmen and my people. It was my purpose to build a house of repose myself for the ark of the covenant of the , the footstool for the feet of our God; and I was preparing to build it.
28:3 But God said to me, You may not build a house for my name, for you are a man who waged wars and shed blood.
28:4 However, the , the God of Israel, chose me from all my fathers family to be king over Israel forever. For he chose Judah as leader, then one family of Judah, that of my father; and finally, among all the sons of my father, it pleased him to make me king over all Israel.
28:5 And of all my sons—for the has given me many sons—he has chosen my son Solomon to sit on the throne of the s kingship over Israel.
28:6 For he said to me: It is your son Solomon who shall build my house and my courts, for I have chosen him for my son, and I will be a father to him.
28:7 I will establish his kingdom forever, if he perseveres in carrying out my commandments and ordinances as he does now.
28:8 Therefore, in the sight of all Israel, the assembly of the , and in the hearing of our God: keep and carry out all the commandments of the , your God, that you may continue to possess this good land and afterward leave it as an inheritance to your children forever.
28:9 As for you, Solomon, my son, know the God of your father and serve him with a whole heart and a willing soul, for the searches all hearts and understands all the minds thoughts. If you search for him, he will be found; but if you abandon him, he will cast you off forever.
28:10 See, then! The has chosen you to build a house as his sanctuary. Be strong and set to work.
28:11 Then David gave to his son Solomon the design of the portico and of the house itself, with its storerooms, its upper rooms and inner chambers, and the shrine containing the cover of the ark.
28:12 He provided also the design for all else that he had in mind by way of courts for the house of the , with the surrounding compartments for the treasuries of the house of God and the treasuries for the votive offerings,
28:13 as well as for the divisions of the priests and Levites, for all the work of the service of the house of the , and for all the liturgical vessels of the house of the .
28:14 He specified the weight of gold to be used in the golden vessels for the various services and the weight of silver to be used in the silver vessels for the various services;
28:15 likewise for the golden menorahs and their lamps he specified the weight of gold for each menorah and its lamps, and for the silver menorahs he specified the weight of silver for each menorah and its lamps, depending on the use to which each menorah was to be put.
28:16 He specified the weight of gold for each table that was to hold the showbread, and the silver for the silver tables;
28:17 the pure gold for the forks, basins, and pitchers; the weight of gold for each golden bowl and the weight of silver for each silver bowl;
28:18 the refined gold, and its weight, to be used for the altar of incense; and, finally, gold to fashion the chariot: the cherubim spreading their wings and covering the ark of the covenant of the .
28:19 All this he wrote down, by the hand of the , to make him understand it—the working out of the whole design.
28:20 Then David said to his son Solomon: Be strong and steadfast, and go to work; do not fear or be dismayed, for the God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or abandon you before you have completed all the work for the service of the house of the .
28:21 The divisions of the priests and Levites are ready for all the service of the house of God; they will be with you in all the work with all those who are eager to show their skill in every kind of craftsmanship. Also the commanders and all the people will do everything that you command.
29:1 King David then said to the whole assembly: My son Solomon, whom alone God has chosen, is still young and inexperienced; the work, however, is great, for this palace is not meant for human beings, but for the God.
29:2 For this reason I have stored up for the house of my God, as far as I was able, gold for what will be made of gold, silver for what will be made of silver, bronze for what will be made of bronze, iron for what will be made of iron, wood for what will be made of wood, onyx stones and settings for them, carnelian and mosaic stones, every other kind of precious stone, and great quantities of marble.
29:3 But now, because of the delight I take in the house of my God, in addition to all that I stored up for the holy house, I give to the house of my God my personal fortune in gold and silver:
29:4 three thousand talents of Ophir gold, and seven thousand talents of refined silver, for overlaying the walls of the rooms,
29:5 for the various utensils to be made of gold and silver, and for every work that is to be done by artisans. Now, who else will contribute generously and consecrate themselves this day to the ?
29:6 Then the heads of the families, the tribal commanders of Israel, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and those who had command of the kings affairs came forward willingly
29:7 and contributed for the service of the house of God five thousand talents and ten thousand darics of gold, ten thousand talents of silver, eighteen thousand talents of bronze, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.
29:8 Those who had precious stones gave them into the keeping of Jehiel the Gershonite for the treasury of the house of the .
29:9 The people rejoiced over these free-will offerings, for they had been contributed to the wholeheartedly. King David also rejoiced greatly.
29:10 Then David blessed the in the sight of the whole assembly. David said: Blessed are you, , God of Israel our father, from eternity to eternity.
29:11 Yours, , are greatness and might, majesty, victory, and splendor. For all in heaven and on earth is yours; yours, , is kingship; you are exalted as head over all.
29:12 Riches and glory are from you, and you have dominion over all. In your hand are power and might; it is yours to give greatness and strength to all.
29:13 Therefore, our God, we give you thanks and we praise the majesty of your name.
29:14 But who am I, and who are my people, that we should have the means to contribute so freely? For everything is from you, and what we give is what we have from you.
29:15 For before you we are strangers and travelers, like all our ancestors. Our days on earth are like a shadow, without a future.
29:16 our God, all this wealth that we have brought together to build you a house for your holy name comes from you and is entirely yours.
29:17 I know, my God, that you put hearts to the test and that you take pleasure in integrity. With a whole heart I have willingly given all these things, and now with joy I have seen your people here present also giving to you generously.
29:18 , God of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, keep such thoughts in the hearts and minds of your people forever, and direct their hearts toward you.
29:19 Give to my son Solomon a wholehearted desire to keep your commandments, precepts, and statutes, that he may carry out all these plans and build the palace for which I have made preparation.
29:20 Then David told the whole assembly, Now bless the your God! And the whole assembly blessed the , the God of their ancestors, bowing down in homage before the and before the king.
29:21 On the following day they brought sacrifices and burnt offerings to the , a thousand bulls, a thousand rams, and a thousand lambs, together with their libations and many other sacrifices for all Israel;
29:22 and on that day they ate and drank in the s presence with great rejoicing. Then for a second time they proclaimed Davids son Solomon king, and they anointed him for the as ruler, and Zadok as priest.
29:23 Thereafter Solomon sat on the throne of the as king succeeding his father David; he prospered, and all Israel obeyed him.
29:24 All the commanders and warriors, and also all the other sons of King David, swore allegiance to King Solomon.
29:25 And the exalted Solomon greatly in the eyes of all Israel, giving him a glorious reign such as had not been enjoyed by any king over Israel before him.
29:26 Thus David, the son of Jesse, had reigned over all Israel.
29:27 He was king over Israel for forty years: he was king seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
29:28 He died at a ripe old age, rich in years and wealth and glory, and his son Solomon succeeded him as king.
29:29 Now the deeds of King David, first and last, are recorded in the history of Samuel the seer, the history of Nathan the prophet, and the history of Gad the seer,
29:30 together with the particulars of his reign and valor, and of the events that affected him and all Israel and all the kingdoms of the earth.
2 CHRONICLES
1:1 Solomon, son of David, strengthened his hold on the kingdom, for the , his God, was with him, making him ever greater.
1:2 Solomon summoned all Israel, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, the judges, the princes of all Israel, and the family heads;
1:3 and, accompanied by the whole assembly, Solomon went to the high place at Gibeon, because the tent of meeting of God, made in the wilderness by Moses, the s servant, was there.
1:4 David had, however, brought up the ark of God from Kiriath-jearim to Jerusalem, where he had provided a place and pitched a tent for it;
1:5 the bronze altar made by Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, he put in front of the tabernacle of the . There Solomon and the assembly sought out the ,
1:6 and Solomon offered sacrifice in the s presence on the bronze altar at the tent of meeting; he sacrificed a thousand burnt offerings upon it.
1:7 That night God appeared to Solomon and said to him: Whatever you ask, I will give you.
1:8 Solomon answered God: You have shown great favor to David my father, and you have made me king to succeed him.
1:9 Now, God, may your word to David my father be confirmed, for you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth.
1:10 Give me, therefore, wisdom and knowledge to govern this people, for otherwise who could rule this vast people of yours?
1:11 God then replied to Solomon: Because this has been your wish—you did not ask for riches, treasures, and glory, or the life of those who hate you, or even for a long life for yourself, but you have asked for wisdom and knowledge in order to rule my people over whom I have made you king—
1:12 wisdom and knowledge are given you. I will also give you riches, treasures, and glory, such as kings before you never had, nor will those who come after you.
1:13 Solomon returned to Jerusalem from the high place at Gibeon, from before the tent of meeting, and became king over Israel.
1:14 Solomon amassed chariots and horses: he had one thousand four hundred chariots and twelve thousand horses; these he allocated among the chariot cities and to the kings service in Jerusalem.
1:15 The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as stones, and cedars as numerous as the sycamores of the Shephelah.
1:16 Solomons horses were imported from Egypt and Cilicia, where the kings agents purchased them at the prevailing price.
1:17 A chariot imported from Egypt cost six hundred shekels of silver, a horse one hundred and fifty shekels; so they were exported to all the Hittite and Aramean kings.
1:18 Solomon gave orders for the building of a house for the name of the and also a kings house for himself.
2:1 Solomon conscripted seventy thousand men to carry stones and eighty thousand to cut the stones in the mountains, and over these he placed three thousand six hundred overseers.
2:2 Moreover, Solomon sent this message to Huram, king of Tyre: As you dealt with David my father, and sent him cedars to build a house for his dwelling—
2:3 now I am going to build a house for the name of the , my God, and to consecrate it to him, for the burning of fragrant incense in his presence, for the perpetual display of the showbread, for burnt offerings morning and evening, and for the sabbaths, new moons, and festivals of the , our God: such is Israels perpetual obligation.
2:4 And the house I am going to build must be great, for our God is greater than all other gods.
2:5 Yet who is really able to build him a house, since the heavens and even the highest heavens cannot contain him? And who am I that I should build him a house, unless it be to offer incense in his presence?
2:6 Now, send me men skilled at work in gold, silver, bronze, and iron, in purple, crimson, and violet fabrics, and who know how to do engraved work, to join the skilled craftsmen who are with me in Judah and Jerusalem, whom David my father appointed.
2:7 Also send me boards of cedar, cypress and cabinet wood from Lebanon, for I realize that your servants know how to cut the wood of Lebanon. My servants will work with yours
2:8 in order to prepare for me a great quantity of wood, since the house I intend to build must be great and wonderful.
2:9 I will furnish as food for your servants, the woodcutters, twenty thousand kors of wheat, twenty thousand kors of barley, twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of oil.
2:10 Huram, king of Tyre, wrote an answer which he sent to Solomon: Because the loves his people, he has placed you over them as king.
2:11 He added: Blessed be the , the God of Israel, who made heaven and earth, for having given King David a wise son of intelligence and understanding, who will build a house for the and also his own royal house.
2:12 I am now sending you a craftsman of great skill, Huram-abi,
2:13 son of a Danite woman and of a father from Tyre; he knows how to work with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, with stone and wood, with purple, violet, fine linen, and crimson, and also how to do all kinds of engraved work and to devise every type of design that may be given him and your craftsmen and the craftsmen of my lord David your father.
2:14 And now, let my lord send to his servants the wheat, barley, oil, and wine which he has promised.
2:15 For our part, we will cut trees on Lebanon, as many as you need, and send them down to you in rafts to the port of Joppa, whence you may take them up to Jerusalem.
2:16 Thereupon Solomon took a census of all the alien men resident in the land of Israel (following the census David his father had taken of them); they were found to number one hundred fifty-three thousand six hundred.
2:17 Of these he made seventy thousand carriers and eighty thousand cutters in the mountains, and three thousand six hundred overseers to keep the people working.
3:1 Then Solomon began to build the house of the in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, which had been shown to David his father, in the place David had prepared, the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
3:2 He began to build in the second month of the fourth year of his reign.
3:3 These were the specifications laid down by Solomon for building the house of God: the length was sixty cubits according to the old measure, and the width was twenty cubits;
3:4 the front porch along the width of the house was also twenty cubits, and it was twenty cubits high. He covered its interior with pure gold.
3:5 The nave he overlaid with cypress wood and overlaid that with fine gold, embossing on it palms and chains.
3:6 He also covered the house with precious stones for splendor; the gold was from Parvaim.
3:7 The house, its beams and thresholds, as well as its walls and its doors, he overlaid with gold, and he engraved cherubim upon the walls.
3:8 He also made the room of the holy of holies. Its length corresponded to the width of the house, twenty cubits, and its width was also twenty cubits. He overlaid it with fine gold to the amount of six hundred talents.
3:9 The weight of the nails was fifty gold shekels. The upper chambers he likewise overlaid with gold.
3:10 For the room of the holy of holies he made two cherubim of carved workmanship, which were then covered with gold.
3:11 The wings of the cherubim spanned twenty cubits: one wing of each cherub, five cubits in length, extended to a wall of the house, while the other wing, also five cubits in length, touched the corresponding wing of the other cherub.
3:12 The wing of the cherub, five cubits, touched the wall of the house, and the other wing, five cubits, was joined to the wing of the other cherub.
3:13 The combined wingspread of the two cherubim was thus twenty cubits. They stood upon their own feet, facing toward the nave.
3:14 He made the veil of violet, purple, crimson, and fine linen, and had cherubim embroidered upon it.
3:15 In front of the house he set two columns thirty-five cubits high; the capital of each was five cubits.
3:16 He devised chains in the form of a collar with which he encircled the capitals of the columns, and he made a hundred pomegranates which he set on the chains.
3:17 He set up the columns to correspond with the nave, one for the right side and the other for the left, and he called the one to the right Jachin and the one to the left Boaz.
4:1 Then he made a bronze altar twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide and ten cubits high.
4:2 He also made the molten sea. It was made with a circular rim, and measured ten cubits across, five in height, and thirty in circumference.
4:3 Under the brim a ring of figures of oxen encircled it for ten cubits, all the way around the compass of the sea; there were two rows of oxen cast in one mold with the sea.
4:4 This rested on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east, with their haunches all toward the center; upon them was set the sea.
4:5 It was a handbreadth thick, and its brim resembled that of a cup, being lily-shaped. It had a capacity of three thousand baths.
4:6 Then he made ten basins for washing, placing five of them to the right and five to the left. In these the victims for the burnt offerings were washed; but the sea was for the priests to wash in.
4:7 He made the menorahs of gold, ten of them as was prescribed, and placed them in the nave, five to the right and five to the left.
4:8 He made ten tables and had them set in the nave, five to the right and five to the left; and he made a hundred golden bowls.
4:9 He made the court of the priests and the great courtyard and the gates of the courtyard; the gates he covered with bronze.
4:10 The sea he placed off to the southeast from the south side of the house.
4:11 When Huram had made the pots, shovels, and bowls, he finished all his work for King Solomon in the house of God:
4:12 two columns; two nodes for the capitals on top of the columns; and two pieces of netting covering the two nodes for the capitals on top of the columns;
4:13 four hundred pomegranates in double rows on both pieces of netting that covered the two nodes of the capitals on top of the columns.
4:14 He made the stands, and the basins on the stands;
4:15 one sea, and the twelve oxen under it;
4:16 pots, shovels, forks, and all the articles Huram-abi made for King Solomon for the house of the ; they were of burnished bronze.
4:17 The king had them cast in the neighborhood of the Jordan, between Succoth and Zeredah, in thick clay molds.
4:18 Solomon made all these vessels, so many in number that the weight of the bronze could not be determined.
4:19 Solomon made all the articles that were for the house of God: the golden altar, the tables on which the showbread lay,
4:20 the menorahs and their lamps of pure gold which were to burn as prescribed before the inner sanctuary,
4:21 flowers, lamps, and gold tongs (this was of purest gold),
4:22 snuffers, bowls, cups, and firepans of pure gold. As for the entrance to the house, its inner doors to the holy of holies, as well as the doors to the nave of the temple, were of gold.
5:1 When all the work undertaken by Solomon for the house of the was completed, he brought in the votive offerings of David his father, putting the silver, the gold, and other articles in the treasuries of the house of God.
5:2 Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel and all the heads of the tribes, the princes in the ancestral houses of the Israelites, to Jerusalem to bring up the ark of the s covenant from the City of David, which is Zion.
5:3 All the people of Israel assembled before the king during the festival of the seventh month.
5:4 When all the elders of Israel had arrived, the Levites took up the ark;
5:5 and they brought up the ark and the tent of meeting with all the sacred vessels that were in the tent. The levitical priests brought them up.
5:6 King Solomon and the entire community of Israel, gathered for the occasion before the ark, sacrificed sheep and oxen too many to number or count.
5:7 The priests brought the ark of the covenant of the to its place: the inner sanctuary of the house, the holy of holies, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
5:8 The cherubim had their wings spread out over the place of the ark, covering the ark and its poles from above.
5:9 The poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the holy place in front of the inner sanctuary. (They cannot be seen from outside, but they remain there to this day.)
5:10 There was nothing in the ark but the two tablets which Moses had put there at Horeb when the made a covenant with the Israelites after they went forth from Egypt.
5:11 When the priests left the holy place (all the priests who were present had purified themselves regardless of the rotation of their various divisions),
5:12 the Levites who were singers, all who belonged to Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and their sons and brothers, clothed in fine linen, with cymbals, harps, and lyres, stood east of the altar, and with them a hundred and twenty priests blowing trumpets.
5:13 When the trumpeters and singers were heard as a single voice praising and giving thanks to the , and when they raised the sound of the trumpets, cymbals, and other musical instruments to Praise the , who is so good, whose love endures forever, the cloud filled the house of the .
5:14 The priests could no longer minister because of the cloud, since the glory of the had filled the house of God.
6:1 Then Solomon said: The intends to dwell in the dark cloud;
6:2 I have built you a princely house, the base for your enthronement forever.
6:3 The king turned and blessed the whole assembly of Israel, while the whole assembly of Israel stood.
6:4 He said: Blessed be the , the God of Israel, who with his own mouth spoke a promise to David my father and by his hand fulfilled it, saying:
6:5 Since the day I brought my people out of the land of Egypt, I have not chosen a city out of any tribe of Israel for the building of a house, that my name might be there; nor have I chosen any man to be ruler of my people Israel;
6:6 but now I have chosen Jerusalem, that my name may be there, and I have chosen David to rule my people Israel.
6:7 When David my father wished to build a house for the name of the , the God of Israel,
6:8 the said to him: In wishing to build a house for my name, you did well.
6:9 But it is not you who will build the house, but your son, who comes from your loins: he shall build the house for my name.
6:10 Now the has fulfilled the word he spoke. I have succeeded David my father, and I sit on the throne of Israel, as the has said, and I have built this house for the name of the , the God of Israel.
6:11 I have placed there the ark, in which is the covenant of the that he made with the Israelites.
6:12 Then he stood before the altar of the in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel and stretched forth his hands.
6:13 Solomon had made a bronze platform five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high, which he had placed in the middle of the courtyard. Having ascended it, Solomon knelt in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel and stretched forth his hands toward heaven.
6:14 He said: , God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven or on earth; you keep the covenant and love toward your servants who walk before you with their whole heart,
6:15 the covenant that you kept toward your servant, David my father. That which you promised him, your mouth has spoken and your hand has fulfilled this very day.
6:16 And now, , God of Israel, keep toward your servant, David my father, what you promised: There shall never be wanting someone from your line to sit before me on the throne of Israel, provided that your descendants keep to their way, walking by my law, as you have.
6:17 Now, , God of Israel, may the words which you spoke to David your servant be confirmed.
6:18 Is God indeed to dwell with human beings on earth? If the heavens and the highest heavens cannot contain you, how much less this house which I have built!
6:19 Regard kindly the prayer and petition of your servant, , my God, and listen to the cry of supplication which I, your servant, utter before you.
6:20 May your eyes be open day and night toward this house, the place where you have decreed your name shall be; listen to the prayer your servant makes toward this place.
6:21 Listen to the petition of your servant and of your people Israel which they offer toward this place. Listen, from the place of your enthronement, heaven, and listen and forgive.
6:22 If someone sins against a neighbor and is required to take an oath sanctioned by a curse, and comes and takes the oath before your altar in this house,
6:23 listen in heaven: act and judge your servants. Condemn the wicked, requiting their ways; acquit the just, rewarding their justice.
6:24 When your people Israel are defeated by an enemy because they have sinned against you, and then they turn, praise your name, pray to you, and entreat you in this house,
6:25 listen from heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land you gave them and their ancestors.
6:26 When the heavens are closed so that there is no rain, because they have sinned against you, but they pray toward this place and praise your name, and turn from their sin because you have afflicted them,
6:27 listen in heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel. (For you teach them the good way in which they should walk.) Give rain upon this land of yours which you have given to your people as their heritage.
6:28 If there is famine in the land or pestilence; or if blight comes, or mildew, or locusts swarm, or caterpillars; when their enemies besiege them at any of their gates; whatever plague or sickness there may be;
6:29 whatever prayer of petition any may make, any of your people Israel, who know affliction and pain and stretch out their hands toward this house,
6:30 listen from heaven, the place of your enthronement, and forgive. Render to each and all according to their ways, you who know every heart; for it is you alone who know the heart of every human being.
6:31 So may they revere you and walk in your ways as long as they live on the land you gave our ancestors.
6:32 To the foreigners, likewise, who are not of your people Israel, but who come from a distant land for the sake of your great name, your mighty hand and outstretched arm, and come in prayer to this house,
6:33 listen from heaven, the place of your enthronement. Do all that the foreigner asks of you, that all the peoples of the earth may know your name, may revere you as do your people Israel, and may know that your name has been invoked upon this house that I have built.
6:34 When your people go out to war against their enemies, by whatever way you send them, and they pray to you toward the city you have chosen and the house I have built for your name,
6:35 listen from heaven to their prayer and petition, and uphold their cause.
6:36 When they sin against you (for there is no one who does not sin), and in your anger against them you deliver them to an enemy, so that their captors carry them off to another land, far or near,
6:37 and they have a change of heart in the land of their captivity and they turn and entreat you in the land of their captors and say, We have sinned and done wrong; we have been wicked,
6:38 if with all their heart and soul they turn back to you in the land of those who took them captive, and pray toward their land which you gave their ancestors, the city you have chosen, and the house which I have built for your name,
6:39 listen from heaven, the place of your enthronement, to their prayer and petitions, and uphold their cause. Forgive your people who have sinned against you.
6:40 Now, my God, may your eyes be open and your ears be attentive to the prayer of this place.
6:41 And now: Arise, God, come to your resting place, you and your majestic ark. Your priests, God, will be clothed with salvation, your faithful ones rejoice in good things.
6:42 God, do not reject the plea of your anointed, remember the devotion of David, your servant.
7:1 When Solomon had ended his prayer, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offerings and the sacrifices, and the glory of the filled the house.
7:2 But the priests could not enter the house of the , for the glory of the filled the house of the .
7:3 All the Israelites looked on while the fire came down and the glory of the was upon the house, and they fell down upon the pavement with their faces to the earth and worshiped, praising the , who is so good, whose love endures forever.
7:4 The king and all the people offered sacrifices before the .
7:5 King Solomon offered as sacrifice twenty-two thousand oxen, and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. Thus the king and all the people dedicated the house of God.
7:6 The priests were standing at their stations, as were the Levites, with the musical instruments of the which King David had made to give thanks to the , whose love endures forever, when David offered praise through them. The priests opposite them blew the trumpets and all Israel stood.
7:7 Then Solomon consecrated the middle of the court facing the house of the ; he offered there the burnt offerings and the fat of the communion offerings, since the bronze altar which Solomon had made could not hold the burnt offering, the grain offering, and the fat.
7:8 On this occasion Solomon and with him all Israel, a great assembly from Lebo-hamath to the Wadi of Egypt, celebrated the festival for seven days.
7:9 On the eighth day they held a solemn assembly, for they had celebrated the dedication of the altar for seven days and the feast for seven days.
7:10 On the twenty-third day of the seventh month he dismissed the people to their tents, rejoicing and glad of heart because of all the blessings the had given to David, to Solomon, and to his people Israel.
7:11 Solomon finished building the house of the , the house of the king, and everything else he wanted to do in regard to the house of the and his own house.
7:12 The appeared to Solomon during the night and said to him: I have heard your prayer, and I have chosen this place for my house of sacrifice.
7:13 If I close heaven so that there is no rain, if I command the locust to devour the land, if I send pestilence among my people,
7:14 if then my people, upon whom my name has been pronounced, humble themselves and pray, and seek my face and turn from their evil ways, I will hear them from heaven and pardon their sins and heal their land.
7:15 Now, therefore, my eyes shall be open and my ears attentive to the prayer of this place;
7:16 now I have chosen and consecrated this house that my name may be there forever; my eyes and my heart shall be there always.
7:17 As for you, if you walk before me as David your father did, doing all that I have commanded you and keeping my statutes and ordinances,
7:18 I will establish the throne of your kingship as I covenanted with David your father when I said, There shall never be wanting someone from your line as ruler in Israel.
7:19 But if ever you turn away and forsake my commandments and statutes which I set before you, and proceed to serve other gods, and bow down to them,
7:20 I will uproot the people from the land I gave and repudiate the house I have consecrated for my name. I will make it a proverb and a byword among all nations.
7:21 And this house which is so exalted—every passerby shall be horrified and ask: Why has the done such things to this land and to this house?
7:22 And the answer will come: Because they abandoned the , the God of their ancestors, who brought them out of the land of Egypt, and they embraced other gods, bowing down to them and serving them. That is why he has brought upon them all this evil.
8:1 After the twenty years during which Solomon built the house of the and his own house,
8:2 he built up the cities which Huram had given him, and settled Israelites there.
8:3 Then Solomon went to Hamath of Zoba and conquered it.
8:4 He built Tadmor in the wilderness and all the supply cities, which he built in Hamath.
8:5 He built Upper Beth-horon and Lower Beth-horon, fortified cities with walls, gates, and bars;
8:6 also Baalath, all the supply cities belonging to Solomon, and all the cities for the chariots, the cities for horses, and whatever else Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and in the entire land under his dominion.
