26:11 The priests and prophets said to the princes and to all the people, Sentence this man to death! He has prophesied against this city! You heard it with your own ears.
26:12 Jeremiah said to the princes and all the people: It was the who sent me to prophesy against this house and city everything you have heard.
26:13 Now, therefore, reform your ways and your deeds; listen to the voice of the your God, so that the will have a change of heart regarding the evil he has spoken against you.
26:14 As for me, I am in your hands; do with me what is good and right in your eyes.
26:15 But you should certainly know that by putting me to death, you bring innocent blood on yourselves, on this city and its inhabitants. For in truth it was the who sent me to you, to speak all these words for you to hear.
26:16 Then the princes and all the people said to the priests and the prophets, This man does not deserve a death sentence; it is in the name of the , our God, that he speaks to us.
26:17 At this, some of the elders of the land arose and said to the whole assembly of the people,
26:18 Micah of Moresheth used to prophesy in the days of Hezekiah, king of Judah, and he said to all the people of Judah: Thus says the of hosts: Zion shall be plowed as a field, Jerusalem, a heap of ruins, and the temple mount, a forest ridge.
26:19 Did Hezekiah, king of Judah, and all Judah condemn him to death? Did he not fear the and entreat the favor of the , so that the had a change of heart regarding the evil he had spoken against them? We, however, are about to do great evil against ourselves.
26:20 There was another man who used to prophesy in the name of the , Uriah, son of Shemaiah, from Kiriath-jearim; he prophesied against this city and this land the same message as Jeremiah.
26:21 When King Jehoiakim and all his officers and princes heard his words, the king sought to have him killed. But Uriah heard of it and fled in fear to Egypt.
26:22 Then King Jehoiakim sent Elnathan, son of Achbor, and others with him into Egypt,
26:23 and they brought Uriah out of Egypt and took him to Jehoiakim the king, who struck him down with the sword and threw his corpse into the common burial ground.
26:24 But the hand of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, protected Jeremiah, so they did not hand him over to the people to be put to death.
27:1 In the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, son of Josiah, king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the :
27:2 The said to me: Make for yourself thongs and yoke bars and put them on your shoulders.
27:3 Send them to the kings of Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, Tyre, and Sidon, through the ambassadors who have come to Jerusalem to Zedekiah, king of Judah,
27:4 and command them to tell their lords: Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel, Thus shall you say to your lords:
27:5 It was I who made the earth, human being and beast on the face of the earth, by my great power, with my outstretched arm; and I can give them to whomever I think fit.
27:6 Now I have given all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, my servant; even the wild animals I have given him to serve him.
27:7 All nations shall serve him and his son and his grandson, until the time comes for him and his land; then many nations and great kings will enslave him.
27:8 Meanwhile, the nation or the kingdom that will not serve him, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, or bend its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, I will punish that nation with sword, famine, and pestilence—oracle of the —until I finish them by his hand.
27:9 You, however, must not listen to your prophets, to your diviners and dreamers, to your soothsayers and sorcerers, who say to you, Do not serve the king of Babylon.
27:10 For they prophesy lies to you, so as to drive you far from your land, making me banish you so that you perish.
27:11 The people that bends the neck to the yoke of the king of Babylon to serve him, I will leave in peace on its own land—oracle of the —to cultivate it and dwell on it.
27:12 To Zedekiah, king of Judah, I spoke the same words: Bend your necks to the yoke of the king of Babylon; serve him and his people, so that you may live.
27:13 Why should you and your people die by sword, famine, and pestilence, in accordance with the word the has spoken to the nation that will not serve the king of Babylon?
27:14 Do not listen to the words of the prophets who say to you, Do not serve the king of Babylon. They prophesy lies to you!
27:15 I did not send them—oracle of the —but they prophesy falsely in my name. As a result I must banish you, and you will perish, you and the prophets who are prophesying to you.
27:16 To the priests and to all the people I said: Thus says the : Do not listen to the words of your prophets who prophesy to you: The vessels of the house of the will soon be brought back from Babylon, for they prophesy lies to you.
27:17 Do not listen to them! Serve the king of Babylon that you may live. Why should this city become rubble?
27:18 If they were prophets, if the word of the were with them, then they would intercede with the of hosts, that the vessels remaining in the house of the and in the house of the king of Judah and in Jerusalem should not also go to Babylon.
27:19 For thus says the of hosts concerning the pillars, the sea, the stands, and the rest of the vessels remaining in this city,
27:20 which Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, did not take when he exiled Jeconiah, son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, from Jerusalem to Babylon, along with all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem—
27:21 thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel, concerning the vessels remaining in the house of the , in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem:
27:22 To Babylon they shall go, and there they shall remain, until the day I look for them—oracle of the ; then I will bring them back and restore them to this place.
28:1 That same year, in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah, in the fifth month of the fourth year, Hananiah the prophet, son of Azzur, from Gibeon, said to me in the house of the in the sight of the priests and all the people:
28:2 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon.
28:3 Within two years I will restore to this place all the vessels of the house of the which Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, took from this place and carried away to Babylon.
28:4 And Jeconiah, son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, and all the exiles of Judah who went to Babylon, I will bring back to this place—oracle of the —for I will break the yoke of the king of Babylon.
28:5 Jeremiah the prophet answered the prophet Hananiah in the sight of the priests and all the people standing in the house of the ,
28:6 and said: Amen! thus may the do! May the fulfill your words that you have prophesied, by bringing back the vessels of the house of the and all the exiles from Babylon to this place!
28:7 But now, listen to the word I am about to speak in your hearing and the hearing of all the people.
28:8 In the past, the prophets who came before you and me prophesied war, disaster, and pestilence against many lands and mighty kingdoms.
28:9 But the prophet who prophesies peace is recognized as the prophet whom the has truly sent only when his word comes to pass.
28:10 Thereupon Hananiah the prophet took the yoke bar from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet and broke it.
28:11 He said in the sight of all the people: Thus says the : Like this, within two years I will break the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, from the neck of all the nations. At that, the prophet Jeremiah went on his way.
28:12 After Hananiah the prophet had broken the yoke bar off the neck of the prophet Jeremiah, the word of the came to Jeremiah:
28:13 Go tell Hananiah this: Thus says the : By breaking a wooden yoke bar, you make an iron yoke!
28:14 For thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: A yoke of iron I have placed on the necks of all these nations serving Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and they shall serve him; even the wild animals I have given him.
28:15 And Jeremiah the prophet said to Hananiah the prophet: Listen to this, Hananiah! The has not sent you, and you have led this people to rely on deception.
28:16 For this, says the , I am sending you from the face of the earth; this very year you shall die, because you have preached rebellion against the .
28:17 Hananiah the prophet died in that year, in the seventh month.
29:1 These are the words of the scroll which Jeremiah the prophet sent from Jerusalem to the remaining elders among the exiles, to the priests, the prophets, and all the people whom Nebuchadnezzar exiled from Jerusalem to Babylon.
29:2 This was after King Jeconiah and the queen mother, the court officials, the princes of Judah and Jerusalem, the artisans and smiths had left Jerusalem.
29:3 Delivered in Babylon by Elasah, son of Shaphan, and by Gemariah, son of Hilkiah, whom Zedekiah, king of Judah, sent to the king of Babylon, the letter read:
29:4 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel, to all the exiles whom I exiled from Jerusalem to Babylon:
29:5 Build houses and live in them; plant gardens and eat their fruits.
29:6 Take wives and have sons and daughters; find wives for your sons and give your daughters to husbands, so that they may bear sons and daughters. Increase there; do not decrease.
29:7 Seek the welfare of the city to which I have exiled you; pray for it to the , for upon its welfare your own depends.
29:8 For thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Do not be deceived by the prophets and diviners who are among you; do not listen to those among you who dream dreams,
29:9 for they prophesy lies to you in my name; I did not send them—oracle of the .
29:10 For thus says the : Only after seventy years have elapsed for Babylon will I deal with you and fulfill for you my promise to bring you back to this place.
29:11 For I know well the plans I have in mind for you—oracle of the —plans for your welfare and not for woe, so as to give you a future of hope.
29:12 When you call me, and come and pray to me, I will listen to you.
29:13 When you look for me, you will find me. Yes, when you seek me with all your heart,
29:14 I will let you find me—oracle of the —and I will change your lot; I will gather you together from all the nations and all the places to which I have banished you—oracle of the —and bring you back to the place from which I have exiled you.
29:15 As for your saying, The has raised up for us prophets here in Babylon—
29:16 Thus says the concerning the king sitting on Davids throne and all the people living in this city, your kinsmen who did not go with you into exile;
29:17 thus says the of hosts: I am sending against them sword, famine, and pestilence. I will make them like rotten figs, so spoiled that they cannot be eaten.
29:18 I will pursue them with sword, famine, and pestilence, and make them an object of horror to all the kingdoms of the earth, a curse, a desolation, a hissing, and a reproach to all the nations among which I have banished them,
29:19 because they did not listen to my words—oracle of the —even though I kept sending them my servants the prophets, but they would not listen to them—oracle of the .
29:20 As for you, listen to the word of the , all you exiles whom I sent away from Jerusalem to Babylon.
29:21 This is what the of hosts, the God of Israel, says about Ahab, son of Kolaiah, and Zedekiah, son of Maaseiah, who prophesy lies to you in my name: I am handing them over to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, who will kill them before your eyes.
29:22 And because of them this curse will be used by all the exiles of Judah in Babylon: May the make you like Zedekiah and Ahab, whom the king of Babylon roasted in fire,
29:23 because they have committed an outrage in Israel, committing adultery with their neighbors wives, and alleging in my name things I did not command. I know, I am witness—oracle of the .
29:24 To Shemaiah, the Nehelamite, say:
29:25 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Because you sent documents in your own name to all the people in Jerusalem, to Zephaniah, the priest, son of Maaseiah, and to all the priests saying:
29:26 It is the who has appointed you priest in place of the priest Jehoiada, to provide officers for the house of the , that you may confine in stocks or pillory any madman who poses as a prophet.
29:27 Why, then, have you not rebuked Jeremiah of Anathoth who poses as a prophet among you?
29:28 For he sent this message to us in Babylon: It will be a long time; build houses to live in; plant gardens and eat their fruit. . . .
29:29 When the priest Zephaniah read this letter to Jeremiah the prophet,
29:30 the word of the came to Jeremiah:
29:31 Send to all the exiles: Thus says the concerning Shemaiah, the Nehelamite: Because Shemaiah prophesies to you, although I did not send him, and has led you to rely on a lie,
29:32 therefore thus says the , I will punish Shemaiah, the Nehelamite, and his descendants. None of them shall dwell among this people to see the good I will do for this people—oracle of the —because he preached rebellion against the .
30:1 This word came to Jeremiah from the :
30:2 Thus says the , the God of Israel: Write down on a scroll all the words I have spoken to you.
30:3 For indeed, the days are coming—oracle of the —when I will restore the fortunes of my people Israel and Judah—oracle of the . I will bring them back to the land which I gave to their ancestors, and they shall take possession of it.
30:4 These are the words the spoke to Israel and to Judah:
30:5 Thus says the : We hear a cry of fear: terror, not peace.
30:6 Inquire and see: does a male give birth? Why, then, do I see all these men, their hands on their loins Like women in labor, all their faces drained of color?
30:7 Ah! How mighty is that day— there is none like it! A time of distress for Jacob, though he shall be saved from it.
30:8 On that day—oracle of the of hosts—I will break his yoke off your neck and snap your bonds. Strangers shall no longer enslave them;
30:9 instead, they shall serve the , their God, and David, their king, whom I will raise up for them.
30:10 But you, my servant Jacob, do not fear!—oracle of the — do not be dismayed, Israel! For I will soon deliver you from places far away, your offspring from the land of their exile; Jacob shall again find rest, secure, with none to frighten him,
30:11 for I am with you—oracle of the —to save you. I will bring to an end all the nations among whom I have scattered you; but you I will not bring to an end. I will chastise you as you deserve, I will not let you go unpunished.
30:12 For thus says the : Incurable is your wound, grievous your injury;
30:13 There is none to plead your case, no remedy for your running sore, no healing for you.
30:14 All your lovers have forgotten you, they do not seek you out. I struck you as an enemy would strike, punishing you cruelly.
30:15 Why cry out over your wound? There is no relief for your pain. Because of your great guilt, your numerous sins, I have done this to you.
30:16 Yet all who devour you shall be devoured, all your enemies shall go into exile. All who plunder you shall become plunder, all who pillage you I will hand over to be pillaged.
30:17 For I will restore your health; I will heal your injuries—oracle of the . The outcast they have called you, whom no one looks for.
30:18 Thus says the : See! I will restore the fortunes of Jacobs tents, on his dwellings I will have compassion; A city shall be rebuilt upon its own ruins, a citadel restored where it should be.
30:19 From them will come praise, the sound of people rejoicing. I will increase them, they will not decrease, I will glorify them, they will not be insignificant.
30:20 His children shall be as of old, his assembly shall stand firm in my presence, I will punish all his oppressors.
30:21 His leader shall be one of his own, and his ruler shall emerge from his ranks. He shall approach me when I summon him; Why else would he dare approach me?—oracle of the .
30:22 You shall be my people, and I will be your God.
30:23 Look! The storm of the ! His wrath breaks out In a whirling storm that bursts upon the heads of the wicked.
30:24 The anger of the will not abate until he has carried out completely the decisions of his heart. In days to come you will fully understand it.
31:1 At that time—oracle of the — I will be the God of all the families of Israel, and they shall be my people.
31:2 Thus says the : The people who escaped the sword find favor in the wilderness. As Israel comes forward to receive rest,
31:3 from afar the appears: With age-old love I have loved you; so I have kept my mercy toward you.
31:4 Again I will build you, and you shall stay built, virgin Israel; Carrying your festive tambourines, you shall go forth dancing with merrymakers.
31:5 You shall again plant vineyards on the mountains of Samaria; those who plant them shall enjoy their fruits.
31:6 Yes, a day will come when the watchmen call out on Mount Ephraim: Come, let us go up to Zion, to the , our God.
31:7 For thus says the : Shout with joy for Jacob, exult at the head of the nations; proclaim your praise and say: The has saved his people, the remnant of Israel.
31:8 Look! I will bring them back from the land of the north; I will gather them from the ends of the earth, the blind and the lame in their midst, Pregnant women, together with those in labor— an immense throng—they shall return.
31:9 With weeping they shall come, but with compassion I will guide them; I will lead them to streams of water, on a level road, without stumbling. For I am a father to Israel, Ephraim is my firstborn.
31:10 Hear the word of the , you nations, proclaim it on distant coasts, and say: The One who scattered Israel, now gathers them; he guards them as a shepherd his flock.
31:11 The shall ransom Jacob, he shall redeem him from a hand too strong for him.
31:12 Shouting, they shall mount the heights of Zion, they shall come streaming to the s blessings: The grain, the wine, and the oil, flocks of sheep and cattle; They themselves shall be like watered gardens, never again neglected.
31:13 Then young women shall make merry and dance, young men and old as well. I will turn their mourning into joy, I will show them compassion and have them rejoice after their sorrows.
31:14 I will lavish choice portions on the priests, and my people shall be filled with my blessings— oracle of the .
31:15 Thus says the : In Ramah is heard the sound of sobbing, bitter weeping! Rachel mourns for her children, she refuses to be consoled for her children—they are no more!
31:16 Thus says the : Cease your cries of weeping, hold back your tears! There is compensation for your labor— oracle of the — they shall return from the enemys land.
31:17 There is hope for your future—oracle of the — your children shall return to their own territory.
31:18 Indeed, I heard Ephraim rocking in grief: You chastised me, and I was chastised; I was like an untamed calf. Bring me back, let me come back, for you are the , my God.
31:19 For after I turned away, I repented; after I came to myself, I struck my thigh; I was ashamed, even humiliated, because I bore the disgrace of my youth.
31:20 Is Ephraim not my favored son, the child in whom I delight? Even though I threaten him, I must still remember him! My heart stirs for him, I must show him compassion!—oracle of the .
31:21 Set up road markers, put up signposts; Turn your attention to the highway, the road you walked. Turn back, virgin Israel, turn back to these your cities.
31:22 How long will you continue to hesitate, rebellious daughter? The has created a new thing upon the earth: woman encompasses man.
31:23 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: When I restore their fortunes in the land of Judah and in its cities, they shall again use this greeting: May the bless you, Tent of Justice, Holy Mountain!
31:24 Judah and all its cities, the farmers and those who lead the flock shall dwell there together.
31:25 For I will slake the thirst of the faint; the appetite of all the weary I will satisfy.
31:26 At this I awoke and opened my eyes; my sleep was satisfying.
31:27 See, days are coming—oracle of the —when I will sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah with the seed of human beings and the seed of animals.
31:28 As I once watched over them to uproot and tear down, to demolish, to destroy, and to harm, so I will watch over them to build and to plant—oracle of the .
31:29 In those days they shall no longer say, The parents ate unripe grapes, and the childrens teeth are set on edge,
31:30 but all shall die because of their own iniquity: the teeth of anyone who eats unripe grapes shall be set on edge. 
31:31 See, days are coming—oracle of the —when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and the house of Judah.
31:32 It will not be like the covenant I made with their ancestors the day I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt. They broke my covenant, though I was their master—oracle of the .
31:33 But this is the covenant I will make with the house of Israel after those days—oracle of the . I will place my law within them, and write it upon their hearts; I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
31:34 They will no longer teach their friends and relatives, Know the ! Everyone, from least to greatest, shall know me—oracle of the —for I will forgive their iniquity and no longer remember their sin.
31:35 Thus says the , Who gives the sun to light the day, moon and stars to light the night; Who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar, whose name is of hosts:
31:36 If ever this fixed order gives way before me—oracle of the — Then would the offspring of Israel cease as a people before me forever.
31:37 Thus says the : If the heavens on high could be measured, or the foundations below the earth be explored, Then would I reject all the offspring of Israel because of all they have done—oracle of the . 
31:38 See, days are coming—oracle of the —when the city shall be rebuilt as the s, from the Tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate.
31:39 A measuring line shall be stretched from there straight to the hill Gareb and then turn to Goah.
31:40 The whole valley of corpses and ashes, all the terraced slopes toward the Wadi Kidron, as far as the corner of the Horse Gate at the east, shall be holy to the . Never again shall the city be uprooted or demolished.
32:1 The word came to Jeremiah from the in the tenth year of Zedekiah, king of Judah, the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar.
32:2 At that time the army of the king of Babylon was besieging Jerusalem, while Jeremiah the prophet was confined to the court of the guard, in the house of the king of Judah.
32:3 Zedekiah, king of Judah, had confined him there, saying: How dare you prophesy: Thus says the : I am handing this city over to the king of Babylon that he may capture it.
32:4 Zedekiah, king of Judah, shall not escape the hands of the Chaldeans: he shall indeed be handed over to the king of Babylon. He shall speak with him face to face and see him eye to eye.
32:5 He shall take Zedekiah to Babylon. There he shall remain, until I attend to him—oracle of the . If you fight against the Chaldeans, you cannot win!
32:6 Jeremiah said, This word came to me from the :
32:7 Hanamel, son of your uncle Shallum, will come to you with the offer: Purchase my field in Anathoth, since you, as nearest relative, have the first right of purchase.
32:8 And, just as the had said, my cousin Hanamel came to me in the court of the guard and said, Please purchase my field in Anathoth, in the territory of Benjamin; as nearest relative, you have the first right of possession—purchase it for yourself. Then I knew this was the word of the .
32:9 So I bought the field in Anathoth from my cousin Hanamel, weighing out for him the silver, seventeen shekels of silver.
32:10 When I had written and sealed the deed, called witnesses and weighed out the silver on the scales,
32:11 I accepted the deed of purchase, both the sealed copy, containing title and conditions, and the open copy.
32:12 I gave this deed of purchase to Baruch, son of Neriah, son of Mahseiah, in the presence of my cousin Hanamel and the witnesses who had signed the deed of purchase and before all the Judahites sitting around in the court of the guard.
32:13 In their presence I gave Baruch this charge:
32:14 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Take these deeds of purchase, both the sealed and the open deeds, and put them in an earthenware jar, so they can last a long time.
32:15 For thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: They shall again purchase houses and fields and vineyards in this land.
32:16 After I had given the deed of purchase to Baruch, son of Neriah, I prayed to the :
32:17 Ah, my Lord ! You made the heavens and the earth with your great power and your outstretched arm; nothing is too difficult for you.
32:18 You continue your kindness through a thousand generations; but you repay the ancestors guilt upon their children who follow them. Great and mighty God, whose name is of hosts,
32:19 great in counsel, mighty in deed, whose eyes are fixed on all the ways of mortals, giving to all according to their ways, according to the fruit of their deeds:
32:20 you performed signs and wonders in the land of Egypt and to this day, in Israel and among all peoples, you have made a name for yourself as on this day.
32:21 You brought your people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs and wonders, with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, and great terror.
32:22 And you gave them this land, as you had sworn to their ancestors to give them, a land flowing with milk and honey.
32:23 They went in and took possession of it, but they did not listen to your voice. They did not live by your law; they did not do anything you commanded them to do. Then you made all this evil fall upon them.
32:24 See, the siegeworks have arrived at this city to capture it; the city is handed over to the Chaldeans who are attacking it, with sword, starvation, and disease. What you threatened has happened—you can see it for yourself.
32:25 Yet you told me, my Lord : Purchase the field with silver and summon witnesses, when the city has already been handed over to the Chaldeans!
32:26 Then this word of the came to Jeremiah:
32:27 I am the , the God of all the living! Is anything too difficult for me?
32:28 Therefore the says: I am handing over this city to the Chaldeans and to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and he shall capture it.
32:29 The Chaldeans who are attacking this city shall go in and set the city on fire, burning it and the houses, on whose roofs incense was burned to Baal and libations were poured out to other gods in order to provoke me.
32:30 From their youth the Israelites and the Judahites have been doing only what is evil in my eyes; the Israelites have been provoking me with the works of their hands—oracle of the .
32:31 This city has so stirred my anger and wrath, from the day it was built to this day, that I must put it out of my sight,
32:32 for all the evil the Israelites and Judahites have done to provoke me—they, their kings, their princes, their priests, and their prophets, the people of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
32:33 They turned their backs to me, not their faces; though I taught them persistently, they would not listen or accept correction.
32:34 Instead they set up their abominations in the house which bears my name in order to defile it.
32:35 They built high places to Baal in the Valley of Ben-hinnom to sacrifice their sons and daughters to Molech; I never commanded them to do this, nor did it even enter my mind that they would practice this abomination, so as to bring sin upon Judah.
32:36 Now, therefore, thus says the , the God of Israel, concerning this city, which you say is being handed over to the king of Babylon by means of the sword, starvation, and disease:
32:37 See, I am gathering them from all the lands to which I drove them in my rising fury and great anger; I will bring them back to this place and settle them here in safety.
32:38 They shall be my people, and I will be their God.
32:39 I will give them one heart and one way, that they may fear me always, for their own good and the good of their children after them.
32:40 With them I will make an everlasting covenant, never to cease doing good to them; I will put fear of me in their hearts so that they never turn away from me.
32:41 I will take delight in doing good to them: I will plant them firmly in this land, with all my heart and soul.
32:42 For thus says the : Just as I have brought upon this people all this great evil, so I will bring upon them all the good I have promised them.
32:43 Fields shall be purchased in this land, about which you say, It is a wasteland, without human beings or animals, handed over to the Chaldeans.
32:44 They will purchase fields with silver, write up deeds, seal them, and have them witnessed in the land of Benjamin, in the neighborhood of Jerusalem, in the cities of Judah and of the hill country, in the cities of the Shephelah and the Negeb, when I restore their fortunes—oracle of the .
33:1 The word of the came to Jeremiah a second time while he was still confined in the court of the guard:
33:2 Thus says the who made the earth, giving it shape and stability, is his name:
33:3 Call to me, and I will answer you; I will tell you great things beyond the reach of your knowledge.
33:4 Thus says the , the God of Israel, concerning the houses of this city and the houses of the kings of Judah, which are being torn down because of the siegeworks and the sword:
33:5 men come to battle the Chaldeans, and to fill these houses with the corpses of those whom I have struck down in my raging anger, when I hid my face from this city because of all their wickedness.
33:6 Look! I am bringing the city recovery and healing; I will heal them and reveal to them an abundance of lasting peace.
33:7 I will restore the fortunes of Judah and Israel, and rebuild them as they were in the beginning.
33:8 I will purify them of all the guilt they incurred by sinning against me; I will forgive all their offenses by which they sinned and rebelled against me.
33:9 Then this city shall become joy for me, a name of praise and pride, before all the nations of the earth, as they hear of all the good I am doing for them. They shall fear and tremble because of all the prosperity I give it.
33:10 Thus says the : In this place, about which you say: It is a waste without people or animals! and in the cities of Judah, in the streets of Jerusalem now deserted, without people, without inhabitant, without animal, there shall yet be heard
33:11 the song of joy, the song of gladness, the song of the bridegroom, the song of the bride, the song of those bringing thank offerings to the house of the : Give thanks to the of hosts, for the is good; Gods love endures forever. For I will restore the fortunes of this land as they were in the beginning, says the .
33:12 Thus says the of hosts: In this place, now a waste, without people or animals, and in all its cities there shall again be sheepfolds for the shepherds to rest their flocks.
33:13 In the cities of the hill country, of the Shephelah and the Negeb, in the land of Benjamin and the neighborhood of Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, flocks will again pass under the hands of the one who counts them, says the .
33:14 The days are coming—oracle of the —when I will fulfill the promise I made to the house of Israel and the house of Judah.
33:15 In those days, at that time, I will make a just shoot spring up for David; he shall do what is right and just in the land.
33:16 In those days Judah shall be saved and Jerusalem shall dwell safely; this is the name they shall call her: The our justice.
33:17 For thus says the : David shall never lack a successor on the throne of the house of Israel,
33:18 nor shall the priests of Levi ever be lacking before me, to sacrifice burnt offerings, to burn cereal offerings, and to make sacrifices.
33:19 This word of the also came to Jeremiah:
33:20 Thus says the : If you can break my covenant with day and my covenant with night so that day and night no longer appear in their proper time,
33:21 only then can my covenant with my servant David be broken, so that he will not have a descendant to act as king upon his throne, and my covenant with the priests of Levi who minister to me.
33:22 Just as the host of heaven cannot be numbered and the sands of the sea cannot be counted, so I will multiply the descendants of David my servant and the Levites who minister to me.
33:23 This word of the came to Jeremiah:
33:24 Have you not noticed what these people are saying: The has rejected the two tribes he had chosen? They hold my people in contempt as if it were no longer a nation in their eyes.
33:25 Thus says the : If I have no covenant with day and night, if I did not establish statutes for heaven and earth,
33:26 then I will also reject the descendants of Jacob and of David my servant, no longer selecting from his descendants rulers for the offspring of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Yes, I will restore their fortunes and show them mercy.
34:1 The word which came to Jeremiah from the while Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and all his army and all the earths kingdoms under his rule, and all the peoples were attacking Jerusalem and all her cities:
34:2 Thus says the , the God of Israel: Go to Zedekiah, king of Judah, and tell him: Thus says the : I am handing this city over to the king of Babylon; he will burn it with fire.
34:3 You yourself shall not escape his hand; rather you will be captured and fall into his hand. You shall see the king of Babylon eye to eye and speak to him face to face. Then you shall go to Babylon.
34:4 Just hear the word of the , Zedekiah, king of Judah! Then, says the concerning you, you shall not die by the sword.
34:5 You shall die in peace, and they will burn spices for you as they did for your ancestors, the earlier kings who preceded you, and they shall make lament over you, Alas, Lord. I myself make this promise—oracle of the .
34:6 Jeremiah the prophet told all these things to Zedekiah, king of Judah, in Jerusalem,
34:7 while the army of the king of Babylon was attacking Jerusalem and the remaining cities of Judah, Lachish, and Azekah. Only these fortified cities were left standing out of all the cities of Judah! 
34:8 This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the after King Zedekiah had made a covenant with all the people in Jerusalem to proclaim freedom:
34:9 Everyone must free their Hebrew slaves, male and female, so that no one should hold another Judahite in servitude.
34:10 All the princes and the people who entered this covenant agreed to set free their slaves, their male and female servants, so that they should no longer be in servitude. But even though they agreed and freed them,
34:11 afterward they took back their male and female servants whom they had set free and again forced them into servitude.
34:12 Then this word of the came to Jeremiah:
34:13 Thus says the , the God of Israel: I myself made a covenant with your ancestors the day I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery:
34:14 Every seventh year each of you must set free all Hebrews who have sold themselves to you; six years they shall serve you, but then you shall let them go free. Your ancestors, however, did not listen to me or obey me.
34:15 As for you, today you repented and did what is right in my eyes by proclaiming freedom for your neighbor and making a covenant before me in the house which bears my name.
34:16 But then you again profaned my name by taking back your male and female slaves whom you had just set free for life; you forced them to become your slaves again.
34:17 Therefore, thus says the : You for your part did not obey me by proclaiming freedom for your families and neighbors. So I now proclaim freedom for you—oracle of the —for the sword, starvation, and disease. I will make you an object of horror to all the kingdoms of the earth.
34:18 Those who violated my covenant and did not observe the terms of the covenant they made in my presence—I will make them like the calf which they cut in two so they could pass between its parts—
34:19 the princes of Judah and of Jerusalem, the court officials, the priests, and all the people of the land, who passed between the parts of the calf.
34:20 These I will hand over to their enemies, to those who seek their lives: their corpses shall become food for the birds of the air and the beasts of the field.
34:21 Zedekiah, king of Judah, and his princes, I will hand also over to their enemies, to those who seek their lives, to the army of the king of Babylon which is now withdrawing from you.
34:22 I am giving the command—oracle of the —to bring them back to this city. They shall attack and capture it, and burn it with fire; the cities of Judah I will turn into a waste, where no one dwells.
35:1 The word that came to Jeremiah from the in the days of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah:
35:2 Go to the house of the Rechabites, speak to them, and bring them to the house of the , to one of the rooms there, and give them wine to drink.
35:3 So I took Jaazaniah, son of Jeremiah, son of Habazziniah, his brothers and all his sons—the whole house of the Rechabites—
35:4 and I brought them to the house of the , to the room of the sons of Hanan, son of Igdaliah, the man of God, next to the room of the princes above the room of Maaseiah, son of Shallum, the guard at the entrance.
35:5 I set before the Rechabites bowls full of wine, and cups, and said to them, Drink some wine.
35:6 We do not drink wine, they said to me; Jonadab, Rechabs son, our father, commanded us, Neither you nor your children shall ever drink wine.
35:7 Build no house and sow no seed; do not plant vineyards or own any. You must dwell in tents all your lives, so that you may live long on the land where you live as resident aliens.
35:8 We have obeyed Jonadab, Rechabs son, our father, in everything that he commanded us: not drinking wine as long as we live—neither we nor our wives nor our sons nor our daughters;
35:9 not building houses to live in; not owning vineyards or fields or crops.
35:10 We live in tents, doing everything our father Jonadab commanded us.
35:11 But when Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, invaded this land, we said, Come, let us go into Jerusalem to escape the army of the Chaldeans and the army of the Arameans. That is why we are now living in Jerusalem.
35:12 Then the word of the came to Jeremiah:
35:13 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Go, say to the people of Judah and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem: Will you not take correction and obey my words?—oracle of the .
35:14 The words of Jonadab, Rechabs son, by which he commanded his children not to drink wine, have been upheld: to this day they have not drunk wine; they obeyed their ancestors command. I, however, have spoken to you time and again. But you did not obey me!
35:15 Time and again I sent you all my servants the prophets, saying: Turn away, each of you, from your evil way and reform your actions! Do not follow other gods to serve them that you may remain in the land which I gave you and your ancestors. But you did not pay attention. You did not obey me.
35:16 Yes, the children of Jonadab, Rechabs son, upheld the command which their father laid on them. But this people has not obeyed me!
35:17 Now, therefore, says the God of hosts, the God of Israel: I will soon bring upon Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem every evil with which I threatened them because I spoke but they did not obey, I called but they did not answer.
35:18 But to the house of the Rechabites Jeremiah said: Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Since you have obeyed the command of Jonadab, your father, kept all his commands and done everything he commanded you,
35:19 therefore, thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Never shall there fail to be a descendant of Jonadab, Rechabs son, standing in my presence.
36:1 In the fourth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the :
36:2 Take a scroll and write on it all the words I have spoken to you about Israel, Judah, and all the nations, from the day I first spoke to you, from the days of Josiah, until today.
36:3 Perhaps, if the house of Judah hears all the evil I have in mind to do to them, so that all of them turn from their evil way, then I can forgive their wickedness and their sin.
36:4 So Jeremiah called Baruch, son of Neriah, and he wrote down on a scroll what Jeremiah said, all the words which the had spoken to him.
36:5 Then Jeremiah commanded Baruch: I cannot enter the house of the ; I am barred from it.
36:6 So you yourself must go. On a fast day in the hearing of the people in the s house, read the words of the from the scroll you wrote at my dictation; read them also to all the people of Judah who come up from their cities.
36:7 Perhaps they will present their supplication before the and will all turn back from their evil way; for great is the anger and wrath with which the has threatened this people.
36:8 Baruch, son of Neriah, did everything Jeremiah the prophet commanded; from the scroll he read the s words in the s house.
36:9 In the ninth month, in the fifth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah, all the people of Jerusalem and all those who came from Judahs cities to Jerusalem proclaimed a fast before the .
36:10 So Baruch read the words of Jeremiah from the scroll in the room of Gemariah, son of the scribe Shaphan, in the upper court of the s house, at the entrance of the New Temple Gate, in the hearing of all the people.
36:11 Now Micaiah, son of Gemariah, son of Shaphan, heard all the words of the read from the scroll.
36:12 So he went down to the house of the king, into the scribes chamber, where the princes were meeting in session: Elishama, the scribe; Delaiah, son of Shemaiah; Elnathan, son of Achbor; Gemariah, son of Shaphan; Zedekiah, son of Hananiah; and the other princes.
36:13 Micaiah reported to them all that he had heard Baruch read from his scroll in the hearing of the people.
36:14 The princes immediately sent Jehudi, son of Nethaniah, son of Shelemiah, son of Cushi, to Baruch with the order: The scroll you read in the hearing of the people—bring it with you and come. Scroll in hand, Baruch, son of Neriah, went to them.
36:15 Sit down, they said to him, and read it in our hearing. Baruch read it in their hearing,
36:16 and when they had heard all its words, they turned to each other in alarm and said to Baruch, We have to tell the king all these things.
36:17 Then they asked Baruch: Tell us, please, how did you come to write down all these words? Was it at his dictation?
36:18 Yes, he would dictate all these words to me, Baruch answered them, while I wrote them down with ink in the scroll.
36:19 The princes said to Baruch, Go into hiding, you and Jeremiah; do not let anyone know where you are.
36:20 They went in to the king, into the courtyard; they had deposited the scroll in the room of Elishama the scribe. When they told the king everything that had happened,
36:21 the king sent Jehudi to get the scroll. Jehudi brought it from the room of Elishama the scribe, and read it to the king and to all the princes who were attending the king.
36:22 Now the king was sitting in his winter house, since it was the ninth month, and a fire was burning in the brazier before him.
36:23 Each time Jehudi finished reading three or four columns, he would cut off the piece with a scribes knife and throw it into the fire in the brazier, until the entire scroll was consumed in the fire in the brazier.
36:24 As they were listening to all these words the king and all his officials did not become alarmed, nor did they tear their garments.
36:25 And though Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah urged the king not to burn the scroll, he would not listen to them.
36:26 He commanded Jerahmeel, a royal prince, and Seraiah, son of Azriel, and Shelemiah, son of Abdeel, to arrest Baruch, the scribe, and Jeremiah the prophet. But the had hidden them away.
36:27 The word of the came to Jeremiah, after the king burned the scroll and the words Jeremiah had dictated to Baruch:
36:28 Take another scroll, and write on it all the words in the first scroll, which Jehoiakim, king of Judah, burned.
36:29 And against Jehoiakim, king of Judah, say this: Thus says the : You are the one who burned that scroll, saying, Why did you write on it: Babylons king shall surely come and ravage this land, emptying it of every living thing?
36:30 The now says of Jehoiakim, king of Judah: No descendant of his shall sit on Davids throne; his corpse shall be thrown out, exposed to heat by day, frost by night.
36:31 I will punish him and his descendants and his officials for their wickedness; upon them, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and the people of Judah I will bring all the evil threats to which they did not listen.
36:32 Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to his scribe, Baruch, son of Neriah, who wrote on it at Jeremiahs dictation all the words contained in the scroll which Jehoiakim, king of Judah, had burned in the fire, adding many words like them.
37:1 Zedekiah, son of Josiah, became king, succeeding Coniah, son of Jehoiakim; Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, appointed him king over the land of Judah.
37:2 Neither he, nor his officials, nor the people of the land would listen to the words which the spoke through Jeremiah the prophet.
37:3 Yet King Zedekiah sent Jehucal, son of Shelemiah, and Zephaniah, son of Maaseiah the priest, to Jeremiah the prophet with this request: Please appeal to the , our God, for us.
37:4 At this time Jeremiah still came and went freely among the people; he had not yet been put into prison.
37:5 Meanwhile, Pharaohs army had set out from Egypt, and when the Chaldeans who were besieging Jerusalem heard this report, they withdrew from the city.
37:6 Then the word of the came to Jeremiah the prophet:
37:7 Thus says the , the God of Israel: Thus you must say to the king of Judah who sent you to consult me: Listen! Pharaohs army, which has set out to help you, will return to Egypt, its own land.
37:8 The Chaldeans shall return and attack this city; they shall capture it and destroy it by fire.
37:9 Thus says the : Do not deceive yourselves, saying: The Chaldeans are surely leaving us forever. They are not!
37:10 Even if you could defeat the whole Chaldean army that is now attacking you, and only the wounded remained, each in his tent, these would rise up and destroy the city with fire.
37:11 Now when the Chaldean army withdrew from Jerusalem because of the army of Pharaoh,
37:12 Jeremiah set out from Jerusalem to go to the territory of Benjamin, to receive his share of property among the people.
37:13 But at the Gate of Benjamin, the captain of the guard, by the name of Irijah, son of Shelemiah, son of Hananiah, arrested Jeremiah the prophet, saying, You are deserting to the Chaldeans!
37:14 That is a lie! Jeremiah answered, I am not deserting to the Chaldeans. Without listening to him, Irijah kept Jeremiah in custody and brought him to the princes.
37:15 The princes were enraged at Jeremiah and had Jeremiah beaten and imprisoned in the house of Jonathan the scribe, for they were using it as a jail.
37:16 And so Jeremiah went into a room in the dungeon, where he remained many days.
37:17 Then King Zedekiah had him brought to his palace, and he asked him secretly, Is there any word from the ? There is! Jeremiah answered: You shall be handed over to the king of Babylon.
37:18 Jeremiah then asked King Zedekiah: How have I wronged you or your officials or this people, that you should put me in prison?
37:19 Where are your own prophets who prophesied for you, saying: The King of Babylon will not attack you or this land?
37:20 Please hear me, my lord king! Grant my petition: do not send me back into the house of Jonathan the scribe, or I shall die there.
37:21 So King Zedekiah ordered that Jeremiah be confined in the court of the guard and given a ration of bread every day from the bakers street until all the bread in the city was eaten up. Thus Jeremiah remained in the court of the guard.
38:1 Shephatiah, son of Mattan, Gedaliah, son of Pashhur, Jucal, son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur, son of Malchiah, heard the words Jeremiah was speaking to all the people:
38:2 Thus says the : Those who remain in this city shall die by means of the sword, starvation, and disease; but those who go out to the Chaldeans shall live. Their lives shall be spared them as spoils of war that they may live.
38:3 Thus says the : This city shall certainly be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon; he shall capture it.
38:4 Then the princes said to the king, This man ought to be put to death. He is weakening the resolve of the soldiers left in this city and of all the people, by saying such things to them; he is not seeking the welfare of our people, but their ruin.
38:5 King Zedekiah answered: He is in your hands, for the king could do nothing with them.
38:6 And so they took Jeremiah and threw him into the cistern of Prince Malchiah, in the court of the guard, letting him down by rope. There was no water in the cistern, only mud, and Jeremiah sank down into the mud.
38:7 Now Ebed-melech, an Ethiopian, a court official in the kings house, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the cistern. The king happened to be sitting at the Gate of Benjamin,
38:8 and Ebed-melech went there from the house of the king and said to him,
38:9 My lord king, these men have done wrong in all their treatment of Jeremiah the prophet, throwing him into the cistern. He will starve to death on the spot, for there is no more bread in the city.
38:10 Then the king ordered Ebed-melech the Ethiopian: Take three men with you, and get Jeremiah the prophet out of the cistern before he dies.
38:11 Ebed-melech took the men with him, and went first to the linen closet in the house of the king. He took some old, tattered rags and lowered them by rope to Jeremiah in the cistern.
38:12 Then he said to Jeremiah, Put these old, tattered rags between your armpits and the ropes. Jeremiah did so,
38:13 and they pulled him up by rope out of the cistern. But Jeremiah remained in the court of the guard.
38:14 King Zedekiah summoned Jeremiah the prophet to meet him at the third entrance of the house of the . I have a question to ask you, the king said to Jeremiah. Do not hide anything from me.
38:15 Jeremiah answered Zedekiah: If I tell you anything, will you not have me put to death? If I counsel you, you will not listen to me!
38:16 But King Zedekiah swore to Jeremiah secretly: As the lives who gave us our lives, I will not kill you, nor will I hand you over to those men who seek your life.
38:17 Jeremiah then said to Zedekiah: Thus says the God of hosts, the God of Israel: If you will only surrender to the princes of Babylons king, you shall save your life; this city shall not be destroyed by fire, and you and your household shall live.
38:18 But if you do not surrender to the princes of Babylons king, this city shall fall into the hand of the Chaldeans, who shall destroy it by fire, and you shall not escape their hand.
38:19 King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, I am afraid of the Judahites who have deserted to the Chaldeans; I could be handed over to them, and they will mistreat me.
38:20 You will not be handed over to them, Jeremiah answered. I beg you! Please listen to the voice of the regarding what I tell you so that it may go well with you and your life be spared.
38:21 But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the has shown:
38:22 I see all the women who remain in the house of Judahs king being brought out to the princes of Babylons king, and they are crying: They betrayed you, outdid you, your good friends! Now that your feet are sunk in mud, they slink away.
38:23 All your wives and children shall be brought out to the Chaldeans, and you shall not escape their hands; you shall be handed over to the king of Babylon, and this city shall be destroyed by fire.
38:24 Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, Let no one know about this conversation, or you shall die.
38:25 If the princes should hear I spoke with you and if they should come and ask you, Tell us what you said to the king; do not hide it from us, or we will kill you, or, What did the king say to you?
38:26 then give them this answer: I petitioned the king not to send me back to Jonathans house lest I die there.
38:27 When all the princes came to Jeremiah and questioned him, he answered them with the very words the king had commanded. They said no more to him, for nothing had been overheard of the conversation.
38:28 Thus Jeremiah stayed in the court of the guard until the day Jerusalem was taken.
39:1 When Jerusalem was taken, in the ninth year of Zedekiah, king of Judah, in the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and all his army marched against Jerusalem and placed it under siege.
39:2 In the eleventh year of Zedekiah, on the ninth day of the fourth month, the city wall was breached.
39:3 All the princes of the king of Babylon came and took their seats at the middle gate: Nergal-sharezer of Simmagir, a chief officer; Nebushazban, a high dignitary; and all the rest of the princes of the king of Babylon.
39:4 When Zedekiah, king of Judah, and all his warriors saw this, they fled, leaving the city at night by way of the kings garden, through a gate between the two walls. He went in the direction of the Arabah,
39:5 but the Chaldean army pursued them; they caught up with Zedekiah in the wilderness near Jericho and took him prisoner. They brought him to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, in Riblah, in the land of Hamath, and he pronounced sentence upon him.
39:6 The king of Babylon executed the sons of Zedekiah at Riblah before his very eyes; the king of Babylon also executed all the nobles of Judah.
39:7 He then blinded Zedekiah and bound him in chains to bring him to Babylon.
39:8 The Chaldeans set fire to the kings house and the houses of the people and tore down the walls of Jerusalem.
39:9 Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, deported to Babylon the rest of the people left in the city, those who had deserted to him, and the rest of the workers.
39:10 But Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, left in the land of Judah some of the poor who had nothing and at the same time gave them vineyards and farms.
39:11 Concerning Jeremiah, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, gave these orders through Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard:
39:12 Take him and look after him; do not let anything happen to him. Whatever he may ask, you must do for him.
39:13 Thereupon Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, and Nebushazban, a high dignitary, and Nergal-sharezer, a chief officer, and all the nobles of the king of Babylon,
39:14 had Jeremiah taken out of the courtyard of the guard and entrusted to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, to bring him home. And so he remained among the people.
39:15 While Jeremiah was still imprisoned in the court of the guard, the word of the came to him:
39:16 Go, tell this to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian: Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: See, I am now carrying out my words against this city, for evil and not for good; this will happen in your presence on that day.
39:17 But on that day I will deliver you—oracle of the ; you shall not be handed over to the men you dread.
39:18 I will make certain that you escape and do not fall by the sword. Your life will be your spoils of war because you trusted in me—oracle of the .
40:1 The word which came to Jeremiah from the , after Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, had released him in Ramah, where he found him a prisoner in chains among the captives of Jerusalem and Judah being exiled to Babylon.
40:2 The captain of the bodyguard took charge of Jeremiah and said to him, The , your God, decreed ruin for this place.
40:3 Now he has made it happen, accomplishing what he decreed; because you sinned against the and did not listen to his voice, this decree has been realized against you.
40:4 Now, I release you today from the chains upon your hands; if you want to come with me to Babylon, then come: I will look out for you. But if you do not want to come to Babylon, very well. See, the whole land lies before you; go wherever you think good and proper.
40:5 Or go to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon has set over the cities of Judah. Stay with him among the people. Or go wherever you want! The captain of the bodyguard gave him food and gifts and let him go.
40:6 So Jeremiah went to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, in Mizpah, and dwelt with him among the people left in the land.
40:7 When the military leaders still in the field with their soldiers heard that the king of Babylon had set Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, over the land and had put him in charge of men, women, and children, from the poor of the land who had not been deported to Babylon,
40:8 they and their soldiers came to Gedaliah in Mizpah: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah; Johanan, son of Kareah; Seraiah, son of Tanhumeth; the sons of Ephai of Netophah; and Jezaniah of Beth-maacah.
40:9 Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, swore an oath to them and their men: Do not be afraid to serve the Chaldeans. Stay in the land and serve the king of Babylon, so that everything may go well with you.
40:10 As for me, I will remain in Mizpah, as your representative before the Chaldeans when they come to us. You, for your part, harvest the wine, the fruit, and the oil, store them in jars, and remain in the cities you occupied.
40:11 Then all the Judahites in Moab, in Ammon, in Edom, and those in all other lands heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant in Judah and had set over them Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan.
40:12 They all returned to the land of Judah from the places to which they had scattered. They went to Gedaliah at Mizpah and had a rich harvest of wine and fruit.
40:13 Now Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the military leaders in the field came to Gedaliah in Mizpah
40:14 and said to him, Surely you are aware that Baalis, the Ammonite king, has sent Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, to assassinate you? But Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, would not believe them.
40:15 Then Johanan, son of Kareah, said secretly to Gedaliah in Mizpah: Please let me go and kill Ishmael, son of Nethaniah; no one will know it. What if he assassinates you? All the Judahites who have now rallied behind you would scatter and the remnant of Judah would perish.
40:16 Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, answered Johanan, son of Kareah, You must not do that. What you are saying about Ishmael is a lie!
41:1 In the seventh month, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of royal descent, one of the kings nobles, came with ten men to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, at Mizpah. While they were together at table in Mizpah,
41:2 Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and the ten with him, stood up and struck down Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, with swords. They killed him, since the king of Babylon had set him over the land;
41:3 Ishmael also killed all the Judahites of military age who were with Gedaliah and the Chaldean soldiers stationed there.
41:4 The day after the murder of Gedaliah, before anyone learned about it,
41:5 eighty men, in ragged clothes, with beards shaved off and gashes on their bodies, came from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria, bringing grain offerings and incense for the house of the .
41:6 Weeping as he went, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, set out from Mizpah to meet them. Come to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, he said as he met them.
41:7 Once they were inside the city, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and his men slaughtered them and threw them into the cistern.
41:8 Ten of them said to Ishmael: Do not kill us! We have stores of wheat and barley, oil and honey hidden in the field. So he spared them and did not kill them as he had killed their companions.
41:9 The cistern into which Ishmael threw all the bodies of the men he had killed was the large one King Asa made to defend himself against Baasha, king of Israel; Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, filled this cistern with the slain.
41:10 Ishmael led away the rest of the people left in Mizpah, including the princesses, whom Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, had consigned to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. With these captives, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, set out to cross over to the Ammonites.
41:11 But when Johanan, son of Kareah, and the other army leaders with him heard about the crimes Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had committed,
41:12 they took all their men and set out to attack Ishmael, son of Nethaniah. They overtook him at the great pool in Gibeon.
41:13 At the sight of Johanan, son of Kareah, and the other army leaders, the people with Ishmael rejoiced;
41:14 all of those whom Ishmael had taken captive from Mizpah went back to Johanan, son of Kareah.
41:15 But Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, escaped from Johanan with eight men and fled to the Ammonites.
41:16 Then Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the military leaders took charge of all the rest of the people whom Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had taken away from Mizpah after he killed Gedaliah, son of Ahikam—the soldiers, the women with children, and court officials, whom he brought back from Gibeon.
41:17 They set out and stopped at Geruth Chimham near Bethlehem, intending to go into Egypt.
41:18 They were afraid of the Chaldeans, because Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had slain Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon had set over the land.
42:1 Then all the military leaders, including Johanan, son of Kareah, Azariah, son of Hoshaiah, and all the people, from the least to the greatest,
42:2 approached Jeremiah the prophet and said, Please grant our petition; pray for us to the , your God, for all this remnant. As you see, only a few of us remain, but once we were many.
42:3 May the , your God, show us the way we should take and what we should do.
42:4 Very well! Jeremiah the prophet answered them: I will pray to the , your God, as you desire; whatever the answers, I will tell you; I will withhold nothing from you.
42:5 And they said to Jeremiah, May the be a true and faithful witness against us if we do not follow all the instructions the , your God, sends us through you.
42:6 Whether we like it or not, we will obey the command of the , our God, to whom we are sending you, so that it may go well with us for obeying the command of the , our God.
42:7 Ten days passed before the word of the came to Jeremiah.
42:8 Then he called Johanan, son of Kareah, his army leaders, and all the people, from the least to the greatest,
42:9 and said to them: Thus says the , the God of Israel, to whom you sent me to offer your petition:
42:10 If indeed you will remain in this land, I will build you up, and not tear you down; I will plant you, not uproot you; for I repent of the evil I have done you.
42:11 Do not fear the king of Babylon, as you do now. Do not fear him—oracle of the —for I am with you to save you, to rescue you from his power.
42:12 I will take pity on you, so that he will have pity on you and let you return to your land.
42:13 But if you keep saying, We will not stay in this land, thus disobeying the voice of the , your God,
42:14 and saying, No, we will go to the land of Egypt, where we will not see war, nor hear the trumpet alarm, nor hunger for bread. There we will live!
42:15 then listen to the word of the , remnant of Judah: Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: If you are set on going to Egypt and settling down there once you arrive,
42:16 the sword you fear shall overtake you in the land of Egypt; the hunger you dread shall pursue you to Egypt and there you shall die.
42:17 All those determined to go to Egypt to live shall die by the sword, famine, and disease: not one shall survive or escape the evil that I am bringing upon them.
42:18 For thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Just as my furious wrath was poured out upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so shall my anger be poured out on you when you reach Egypt. You shall become a malediction and a horror, a curse and a reproach, and you shall never see this place again.
42:19 The has spoken to you, remnant of Judah. Do not go to Egypt! Mark well that I am warning you this day.
42:20 At the cost of your lives you have been deceitful, for you yourselves sent me to the , your God, saying, Pray for us to the , our God; whatever the , our God, shall say, tell us and we will do it.
42:21 Today I have told you, but you have not listened to the voice of the your God, in anything that he has sent me to tell you.
42:22 Have no doubt about this: you shall die by the sword, famine, and disease in the place where you want to go and live.
43:1 When Jeremiah finished telling the people all the words the , their God, sent to them,
43:2 Azariah, son of Hoshaiah, Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the others had the insolence to say to Jeremiah: You lie; the , our God, did not send you to tell us, Do not go to Egypt to live there.
43:3 Baruch, son of Neriah, is inciting you against us, to hand us over to the Chaldeans to be killed or exiled to Babylon.
43:4 So Johanan, son of Kareah, and the rest of the leaders and the people did not listen to the voice of the to stay in the land of Judah.
43:5 Instead, Johanan, son of Kareah, and the military leaders took along all the remnant of Judah who had been dispersed among the nations and then had returned to dwell in the land of Judah:
43:6 men, women, and children, the princesses and everyone whom Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, had consigned to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan; also Jeremiah, the prophet, and Baruch, son of Neriah.
43:7 They went to Egypt—they did not listen to the voice of the —and came to Tahpanhes.
43:8 The word of the came to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes:
43:9 Take some large stones in your hand and set them in mortar in the terrace at the entrance to the house of Pharaoh in Tahpanhes, while the Judahites watch.
43:10 Then say to them: Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: I will send for my servant Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. He will place his throne upon these stones which I, Jeremiah, have set up, and stretch his canopy above them.
43:11 He shall come and strike the land of Egypt: with death, those marked for death; with exile, those marked for exile; with the sword, those marked for the sword.
43:12 He shall set fire to the temples of Egypts gods, burn the gods and carry them off. He shall pick the land of Egypt clean, as a shepherd picks lice off his cloak, and then depart victorious.
43:13 He shall smash the obelisks at the Temple of the Sun in the land of Egypt and destroy with fire the temples of the Egyptian gods.
44:1 The word that came to Jeremiah for all the Judahites who were living in Egypt, those living in Migdol, Tahpanhes, and Memphis, and in Upper Egypt:
44:2 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: You yourselves have seen all the evil I brought upon Jerusalem and the other cities of Judah. Today they lie in ruins uninhabited,
44:3 because of the evil they did to provoke me, going after other gods, offering incense and serving other gods they did not know, neither they, nor you, nor your ancestors.
44:4 Though I repeatedly sent you all my servants the prophets, saying: You must not commit this abominable deed I hate,
44:5 they did not listen or incline their ears in order to turn from their evil, no longer offering incense to other gods.
44:6 Therefore the fury of my anger poured forth and kindled fire in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem, to turn them into the ruined wasteland they are today.
44:7 Now thus says the God of hosts, the God of Israel: Why inflict so great an evil upon yourselves, cutting off from Judah man and woman, child and infant, not leaving yourselves even a remnant?
44:8 Why do you provoke me with the works of your hands, offering sacrifice to other gods here in the land of Egypt where you have come to live? Will you cut yourselves off and become a curse, a reproach among all the nations of the earth?
44:9 Have you forgotten the evil of your ancestors, the evil of the kings of Judah, the evil of their wives, and your own evil and the evil of your wives—all that they did in the land of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?
44:10 To this day they have not been crushed down, nor have they shown fear. They have not followed my law and my statutes that I set before you and your ancestors.
44:11 Therefore, thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: I have set my face against you for evil, to cut off all Judah.
44:12 I will take away the remnant of Judah who insisted on going to the land of Egypt to live there; in the land of Egypt they shall meet their end. They shall fall by the sword or be consumed by hunger. From the least to the greatest, they shall die by sword or hunger; they shall become a malediction, a horror, a curse, a reproach.
44:13 Thus I will punish those who live in Egypt, just as I punished Jerusalem, with sword, hunger, and disease,
44:14 so that none of the remnant of Judah who came to live in the land of Egypt shall escape or survive. No one shall return to the land of Judah. Even though they long to return and live there, they shall not return except as refugees.
44:15 They answered Jeremiah—all the men who knew that their wives were offering sacrifices to other gods, all the women standing there in the immense crowd, and all the people who lived in Lower and Upper Egypt:
44:16 Regarding the word you have spoken to us in the name of the , we are not listening to you.
44:17 Rather we will go on doing what we proposed; we will offer incense to the Queen of Heaven and pour out libations to her, just as we have done, along with our ancestors, our kings and princes, in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. Then we had plenty to eat, we prospered, and we suffered no misfortune.
44:18 But ever since we stopped offering sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out libations to her, we lack everything and are being destroyed by sword and hunger.
44:19 And the women said, When we offered sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and poured out libations to her, did we bake cakes in her image and pour out libations to her without our husbands consent?
44:20 To all the people, men and women, who gave him this answer, Jeremiah said:
44:21 As for the sacrifices you offered in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem—you, your ancestors, your kings and princes, and the people of the land—did not the remember them? Did it not enter his mind?
44:22 The could no longer bear the evil of your deeds, the abominations you were doing; then your land became a waste, a horror, a curse, without even one inhabitant, as it is today.
44:23 Because you offered sacrifice and sinned against the , not listening to the voice of the , not following his law, his statutes, and his decrees, therefore this evil has overtaken you, as it is today.
44:24 Jeremiah said to all the people and to all the women: Hear the word of the , all you Judahites in the land of Egypt:
44:25 Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: You and your wives have carried out with your hands what your mouths have spoken: We will go on fulfilling the vows we have made to offer sacrifice to the Queen of Heaven and to pour out libations to her. Very well! keep your vows, fulfill your vows!
44:26 And then listen to the word of the , all you Judahites living in Egypt; I swear by my own great name, says the : in the whole land of Egypt, my name shall no longer be pronounced by the lips of any Judahite, saying, As the Lord lives.
44:27 I am watching over them for evil, not for good. All the Judahites in Egypt shall come to an end by sword or famine until they are completely destroyed.
44:28 Those who escape the sword to return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah shall be few in number. The whole remnant of Judah who came to Egypt to live shall know whose word stands, mine or theirs.
44:29 And this shall be a sign to you—oracle of the —I will punish you in this place so that you will know that my words stand solidly against you for evil.
44:30 Thus says the : See! I will hand over Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, to his enemies, to those seeking his life, just as I handed over Zedekiah, king of Judah, to his enemy Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, to the one seeking his life.
45:1 The word that Jeremiah the prophet spoke to Baruch, son of Neriah, when he wrote on a scroll words from Jeremiahs own mouth in the fourth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah:
45:2 Thus says the , God of Israel, to you, Baruch.
45:3 You said, Woe is me! the has added grief to my pain. I have worn myself out with groaning; rest eludes me.
45:4 You must say this to him. Thus says the : What I have built, I am tearing down; what I have planted, I am uprooting: all this land.
45:5 And you, do you seek great things for yourself? Do not seek them! I am bringing evil on all flesh—oracle of the —but I will grant you your life as spoils of war, wherever you may go.
46:1 The word of the that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the nations.
46:2 Concerning Egypt. Against the army of Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, defeated at Carchemish on the Euphrates by Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, in the fourth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah:
46:3 Prepare buckler and shield! move forward to battle!
46:4 Harness the horses, charioteers, mount up! Fall in, with helmets on; polish your spears, put on your armor.
46:5 What do I see? Are they panicking, falling apart? Their warriors are hammered back, They flee headlong never making a stand. Terror on every side— oracle of the !
46:6 The swift cannot flee, nor the warrior escape: There up north, on the banks of the Euphrates they stumble and fall.
46:7 Who is this? Like the Nile, it rears up; like rivers, its waters surge.
46:8 Egypt rears up like the Nile, like rivers, its waters surge. I will rear up, it says, and cover the earth, destroying the city and its people.
46:9 Forward, horses! charge, chariots! March forth, warriors, Cush and Put, bearing shields, Archers of Lud, stretching bows!
46:10 Today belongs to the Lord of hosts, a day of vengeance, vengeance on his foes! The sword devours and is sated, drunk with their blood: for the Lord of hosts holds a sacrifice in the land of the north, on the River Euphrates.
46:11 Go up to Gilead, procure balm, Virgin daughter Egypt! No use to multiply remedies; for you there is no healing.
46:12 The nations hear your cries, your screaming fills the earth. Warrior stumbles against warrior, both collapse together.
46:13 The word that the spoke to Jeremiah the prophet when Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, came to attack the land of Egypt:
46:14 Proclaim in Egypt, announce in Migdol, announce in Memphis and Tahpanhes! Say: Fall in, get ready, the sword has devoured your neighbors.
46:15 Why has Apis fled? Your champion did not stand, Because the thrust him down;
46:16 he stumbled repeatedly then collapsed. They said to each other, Get up! We must return to our own people, To the land of our birth, away from the destroying sword.
46:17 Give Pharaoh, king of Egypt, the name Braggart-missed-his-chance.
46:18 As I live, says the King whose name is of hosts, Like Tabor above mountains, like Carmel above the sea, he comes.
46:19 Pack your bags for exile, enthroned daughter Egypt; Memphis shall become a wasteland, an empty ruin.
46:20 Egypt is a beautiful heifer, a horsefly from the north keeps coming.
46:21 Even the mercenaries in her ranks are like fattened calves; They too turn and flee together— they do not stand their ground, For their day of ruin comes upon them, their time of punishment.
46:22 Her voice is like a snake! Yes, they come in force; They attack her with axes, like those who fell trees.
46:23 They cut down her forest—oracle of the — impenetrable though it be; More numerous than locusts, they cannot be counted.
46:24 Shamed is daughter Egypt, handed over to a people from the north.
46:25 The of hosts, the God of Israel, has said: See! I will punish Amon of Thebes and Egypt, gods, kings, Pharaoh, and those who trust in him.
46:26 I will hand them over to those who seek their lives, to Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, and to his officers. But later, Egypt shall be inhabited again, as in days of old—oracle of the .
46:27 But you, my servant Jacob, do not fear; do not be dismayed, Israel! Listen! I will deliver you from far-off lands; your offspring, from the land of their exile. Jacob shall again find rest, secure, with none to frighten him.
46:28 You, Jacob my servant, must not fear—oracle of the — for I am with you; I will make an end of all the nations to which I have driven you, But of you I will not make an end: I will chastise you as you deserve, I cannot let you go unpunished.
47:1 The word of the that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the Philistines, before Pharaoh attacked Gaza:
47:2 Thus says the : See: waters are rising from the north, to become a torrent in flood; They shall flood the land and all it contains, the cities and their inhabitants. People will howl and wail, every inhabitant of the land.
47:3 At the noise of the pounding hooves of his steeds, the clanking chariots, the rumbling wheels, Parents do not turn back for their children; their hands hang helpless,
47:4 Because of the day that is coming to destroy all the Philistines And cut off from Tyre and Sidon the last of their allies. Yes, the is destroying the Philistines, the remnant from the coasts of Caphtor.
47:5 Baldness is visited upon Gaza, Ashkelon is reduced to silence; Ashdod, remnant of their strength, how long will you gash yourself?
47:6 Ah! Sword of the ! When will you find rest? Return to your scabbard; stop, be still!
47:7 How can it find rest when the has commanded it? Against Ashkelon and the seacoast, there he has appointed it.
48:1 Concerning Moab. Thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Ah, Nebo! it is ravaged; Kiriathaim is disgraced, captured; Disgraced and overthrown is the stronghold:
48:2 Moabs glory is no more. In Heshbon they plot evil against her: Come! We will put an end to her as a nation. You, too, Madmen, shall be silenced; you the sword stalks!
48:3 Listen! an outcry from Horonaim, Ruin and great destruction!
48:4 Moab is crushed! their outcry is heard in Zoar.
48:5 Up the ascent of Luhith they go weeping; At the descent to Horonaim they hear cries of anguish:
48:6 Flee, save your lives! Be like a wild donkey in the wilderness!
48:7 Because you trusted in your works and your treasures, you also shall be captured. Chemosh shall go into exile, his priests and princes with him.
48:8 The destroyer comes upon every city, not a city escapes; Ruined is the valley, wasted the plateau—oracle of the .
48:9 Set up a tombstone for Moab; it will soon become a complete wasteland, Its cities turned into ruins where no one dwells.
48:10 Cursed are they who do the s work carelessly, cursed those who keep their sword from shedding blood.
48:11 Moab has been resting from its youth, suspended above its dregs, Never poured from flask to flask, never driven into exile. Thus it retained its flavor, its bouquet is not lost.
48:12 Be assured! The days are coming—oracle of the —when I will send him wine-makers to decant the wine; they shall empty its flasks and smash its jars.
48:13 Chemosh shall disappoint Moab, just as the house of Israel was disappointed by Bethel, in which they trusted.
48:14 How can you say, We are heroes, mighty warriors?
