48:15 The one who ravages Moab and its cities comes up, the best of its youth go down to slaughter— oracle of the King, whose name is of hosts.
48:16 Moabs ruin is near at hand, its disaster approaches swiftly.
48:17 Mourn, all you neighbors, all you who know its name! Say: How the mighty scepter is broken, the glorious staff!
48:18 Come down from glory, sit on the parched ground, enthroned daughter Dibon; Moabs destroyer has fallen upon you, has shattered your strongholds.
48:19 Stand along the road, keep watch, enthroned Aroer; Ask the fleeing man, the escaping woman: ask them what has happened.
48:20 Moab is put to shame, destroyed. Wail and cry out, Proclaim it at the Arnon: Moab is destroyed!
48:21 Judgment has come upon the plateau: on Holon, Jahzah, and Mephaath,
48:22 on Dibon, Nebo, and Beth-diblathaim,
48:23 on Kiriathaim, Beth-gamul, and Beth-meon,
48:24 on Kerioth and on Bozrah: on all the cities of the land of Moab, far and near.
48:25 The horn of Moab is cut off, its arm is broken—oracle of the .
48:26 Make him drunk because he set himself over against the ; let Moab swim in his vomit and become a laughingstock.
48:27 Has Israel not been a laughingstock to you? Was he caught among thieves that you wag your heads whenever you speak of him?
48:28 Abandon the cities, take shelter in the crags, inhabitants of Moab. Be like the dove that nests in the walls of a gorge.
48:29 We have heard of the pride of Moab, pride beyond bounds: His loftiness, his pride, his scorn, his insolent heart.
48:30 I myself know his arrogance—oracle of the — liar in word, liar in deed.
48:31 And so I wail over Moab, over all Moab I cry, over the people of Kir-heres I moan.
48:32 More than for Jazer I weep for you, vine of Sibmah. Your tendrils trailed down to the sea, as far as Jazer they stretched. Upon your summer harvest and your vintage, the destroyer has fallen.
48:33 Joy and gladness are taken away from the garden land, the land of Moab. I dry up the wine from the wine vats, the treader treads no more, the vintage shout is stilled.
48:34 The cry of Heshbon and Elealeh is heard as far as Jahaz; they call from Zoar to Horonaim and to Eglath-shelishiyah; even the waters of Nimrim turn into a wasteland.
48:35 I will leave no one in Moab—oracle of the —to offer burnt offerings on the high place or to make sacrifices to their gods.
48:36 Hence my heart wails like a flute for Moab; my heart wails like a flute for the people of Kir-heres: the wealth they accumulated has perished.
48:37 Every head has been shaved bald, every beard cut off; every hand gashed, and all their loins are draped in sackcloth.
48:38 On all the rooftops of Moab and in all its squares there is mourning. I have shattered Moab like a pot that no one wants—oracle of the .
48:39 How terrified they are, how they wail! How Moab turns its back in shame! Moab has become a laughingstock and a horror to all its neighbors!
48:40 For thus says the : Look there! Like an eagle he swoops, spreading his wings over Moab.
48:41 Cities are captured, strongholds seized: On that day the hearts of Moabs warriors become like the heart of a woman in labor.
48:42 Moab shall be wiped out, a people no more, because it set itself over against the .
48:43 Terror, pit, and trap be upon you, enthroned Moab—oracle of the .
48:44 Those fleeing the terror fall into the pit; Those climbing out of the pit are caught in the trap; Ah, yes! I will bring these things upon Moab in the year of their punishment—oracle of the .
48:45 In Heshbons shadow the fugitives stop short, exhausted; For fire blazes up from Heshbon, and flames up from the house of Sihon: It consumes the forehead of Moab, the scalp of the noisemakers.
48:46 Woe to you, Moab! You are finished, people of Chemosh! Your sons are taken into exile, your daughters into captivity.
48:47 Yet I will restore the fortunes of Moab in the days to come—oracle of the . Thus far the judgment on Moab.
49:1 Concerning the Ammonites. Thus says the : Has Israel no sons? none to inherit? Why has Milcom disinherited Gad, why are his people living in its cities?
49:2 Therefore the days are coming—oracle of the — when I will sound the battle alarm against Rabbah of the Ammonites; It shall become a mound of ruins, and its villages destroyed by fire. Israel shall then inherit those who disinherited it— oracle of the .
49:3 Wail, Heshbon, The ruin is destroyed! shriek, villages of Rabbah! Put on sackcloth and lament! Run back and forth in the sheepfolds. For Milcom is going into exile, taking priest and prince with him.
49:4 Why boast in your strength, your ebbing strength, rebellious daughter? Why trust in your treasures, saying, Who would dare attack me?
49:5 See, I am bringing terror upon you— oracle of the Lord of hosts— from all around you; You shall be scattered, each in headlong flight, with no one to gather the fugitives.
49:6 But afterward I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites—oracle of the . 
49:7 Concerning Edom. Thus says the of hosts: Is there no more wisdom in Teman, has counsel perished from the prudent, is their wisdom gone?
49:8 Flee, retreat, hide deep for lodging, inhabitants of Dedan: For I bring disaster upon Esau when I come to punish them.
49:9 If vintagers came upon you, they would leave no gleanings; If thieves by night, they would destroy as they pleased.
49:10 So I myself will strip Esau; I will uncover his lairs so he cannot hide. Offspring and family are destroyed, neighbors, too; he is no more.
49:11 Leave your orphans behind, I will keep them alive; your widows, let them trust in me.
49:12 For thus says the : Look, even those not sentenced to drink the cup must drink it! Shall you then go unpunished? You shall not! You shall drink every bit of it!
49:13 By myself I have sworn—oracle of the —Bozrah shall become an object of horror, a disgrace, a desolation, and a curse. Bozrah and all its cities shall become ruins forever.
49:14 I have heard a report from the , a herald has been sent among the nations: Gather together, move against it, get ready for battle!
49:15 I will make you the least among the nations, despised by all people!
49:16 The terror you spread, the pride of your heart, beguiled you. You denizens of rocks and crevices, occupying towering peaks: Though you build your nest high as the eagle, from there I will bring you down—oracle of the .
49:17 Edom shall become an object of horror. Passersby recoil in terror, hissing at all its wounds.
49:18 As when Sodom, Gomorrah, and their neighbors were overthrown—oracle of the —no one shall live in it, nor anyone settle there.
49:19 As when a lion comes up from a thicket of the Jordan to a permanent pasture, So in an instant, I will chase them off; I will establish there whomever I choose. For who is like me? Who holds me accountable? What shepherd can stand against me?
49:20 Therefore, listen to the strategy the devised for Edom; The plans he has drawn up against the inhabitants of Teman: They shall be dragged away, even the smallest of the flock; their pasture shall be aghast because of them.
49:21 With the din of their collapse the earth quakes, to the Red Sea the outcry is heard!
49:22 Look! like an eagle he soars aloft, and spreads his wings over Bozrah; On that day the hearts of Edoms warriors become like the heart of a woman in labor.
49:23 Concerning Damascus. Hamath and Arpad are shamed, for they have heard bad news; Anxious, they surge like the sea which cannot calm down.
49:24 Damascus loses heart, turns to flee; panic has seized it. Distress and pangs take hold, like the pain of a woman in labor.
49:25 How can the glorious city be abandoned, the town of joy!
49:26 But now its young men shall fall in its squares, all the warriors destroyed on that day— oracle of the of hosts.
49:27 I will set fire to the wall of Damascus; it shall devour the palaces of Ben-hadad.
49:28 About Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor, which Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, defeated. Thus says the : Rise up, attack Kedar, destroy the people from the east.
49:29 Their tents and flocks shall be taken away, their tent curtains and all their goods; Their camels they carry off, they shout over them, Terror on every side!
49:30 Flee! wander about, hide deep for lodging, inhabitants of Hazor—oracle of the ; For Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has devised a strategy against you, drawn up a plan against you,
49:31 Get up! set out against a tranquil nation, living in security—oracle of the — Without gates or bars, dwelling alone.
49:32 Their camels shall become spoils, their hordes of cattle, plunder; I will scatter to the winds those who shave their temples; from every side I will bring their ruin— oracle of the .
49:33 Hazor shall become a haunt for jackals, a wasteland forever, Where no one lives, no mortal stays.
49:34 The word of the that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning Elam at the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah:
49:35 Thus says the of hosts: Look! I will break the bow of Elam, the mainstay of their might.
49:36 I will bring upon Elam the four winds from the four ends of the heavens: I will scatter them to all these winds, until there is no nation to which the outcasts of Elam have not gone.
49:37 I will terrify Elam before their foes, those seeking their life; I will bring evil upon them, my burning wrath—oracle of the . I will send sword after them until I have finished them off;
49:38 I will set up my throne in Elam and destroy from there king and princes— oracle of the .
49:39 But at the end of days I will restore the fortunes of Elam—oracle of the .
50:1 The word the spoke against Babylon, against the land of the Chaldeans, through Jeremiah the prophet:
50:2 Proclaim this among the nations, announce it! Announce it, do not hide it, but say: Babylon is captured, Bel put to shame, Marduk terrified; its images are put to shame, its idols shattered.
50:3 A nation from the north advances against it, making the land desolate So that no one can live there; human beings and animals have fled.
50:4 In those days and at that time—oracle of the — Israelite and Judahite shall come together, Weeping as they come, to seek the , their God;
50:5 They shall ask for Zion, seeking out the way. Come, let us join ourselves to the in an everlasting covenant, never to be forgotten.
50:6 Lost sheep were my people, their shepherds misled them, leading them astray on the mountains; From mountain to hill they wandered, forgetting their fold.
50:7 Whoever happened upon them devoured them; their enemies said, We are not guilty, Because they sinned against the , the abode of justice, the hope of their ancestors.
50:8 Flee from the midst of Babylon, leave the land of the Chaldeans, be like rams at the head of the flock.
50:9 See, I am stirring up against Babylon a band of great nations from the land of the north; They are arrayed against her, from there she shall be taken. Their arrows are like the arrows of a skilled warrior who never returns empty-handed.
50:10 Chaldea shall become plunder; all its plunderers shall be enriched— oracle of the .
50:11 Yes, rejoice and exult, you that plunder my heritage; Frisk like calves on the grass, neigh like stallions!
50:12 Your mother will indeed be put to shame, she that bore you shall be abashed; See, the last of the nations, a wilderness, a dry wasteland.
50:13 Because of the s wrath it shall be uninhabited, become an utter wasteland; Everyone who passes by Babylon will be appalled and hiss at all its wounds.
50:14 Take your posts encircling Babylon, you who bend the bow; Shoot at it, do not spare your arrows,
50:15 raise the war cry against it on every side. It surrenders, its bastions fall, its walls are torn down: This is retribution from the ! Take retribution on her, as she has done, do to her; for she sinned against the .
50:16 Cut off the sower from Babylon and those who wield sickles at harvest time! Before the destroying sword, all of them turn back to their own people, all flee to their own land.
50:17 Israel was a stray sheep that lions pursued; The king of Assyria once devoured him; now Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon gnaws his bones.
50:18 Therefore, thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: I will punish the king of Babylon and his land, as I once punished the king of Assyria;
50:19 But I will bring Israel back to its pasture, to feed on Carmel and Bashan, And on Mount Ephraim and Gilead, until they have their fill.
50:20 In those days, at that time—oracle of the : The guilt of Israel may be sought, but it no longer exists, the sin of Judah, but it can no longer be found; for I will forgive the remnant I preserve.
50:21 Attack the land of Merathaim, and those who live in Pekod; Slaughter and put them under the ban—oracle of the — do all I have commanded you.
50:22 Battle alarm in the land, great destruction!
50:23 How the hammer of the whole earth has been cut off and broken! What an object of horror Babylon has become among the nations!
50:24 You ensnared yourself and were caught, Babylon, before you knew it! You were discovered and seized, because you challenged the .
50:25 The opens his armory, brings out the weapons of his wrath; The Lord of hosts has work to do in the land of the Chaldeans.
50:26 Come upon them from every side, open their granaries, Pile them up in heaps and put them under the ban; do not leave a remnant.
50:27 Slay all the oxen, take them down to slaughter; Woe to them! their day has come, the time of their punishment.
50:28 Listen! the fugitives, the refugees from the land of Babylon: They announce in Zion the retribution of the , our God.
50:29 Call archers out against Babylon, all who bend the bow; Encamp around them; let no one escape. Repay them for their deeds; what they have done, do to them, For they insulted the , the Holy One of Israel.
50:30 Therefore their young men shall fall in the squares, all their warriors shall be stilled on that day— oracle of the .
50:31 I am against you, O Insolence— oracle of the Lord of hosts; For your day has come, the time for me to punish you.
50:32 Insolence stumbles and falls; there is no one to raise him up. I will kindle a fire in his cities to devour everything around him.
50:33 Thus says the of hosts: Oppressed are the people of Israel, together with the people of Judah; All their captors hold them fast and refuse to let them go.
50:34 Strong is their Redeemer, whose name is of hosts, The sure defender of their cause, who gives rest to their land, but unrest to those who live in Babylon.
50:35 A sword upon the Chaldeans—oracle of the — upon the inhabitants of Babylon, her princes and sages!
50:36 A sword upon the soothsayers, and they become fools! A sword upon the warriors, and they tremble;
50:37 A sword upon their motley throng, and they become women! A sword upon their treasures, and they are plundered;
50:38 A drought upon the waters, and they dry up! For it is a land of idols, soon made frantic by phantoms.
50:39 Hence, wildcats shall dwell there with hyenas, and ostriches occupy it; Never again shall it be inhabited or settled, from age to age.
50:40 As happened when God overturned Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighbors—oracle of the — No one shall dwell there, no mortal shall settle there.
50:41 See, a people comes from the north, a great nation, and mighty kings rising from the ends of the earth.
50:42 Bow and javelin they wield, cruel and pitiless are they; They sound like the roaring sea, as they ride forth on horses, Each in place for battle against you, daughter Babylon.
50:43 The king of Babylon hears news of them, and his hands hang helpless; Anguish takes hold of him, like the pangs of a woman giving birth.
50:44 As happens when a lion comes up from a thicket of the Jordan to permanent pasture, So I, in an instant, will chase them off, and establish there whomever I choose! For who is like me? Who can call me to account? What shepherd can stand against me?
50:45 Therefore, hear the strategy of the , which he has devised against Babylon; Hear the plans drawn up against the land of the Chaldeans: They shall be dragged away, even the smallest sheep; their own pasture aghast because of them.
50:46 At the cry Babylon is captured! the earth quakes; the outcry is heard among the nations.
51:1 Thus says the : See! I rouse against Babylon, and the inhabitants of Chaldea, a destroyer wind.
51:2 To Babylon I will send winnowers to winnow and lay waste the land; They shall besiege it on every side on the day of affliction.
51:3 How can the archers draw back their bows, lift their armor? Do not spare her young men, put the entire army under the ban.
51:4 The slain shall fall in the land of Chaldea, the wounded, in its streets;
51:5 For Israel and Judah are not left widowed by their God, the of hosts, Even though the land is full of guilt against the Holy One of Israel.
51:6 Flee from Babylon; each of you save your own life, do not perish because of her guilt; This is a time of retribution from the ,
51:7 who pays out her due. Babylon was a golden cup in the hand of the making the whole earth drunk; The nations drank its wine, thus they have gone mad.
51:8 Babylon suddenly falls and is broken: wail over her! Bring balm for her wounds, in case she can be healed.
51:9 We have tried to heal Babylon, but she cannot be healed. Leave her, each of us must go to our own land. The judgment against her reaches the heavens, it touches the clouds.
51:10 The has brought forth our vindication; come, let us tell in Zion what the , our God, has done.
51:11 Sharpen the arrows, fill the quivers; The has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes, for his resolve is Babylons destruction. Yes, it is retribution from the , retribution for his temple.
51:12 Over the walls of Babylon raise a signal, reinforce the watch; Post sentries, arrange ambushes! For the has both planned and carried out what he spoke against the inhabitants of Babylon.
51:13 You who dwell by mighty waters, rich in treasure, Your end has come, the time at which you shall be cut off!
51:14 The of hosts has sworn by himself: I will fill you with people as numerous as locusts, who shall raise over you a joyous shout!
51:15 He made the earth by his power, established the world by wisdom, and by his skill stretched out the heavens.
51:16 When he thunders, the waters in the heavens roar, he summons clouds from the ends of the earth, Makes lightning flash in the rain, and brings out winds from their storehouses.
51:17 Every man is stupid, ignorant; every artisan is put to shame by his idol: He molds a fraud, without life-breath.
51:18 They are nothing, a ridiculous work, that will perish at the time of punishment.
51:19 Jacobs portion is nothing like them: he is the creator of all things. Israel is his very own tribe; of hosts is his name.
51:20 You are my hammer, a weapon for war; With you I shatter nations, with you I destroy kingdoms.
51:21 With you I shatter horse and rider, with you I shatter chariot and driver.
51:22 With you I shatter man and woman, with you I shatter old and young, with you I shatter the young man and young woman.
51:23 With you I shatter shepherd and flock, with you I shatter farmer and team, with you I shatter governors and officers.
51:24 Thus I will repay Babylon, all the inhabitants of Chaldea, For all the evil they committed against Zion, before your very eyes—oracle of the .
51:25 Beware! I am against you, destroying mountain—oracle of the — destroyer of the entire earth, I will stretch forth my hand against you, roll you down over the cliffs, and make you a burnt mountain:
51:26 They will not take from you a cornerstone, or a foundation stone; You shall remain ruins forever— oracle of the .
51:27 Raise a signal in the land, sound the trumpet among the nations; Dedicate nations for war against her, summon against her the kingdoms: Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz; Appoint a recruiting officer against her, dispatch horses like bristling locusts.
51:28 Dedicate nations for war against her: the king of the Medes, Its governors and all its officers, every land in its domain.
51:29 The earth quakes and writhes, the s plan against Babylon is carried out, Turning the land of Babylon into a wasteland without inhabitants.
51:30 Babylons warriors have ceased to fight, they remain in their strongholds; Dried up is their strength, they have become women. Burned down are their homes, broken their gates.
51:31 One runner meets another, herald meets herald, Telling the king of Babylon that his entire city has been taken.
51:32 The fords have been seized, marshes set on fire, warriors panic.
51:33 For thus says the of hosts, the God of Israel: Daughter Babylon is like a threshing floor at the time of treading; Yet a little while, and the harvest time will come for her.
51:34 He consumed me, defeated me, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon; he left me like an empty vessel, Swallowed me like a sea monster, filled his belly with my delicacies and cast me out.
51:35 Let my torn flesh be visited upon Babylon, says enthroned Zion; My blood upon the inhabitants of Chaldea, says Jerusalem.
51:36 But now, thus says the : I will certainly defend your cause, I will certainly avenge you; I will dry up her sea, and drain her fountain.
51:37 Babylon shall become a heap of ruins, a haunt of jackals; A place of horror and hissing, without inhabitants.
51:38 They roar like lions, growl like lion cubs.
51:39 When they are parched, I will set drink before them to make them drunk, that they may be overcome with everlasting sleep, never to awaken— oracle of the .
51:40 I will bring them down like lambs to slaughter, like rams and goats.
51:41 How she has been seized, taken captive, the glory of the whole world! What a horror Babylon has become among the nations:
51:42 against Babylon the sea rises, she is overwhelmed by roaring waves!
51:43 Her cities have become wasteland, a parched and arid land Where no one lives, no one passes through.
51:44 I will punish Bel in Babylon, and make him vomit up what he swallowed; nations shall no longer stream to him. Even the wall of Babylon falls!
51:45 Leave her, my people; each of you save your own life from the burning wrath of the .
51:46 Do not be discouraged when rumors spread through the land; this year one rumor comes, next year another: Violence in the land! or Ruler against ruler!
51:47 Realize that the days are coming when I will punish the idols of Babylon; the whole land shall be put to shame, all her slain shall fall in her midst.
51:48 Then heaven and earth and everything in them shall shout over Babylon with joy, when the destroyers come against her from the north—oracle of the .
51:49 Babylon, too, must fall, you slain of Israel, because by the hand of Babylon the slain of all the earth have fallen.
51:50 You who have escaped the sword, go, do not stand idle; Remember the from far away, let Jerusalem come to mind.
51:51 We are ashamed because we have heard taunts, disgrace covers our faces; strangers have entered sanctuaries in the s house.
51:52 Therefore see, the days are coming—oracle of the — when I will punish her idols, and throughout the land the wounded will groan.
51:53 Though Babylon scale the heavens, and make her strong heights inaccessible, my destroyers shall reach her—oracle of the .
51:54 A sound of crying from Babylon, great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans;
51:55 For the lays Babylon waste, silences her loud cry, Waves roaring like mighty waters, a clamor resounding.
51:56 For the destroyer comes upon her, upon Babylon; warriors are captured, their bows broken; The is a God of recompense, he will surely repay.
51:57 I will make her princes and sages drunk, with her governors, officers, and warriors, so that they sleep an everlasting sleep, never to awaken—oracle of the King, whose name is of hosts.
51:58 Thus says the of hosts: The walls of spacious Babylon shall be leveled to the ground, its lofty gates destroyed by fire. The toil of the peoples is for nothing; the nations weary themselves for what the flames consume.
51:59 The mission Jeremiah the prophet gave to Seraiah, son of Neriah, son of Mahseiah, when he went to Babylon with King Zedekiah, king of Judah, in the fourth year of his reign; Seraiah was chief quartermaster.
51:60 Jeremiah wrote down on one scroll the disaster that would befall Babylon; all these words were written against Babylon.
51:61 And Jeremiah said to Seraiah: When you reach Babylon, see that you read all these words aloud,
51:62 and then say: , you yourself spoke against this place in order to cut it down so that nothing, human being or beast, could live in it, because it is to remain a wasteland forever.
51:63 When you have finished reading this scroll, tie a stone to it and throw it into the Euphrates,
51:64 and say: Thus Babylon shall sink. It will never rise, because of the disaster I am bringing upon it. Thus far the words of Jeremiah.
52:1 Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king; he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mothers name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah from Libnah.
52:2 He did what was evil in the sight of the , just as Jehoiakim had done.
52:3 Indeed, the things done in Jerusalem and in Judah so angered the that he cast them out from his presence. Thus Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
52:4 In the tenth month of the ninth year of his reign, on the tenth day of the month, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his entire army advanced against Jerusalem, encamped around it, and built siege walls on every side.
52:5 The siege of the city continued until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
52:6 On the ninth day of the fourth month, when famine had gripped the city and the people had no more bread,
52:7 the city walls were breached. All the soldiers fled and left the city by night through the gate between the two walls which was near the kings garden. With the Chaldeans surrounding the city, they went in the direction of the Arabah.
52:8 But the Chaldean army pursued the king and overtook Zedekiah in the wilderness near Jericho; his whole army fled from him.
52:9 The king, therefore, was arrested and brought to Riblah, in the land of Hamath, to the king of Babylon, who pronounced judgment on him.
52:10 As Zedekiah looked on, the king of Babylon slaughtered his sons before his eyes! All the nobles of Judah were slaughtered at Riblah.
52:11 And the eyes of Zedekiah he then blinded, bound him with chains, and the king of Babylon brought him to Babylon and kept him in prison until the day he died.
52:12 On the tenth day of the fifth month, this was in the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, came to Jerusalem as the representative of the king of Babylon.
52:13 He burned the house of the , the palace of the king, and all the houses of Jerusalem; every large building he destroyed with fire.
52:14 Then the Chaldean troops with the captain of the guard tore down all the walls that surrounded Jerusalem.
52:15 Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, led into exile the remnant of people left in the city, those who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the artisans.
52:16 But Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, left behind some of the countrys poor as vinedressers and farmers.
52:17 The bronze pillars that belonged to the house of the , and the wheeled carts and the bronze sea in the house of the , the Chaldeans broke into pieces; they carried away all the bronze to Babylon.
52:18 They also took the pots, shovels, snuffers, bowls, pans, and all the bronze vessels used for service;
52:19 the basins, fire holders, bowls, pots, lampstands, pans, the sacrificial bowls made of gold or silver. Along with these furnishings the captain of the guard carried off
52:20 the two pillars, the one sea and its base of twelve oxen cast in bronze, and the wheeled carts King Solomon had commissioned for the house of the . The bronze from all these furnishings was impossible to weigh.
52:21 As for the pillars, each of them was eighteen cubits high and twelve cubits in diameter; each was four fingers thick and hollow inside.
52:22 A bronze capital five cubits high crowned the one pillar, and a network with pomegranates encircled the capital, all of bronze; and so for the other pillar, with pomegranates.
52:23 There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides, a hundred pomegranates surrounding the network.
52:24 The captain of the guard also took Seraiah the high priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three keepers of the entrance.
52:25 From the city he took one courtier, a commander of soldiers, and seven men in the personal service of the king still in the city, the scribe of the army commander who mustered the people of the land, and sixty of the common people remaining in the city.
52:26 The captain of the guard, Nebuzaradan, arrested them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah,
52:27 who had them struck down and executed in Riblah, in the land of Hamath. Thus Judah was exiled from the land.
52:28 This is the number of people Nebuchadnezzar led away captive: in his seventh year, three thousand twenty-three people of Judah;
52:29 in the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar, eight hundred thirty-two persons from Jerusalem;
52:30 in the twenty-third year of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, deported seven hundred forty-five Judahites: four thousand six hundred persons in all. 
52:31 In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, Evil-merodach, king of Babylon, in the inaugural year of his reign, raised up Jehoiachin, king of Judah, and released him from prison.
52:32 He spoke kindly to him and gave him a throne higher than the thrones of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
52:33 Jehoiachin took off his prison garb and ate at the kings table as long as he lived.
52:34 The allowance given him by the king of Babylon was a perpetual allowance, in fixed daily amounts, all the days of his life until the day of his death.
LAMENTATIONS
1:1 How solitary sits the city, once filled with people. She who was great among the nations is now like a widow. Once a princess among the provinces, now a toiling slave.
1:2 She weeps incessantly in the night, her cheeks damp with tears. She has no one to comfort her from all her lovers; Her friends have all betrayed her, and become her enemies.
1:3 Judah has gone into exile, after oppression and harsh labor; She dwells among the nations, yet finds no rest: All her pursuers overtake her in the narrow straits.
1:4 The roads to Zion mourn, empty of pilgrims to her feasts. All her gateways are desolate, her priests groan, Her young women grieve; her lot is bitter.
1:5 Her foes have come out on top, her enemies are secure; Because the has afflicted her for her many rebellions. Her children have gone away, captive before the foe.
1:6 From daughter Zion has gone all her glory: Her princes have become like rams that find no pasture. They have gone off exhausted before their pursuers.
1:7 Jerusalem remembers in days of wretched homelessness, All the precious things she once had in days gone by. But when her people fell into the hands of the foe, and she had no help, Her foes looked on and laughed at her collapse.
1:8 Jerusalem has sinned grievously, therefore she has become a mockery; Those who honored her now demean her, for they saw her nakedness; She herself groans out loud, and turns away.
1:9 Her uncleanness is on her skirt; she has no thought of her future. Her downfall is astonishing, with no one to comfort her. Look, O , at my misery; how the enemy triumphs!
1:10 The foe stretched out his hands to all her precious things; She has seen the nations enter her sanctuary, Those you forbade to come into your assembly.
1:11 All her people groan, searching for bread; They give their precious things for food, to retain the breath of life. Look, O , and pay attention to how I have been demeaned!
1:12 Come, all who pass by the way, pay attention and see: Is there any pain like my pain, which has been ruthlessly inflicted upon me, With which the has tormented me on the day of his blazing wrath?
1:13 From on high he hurled fire down into my very bones; He spread out a net for my feet, and turned me back. He has left me desolate, in misery all day long.
1:14 The yoke of my rebellions is bound together, fastened by his hand. His yoke is upon my neck; he has made my strength fail. The Lord has delivered me into the grip of those I cannot resist.
1:15 All my valiant warriors my Lord has cast away; He proclaimed a feast against me to crush my young men; My Lord has trodden in the wine press virgin daughter Judah.
1:16 For these things I weep—My eyes! My eyes! They stream with tears! How far from me is anyone to comfort, anyone to restore my life. My children are desolate; the enemy has prevailed.
1:17 Zion stretches out her hands, with no one to comfort her; The has ordered against Jacob his foes all around; Jerusalem has become in their midst a thing unclean.
1:18 The is in the right; I had defied his command. Listen, all you peoples, and see my pain: My young women and young men have gone into captivity.
1:19 I cried out to my lovers, but they failed me. My priests and my elders perished in the city; How desperately they searched for food, to save their lives!
1:20 Look, O , at the anguish I suffer! My stomach churns, And my heart recoils within me: How bitter I am! Outside the sword bereaves— indoors, there is death.
1:21 Hear how I am groaning; there is no one to comfort me. All my enemies hear of my misery and rejoice over what you have done. Bring on the day you proclaimed, and let them become like me!
1:22 Let all their evil come before you and deal with them As you have so ruthlessly dealt with me for all my rebellions. My groans are many, my heart is sick.
2:1 How the Lord in his wrath has abhorred daughter Zion, Casting down from heaven to earth the glory of Israel, Not remembering his footstool on the day of his wrath!
2:2 The Lord has devoured without pity all of Jacobs dwellings; In his fury he has razed daughter Judahs defenses, Has brought to the ground in dishonor a kingdom and its princes.
2:3 In blazing wrath, he cut down entirely the horn of Israel; He withdrew the support of his right hand when the enemy approached; He burned against Jacob like a blazing fire that consumes everything in its path.
2:4 He bent his bow like an enemy; the arrow in his right hand Like a foe, he killed all those held precious; On the tent of daughter Zion he poured out his wrath like fire.
2:5 The Lord has become the enemy, he has devoured Israel: Devoured all its strongholds, destroyed its defenses, Multiplied moaning and groaning throughout daughter Judah.
2:6 He laid waste his booth like a garden, destroyed his shrine; The has blotted out in Zion feast day and sabbath, Has scorned in fierce wrath king and priest.
2:7 The Lord has rejected his altar, spurned his sanctuary; He has handed over to the enemy the walls of its strongholds. They shout in the house of the as on a feast day.
2:8 The was bent on destroying the wall of daughter Zion: He stretched out the measuring line; did not hesitate to devour, Brought grief on rampart and wall till both succumbed.
2:9 Her gates sank into the ground; he smashed her bars to bits. Her king and her princes are among the nations; instruction is wanting, Even her prophets do not obtain any vision from the .
2:10 The elders of daughter Zion sit silently on the ground; They cast dust on their heads and dress in sackcloth; The young women of Jerusalem bow their heads to the ground.
2:11 My eyes are spent with tears, my stomach churns; My bile is poured out on the ground at the brokenness of the daughter of my people, As children and infants collapse in the streets of the town.
2:12 They cry out to their mothers, Where is bread and wine? As they faint away like the wounded in the streets of the city, As their life is poured out in their mothers arms.
2:13 To what can I compare you—to what can I liken you— O daughter Jerusalem? What example can I give in order to comfort you, virgin daughter Zion? For your breach is vast as the sea; who could heal you?
2:14 Your prophets provided you visions of whitewashed illusion; They did not lay bare your guilt, in order to restore your fortunes; They saw for you only oracles of empty deceit.
2:15 All who pass by on the road, clap their hands at you; They hiss and wag their heads over daughter Jerusalem: Is this the city they used to call perfect in beauty and joy of all the earth?
2:16 They open their mouths against you, all your enemies; They hiss and gnash their teeth, saying, We have devoured her! How we have waited for this day— we have lived to see it!
2:17 The has done what he planned. He has fulfilled the threat Decreed from days of old, destroying without pity! He let the enemy gloat over you and exalted the horn of your foes.
2:18 Cry out to the Lord from your heart, wall of daughter Zion! Let your tears flow like a torrent day and night; Give yourself no rest, no relief for your eyes.
2:19 Rise up! Wail in the night, at the start of every watch; Pour out your heart like water before the Lord; Lift up your hands to him for the lives of your children, Who collapse from hunger at the corner of every street.
2:20 Look, O , and pay attention: to whom have you been so ruthless? Must women eat their own offspring, the very children they have borne? Are priest and prophet to be slain in the sanctuary of the Lord?
2:21 They lie on the ground in the streets, young and old alike; Both my young women and young men are cut down by the sword; You killed them on the day of your wrath, slaughtered without pity.
2:22 You summoned as to a feast day terrors on every side; On the day of the s wrath, none survived or escaped. Those I have borne and nurtured, my enemy has utterly destroyed.
3:1 I am one who has known affliction under the rod of Gods anger,
3:2 One whom he has driven and forced to walk in darkness, not in light;
3:3 Against me alone he turns his hand— again and again all day long.
3:4 He has worn away my flesh and my skin, he has broken my bones;
3:5 He has besieged me all around with poverty and hardship;
3:6 He has left me to dwell in dark places like those long dead.
3:7 He has hemmed me in with no escape, weighed me down with chains;
3:8 Even when I cry for help, he stops my prayer;
3:9 He has hemmed in my ways with fitted stones, and made my paths crooked.
3:10 He has been a bear lying in wait for me, a lion in hiding!
3:11 He turned me aside and tore me apart, leaving me ravaged.
3:12 He bent his bow, and set me up as a target for his arrow.
3:13 He pierced my kidneys with shafts from his quiver.
3:14 I have become a laughingstock to all my people, their taunt all day long;
3:15 He has sated me with bitterness, filled me with wormwood.
3:16 He has made me eat gravel, trampled me into the dust;
3:17 My life is deprived of peace, I have forgotten what happiness is;
3:18 My enduring hope, I said, has perished before the .
3:19 The thought of my wretched homelessness is wormwood and poison;
3:20 Remembering it over and over, my soul is downcast.
3:21 But this I will call to mind; therefore I will hope:
3:22 The s acts of mercy are not exhausted, his compassion is not spent;
3:23 They are renewed each morning— great is your faithfulness!
3:24 The is my portion, I tell myself, therefore I will hope in him.
3:25 The is good to those who trust in him, to the one that seeks him;
3:26 It is good to hope in silence for the s deliverance.
3:27 It is good for a person, when young, to bear the yoke,
3:28 To sit alone and in silence, when its weight lies heavy,
3:29 To put ones mouth in the dust— there may yet be hope—
3:30 To offer ones cheek to be struck, to be filled with disgrace.
3:31 For the Lord does not reject forever;
3:32 Though he brings grief, he takes pity, according to the abundance of his mercy;
3:33 He does not willingly afflict or bring grief to human beings.
3:34 That someone tramples underfoot all the prisoners in the land,
3:35 Or denies justice to anyone in the very sight of the Most High,
3:36 Or subverts a persons lawsuit— does the Lord not see?
3:37 Who speaks so that it comes to pass, unless the Lord commands it?
3:38 Is it not at the word of the Most High that both good and bad take place?
3:39 What should the living complain about? about their sins!
3:40 Let us search and examine our ways, and return to the !
3:41 Let us lift up our hearts as well as our hands toward God in heaven!
3:42 We have rebelled and been obstinate; you have not forgiven us.
3:43 You wrapped yourself in wrath and pursued us, killing without pity;
3:44 You wrapped yourself in a cloud, which no prayer could pierce.
3:45 You have made us filth and rubbish among the peoples.
3:46 They have opened their mouths against us, all our enemies;
3:47 Panic and the pit have been our lot, desolation and destruction;
3:48 My eyes stream with tears over the destruction of the daughter of my people.
3:49 My eyes will flow without ceasing, without rest,
3:50 Until the from heaven looks down and sees.
3:51 I am tormented by the sight of all the daughters of my city.
3:52 Without cause, my enemies snared me as though I were a bird;
3:53 They tried to end my life in the pit, pelting me with stones.
3:54 The waters flowed over my head: and I said, I am lost!
3:55 I have called upon your name, O , from the bottom of the pit;
3:56 You heard me call, Do not let your ear be deaf to my cry for help.
3:57 You drew near on the day I called you; you said, Do not fear!
3:58 You pleaded my case, Lord, you redeemed my life.
3:59 You see, , how I am wronged; do me justice!
3:60 You see all their vindictiveness, all their plots against me.
3:61 You hear their reproach, , all their plots against me,
3:62 The whispered murmurings of my adversaries, against me all day long;
3:63 Look! Whether they sit or stand, I am the butt of their taunt.
3:64 Give them what they deserve, , according to their deeds;
3:65 Give them hardness of heart; your curse be upon them;
3:66 Pursue them in wrath and destroy them from under the s heaven!
4:1 How the gold has lost its luster, the noble metal changed; Jewels lie scattered at the corner of every street.
4:2 And Zions precious children, worth their weight in gold— How they are treated like clay jugs, the work of any potter!
4:3 Even jackals offer their breasts to nurse their young; But the daughter of my people is as cruel as the ostrich in the wilderness.
4:4 The tongue of the infant cleaves to the roof of its mouth in thirst; Children beg for bread, but no one gives them a piece.
4:5 Those who feasted on delicacies are abandoned in the streets; Those who reclined on crimson now embrace dung heaps.
4:6 The punishment of the daughter of my people surpassed the penalty of Sodom, Which was overthrown in an instant with no hand laid on it.
4:7 Her princes were brighter than snow, whiter than milk, Their bodies more ruddy than coral, their beauty like the sapphire.
4:8 Now their appearance is blacker than soot, they go unrecognized in the streets; Their skin has shrunk on their bones, and become dry as wood.
4:9 Better for those pierced by the sword than for those pierced by hunger, Better for those who bleed from wounds than for those who lack food.
4:10 The hands of compassionate women have boiled their own children! They became their food when the daughter of my people was shattered.
4:11 The has exhausted his anger, poured out his blazing wrath; He has kindled a fire in Zion that has consumed her foundations.
4:12 The kings of the earth did not believe, nor any of the worlds inhabitants, That foe or enemy could enter the gates of Jerusalem.
4:13 Except for the sins of her prophets and the crimes of her priests, Who poured out in her midst the blood of the just.
4:14 They staggered blindly in the streets, defiled with blood, So that people could not touch even their garments:
4:15 Go away! Unclean! they cried to them, Away, away, do not touch! If they went away and wandered, it would be said among the nations, They can no longer live here!
4:16 The presence of the was their portion, but he no longer looks upon them. The priests are shown no regard, the elders, no mercy.
4:17 Even now our eyes are worn out, searching in vain for help; From our watchtower we have watched for a nation unable to save.
4:18 They dogged our every step, we could not walk in our squares; Our end drew near, our time was up; yes, our end had come.
4:19 Our pursuers were swifter than eagles in the sky, In the mountains they were hot on our trail, they ambushed us in the wilderness.
4:20 The s anointed—our very lifebreath!— was caught in their snares, He in whose shade we thought to live among the nations.
4:21 Rejoice and gloat, daughter Edom, dwelling in the land of Uz, The cup will pass to you as well; you shall become drunk and strip yourself naked!
4:22 Your punishment is completed, daughter Zion, the Lord will not prolong your exile; The Lord will punish your iniquity, daughter Edom, will lay bare your sins.
5:1 Remember, , what has happened to us, pay attention, and see our disgrace:
5:2 Our heritage is turned over to strangers, our homes, to foreigners.
5:3 We have become orphans, without fathers; our mothers are like widows.
5:4 We pay money to drink our own water, our own wood comes at a price.
5:5 With a yoke on our necks, we are driven; we are worn out, but allowed no rest.
5:6 We extended a hand to Egypt and Assyria, to satisfy our need of bread.
5:7 Our ancestors, who sinned, are no more; but now we bear their guilt.
5:8 Servants rule over us, with no one to tear us from their hands.
5:9 We risk our lives just to get bread, exposed to the desert heat;
5:10 Our skin heats up like an oven, from the searing blasts of famine.
5:11 Women are raped in Zion, young women in the cities of Judah;
5:12 Princes have been hanged by them, elders shown no respect.
5:13 Young men carry millstones, boys stagger under loads of wood;
5:14 The elders have abandoned the gate, the young men their music.
5:15 The joy of our hearts has ceased, dancing has turned into mourning;
5:16 The crown has fallen from our head: woe to us that we sinned!
5:17 Because of this our hearts grow sick, at this our eyes grow dim:
5:18 Because of Mount Zion, lying desolate, and the jackals roaming there!
5:19 But you, , are enthroned forever; your throne stands from age to age.
5:20 Why have you utterly forgotten us, forsaken us for so long?
5:21 Bring us back to you, , that we may return: renew our days as of old.
5:22 For now you have indeed rejected us and utterly turned your wrath against us.
EZEKIEL
1:1 In the thirtieth year, on the fifth day of the fourth month, while I was among the exiles by the river Chebar, the heavens opened, and I saw divine visions.—
1:2 On the fifth day of the month—this was the fifth year of King Jehoiachins exile—
1:3 the word of the came to the priest Ezekiel, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the river Chebar. There the hand of the came upon him.
1:4 As I watched, a great stormwind came from the North, a large cloud with flashing fire, a bright glow all around it, and something like polished metal gleamed at the center of the fire.
1:5 From within it figures in the likeness of four living creatures appeared. This is what they looked like:
1:6 They were in human form, but each had four faces and four wings,
1:7 and their legs were straight, the soles of their feet like the hooves of a bull, gleaming like polished brass.
1:8 Human hands were under their wings, and the wings of one touched those of another.
1:9 Their faces and their wings looked out on all their four sides; they did not turn when they moved, but each went straight ahead.
1:10 Their faces were like this: each of the four had a human face, and on the right the face of a lion, and on the left, the face of an ox, and each had the face of an eagle.
1:11 Such were their faces. Their wings were spread out above. On each one, two wings touched one another, and the other two wings covered the body.
1:12 Each went straight ahead. Wherever the spirit would go, they went; they did not change direction when they moved.
1:13 And the appearance of the living creatures seemed like burning coals of fire. Something indeed like torches moved back and forth among the living creatures. The fire gleamed intensely, and from it lightning flashed.
1:14 The creatures darting back and forth flashed like lightning.
1:15 As I looked at the living creatures, I saw wheels on the ground, one alongside each of the four living creatures.
1:16 The wheels and their construction sparkled like yellow topaz, and all four of them looked the same: their construction seemed as though one wheel was inside the other.
1:17 When they moved, they went in any of the four directions without veering as they moved.
1:18 The four of them had rims, high and fearsome—eyes filled the four rims all around.
1:19 When the living creatures moved, the wheels moved with them; and when the living creatures were raised from the ground, the wheels also were raised.
1:20 Wherever the spirit would go, they went. And they were raised up together with the living creatures, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
1:21 Wherever the living creatures moved, the wheels moved; when they stood still, the wheels stood still. When they were lifted up from the earth, the wheels were lifted up with them. For the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
1:22 Above the heads of the living creatures was a likeness of the firmament; it was awesome, stretching upwards like shining crystal over their heads.
1:23 Beneath the firmament their wings stretched out toward one another; each had two wings covering the body.
1:24 Then I heard the sound of their wings, like the roaring of mighty waters, like the voice of the Almighty. When they moved, the sound of the tumult was like the din of an army. And when they stood still, they lowered their wings.
1:25 While they stood with their wings lowered, a voice came from above the firmament over their heads.
1:26 Above the firmament over their heads was the likeness of a throne that looked like sapphire; and upon this likeness of a throne was seated, up above, a figure that looked like a human being.
1:27 And I saw something like polished metal, like the appearance of fire enclosed on all sides, from what looked like the waist up; and from what looked like the waist down, I saw something like the appearance of fire and brilliant light surrounding him.
1:28 Just like the appearance of the rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day so was the appearance of brilliance that surrounded him. Such was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the . And when I saw it, I fell on my face and heard a voice speak.
2:1 The voice said to me: Son of man, stand up! I wish to speak to you.
2:2 As he spoke to me, the spirit entered into me and set me on my feet, and I heard the one who was speaking
2:3 say to me: Son of man, I am sending you to the Israelites, a nation of rebels who have rebelled against me; they and their ancestors have been in revolt against me to this very day.
2:4 Their children are bold of face and stubborn of heart—to them I am sending you. You shall say to them: Thus says the Lord .
2:5 And whether they hear or resist—they are a rebellious house—they shall know that a prophet has been among them.
2:6 But as for you, son of man, do not fear them or their words. Do not fear, even though there are briers or thorns and you sit among scorpions. Do not be afraid of their words or be terrified by their looks for they are a rebellious house.
2:7 You must speak my words to them, whether they hear or resist, because they are rebellious.
2:8 But you, son of man, hear me when I speak to you and do not rebel like this rebellious house. Open your mouth and eat what I am giving you.
2:9 It was then I saw a hand stretched out to me; in it was a written scroll.
2:10 He unrolled it before me; it was covered with writing front and back. Written on it was: Lamentation, wailing, woe!
3:1 He said to me: Son of man, eat what you find here: eat this scroll, then go, speak to the house of Israel.
3:2 So I opened my mouth, and he gave me the scroll to eat.
3:3 Son of man, he said to me, feed your stomach and fill your belly with this scroll I am giving you. I ate it, and it was as sweet as honey in my mouth.
3:4 Then he said to me, Son of man, go now to the house of Israel, and speak my words to them.
3:5 Not to a people with obscure speech and difficult language am I sending you, but to the house of Israel.
3:6 Nor to many nations of obscure speech and difficult language whose words you cannot understand. For if I were to send you to these, they would listen to you.
3:7 But the house of Israel will refuse to listen to you, since they refuse to listen to me. For the whole house of Israel is stubborn of brow and hard of heart.
3:8 Look! I make your face as hard as theirs, and your brow as stubborn as theirs.
3:9 Like diamond, harder than flint, I make your brow. Do not be afraid of them, or be terrified by their looks, for they are a rebellious house.
3:10 Then he said to me, Son of man, take into your heart all my words that I speak to you; hear them well.
3:11 Now go to the exiles, to your own people, and speak to them. Say to them, whether they hear or refuse to hear: Thus says the God!
3:12 Then the spirit lifted me up, and I heard behind me a loud rumbling noise as the glory of the rose from its place:
3:13 the noise of the wings of the living creatures beating against one another, and the noise of the wheels alongside them, a loud rumbling.
3:14 And the spirit lifted me up and took me away, and I went off, my spirit angry and bitter, for the hand of the pressed hard on me.
3:15 Thus I came to the exiles who lived at Tel-abib by the river Chebar; and there where they dwelt, I stayed among them distraught for seven days.
3:16 At the end of the seven days, the word of the came to me: 
3:17 Son of man, I have appointed you a sentinel for the house of Israel. When you hear a word from my mouth, you shall warn them for me.
3:18 If I say to the wicked, You shall surely die—and you do not warn them or speak out to dissuade the wicked from their evil conduct in order to save their lives—then they shall die for their sin, but I will hold you responsible for their blood.
3:19 If, however, you warn the wicked and they still do not turn from their wickedness and evil conduct, they shall die for their sin, but you shall save your life.
3:20 But if the just turn away from their right conduct and do evil when I place a stumbling block before them, then they shall die. Even if you warned them about their sin, they shall still die, and the just deeds that they performed will not be remembered on their behalf. I will, however, hold you responsible for their blood.
3:21 If, on the other hand, you warn the just to avoid sin, and they do not sin, they will surely live because of the warning, and you in turn shall save your own life.
3:22 The hand of the came upon me there and he said to me: Get up and go out into the plain, where I will speak with you.
3:23 So I got up and went out into the plain. There it was! The glory of the was standing there like the glory I had seen by the river Chebar. Then I fell on my face,
3:24 but the spirit entered into me, set me on my feet; he spoke to me, and said: Go, shut yourself in your house.
3:25 As for you, son of man, know that they will put ropes on you and bind you with them, so that you cannot go out among them.
3:26 And I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so that you will be mute, no longer one who rebukes them for being a rebellious house.
3:27 Only when I speak to you and open your mouth, shall you say to them: Thus says the God: Let those who hear, hear! Let those who resist, resist! They are truly a rebellious house.
4:1 You, son of man, take a clay tablet; place it in front of you, and draw on it a city, Jerusalem.
4:2 Lay siege to it: build up siege works, raise a ramp against it, pitch camps and set up battering rams all around it.
4:3 Then take an iron pan and set it up as an iron wall between you and the city. Set your face toward it and put it under siege. So you must lay siege to it as a sign for the house of Israel.
4:4 Then lie down on your left side, while I place the guilt of the house of Israel upon you. As many days as you lie like this, you shall bear their guilt.
4:5 I allot you three hundred and ninety days during which you must bear the guilt of the house of Israel, the same number of years they sinned.
4:6 When you have completed this, you shall lie down a second time, on your right side to bear the guilt of the house of Judah forty days; I allot you one day for each year.
4:7 Turning your face toward the siege of Jerusalem, with bared arm you shall prophesy against it.
4:8 See, I bind you with ropes so that you cannot turn from one side to the other until you have completed the days of your siege.
4:9 Then take wheat and barley, beans and lentils, millet and spelt; put them into a single pot and make them into bread. Eat it for as many days as you lie upon your side, three hundred and ninety days.
4:10 The food you eat shall be twenty shekels a day by weight; each day you shall eat it.
4:11 And the water you drink shall be the sixth of a hin by measure; each day you shall drink it.
4:12 And the barley cake you eat you must bake on human excrement in the sight of all.
4:13 The said: Thus the Israelites shall eat their food, unclean, among the nations where I drive them.
4:14 Oh no, Lord , I protested. Never have I defiled myself nor have I eaten carrion flesh or flesh torn by wild beasts, nor from my youth till now has any unclean meat entered my mouth.
4:15 Very well, he replied, I will let you use cow manure in place of human dung. You can bake your bread on that.
4:16 Then he said to me: Son of man, I am about to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem so they shall eat bread which they have weighed out anxiously and drink water which they have measured out fearfully.
4:17 Because they lack bread and water they shall be devastated; each and every one will waste away because of their guilt.
5:1 Now you, son of man, take a sharp sword and use it like a barbers razor, to shave your head and your beard. Then take a balance scale for weighing and divide the hair.
5:2 Set a third on fire within the city, when the days of your siege are completed; place another third around the city and strike it with the sword; the final third scatter to the wind and then unsheathe the sword after it.
5:3 But take a few of the hairs and tie them in the hem of your garment.
5:4 Take some of these and throw them into the fire and burn them in the fire. Because of this, fire will flash out against the whole house of Israel.
5:5 Thus says the Lord : This is Jerusalem! I placed it in the midst of the nations, surrounded by foreign lands.
5:6 But it rebelled against my ordinances more wickedly than the nations, and against my statutes more than the foreign lands around it; they rejected my ordinances and did not walk in my statutes.
5:7 Therefore, thus says the Lord : Because you have caused more uproar than the nations surrounding you, not living by my statutes nor carrying out my judgments, nor even living by the ordinances of the surrounding nations;
5:8 therefore, thus says the Lord : See, I am coming against you! I will carry out judgments among you while the nations look on.
5:9 Because of all your abominations I will do to you what I have never done before, the like of which I will never do again.
5:10 Therefore, parents will eat their children in your midst, and children will eat their parents. I will inflict punishments upon you and scatter all who remain to the winds.
5:11 Therefore, as I live, says the Lord , because you have defiled my sanctuary with all your atrocities and all your abominations, I will surely withdraw and not look upon you with pity nor spare you.
5:12 A third of your people shall die of disease or starve to death within you; another third shall fall by the sword all around you; a third I will scatter to the winds and pursue them with the sword.
5:13 Thus my anger will spend itself; I will vent my wrath against them until I am satisfied. Then they will know that I the spoke in my passion when I spend my wrath upon them.
5:14 I will make you a desolation and a reproach among the nations around you, in the sight of every passerby.
5:15 And you will be a reproach and a taunt, a warning and a horror to the nations around you when I execute judgments against you in angry wrath, with furious chastisements. I, the , have spoken!
5:16 When I loose against you the deadly arrows of starvation that I am sending to destroy you, I will increase starvation and will break your staff of bread.
5:17 I will send against you starvation and wild beasts who will leave you childless, while disease and bloodshed sweep through you. I will bring the sword against you. I, the , have spoken.
6:1 The word of the came to me:
6:2 Son of man, set your face toward the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them:
6:3 You shall say: Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord . Thus says the Lord to the mountains and hills, to the ravines and valleys: Pay attention! I am bringing a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.
6:4 Your altars shall be laid waste, your incense stands smashed, and I will throw your slain down in front of your idols.
6:5 Yes, I will lay the corpses of the Israelites in front of their idols, and scatter your bones around your altars.
6:6 Wherever you live, cities shall be ruined and high places laid waste, in order that your altars be laid waste and devastated, your idols broken and smashed, your incense altars hacked to pieces, and whatever you have made wiped out.
6:7 The slain shall fall in your midst, and you shall know that I am the .
6:8 But I will spare some of you from the sword to live as refugees among the nations when you are scattered to foreign lands.
6:9 Then your refugees will remember me among the nations to which they have been exiled, after I have broken their lusting hearts that turned away from me and their eyes that lusted after idols. They will loathe themselves for all the evil they have done, for all their abominations.
6:10 Then they shall know that I the did not threaten in vain to inflict this evil on them.
6:11 Thus says the Lord : Clap your hands, stamp your feet, and cry Alas! for all the evil abominations of the house of Israel! They shall fall by the sword, starvation, and disease.
6:12 Those far off shall die of disease, those nearby shall fall by the sword, and those who survive and are spared shall perish by starvation; thus will I spend my fury upon them.
6:13 They shall know that I am the , when their slain lie among their idols, all around their altars, on every high hill and mountaintop, beneath every green tree and leafy oak—any place they offer sweet-smelling oblations to all their idols.
6:14 I will stretch out my hand against them; I will make the land a desolate waste, from the wilderness to Riblah, wherever they live. Thus they shall know that I am the .
7:1 The word of the came to me:
7:2 Son of man, now say: Thus says the Lord to the land of Israel: An end! The end comes upon the four corners of the land!
7:3 Now the end is upon you; I will unleash my anger against you, judge you according to your ways, and hold against you all your abominations.
7:4 My eye will not spare you, nor will I have pity; but I will hold your conduct against you, since your abominations remain within you; then shall you know that I am the .
7:5 Thus says the Lord : Evil upon evil! See it coming!
7:6 An end is coming, the end is coming; it is ripe for you! See it coming!
7:7 The crisis has come for you who dwell in the land! The time has come, near is the day: panic, no rejoicing on the mountains.
7:8 Soon now I will pour out my fury upon you and spend my anger against you; I will judge you according to your ways and hold against you all your abominations.
7:9 My eye will not spare, nor will I take pity; I will hold your conduct against you since your abominations remain within you, then you shall know that it is I, the , who strikes.
7:10 The day is here! Look! it is coming! The crisis has come! Lawlessness is blooming, insolence budding;
7:11 the violent have risen up to wield a scepter of wickedness. But none of them shall remain; none of their crowd, none of their wealth, for none of them are innocent.
7:12 The time has come, the day dawns. The buyer must not rejoice, nor the seller mourn, for wrath is coming upon all the throng.
7:13 Assuredly, the seller shall not regain what was sold, as long as they all live; for the vision is for the whole crowd: it shall not be revoked! Yes, because of their guilt, they shall not hold on to life.
7:14 They will sound the trumpet and get everything ready, but no one will go out to battle, for my wrath weighs upon all the crowd.
7:15 The sword is outside; disease and hunger are within. Whoever is in the fields will die by the sword; whoever is in the city disease and hunger will devour.
7:16 If their survivors flee, they will die on the mountains, moaning like doves of the valley on account of their guilt.
7:17 All their hands will hang limp, and all their knees turn to water.
7:18 They put on sackcloth, horror clothes them; shame is on all their faces, all their heads are shaved bald.
7:19 They fling their silver into the streets, and their gold is considered unclean. Their silver and gold cannot save them on the day of the s wrath. They cannot satisfy their hunger or fill their bellies, for it has been the occasion of their sin.
7:20 In their beautiful ornaments they took pride; out of them they made their abominable images, their detestable things. For this reason I will make them unclean.
7:21 I will hand them over as spoils to foreigners, as plunder to the wicked of the earth, so that they may defile them.
7:22 I will turn my face away from them. My treasure will be defiled; the violent will enter and defile it.
7:23 They will wreak slaughter, for the land is filled with bloodshed and the city with violence.
7:24 I will bring in the worst of the nations to take possession of their houses. I will put an end to their proud strength, and their sanctuaries will be defiled.
7:25 When anguish comes, they will seek peace, but there is none.
7:26 Disaster after disaster, rumor upon rumor. They keep seeking a vision from the prophet; instruction from the priest is missing, and counsel from the elders.
7:27 The king mourns, the prince is terror-stricken, the hands of the common people tremble. I will deal with them according to their ways, and according to their judgments I will judge them. They shall know that I am the .
8:1 In the sixth year, on the fifth day of the sixth month, as I was sitting in my house, with the elders of Judah sitting before me, the hand of the Lord fell upon me there.
8:2 I looked up and there was a figure that looked like a man. Downward from what looked like his waist, there was fire; from his waist upward, like the brilliance of polished bronze.
8:3 He stretched out the form of a hand and seized me by the hair of my head. The spirit lifted me up between earth and heaven and brought me in divine vision to Jerusalem to the entrance of the inner gate facing north where the statue of jealousy that provokes jealousy stood.
8:4 There I saw the glory of the God of Israel, like the vision I had seen in the plain.
8:5 He said to me: Son of man, lift your eyes to the north! I looked to the north and there in the entry north of the altar gate was this statue of jealousy.
8:6 He asked, Son of man, do you see what they are doing? Do you see the great abominations that the house of Israel is practicing here, so that I must depart from my sanctuary? You shall see even greater abominations!
8:7 Then he brought me to the entrance of the courtyard, and there I saw a hole in the wall.
8:8 Son of man, he ordered, dig through the wall. I dug through the wall—there was a doorway.
8:9 Go in, he said to me, and see the evil abominations they are doing here.
8:10 I went in and looked—figures of all kinds of creeping things and loathsome beasts, all the idols of the house of Israel, pictured around the wall.
8:11 Before them stood seventy of the elders of the house of Israel. Among them stood Jaazaniah, son of Shaphan, each with censer in hand; a cloud of incense drifted upward.
8:12 Then he said to me: Do you see, son of man, what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark, each in his idol chamber? They think: The cannot see us; the has forsaken the land.
8:13 He said: You will see them practicing even greater abominations.
8:14 Then he brought me to the entrance of the north gate of the house of the . There women sat and wept for Tammuz.
8:15 He said to me: Do you see this, son of man? You will see other abominations, greater than these!
8:16 Then he brought me into the inner court of the house of the . There at the door of the s temple, between the porch and the altar, were about twenty-five men with their backs to the s temple and their faces toward the east; they were bowing eastward to the sun.
8:17 He said: Do you see, son of man? Are the abominable things the house of Judah has done here so slight that they should also fill the land with violence, provoking me again and again? Now they are putting the branch to my nose!
8:18 Therefore I in turn will act furiously: my eye will not spare, nor will I take pity. Even if they cry out in a loud voice for me to hear, I shall not listen to them.
9:1 Then he cried aloud for me to hear: Come, you scourges of the city!
9:2 And there were six men coming from the direction of the upper gate which faces north, each with a weapon of destruction in his hand. In their midst was a man dressed in linen, with a scribes case at his waist. They entered and stood beside the bronze altar.
9:3 Then the glory of the God of Israel moved off the cherub and went up to the threshold of the temple. He called to the man dressed in linen with the scribes case at his waist,
9:4 and the said to him: Pass through the city, through the midst of Jerusalem, and mark an X on the foreheads of those who grieve and lament over all the abominations practiced within it.
9:5 To the others he said in my hearing: Pass through the city after him and strike! Do not let your eyes spare; do not take pity.
9:6 Old and young, male and female, women and children—wipe them out! But do not touch anyone marked with the X. Begin at my sanctuary. So they began with the elders who were in front of the temple.
9:7 Defile the temple, he said to them, fill its courts with the slain. Then go out and strike in the city.
9:8 As they were striking, I was left alone. I fell on my face, crying out, Alas, Lord ! Will you destroy all that is left of Israel when you pour out your fury on Jerusalem?
9:9 He answered me: The guilt of the house of Israel and the house of Judah is too great to measure; the land is filled with bloodshed, the city with lawlessness. They think that the has abandoned the land, that he does not see them.
9:10 My eye, however, will not spare, nor shall I take pity, but I will bring their conduct down upon their heads.
9:11 Just then the man dressed in linen with the scribes case at his waist made his report: I have done as you commanded!
10:1 Then I looked and there above the firmament over the heads of the cherubim was something like a sapphire, something that looked like a throne.
10:2 And he said to the man dressed in linen: Go within the wheelwork under the cherubim; fill both your hands with burning coals from the place among the cherubim, then scatter them over the city. As I watched, he entered.
10:3 Now the cherubim were standing to the south of the temple when the man went in and a cloud filled the inner court.
10:4 The glory of the had moved off the cherubim to the threshold of the temple; the temple was filled with the cloud, the whole court brilliant with the glory of the .
10:5 The sound of the wings of the cherubim could be heard as far as the outer court; it was like the voice of God Almighty speaking.
10:6 He commanded the man dressed in linen: Take fire from within the wheelwork among the cherubim. The man entered and stood by one of the wheels.
10:7 Thereupon a cherub stretched out a hand from among the cherubim toward the fire in the midst of the cherubim, took some, and put it in the hands of the one dressed in linen. He took it and came out.
10:8 Something like a human hand was visible under the wings of the cherubim.
10:9 I also saw four wheels beside the cherubim, one wheel beside each cherub, and the wheels appeared to have the sparkle of yellow topaz.
10:10 And the appearance of the four all seemed alike, as though one wheel were inside the other.
10:11 When they moved, they went in any of the four directions without veering as they moved; in whatever direction the first cherub faced, the others followed without veering as they went.
10:12 Their entire bodies—backs, hands, and wings—and wheels were covered with eyes all around like the four wheels.
10:13 I heard the wheels called wheelwork.
10:14 Each living creature had four faces: the first a cherub, the second a human being, the third a lion, the fourth an eagle.
10:15 When the cherubim rose up, they were indeed the living creatures I had seen by the river Chebar.
10:16 When the cherubim moved, the wheels went beside them; when the cherubim lifted up their wings to rise from the earth, even then the wheels did not leave their sides.
10:17 When they stood still, the wheels stood still; when they rose up, the wheels rose up with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in them.
10:18 Then the glory of the left the threshold of the temple and took its place upon the cherubim.
10:19 The cherubim lifted their wings and rose up from the earth before my eyes as they departed with the wheels beside them. They stopped at the entrance of the eastern gate of the s house, and the glory of the God of Israel was up above them.
10:20 These were the living creatures I had seen beneath the God of Israel by the river Chebar. Now I knew they were cherubim.
10:21 Each of them had four faces and four wings, and something like human hands under their wings.
10:22 Their faces looked just like the faces I had seen by the river Chebar; and each one went straight ahead.
11:1 The spirit lifted me up and brought me to the east gate of the house of the facing east. There at the entrance of the gate were twenty-five men; among them I saw the public officials Jaazaniah, son of Azzur, and Pelatiah, son of Benaiah.
11:2 The said to me: Son of man, these are the men who are planning evil and giving wicked counsel in this city.
11:3 They are saying, No need to build houses! The city is the pot, and we are the meat.
11:4 Therefore prophesy against them, son of man, prophesy!
11:5 Then the spirit of the fell upon me and told me to say: Thus says the : This is how you talk, house of Israel. I know the things that come into your mind!
11:6 You have slain many in this city, filled its streets with the slain.
11:7 Therefore thus says the Lord : The slain whom you piled up in it, that is the meat, the pot is the city. But you I will bring out of it.
11:8 You fear the sword—that sword I will bring upon you—oracle of the Lord .
11:9 I will bring you out of the city, hand you over to foreigners, and execute judgments against you.
11:10 By the sword you shall fall. At the borders of Israel I will judge you so that you will know that I am the .
11:11 The city shall not be a pot for you, nor shall you be meat within it. At the borders of Israel I will judge you,
11:12 so you shall know that I am the , whose statutes you did not follow, whose ordinances you did not keep. Instead, you acted according to the ordinances of the nations around you.
11:13 While I was prophesying, Pelatiah, the son of Benaiah, dropped dead. I fell down on my face and cried out in a loud voice: Alas, Lord ! You are finishing off what remains of Israel!
11:14 The word of the came to me:
11:15 Son of man, the inhabitants of Jerusalem are saying about all your relatives, the other exiles, and all the house of Israel, They are far away from the . The land is given to us as a possession.
11:16 Therefore say: Thus says the Lord : I have indeed sent them far away among the nations, scattered them over the lands, and have been but little sanctuary for them in the lands to which they have gone.
11:17 Therefore, thus says the Lord , I will gather you from the nations and collect you from the lands through which you were scattered, so I can give you the land of Israel.
11:18 They will enter it and remove all its atrocities and abominations.
11:19 And I will give them another heart and a new spirit I will put within them. From their bodies I will remove the hearts of stone, and give them hearts of flesh,
11:20 so that they walk according to my statutes, taking care to keep my ordinances. Thus they will be my people, and I will be their God.
11:21 But as for those whose hearts are devoted to their atrocities and abominations, I will bring their conduct down upon their heads—oracle of the Lord .
11:22 Then the cherubim lifted their wings and the wheels alongside them, with the glory of the God of Israel above them.
11:23 The glory of the rose up from the middle of the city and came to rest on the mountain east of the city.
11:24 In a vision, the spirit lifted me up and brought me back to the exiles in Chaldea, by the spirit of God. The vision I had seen left me,
11:25 and I told the exiles everything the had shown me.
12:1 The word of the came to me:
12:2 Son of man, you live in the midst of a rebellious house; they have eyes to see, but do not see, and ears to hear but do not hear. They are such a rebellious house!
12:3 Now, son of man, during the day while they watch, pack a bag for exile, and again while they watch, go into exile from your place to another place; perhaps they will see that they are a rebellious house.
12:4 During the day, while they watch, bring out your bag, an exiles bag. In the evening, again while they watch, go out as if into exile.
12:5 While they watch, dig a hole through the wall and go out through it.
12:6 While they watch, shoulder your load and go out in darkness. Cover your face so you cannot see the land, for I am making you a sign for the house of Israel!
12:7 I did just as I was commanded. During the day I brought out my bag, an exiles bag. In the evening while they watched, I dug a hole through the wall with my hands and set out in darkness, shouldering my load.
12:8 In the morning, the word of the came to me:
12:9 Son of man, did not the house of Israel, that house of rebels, say, What are you doing?
12:10 Tell them: Thus says the Lord : This load is the prince in Jerusalem and the whole house of Israel within it.
12:11 Say, I am a sign for you: just as I have done, so it shall be done to them; into exile, as captives they shall go.
12:12 The prince among them shall shoulder his load in darkness and go out through the hole they dug in the wall to bring him out. His face shall be covered so that he cannot even see the ground.
12:13 I will spread my net over him and he shall be caught in my snare. I will bring him into Babylon, to the land of the Chaldeans, though he shall not see it, and there he shall die.
12:14 All his retinue, his aides and all his troops, I will scatter to the winds and pursue them with the sword.
