7:16 They have again become useless, they have been like a treacherous bow. Their princes shall fall by the sword because of the insolence of their tongues; thus they shall be mocked in the land of Egypt.
8:1 Put the trumpet to your lips! One like an eagle is over the house of the ! Because they have violated my covenant, and rebelled against my law,
8:2 They cry out to me, My God! We know you!
8:3 But Israel has rejected what is good; the enemy shall pursue him.
8:4 They made kings, but not by my authority; they established princes, but without my knowledge. With their silver and gold they made idols for themselves, to their own destruction.
8:5 He has rejected your calf, Samaria! My wrath is kindled against them; How long will they be incapable of innocence in Israel?
8:6 An artisan made it, it is no god at all. The calf of Samaria will be dashed to pieces.
8:7 When they sow the wind, they will reap the whirlwind; The stalk of grain that forms no head can yield no flour; Even if it could, strangers would swallow it.
8:8 Israel is swallowed up; now they are among the nations, like a useless vessel.
8:9 For they went up to Assyria— a wild ass off on its own— Ephraim bargained for lovers.
8:10 Even though they bargain with the nations, I will now gather them together; They will soon succumb under the burden of king and princes.
8:11 When Ephraim made many altars to expiate sin, they became altars for sinning.
8:12 Though I write for him my many instructions, they are considered like a strangers.
8:13 They love sacrifice, they sacrifice meat and eat it, but the is not pleased with them. Now he will remember their guilt and punish their sins; they shall return to Egypt.
8:14 Israel has forgotten his maker and has built palaces. Judah, too, has fortified many cities, but I will send fire upon his cities, to devour their strongholds.
9:1 Do not rejoice, Israel, do not exult like the nations! For you have prostituted yourself, abandoning your God, loving a prostitutes fee upon every threshing floor.
9:2 Threshing floor and wine press will not nourish them, the new wine will fail them.
9:3 They will not dwell in the s land; Ephraim will return to Egypt, and in Assyria they will eat unclean food.
9:4 They will not pour libations of wine to the , and their sacrifices will not please him. Their bread will be like mourners bread, that makes unclean all who eat of it; Their food will be for their own appetites; it cannot enter the house of the .
9:5 What will you do on the festival day, the day of the s feast?
9:6 When they flee from the devastation, Egypt will gather them, Memphis will bury them. Weeds will overgrow their silver treasures, and thorns, their tents.
9:7 They have come, the days of punishment! they have come, the days of recompense! Let Israel know it! The prophet is a fool, the man of the spirit is mad! Because your iniquity is great, great, too, is your hostility.
9:8 The watchman of Ephraim, the people of my God, is the prophet; yet a fowlers snare is on all his ways, hostility in the house of his God.
9:9 They have sunk to the depths of corruption, as in the days of Gibeah; God will remember their iniquity and punish their sins.
9:10 Like grapes in the desert, I found Israel; Like the first fruits of the fig tree, its first to ripen, I looked on your ancestors. But when they came to Baal-peor and consecrated themselves to the Shameful One, they became as abhorrent as the thing they loved.
9:11 Ephraim is like a bird: their glory flies away— no birth, no pregnancy, no conception.
9:12 Even though they bring up their children, I will make them childless, until no one is left. Indeed, woe to them when I turn away from them!
9:13 Ephraim, as I saw, was a tree planted in a meadow; But now Ephraim will bring out his children to the slaughterer!
9:14 Give them, ! give them what? Give them a miscarrying womb, and dry breasts!
9:15 All their misfortune began in Gilgal; yes, there I rejected them. Because of their wicked deeds I will drive them out of my house. I will love them no longer; all their princes are rebels.
9:16 Ephraim is stricken, their root is dried up; they will bear no fruit. Were they to bear children, I would slay the beloved of their womb.
9:17 My God will disown them because they have not listened to him; they will be wanderers among the nations.
10:1 Israel is a luxuriant vine whose fruit matches its growth. The more abundant his fruit, the more altars he built; The more productive his land, the more sacred pillars he set up.
10:2 Their heart is false! Now they will pay for their guilt: God will break down their altars and destroy their sacred pillars.
10:3 For now they will say, We have no king! Since we do not fear the , the king—what could he do for us?
10:4 They make promises, swear false oaths, and make covenants, While lawsuits sprout like poisonous weeds in the furrows of a field!
10:5 The inhabitants of Samaria are afraid for the calf of Beth-aven; Its people mourn for it and its idolatrous priests wail over it, —over its glory which has departed from it.
10:6 It too will be carried to Assyria, as an offering to the great king. Ephraim will be put to shame, Israel will be shamed by his schemes.
10:7 Samaria and her king will disappear, like a twig upon the waters.
10:8 The high places of Aven will be destroyed, the sin of Israel; thorns and thistles will overgrow their altars. Then they will cry out to the mountains, Cover us! and to the hills, Fall upon us!
10:9 Since the days of Gibeah you have sinned, Israel. There they took their stand; will war not reach them in Gibeah? Against a perverse people
10:10 I came and I chastised them; Peoples will be gathered against them when I bind them to their two crimes.
10:11 Ephraim was a trained heifer, that loved to thresh; I myself laid a yoke upon her beautiful neck; I will make Ephraim break ground, Judah must plow, Jacob must harrow for himself:
10:12 Sow for yourselves justice, reap the reward of loyalty; Break up for yourselves a new field, for it is time to seek the , till he comes and rains justice upon you.
10:13 But you have plowed wickedness, reaped perversity, and eaten the fruit of falsehood. Because you have trusted in your own power, and in your many warriors,
10:14 The clamor of war shall break out among your people and all your fortresses shall be ravaged As Salman ravaged Beth-arbel on the day of war, smashing mothers along with their children.
10:15 So it will be done to you, Bethel, because of your utter wickedness: At dawn the king of Israel will utterly disappear.
11:1 When Israel was a child I loved him, out of Egypt I called my son.
11:2 The more I called them, the farther they went from me, Sacrificing to the Baals and burning incense to idols.
11:3 Yet it was I who taught Ephraim to walk, who took them in my arms; but they did not know that I cared for them.
11:4 I drew them with human cords, with bands of love; I fostered them like those who raise an infant to their cheeks; I bent down to feed them.
11:5 He shall return to the land of Egypt, Assyria shall be his king, because they have refused to repent.
11:6 The sword shall rage in his cities: it shall destroy his diviners, and devour them because of their schemings.
11:7 My people have their mind set on apostasy; though they call on God in unison, he shall not raise them up.
11:8 How could I give you up, Ephraim, or deliver you up, Israel? How could I treat you as Admah, or make you like Zeboiim? My heart is overwhelmed, my pity is stirred.
11:9 I will not give vent to my blazing anger, I will not destroy Ephraim again; For I am God and not a man, the Holy One present among you; I will not come in wrath.
11:10 They shall follow the , who roars like a lion; When he roars, his children shall come frightened from the west,
11:11 Out of Egypt they shall come trembling, like birds, like doves, from the land of Assyria; And I will resettle them in their homes, oracle of the .
12:1 Ephraim has surrounded me with lies, the house of Israel, with deceit; Judah still wanders about with gods, and is faithful to holy ones.
12:2 Ephraim shepherds the wind, and pursues the east wind all day long. He multiplies lies and violence: They make a covenant with Assyria, and oil is carried to Egypt.
12:3 The has a dispute with Judah, and will punish Jacob for his conduct, and repay him for his deeds.
12:4 In the womb he supplanted his brother, and in his vigor he contended with a divine being;
12:5 He contended with an angel and prevailed, he wept and entreated him. At Bethel he met with him, and there he spoke with him.
12:6 The is the God of hosts, the is his name!
12:7 You must return to your God. Maintain loyalty and justice and always hope in your God.
12:8 A merchant who holds a false balance, he loves to extort!
12:9 Ephraim has said, How rich I have become; I have made a fortune! All his gain will not suffice for the guilt of his sin.
12:10 I the have been your God, since the land of Egypt; I will again have you live in tents, as on feast days.
12:11 I spoke to the prophets, I granted many visions, and through the prophets I told parables.
12:12 In Gilead is falsehood, they have come to nothing; in Gilgal they sacrifice bulls, But their altars are like heaps of stones in the furrows of the field.
12:13 Jacob fled to the land of Aram, and Israel served for a wife; for a wife he tended sheep.
12:14 But by a prophet the brought Israel out of Egypt, and by a prophet Israel was tended.
12:15 Ephraim has aroused bitter anger, so his Lord shall cast his bloodguilt upon him and repay him for his scorn.
13:1 When Ephraim spoke there was terror; he was exalted in Israel; but he became guilty through Baal and died.
13:2 Now they continue to sin, making for themselves molten images, Silver idols according to their skill, all of them the work of artisans. To these, offer sacrifice, they say. People kiss calves!
13:3 Therefore, they will be like a morning cloud or like the dew that vanishes with the dawn, Like chaff storm-driven from the threshing floor or like smoke out of the window.
13:4 I, the , am your God, since the land of Egypt; Gods apart from me you do not know; there is no savior but me.
13:5 I fed you in the wilderness, in the parched land.
13:6 When I fed them, they were satisfied; when satisfied, they became proud, therefore they forgot me.
13:7 So, I will be like a lion to them, like a leopard by the road I will keep watch.
13:8 I will attack them like a bear robbed of its young, and tear their hearts from their breasts; I will devour them on the spot like a lion, as a wild animal would rip them open.
13:9 I destroy you, Israel! who is there to help you?
13:10 Where now is your king, that he may rescue you? And all your princes, that they may defend you? Of whom you said, Give me a king and princes?
13:11 I give you a king in my anger, and I take him away in my wrath.
13:12 The guilt of Ephraim is wrapped up, his sin is stored away.
13:13 The birth pangs will come for him, but this is an unwise child, Who, when it is time, does not present himself at the mouth of the womb.
13:14 Shall I deliver them from the power of Sheol? shall I redeem them from death? Where are your plagues, O death! where is your sting, Sheol! Compassion is hidden from my eyes.
13:15 Though Ephraim may flourish among his brothers, an east wind will come, a wind from the , rising from the wilderness, That will dry up his spring, and leave his fountain dry. It will loot his treasury of every precious thing.
14:1 Samaria has become guilty, for she has rebelled against her God. They shall fall by the sword, their infants shall be dashed to pieces, their pregnant women shall be ripped open.
14:2 Return, Israel, to the , your God; you have stumbled because of your iniquity.
14:3 Take with you words, and return to the ; Say to him, Forgive all iniquity, and take what is good. Let us offer the fruit of our lips.
14:4 Assyria will not save us, nor will we mount horses; We will never again say, Our god, to the work of our hands; for in you the orphan finds compassion.
14:5 I will heal their apostasy, I will love them freely; for my anger is turned away from them.
14:6 I will be like the dew for Israel: he will blossom like the lily; He will strike root like the Lebanon cedar,
14:7 and his shoots will go forth. His splendor will be like the olive tree and his fragrance like Lebanon cedar.
14:8 Again they will live in his shade; they will raise grain, They will blossom like the vine, and his renown will be like the wine of Lebanon.
14:9 Ephraim! What more have I to do with idols? I have humbled him, but I will take note of him. I am like a verdant cypress tree. From me fruit will be found for you!
14:10 Who is wise enough to understand these things? Who is intelligent enough to know them? Straight are the paths of the , the just walk in them, but sinners stumble in them.
JOEL
1:1 The word of the which came to Joel, the son of Pethuel.
1:2 Listen to this, you elders! Pay attention, all who dwell in the land! Has anything like this ever happened in your lifetime, or in the lifetime of your ancestors?
1:3 Report it to your children. Have your children report it to their children, and their children to the next generation.
1:4 What the cutter left, the swarming locust has devoured; What the swarming locust left, the hopper has devoured; What the hopper left, the consuming locust has devoured.
1:5 Wake up, you drunkards, and weep; wail, all you wine drinkers, Over the new wine, taken away from your mouths.
1:6 For a nation invaded my land, powerful and past counting, With teeth like a lions, fangs like those of a lioness.
1:7 It has stripped bare my vines, splintered my fig tree, Shearing off its bark and throwing it away, until its branches turn white.
1:8 Wail like a young woman dressed in sackcloth for the husband of her youth.
1:9 Grain offering and libation are cut off from the house of the ; In mourning are the priests, the ministers of the .
1:10 The field is devastated; the farmland mourns, Because the grain is devastated, the wine has dried up, the oil has failed.
1:11 Be appalled, you farmers! wail, you vinedressers, Over the wheat and the barley, because the harvest in the field is ruined.
1:12 The vine has dried up, the fig tree has withered; The pomegranate, even the date palm and the apple— every tree in the field has dried up. Joy itself has dried up among the people.
1:13 Gird yourselves and lament, you priests! wail, ministers of the altar! Come, spend the night in sackcloth, ministers of my God! For the grain offering and the libation are withheld from the house of your God.
1:14 Proclaim a holy fast! Call an assembly! Gather the elders, all who dwell in the land, To the house of the , your God, and cry out to the !
1:15 O! The day! For near is the day of the , like destruction from the Almighty it is coming!
1:16 Before our very eyes has not food been cut off? And from the house of our God, joy and gladness?
1:17 The seed lies shriveled beneath clods of dirt; the storehouses are emptied. The granaries are broken down, for the grain is dried up.
1:18 How the animals groan! The herds of cattle are bewildered! Because they have no pasture, even the flocks of sheep are starving.
1:19 To you, , I cry! for fire has devoured the wilderness pastures, flame has scorched all the trees in the field.
1:20 Even the animals in the wild cry out to you; For the streams of water have run dry, and fire has devoured the wilderness pastures.
2:1 Blow the horn in Zion, sound the alarm on my holy mountain! Let all the inhabitants of the land tremble, for the day of the is coming! Yes, it approaches,
2:2 a day of darkness and gloom, a day of thick clouds! Like dawn spreading over the mountains, a vast and mighty army! Nothing like it has ever happened in ages past, nor will the future hold anything like it, even to the most distant generations.
2:3 Before it, fire devours, behind it flame scorches. The land before it is like the garden of Eden, and behind it, a desolate wilderness; from it nothing escapes.
2:4 Their appearance is that of horses; like war horses they run.
2:5 Like the rumble of chariots they hurtle across mountaintops; Like the crackling of fiery flames devouring stubble; Like a massive army in battle formation.
2:6 Before them peoples tremble, every face turns pale.
2:7 Like warriors they run, like soldiers they scale walls, Each advancing in line, without swerving from the course.
2:8 No one crowds the other; each advances in its own track; They plunge through the weapons; they are not checked.
2:9 They charge the city, they run upon the wall, they climb into the houses; Through the windows they enter like thieves.
2:10 Before them the earth trembles; the heavens shake; Sun and moon are darkened, and the stars withhold their brightness.
2:11 The raises his voice at the head of his army; How immense is his host! How numerous those who carry out his command! How great is the day of the ! Utterly terrifying! Who can survive it?
2:12 Yet even now—oracle of the — return to me with your whole heart, with fasting, weeping, and mourning.
2:13 Rend your hearts, not your garments, and return to the , your God, For he is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love, and relenting in punishment.
2:14 Perhaps he will again relent and leave behind a blessing, Grain offering and libation for the , your God.
2:15 Blow the horn in Zion! Proclaim a fast, call an assembly!
2:16 Gather the people, sanctify the congregation; Assemble the elderly; gather the children, even infants nursing at the breast; Let the bridegroom leave his room, and the bride her bridal tent.
2:17 Between the porch and the altar let the priests weep, let the ministers of the weep and say: Spare your people, ! do not let your heritage become a disgrace, a byword among the nations! Why should they say among the peoples, Where is their God?
2:18 Then the grew jealous for his land and took pity on his people.
2:19 In response the said to his people: I am sending you grain, new wine, and oil, and you will be satisfied by them; Never again will I make you a disgrace among the nations.
2:20 The northerner I will remove far from you, driving them out into a dry and desolate land, Their vanguard to the eastern sea, their rearguard to the western sea, And their stench will rise, their stink will ascend, What great deeds the Lord has done!
2:21 Do not fear, O land! delight and rejoice, for the has done great things!
2:22 Do not fear, you animals in the wild, for the wilderness pastures sprout green grass. The trees bear fruit, the fig tree and the vine produce their harvest.
2:23 Children of Zion, delight and rejoice in the , your God! For he has faithfully given you the early rain, sending rain down on you, the early and the late rains as before.
2:24 The threshing floors will be full of grain, the vats spilling over with new wine and oil.
2:25 I will repay you double what the swarming locust has eaten, The hopper, the consuming locust, and the cutter, my great army I sent against you.
2:26 You will eat until you are fully satisfied, then you will praise the name of the , your God, Who acts so wondrously on your behalf! My people will never again be put to shame.
2:27 Then you will know that I am in the midst of Israel: I, the , am your God, and there is no other; my people will never again be put to shame.
3:1 It shall come to pass I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh. Your sons and daughters will prophesy, your old men will dream dreams, your young men will see visions.
3:2 Even upon your male and female servants, in those days, I will pour out my spirit.
3:3 I will set signs in the heavens and on the earth, blood, fire, and columns of smoke;
3:4 The sun will darken, the moon turn blood-red, Before the day of the arrives, that great and terrible day.
3:5 Then everyone who calls upon the name of the will escape harm. For on Mount Zion there will be a remnant, as the has said, And in Jerusalem survivors whom the will summon.
4:1 For see, in those days and at that time, when I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem,
4:2 I will gather all the nations and bring them down to the Valley of Jehoshaphat. There I will enter into judgment with them on behalf of my people, my heritage, Israel; Because they scattered them among the nations, they divided up my land.
4:3 For my people they cast lots, trading a young boy for the price of a prostitute, exchanging a young girl for the wine they drank.
4:4 Moreover, what are you doing to me, Tyre and Sidon, and all the regions of Philistia? Are you paying me back for something? If you are, I will very quickly turn your deeds back upon your own head.
4:5 You took my silver and my gold and brought my priceless treasures into your temples!
4:6 You sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, taking them far from their own country!
4:7 Look! I am rousing them from the place to which you sold them, and I will turn your deeds back upon your own head.
4:8 I will sell your sons and daughters to the Judahites who will sell them to the Sabeans, a distant nation. The has spoken!
4:9 Announce this to the nations: Proclaim a holy war! Alert the warriors! Let all the soldiers report and march!
4:10 Beat your plowshares into swords, and your pruning knives into spears; let the weakling boast, I am a warrior!
4:11 Hurry and come, all you neighboring peoples, assemble there! Bring down, , your warriors!
4:12 Let the nations rouse themselves and come up to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; For there I will sit in judgment upon all the neighboring nations.
4:13 Wield the sickle, for the harvest is ripe; Come and tread, for the wine press is full; The vats overflow, for their crimes are numerous.
4:14 Crowds upon crowds in the Valley of Decision; For near is the day of the in the Valley of Decision.
4:15 Sun and moon are darkened, and the stars withhold their brightness,
4:16 The roars from Zion, and from Jerusalem raises his voice, The heavens and the earth quake, but the will be a shelter for his people, a fortress for the people of Israel.
4:17 Then you will know that I the am your God, dwelling on Zion, my holy mountain; Jerusalem will be holy, and strangers will never again travel through her.
4:18 On that day the mountains will drip new wine, and the hills flow with milk, All the streams of Judah will flow with water. A spring will rise from the house of the , watering the Valley of Shittim.
4:19 Egypt will be a waste, Edom a desolate wilderness, Because of violence done to the Judahites, because they shed innocent blood in their land.
4:20 But Judah will be inhabited forever, and Jerusalem for all generations.
4:21 I will avenge their blood, and I will not acquit the guilt. The dwells in Zion.
AMOS
1:1 The words of Amos, who was one of the sheepbreeders from Tekoa, which he received in a vision concerning Israel in the days of Uzziah, king of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam, son of Joash, king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.
1:2 He said: The roars from Zion, and raises his voice from Jerusalem; The pastures of the shepherds languish, and the summit of Carmel withers.
1:3 Thus says the : For three crimes of Damascus, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they threshed Gilead with sledges of iron,
1:4 I will send fire upon the house of Hazael, and it will devour the strongholds of Ben-hadad.
1:5 I will break the barred gate of Damascus; From the Valley of Aven I will cut off the one enthroned, And the sceptered ruler from Beth-eden; the people of Aram shall be exiled to Kir, says the .
1:6 Thus says the : For three crimes of Gaza, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they exiled an entire population, handing them over to Edom,
1:7 I will send fire upon the wall of Gaza, and it will devour its strongholds;
1:8 From Ashdod I will cut off the one enthroned and the sceptered ruler from Ashkelon; I will turn my hand against Ekron, and the last of the Philistines shall perish, says the Lord .
1:9 Thus says the : For three crimes of Tyre, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they handed over an entire population to Edom, and did not remember their covenant of brotherhood,
1:10 I will send fire upon the wall of Tyre, and it will devour its strongholds.
1:11 Thus says the : For three crimes of Edom, and now four— I will not take it back— Because he pursued his brother with the sword, suppressing all pity, Persisting in his anger, his wrath raging without end,
1:12 I will send fire upon Teman, and it will devour the strongholds of Bozrah.
1:13 Thus says the : For three crimes of the Ammonites, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they ripped open pregnant women in Gilead, in order to extend their territory,
1:14 I will kindle a fire upon the wall of Rabbah, and it will devour its strongholds Amid war cries on the day of battle, amid stormwind on the day of tempest.
1:15 Their king shall go into exile, he and his princes with him, says the .
2:1 Thus says the : For three crimes of Moab, and now four— I will not take it back— Because he burned to ashes the bones of Edoms king,
2:2 I will send fire upon Moab, and it will devour the strongholds of Kerioth; Moab shall meet death amid uproar, battle cries and blasts of the rams horn.
2:3 I will cut off the ruler from its midst, and all the princes I will slay with him, says the .
2:4 Thus says the : For three crimes of Judah, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they spurned the instruction of the , and did not keep his statutes; Because the lies which their ancestors followed have led them astray,
2:5 I will send fire upon Judah, and it will devour the strongholds of Jerusalem.
2:6 Thus says the : For three crimes of Israel, and now four— I will not take it back— Because they hand over the just for silver, and the poor for a pair of sandals;
2:7 They trample the heads of the destitute into the dust of the earth, and force the lowly out of the way. Son and father sleep with the same girl, profaning my holy name.
2:8 Upon garments taken in pledge they recline beside any altar. Wine at treasury expense they drink in their temples.
2:9 Yet it was I who destroyed the Amorites before them, who were as tall as cedars, and as strong as oak trees. I destroyed their fruit above and their roots beneath.
2:10 It was I who brought you up from the land of Egypt, and who led you through the desert for forty years, to occupy the land of the Amorites;
2:11 I who raised up prophets among your children, and nazirites among your young men. Is this not so, Israelites?— oracle of the .
2:12 But you made the nazirites drink wine, and commanded the prophets, Do not prophesy!
2:13 Look, I am groaning beneath you, as a wagon groans when laden with sheaves.
2:14 Flight shall elude the swift, and the strong shall not retain strength; The warrior shall not save his life,
2:15 nor shall the archer stand his ground; The swift of foot shall not escape, nor shall the horseman save his life.
2:16 And the most stouthearted of warriors shall flee naked on that day— oracle of the .
3:1 Hear this word, Israelites, that the speaks concerning you, concerning the whole family I brought up from the land of Egypt:
3:2 You alone I have known, among all the families of the earth; Therefore I will punish you for all your iniquities.
3:3 Do two journey together unless they have agreed?
3:4 Does a lion roar in the forest when it has no prey? Does a young lion cry out from its den unless it has seized something?
3:5 Does a bird swoop down on a trap on the ground when there is no lure for it? Does a snare spring up from the ground without catching anything?
3:6 Does the rams horn sound in a city without the people becoming frightened? Does disaster befall a city unless the has caused it?
3:7 (Indeed, the Lord does nothing without revealing his plan to his servants the prophets.)
3:8 The lion has roared, who would not fear? The Lord has spoken, who would not prophesy?
3:9 Proclaim this in the strongholds of Assyria, in the strongholds of the land of Egypt: Gather on the mount of Samaria, and see the great disorders within it, the oppressions within its midst.
3:10 They do not know how to do what is right— oracle of the — Storing up in their strongholds violence and destruction.
3:11 Therefore thus says the Lord : An enemy shall surround the land, tear down your fortresses, and pillage your strongholds.
3:12 Thus says the : As the shepherd rescues from the mouth of the lion a pair of sheeps legs or the tip of an ear, So shall the Israelites escape, those who dwell in Samaria, With the corner of a couch or a piece of a cot.
3:13 Hear and bear witness against the house of Jacob— an oracle of the Lord , the God of hosts:
3:14 On the day when I punish Israel for its crimes, I will also punish the altars of Bethel; The horns of the altar shall be broken off and fall to the ground.
3:15 I will strike the winter house and the summer house; The houses of ivory shall lie in ruin, and their many rooms shall be no more— oracle of the .
4:1 Hear this word, you cows of Bashan, who live on the mount of Samaria: Who oppress the destitute and abuse the needy; Who say to your husbands, Bring us a drink!
4:2 The Lord has sworn by his holiness: Truly days are coming upon you when they shall drag you away with ropes, your children with fishhooks;
4:3 You shall go out through the breached walls one in front of the other, And you shall be exiled to Harmon— oracle of the .
4:4 Come to Bethel and sin, to Gilgal and sin all the more! Each morning bring your sacrifices, every third day your tithes;
4:5 Burn leavened bread as a thanksgiving sacrifice, proclaim publicly your voluntary offerings, For so you love to do, Israelites— oracle of the Lord .
4:6 Though I made your teeth clean of food in all your cities, and made bread scarce in all your dwellings, Yet you did not return to me— oracle of the .
4:7 And I withheld the rain from you when the harvest was still three months away; I sent rain upon one city but not upon another; One field was watered by rain, but the one I did not water dried up;
4:8 Two or three cities staggered to another to drink water but were not satisfied; Yet you did not return to me— oracle of the .
4:9 I struck you with blight and mildew; locusts devoured your gardens and vineyards, the caterpillar consumed your fig trees and olive trees; Yet you did not return to me— oracle of the .
4:10 I sent upon you pestilence like that of Egypt; with the sword I killed your young men and your captured horses, and to your nostrils I brought the stench of your camps; Yet you did not return to me— oracle of the .
4:11 I overthrew you as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah; you were like a brand plucked from the fire, Yet you did not return to me— oracle of the .
4:12 Therefore thus I will do to you, Israel: and since I will deal thus with you, prepare to meet your God, O Israel!
4:13 The one who forms mountains and creates winds, and declares to mortals their thoughts; Who makes dawn into darkness and strides upon the heights of the earth, the , the God of hosts, is his name!
5:1 Hear this word which I utter concerning you, this dirge, house of Israel:
5:2 She is fallen, to rise no more, virgin Israel; She lies abandoned on her land, with no one to raise her up.
5:3 For thus says the Lord to the house of Israel: The city that marched out with a thousand shall be left with a hundred, Another that marched out with a hundred shall be left with ten.
5:4 For thus says the to the house of Israel: Seek me, that you may live,
5:5 but do not seek Bethel; Do not come to Gilgal, and do not cross over to Beer-sheba; For Gilgal shall be led into exile and Bethel shall be no more.
5:6 Seek the , that you may live, lest he flare up against the house of Joseph like a fire that shall consume the house of Israel, with no one to quench it.
5:8 The one who made the Pleiades and Orion, who turns darkness into dawn, and darkens day into night; Who summons the waters of the sea, and pours them out on the surface of the earth;
5:9 Who makes destruction fall suddenly upon the stronghold and brings ruin upon the fortress, the is his name.
5:7 Woe to those who turn justice into wormwood and cast righteousness to the ground,
5:10 They hate those who reprove at the gate and abhor those who speak with integrity;
5:11 Therefore, because you tax the destitute and exact from them levies of grain, Though you have built houses of hewn stone, you shall not live in them; Though you have planted choice vineyards, you shall not drink their wine.
5:12 Yes, I know how many are your crimes, how grievous your sins: Oppressing the just, accepting bribes, turning away the needy at the gate.
5:13 (Therefore at this time the wise are struck dumb for it is an evil time.)
5:14 Seek good and not evil, that you may live; Then truly the , the God of hosts, will be with you as you claim.
5:15 Hate evil and love good, and let justice prevail at the gate; Then it may be that the , the God of hosts, will have pity on the remnant of Joseph.
5:16 Therefore, thus says the , the God of hosts, the Lord: In every square there shall be lamentation, and in every street they shall cry, Oh, no! They shall summon the farmers to wail and the professional mourners to lament.
5:17 And in every vineyard there shall be lamentation when I pass through your midst, says the .
5:18 Woe to those who yearn for the day of the ! What will the day of the mean for you? It will be darkness, not light!
5:19 As if someone fled from a lion and a bear met him; Or as if on entering the house he rested his hand against the wall, and a snake bit it.
5:20 Truly, the day of the will be darkness, not light, gloom without any brightness!
5:21 I hate, I despise your feasts, I take no pleasure in your solemnities.
5:22 Even though you bring me your burnt offerings and grain offerings I will not accept them; Your stall-fed communion offerings, I will not look upon them.
5:23 Take away from me your noisy songs; The melodies of your harps, I will not listen to them.
5:24 Rather let justice surge like waters, and righteousness like an unfailing stream.
5:25 Did you bring me sacrifices and grain offerings for forty years in the desert, O house of Israel?
5:26 Yet you will carry away Sukuth, your king, and Kaiwan, your star-image, your gods that you have made for yourselves,
5:27 As I exile you beyond Damascus, says the , whose name is the God of hosts.
6:1 Woe to those who are complacent in Zion, secure on the mount of Samaria, Leaders of the first among nations, to whom the people of Israel turn.
6:2 Pass over to Calneh and see, go from there to Hamath the great, and down to Gath of the Philistines. Are you better than these kingdoms, or is your territory greater than theirs?
6:3 You who would put off the day of disaster, yet hasten the time of violence!
6:4 Those who lie on beds of ivory, and lounge upon their couches; Eating lambs taken from the flock, and calves from the stall;
6:5 Who improvise to the music of the harp, composing on musical instruments like David,
6:6 Who drink wine from bowls, and anoint themselves with the best oils, but are not made ill by the collapse of Joseph;
6:7 Therefore, now they shall be the first to go into exile, and the carousing of those who lounged shall cease.
6:8 The Lord has sworn by his very self— an oracle of the , the God of hosts: I abhor the pride of Jacob, I hate his strongholds, and I will hand over the city with everything in it;
6:9 Should there remain ten people in a single house, these shall die.
6:10 When a relative or one who prepares the body picks up the remains to carry them out of the house, If he says to someone in the recesses of the house, Is anyone with you? and the answer is, No one, Then he shall say, Silence! for no one must mention the name of the .
6:11 Indeed, the has given the command to shatter the great house to bits, and reduce the small house to rubble.
6:12 Can horses run over rock, or can one plow the sea with oxen? Yet you have turned justice into gall, and the fruit of righteousness into wormwood,
6:13 You who rejoice in Lodebar, and say, Have we not, by our own strength, seized Karnaim for ourselves?
6:14 Look, I am raising up against you, house of Israel— oracle of the , the God of hosts— A nation that shall oppress you from Lebo-hamath even to the Wadi Arabah.
7:1 This is what the Lord showed me: He was forming a locust swarm when the late growth began to come up (the late growth after the kings mowing).
7:2 When they had finished eating the grass in the land, I said: Forgive, O Lord ! Who will raise up Jacob? He is so small!
7:3 The relented concerning this. This shall not be, said the Lord .
7:4 This is what the Lord showed me: He was summoning a rain of fire. It had devoured the great abyss and was consuming the fields.
7:5 Then I said: Cease, O Lord ! Who will raise up Jacob? He is so small!
7:6 The relented concerning this. This also shall not be, said the Lord .
7:7 This is what the Lord showed me: He was standing, plummet in hand, by a wall built with a plummet.
7:8 The Lord asked me, What do you see, Amos? And I answered, A plummet. Then the said: See, I am laying the plummet in the midst of my people Israel; I will forgive them no longer.
7:9 The high places of Isaac shall be laid waste, and the sanctuaries of Israel made desolate; and I will attack the house of Jeroboam with the sword.
7:10 Amaziah, the priest of Bethel, sent word to Jeroboam, king of Israel: Amos has conspired against you within the house of Israel; the country cannot endure all his words.
7:11 For this is what Amos says: Jeroboam shall die by the sword, and Israel shall surely be exiled from its land.
7:12 To Amos, Amaziah said: Off with you, seer, flee to the land of Judah and there earn your bread by prophesying!
7:13 But never again prophesy in Bethel; for it is the kings sanctuary and a royal temple.
7:14 Amos answered Amaziah, I am not a prophet, nor do I belong to a company of prophets. I am a herdsman and a dresser of sycamores,
7:15 but the took me from following the flock, and the said to me, Go, prophesy to my people Israel.
7:16 Now hear the word of the : You say: Do not prophesy against Israel, do not preach against the house of Isaac.
7:17 Therefore thus says the : Your wife shall become a prostitute in the city, and your sons and daughters shall fall by the sword. Your land shall be parcelled out by measuring line, and you yourself shall die in an unclean land; and Israel shall be exiled from its land.
8:1 This is what the Lord showed me: a basket of end-of-summer fruit.
8:2 He asked, What do you see, Amos? And I answered, A basket of end-of-summer fruit. And the said to me: The end has come for my people Israel; I will forgive them no longer.
8:3 The temple singers will wail on that day— oracle of the Lord . Many shall be the corpses, strewn everywhere—Silence!
8:4 Hear this, you who trample upon the needy and destroy the poor of the land:
8:5 When will the new moon be over, you ask, that we may sell our grain, And the sabbath, that we may open the grain-bins? We will diminish the ephah, add to the shekel, and fix our scales for cheating!
8:6 We will buy the destitute for silver, and the poor for a pair of sandals; even the worthless grain we will sell!
8:7 The has sworn by the pride of Jacob: Never will I forget a thing they have done!
8:8 Shall not the land tremble because of this, and all who dwell in it mourn? It will all rise up and toss like the Nile, and subside like the river of Egypt.
8:9 On that day—oracle of the Lord — I will make the sun set at midday and in broad daylight cover the land with darkness.
8:10 I will turn your feasts into mourning and all your songs into dirges. I will cover the loins of all with sackcloth and make every head bald. I will make it like the time of mourning for an only child, and its outcome like a day of bitter weeping.
8:11 See, days are coming—oracle of the Lord — when I will send a famine upon the land: Not a hunger for bread, or a thirst for water, but for hearing the word of the .
8:12 They shall stagger from sea to sea and wander from north to east In search of the word of the , but they shall not find it.
8:13 On that day, beautiful young women and young men shall faint from thirst,
8:14 Those who swear by Ashima of Samaria, and who say, By the life of your god, O Dan, By the life of the Power of Beer-sheba! They shall fall, never to rise again.
9:1 I saw the Lord standing beside the altar. And he said: Strike the capitals so that the threshold shakes! Break them off on the heads of them all! Those who are left I will slay with the sword. Not one shall get away, no survivor shall escape.
9:2 Though they dig down to Sheol, even from there my hand shall take them; Though they climb to the heavens, even from there I shall bring them down.
9:3 Though they hide on the summit of Carmel, there too I will hunt them down and take them; Though they hide from my gaze at the bottom of the sea, there I will command the serpent to bite them.
9:4 Though they go into captivity before their enemies, there I will command the sword to slay them. I will fix my gaze upon them for evil and not for good.
9:5 The Lord of hosts, Who melts the earth with his touch, so that all who dwell on it mourn, So that it will all rise up like the Nile, and subside like the river of Egypt;
9:6 Who has built his upper chamber in heaven, and established his vault over the earth; Who summons the waters of the sea and pours them upon the surface of the earth— the is his name.
9:7 Are you not like the Ethiopians to me, O Israelites?—oracle of the — Did I not bring the Israelites from the land of Egypt as I brought the Philistines from Caphtor and the Arameans from Kir?
9:8 See, the eyes of the Lord are on this sinful kingdom, and I will destroy it from the face of the earth— But I will not destroy the house of Jacob completely— oracle of the .
9:9 For see, I have given the command to sift the house of Israel among all the nations, As one sifts with a sieve, letting no pebble fall to the ground.
9:10 All sinners among my people shall die by the sword, those who say, Disaster will not reach or overtake us.
9:11 On that day I will raise up the fallen hut of David; I will wall up its breaches, raise up its ruins, and rebuild it as in the days of old,
9:12 That they may possess the remnant of Edom, and all nations claimed in my name— oracle of the , the one who does this.
9:13 Yes, days are coming— oracle of the — When the one who plows shall overtake the one who reaps and the vintager, the sower of the seed; The mountains shall drip with the juice of grapes, and all the hills shall run with it.
9:14 I will restore my people Israel, they shall rebuild and inhabit their ruined cities, Plant vineyards and drink the wine, set out gardens and eat the fruits.
9:15 I will plant them upon their own ground; never again shall they be plucked From the land I have given them— the , your God, has spoken.
OBADIAH
1:1 The vision of Obadiah. Thus says the Lord concerning Edom: We have heard a message from the , and a herald has been sent among the nations: Rise up, so we may go to war against it!
1:2 Now I make you least among the nations; you are utterly contemptible.
1:3 The pride of your heart has deceived you— you who dwell in mountain crevices, in your lofty home, Who say in your heart, Who will bring me down to earth?
1:4 Though you soar like the eagle, and your nest is set among the stars, From there I will bring you down— oracle of the .
1:5 If thieves came to you, robbers by night —how you have been destroyed!— would they not steal merely till they had enough? If grape pickers came to you, would they not leave some gleanings?
1:6 How Esau has been searched out, his treasures hunted down!
1:7 To the border they have driven you— all your allies; Your partners have deceived you, they have overpowered you; Those who eat your bread will replace you with foreigners, who have no understanding.
1:8 On that day—oracle of the —will I not make the wise disappear from Edom, and understanding from Mount Esau?
1:9 Teman, your warriors will be terror-stricken, so that everyone on Mount Esau will be cut down.
1:10 Because of violence to your brother Jacob, disgrace will cover you, you will be done away with forever!
1:11 On the day you stood by, the day strangers carried off his possessions, And foreigners entered his gates and cast lots for Jerusalem, you too were like one of them.
1:12 Do not gloat over the day of your brother, the day of his disaster; Do not exult over the people of Judah on the day of their ruin; Do not speak haughtily on the day of distress!
1:13 Do not enter the gate of my people on the day of their calamity; Do not gloat—especially you—over his misfortune on the day of his calamity; Do not lay hands upon his possessions on the day of his calamity!
1:14 Do not stand at the crossroads to cut down his survivors; Do not hand over his fugitives on the day of distress!
1:15 Near is the day of the against all the nations! As you have done, so will it be done to you, your conduct will come back upon your own head;
1:16 As you drank upon my holy mountain, so will all the nations drink continually. Yes, they will drink and swallow, and will become as though they had not been.
1:17 But on Mount Zion there will be some who escape; the mountain will be holy, And the house of Jacob will take possession of those who dispossessed them.
1:18 The house of Jacob will be a fire, the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau stubble. They will set it ablaze and devour it; none will survive of the house of Esau, for the has spoken.
1:19 They will take possession of the Negeb, Mount Esau, the Shephelah, and Philistia, possess the countryside of Ephraim, the countryside of Samaria, Benjamin, and Gilead.
1:20 The exiles of this Israelite army will possess the Canaanite land as far as Zarephath, and the exiles of Jerusalem who are in Sepharad will possess the cities of the Negeb.
1:21 And deliverers will ascend Mount Zion to rule Mount Esau, and the kingship shall be the s.
JONAH
1:1 The word of the came to Jonah, son of Amittai:
1:2 Set out for the great city of Nineveh, and preach against it; for their wickedness has come before me.
1:3 But Jonah made ready to flee to Tarshish, away from the . He went down to Joppa, found a ship going to Tarshish, paid the fare, and went down in it to go with them to Tarshish, away from the .
1:4 The , however, hurled a great wind upon the sea, and the storm was so great that the ship was about to break up.
1:5 Then the sailors were afraid and each one cried to his god. To lighten the ship for themselves, they threw its cargo into the sea. Meanwhile, Jonah had gone down into the hold of the ship, and lay there fast asleep.
1:6 The captain approached him and said, What are you doing asleep? Get up, call on your god! Perhaps this god will be mindful of us so that we will not perish.
1:7 Then they said to one another, Come, let us cast lots to discover on whose account this evil has come to us. So they cast lots, and the lot fell on Jonah.
1:8 They said to him, Tell us why this evil has come to us! What is your business? Where do you come from? What is your country, and to what people do you belong?
1:9 I am a Hebrew, he replied; I fear the , the God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land.
1:10 Now the men were seized with great fear and said to him, How could you do such a thing!—They knew that he was fleeing from the , because he had told them.
1:11 They asked, What shall we do with you, that the sea may calm down for us? For the sea was growing more and more stormy.
1:12 Jonah responded, Pick me up and hurl me into the sea and then the sea will calm down for you. For I know that this great storm has come upon you because of me.
1:13 Still the men rowed hard to return to dry land, but they could not, for the sea grew more and more stormy.
1:14 Then they cried to the : Please, O , do not let us perish for taking this mans life; do not charge us with shedding innocent blood, for you, , have accomplished what you desired.
1:15 Then they picked up Jonah and hurled him into the sea, and the sea stopped raging.
1:16 Seized with great fear of the , the men offered sacrifice to the and made vows.
2:1 But the sent a great fish to swallow Jonah, and he remained in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.
2:2 Jonah prayed to the , his God, from the belly of the fish:
2:3 Out of my distress I called to the , and he answered me; From the womb of Sheol I cried for help, and you heard my voice.
2:4 You cast me into the deep, into the heart of the sea, and the flood enveloped me; All your breakers and your billows passed over me.
2:5 Then I said, I am banished from your sight! How will I again look upon your holy temple?
2:6 The waters surged around me up to my neck; the deep enveloped me; seaweed wrapped around my head.
2:7 I went down to the roots of the mountains; to the land whose bars closed behind me forever, But you brought my life up from the pit, O , my God.
2:8 When I became faint, I remembered the ; My prayer came to you in your holy temple.
2:9 Those who worship worthless idols abandon their hope for mercy.
2:10 But I, with thankful voice, will sacrifice to you; What I have vowed I will pay: deliverance is from the .
2:11 Then the commanded the fish to vomit Jonah upon dry land.
3:1 The word of the came to Jonah a second time:
3:2 Set out for the great city of Nineveh, and announce to it the message that I will tell you.
3:3 So Jonah set out for Nineveh, in accord with the word of the . Now Nineveh was an awesomely great city; it took three days to walk through it.
3:4 Jonah began his journey through the city, and when he had gone only a single days walk announcing, Forty days more and Nineveh shall be overthrown,
3:5 the people of Nineveh believed God; they proclaimed a fast and all of them, great and small, put on sackcloth.
3:6 When the news reached the king of Nineveh, he rose from his throne, laid aside his robe, covered himself with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.
3:7 Then he had this proclaimed throughout Nineveh: By decree of the king and his nobles, no man or beast, no cattle or sheep, shall taste anything; they shall not eat, nor shall they drink water.
3:8 Man and beast alike must be covered with sackcloth and call loudly to God; they all must turn from their evil way and from the violence of their hands.
3:9 Who knows? God may again repent and turn from his blazing wrath, so that we will not perish.
3:10 When God saw by their actions how they turned from their evil way, he repented of the evil he had threatened to do to them; he did not carry it out.
4:1 But this greatly displeased Jonah, and he became angry.
4:2 He prayed to the , O , is this not what I said while I was still in my own country? This is why I fled at first toward Tarshish. I knew that you are a gracious and merciful God, slow to anger, abounding in kindness, repenting of punishment.
4:3 So now, , please take my life from me; for it is better for me to die than to live.
4:4 But the asked, Are you right to be angry?
4:5 Jonah then left the city for a place to the east of it, where he built himself a hut and waited under it in the shade, to see what would happen to the city.
4:6 Then the God provided a gourd plant. And when it grew up over Jonahs head, giving shade that relieved him of any discomfort, Jonah was greatly delighted with the plant.
4:7 But the next morning at dawn God provided a worm that attacked the plant, so that it withered.
4:8 And when the sun arose, God provided a scorching east wind; and the sun beat upon Jonahs head till he became faint. Then he wished for death, saying, It is better for me to die than to live.
4:9 But God said to Jonah, Do you have a right to be angry over the gourd plant? Jonah answered, I have a right to be angry—angry enough to die.
4:10 Then the said, You are concerned over the gourd plant which cost you no effort and which you did not grow; it came up in one night and in one night it perished.
4:11 And should I not be concerned over the great city of Nineveh, in which there are more than a hundred and twenty thousand persons who cannot know their right hand from their left, not to mention all the animals?
MICAH
1:1 The word of the which came to Micah of Moresheth in the days of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, which he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.
1:2 Hear, O peoples, all of you, give heed, O earth, and all that is in it! Let the Lord be witness against you, the Lord from his holy temple!
1:3 For see, the goes out from his place and descending, treads upon the heights of the earth.
1:4 The mountains melt under him and the valleys split open, Like wax before the fire, like water poured down a slope.
1:5 All this is for the crime of Jacob, for the sins of the house of Israel. What is the crime of Jacob? Is it not Samaria? And what is the sin of the house of Judah? Is it not Jerusalem?
1:6 So I will make Samaria a ruin in the field, a place to plant vineyards; I will throw its stones into the valley, and lay bare its foundations.
1:7 All its carved figures shall be broken to pieces, all its wages shall be burned in the fire, and all its idols I will destroy. As the wages of a prostitute it gathered them, and to the wages of a prostitute they shall return.
1:8 For this I will lament and wail, go barefoot and naked; I will utter lamentation like the jackals, mourning like the ostriches,
1:9 For her wound is incurable; it has come even to Judah. It has reached to the gate of my people, even to Jerusalem.
1:10 Do not announce it in Gath, do not weep at all; In Beth-leaphrah roll in the dust.
1:11 Pass by, you who dwell in Shaphir! The inhabitants of Zaanan do not come forth from their city. There is lamentation in Beth-ezel. It will withdraw its support from you.
1:12 The inhabitants of Maroth hope for good, But evil has come down from the to the gate of Jerusalem.
1:13 Harness steeds to the chariots, inhabitants of Lachish; You are the beginning of sin for daughter Zion, For in you were found the crimes of Israel.
1:14 Therefore you must give back the dowry to Moresheth-gath; The houses of Achzib are a dry stream bed to the kings of Israel.
1:15 Again I will bring the conqueror to you, inhabitants of Mareshah; The glory of Israel shall come even to Adullam.
1:16 Make yourself bald, cut off your hair, for the children whom you cherish; Make yourself bald as a vulture, for they are taken from you into exile.
2:1 Ah! you plotters of iniquity, who work out evil on your beds! In the morning light you carry it out for it lies within your power.
2:2 You covet fields, and seize them; houses, and take them; You cheat owners of their houses, people of their inheritance.
2:3 Therefore thus says the : Look, I am planning against this family an evil from which you cannot free your necks; Nor shall you walk with head held high, for it will be an evil time.
2:4 On that day you shall be mocked, and there will be bitter lament: Our ruin is complete, our fields are divided among our captors, The fields of my people are measured out, and no one can get them back!
2:5 Thus you shall have no one in the assembly of the to allot to you a share of land.
2:6 Do not preach, they preach, no one should preach of these things! Shame will not overtake us.
2:7 How can it be said, house of Jacob, Is the short of patience; are these the Lords deeds? Do not my words promise good to the one who walks in justice?
2:8 But you rise up against my people as an enemy: you have stripped off the garment from the peaceful, From those who go their way in confidence, as though it were spoils of war.
2:9 The women of my people you drive out from their pleasant houses; From their children you take away forever the honor I gave them.
2:10 Get up! Leave, this is no place to rest; Because of uncleanness that destroys with terrible destruction.
2:11 If one possessed of a lying spirit speaks deceitfully, saying, I will preach to you wine and strong drink, that one would be the preacher for this people.
2:12 I will gather you, Jacob, each and every one, I will assemble all the remnant of Israel; I will group them like a flock in the fold, like a herd in its pasture; the noise of the people will resound.
2:13 The one who makes a breach goes up before them; they make a breach and pass through the gate; Their king shall go through before them, the at their head.
3:1 And I said: Hear, you leaders of Jacob, rulers of the house of Israel! Is it not your duty to know what is right,
3:2 you who hate what is good, and love evil? You who tear their skin from them, and their flesh from their bones;
3:3 Who eat the flesh of my people, flay their skin from them, and break their bones; Who chop them in pieces like flesh in a kettle, like meat in a pot.
3:4 When they cry to the , he will not answer them; He will hide his face from them at that time, because of the evil they have done.
3:5 Thus says the regarding the prophets: O you who lead my people astray, When your teeth have something to bite you announce peace, But proclaim war against the one who fails to put something in your mouth.
3:6 Therefore you shall have night, not vision, darkness, not divination; The sun shall go down upon the prophets, and the day shall be dark for them.
3:7 Then the seers shall be put to shame, and the diviners confounded; They shall all cover their lips, because there is no answer from God.
3:8 But as for me, I am filled with power, with the spirit of the , with justice and with might; To declare to Jacob his crimes and to Israel his sins.
3:9 Hear this, you leaders of the house of Jacob, you rulers of the house of Israel! You who abhor justice, and pervert all that is right;
3:10 Who build up Zion with bloodshed, and Jerusalem with wickedness!
3:11 Its leaders render judgment for a bribe, the priests teach for pay, the prophets divine for money, While they rely on the , saying, Is not the in the midst of us? No evil can come upon us!
3:12 Therefore, because of you, Zion shall be plowed like a field, and Jerusalem reduced to rubble, And the mount of the temple to a forest ridge.
4:1 In days to come the mount of the s house Shall be established as the highest mountain; it shall be raised above the hills, And peoples shall stream to it:
4:2 Many nations shall come, and say, Come, let us climb the s mountain, to the house of the God of Jacob, That he may instruct us in his ways, that we may walk in his paths. For from Zion shall go forth instruction, and the word of the from Jerusalem.
4:3 He shall judge between many peoples and set terms for strong and distant nations; They shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; One nation shall not raise the sword against another, nor shall they train for war again.
4:4 They shall all sit under their own vines, under their own fig trees, undisturbed; for the of hosts has spoken.
4:5 Though all the peoples walk, each in the name of its god, We will walk in the name of the , our God, forever and ever.
4:6 On that day—oracle of the — I will gather the lame, And I will assemble the outcasts, and those whom I have afflicted.
4:7 I will make of the lame a remnant, and of the weak a strong nation; The shall be king over them on Mount Zion, from now on and forever.
4:8 And you, O tower of the flock, hill of daughter Zion! To you it shall come: the former dominion shall be restored, the reign of daughter Jerusalem.
4:9 Now why do you cry out so? Are you without a king? Or has your adviser perished, That you are seized with pains like a woman in labor?
4:10 Writhe, go into labor, O daughter Zion, like a woman giving birth; For now you shall leave the city and camp in the fields; To Babylon you shall go, there you shall be rescued. There the shall redeem you from the hand of your enemies.
4:11 And now many nations are gathered against you! They say, Let her be profaned, let our eyes see Zions downfall!
4:12 But they do not know the thoughts of the , nor understand his plan: He has gathered them like sheaves to the threshing floor.
4:13 Arise and thresh, O daughter Zion; your horn I will make iron And your hoofs I will make bronze, that you may crush many peoples; You shall devote their spoils to the , their riches to the Lord of the whole earth.
4:14 Now grieve, O grieving daughter! They have laid siege against us! With the rod they strike on the cheek the ruler of Israel.
5:1 But you, Bethlehem-Ephrathah least among the clans of Judah, From you shall come forth for me one who is to be ruler in Israel; Whose origin is from of old, from ancient times.
5:2 Therefore the Lord will give them up, until the time when she who is to give birth has borne, Then the rest of his kindred shall return to the children of Israel.
5:3 He shall take his place as shepherd by the strength of the , by the majestic name of the , his God; And they shall dwell securely, for now his greatness shall reach to the ends of the earth:
5:4 he shall be peace. If Assyria invades our country and treads upon our land, We shall raise against it seven shepherds, eight of royal standing;
5:5 They shall tend the land of Assyria with the sword, and the land of Nimrod with the drawn sword; They will deliver us from Assyria, when it invades our land, when it treads upon our borders.
5:6 The remnant of Jacob shall be in the midst of many peoples, Like dew coming from the , like showers on the grass, Which wait for no one, delay for no human being.
5:7 And the remnant of Jacob shall be among the nations, in the midst of many peoples, Like a lion among beasts of the forest, like a young lion among flocks of sheep; When it passes through it tramples; it tears and no one can rescue.
5:8 Your hand shall be lifted above your foes, and all your enemies shall be cut down.
5:9 On that day—oracle of the — I will destroy the horses from your midst and ruin your chariots;
5:10 I will destroy the cities of your land and tear down all your fortresses.
5:11 I will destroy the sorcery you practice, and there shall no longer be soothsayers among you.
5:12 I will destroy your carved figures and the sacred stones from your midst; And you shall no longer worship the works of your hands.
5:13 I will tear out the asherahs from your midst, and destroy your cities.
5:14 I will wreak vengeance in anger and wrath upon the nations that have not listened.
6:1 Hear, then, what the says: Arise, plead your case before the mountains, and let the hills hear your voice!
6:2 Hear, O mountains, the s case, pay attention, O foundations of the earth! For the has a case against his people; he enters into trial with Israel.
6:3 My people, what have I done to you? how have I wearied you? Answer me!
6:4 I brought you up from the land of Egypt, from the place of slavery I ransomed you; And I sent before you Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.
6:5 My people, remember what Moabs King Balak planned, and how Balaam, the son of Beor, answered him. Recall the passage from Shittim to Gilgal, that you may know the just deeds of the .
6:6 With what shall I come before the , and bow before God most high? Shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves a year old?
6:7 Will the be pleased with thousands of rams, with myriad streams of oil? Shall I give my firstborn for my crime, the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?
6:8 You have been told, O mortal, what is good, and what the requires of you: Only to do justice and to love goodness, and to walk humbly with your God.
6:9 The cries aloud to the city (It is prudent to fear your name!): Hear, O tribe and city assembly,
6:10 Am I to bear criminal hoarding and the accursed short ephah?
6:11 Shall I acquit crooked scales, bags of false weights?
6:12 You whose wealthy are full of violence, whose inhabitants speak falsehood with deceitful tongues in their mouths!
6:13 I have begun to strike you with devastation because of your sins.
6:14 You shall eat, without being satisfied, food that will leave you empty; What you acquire, you cannot save; what you do save, I will deliver up to the sword.
6:15 You shall sow, yet not reap, tread out the olive, yet pour no oil, crush the grapes, yet drink no wine.
6:16 You have kept the decrees of Omri, and all the works of the house of Ahab, and you have walked in their counsels; Therefore I will deliver you up to ruin, and your citizens to derision; and you shall bear the reproach of the nations.
7:1 Woe is me! I am like the one who gathers summer fruit, when the vines have been gleaned; There is no cluster to eat, no early fig that I crave.
7:2 The faithful have vanished from the earth, no mortal is just! They all lie in wait to shed blood, each one ensnares the other.
7:3 Their hands succeed at evil; the prince makes demands, The judge is bought for a price, the powerful speak as they please.
7:4 The best of them is like a brier, the most honest like a thorn hedge. The day announced by your sentinels! Your punishment has come; now is the time of your confusion.
7:5 Put no faith in a friend, do not trust a companion; With her who lies in your embrace watch what you say.
7:6 For the son belittles his father, the daughter rises up against her mother, The daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law, and your enemies are members of your household.
7:7 But as for me, I will look to the , I will wait for God my savior; my God will hear me!
7:8 Do not rejoice over me, my enemy! though I have fallen, I will arise; though I sit in darkness, the is my light.
7:9 I will endure the wrath of the because I have sinned against him, Until he pleads my case, and establishes my right. He will bring me forth to the light; I will see his righteousness.
7:10 When my enemy sees this, shame shall cover her: She who said to me, Where is the , your God? My eyes shall see her downfall; now she will be trampled underfoot, like mud in the streets.
7:11 It is the day for building your walls; on that day your boundaries shall be enlarged.
7:12 It is the day when those from Assyria to Egypt shall come to you, And from Tyre even to the River, from sea to sea, and from mountain to mountain;
7:13 And the earth shall be a waste because of its inhabitants, as a result of their deeds.
7:14 Shepherd your people with your staff, the flock of your heritage, That lives apart in a woodland, in the midst of an orchard. Let them feed in Bashan and Gilead, as in the days of old;
7:15 As in the days when you came from the land of Egypt, show us wonderful signs.
7:16 The nations will see and will be put to shame, in spite of all their strength; They will put their hands over their mouths; their ears will become deaf.
7:17 They will lick the dust like a snake, like crawling things on the ground; They will come quaking from their strongholds; they will tremble in fear of you, the , our God.
7:18 Who is a God like you, who removes guilt and pardons sin for the remnant of his inheritance; Who does not persist in anger forever, but instead delights in mercy,
7:19 And will again have compassion on us, treading underfoot our iniquities? You will cast into the depths of the sea all our sins;
7:20 You will show faithfulness to Jacob, and loyalty to Abraham, As you have sworn to our ancestors from days of old.
NAHUM
1:1 Oracle concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum of Elkosh.
1:2 A jealous and avenging God is the , an avenger is the , full of wrath; The takes vengeance on his adversaries, and rages against his enemies;
1:3 The is slow to anger, yet great in power; the will not leave the guilty unpunished. In stormwind and tempest he comes, and clouds are the dust at his feet;
1:4 He roars at the sea and leaves it dry, and all the rivers he dries up. Laid low are Bashan and Carmel, and the bloom of Lebanon withers;
1:5 The mountains quake before him, and the hills dissolve; The earth is laid waste before him, the world and all who dwell in it.
1:6 Before his wrath, who can stand firm, and who can face his blazing anger? His fury is poured out like fire, and boulders break apart before him.
1:7 The is good to those who wait for him, a refuge on the day of distress, Taking care of those who look to him for protection,
1:8 when the flood rages; He makes an end of his opponents, and pursues his enemies into darkness.
1:9 What do you plot against the , the one about to bring total destruction? No opponent rises a second time!
1:10 Like a thorny thicket, they are tangled, and like drunkards, they are drunk; like dry stubble, they are utterly consumed.
1:11 From you has come one plotting evil against the , one giving sinister counsel.
1:12 Thus says the : though fully intact and so numerous, they shall be mown down and disappear. Though I have humbled you, I will humble you no more.
1:13 Now I will break his yoke off of you, and tear off your bonds.
1:14 The has commanded regarding you: no descendant will again bear your name; From the house of your gods I will abolish the carved and the molten image; I will make your grave a dung heap.
2:1 At this moment on the mountains the footsteps of one bearing good news, of one announcing peace! Celebrate your feasts, Judah, fulfill your vows! For never again will destroyers invade you; they are completely cut off.
2:2 One who scatters has come up against you; guard the rampart, Watch the road, brace yourselves, marshal all your strength!
2:3 The will restore the vine of Jacob, the honor of Israel, Because ravagers have ravaged them and ruined their branches.
2:4 The shields of his warriors are crimsoned, the soldiers clad in scarlet; Like fire are the trappings of the chariots on the day he prepares for war; the cavalry is agitated!
2:5 The chariots dash madly through the streets and wheel in the squares, Looking like torches, bolting like lightning.
2:6 His picked troops are called, ranks break at their charge; To the wall they rush, their screen is set up.
2:7 The river gates are opened, the palace is washed away.
2:8 The mistress is led forth captive, and her maidservants led away, Moaning like doves, beating their breasts.
2:9 Nineveh is like a pool whose waters escape; Stop! Stop! but none turns back.
2:10 Plunder the silver, plunder the gold! There is no end to the treasure, to wealth in every precious thing!
2:11 Emptiness, desolation, waste; melting hearts and trembling knees, Churning in every stomach, every face turning pale!
2:12 Where is the lionesses den, the young lions cave, Where the lion went in and out, and the cub, with no one to disturb them?
2:13 The lion tore apart enough for his cubs, and strangled for his lionesses; He filled his lairs with prey, and his dens with torn flesh.
2:14 I now come against you— oracle of the of hosts— I will consume your chariots in smoke, and the sword will devour your young lions; Your preying on the land I will bring to an end, the cry of your lionesses will be heard no more.
3:1 Ah! The bloody city, all lies, Full of plunder, whose looting never stops!
3:2 The crack of the whip, the rumbling of wheels; Horses galloping, chariots bounding,
3:3 Cavalry charging, the flash of the sword, the gleam of the spear; A multitude of slain, a mass of corpses, Endless bodies to stumble upon!
3:4 For the many debaucheries of the prostitute, a charming mistress of witchcraft, Who enslaved nations with her prostitution, and peoples by her witchcraft:
3:5 I now come against you— oracle of the of hosts— and I will lift your skirt above your face; I will show your nakedness to the nations, to the kingdoms your shame!
3:6 I will cast filth upon you, disgrace you and make you a spectacle;
3:7 Until everyone who sees you runs from you saying, Nineveh is destroyed; who can pity her? Where can I find any to console you?
3:8 Are you better than No-amon that was set among the Niles canals, Surrounded by waters, with the river for her rampart and water for her wall?
3:9 Ethiopia was her strength, and Egypt without end; Put and the Libyans were her allies.
3:10 Yet even she became an exile, and went into captivity; Even her little ones were dashed to pieces at the corner of every street; For her nobles they cast lots, and all her great ones were put into chains.
3:11 You, too, will drink of this; you will be overcome; You, too, will seek a refuge from the foe.
3:12 But all your fortresses are fig trees, bearing early figs; When shaken, they fall into the devourers mouth.
3:13 Indeed your troops are women in your midst; To your foes are open wide the gates of your land, fire has consumed their bars.
3:14 Draw water for the siege, strengthen your fortresses; Go down into the mud and tread the clay, take hold of the brick mold!
3:15 There the fire will consume you, the sword will cut you down; it will consume you like the grasshoppers. Multiply like the grasshoppers, multiply like the locusts!
3:16 You have made your traders more numerous than the stars of the heavens; like grasshoppers that shed their skins and fly away.
3:17 Your sentries are like locusts, and your scribes like locust swarms Gathered on the rubble fences on a cold day! Yet when the sun rises, they vanish, and no one knows where they have gone.
3:18 Your shepherds slumber, O king of Assyria, your nobles have gone to rest; Your people are scattered upon the mountains, with none to gather them.
3:19 There is no healing for your hurt, your wound is fatal. All who hear this news of you clap their hands over you; For who has not suffered under your endless malice?
HABAKKUK
1:1 The oracle which Habakkuk the prophet received in a vision.
1:2 How long, O , must I cry for help and you do not listen? Or cry out to you, Violence! and you do not intervene?
1:3 Why do you let me see iniquity? why do you simply gaze at evil? Destruction and violence are before me; there is strife and discord.
1:4 This is why the law is numb and justice never comes, For the wicked surround the just; this is why justice comes forth perverted.
1:5 Look over the nations and see! Be utterly amazed! For a work is being done in your days that you would not believe, were it told.
1:6 For now I am raising up the Chaldeans, that bitter and impulsive people, Who march the breadth of the land to take dwellings not their own.
1:7 They are terrifying and dreadful; their right and their exalted position are of their own making.
1:8 Swifter than leopards are their horses, and faster than desert wolves. Their horses spring forward; they come from far away; they fly like an eagle hastening to devour.
1:9 All of them come for violence, their combined onslaught, a stormwind to gather up captives like sand.
1:10 They scoff at kings, ridicule princes; They laugh at any fortress, heap up an earthen ramp, and conquer it.
1:11 Then they sweep through like the wind and vanish— they make their own strength their god!
1:12 Are you not from of old, O , my holy God, immortal? , you have appointed them for judgment, O Rock, you have set them in place to punish!
1:13 Your eyes are too pure to look upon wickedness, and the sight of evil you cannot endure. Why, then, do you gaze on the faithless in silence while the wicked devour those more just than themselves?
1:14 You have made mortals like the fish in the sea, like creeping things without a leader.
1:15 He brings them all up with a hook, and hauls them away with his net; He gathers them in his fishing net, and then rejoices and exults.
1:16 Therefore he makes sacrifices to his net, and burns incense to his fishing net; For thanks to them his portion is rich, and his meal lavish.
1:17 Shall they, then, keep on drawing his sword to slaughter nations without mercy?
2:1 I will stand at my guard post, and station myself upon the rampart; I will keep watch to see what he will say to me, and what answer he will give to my complaint.
2:2 Then the answered me and said: Write down the vision; Make it plain upon tablets, so that the one who reads it may run.
2:3 For the vision is a witness for the appointed time, a testimony to the end; it will not disappoint. If it delays, wait for it, it will surely come, it will not be late.
2:4 See, the rash have no integrity; but the just one who is righteous because of faith shall live.
2:5 Indeed wealth is treacherous; a proud man does not succeed. He who opens wide his throat like Sheol, and is insatiable as death, Who gathers to himself all the nations, and collects for himself all the peoples—
2:6 Shall not all these take up a taunt against him, and make a riddle about him, saying: Ah! you who store up what is not yours —how long can it last!— you who load yourself down with collateral.
2:7 Will your debtors not rise suddenly? Will they not awake, those who make you tremble? You will become their spoil!
2:8 Because you plundered many nations, the remaining peoples shall plunder you; Because of the shedding of human blood, and violence done to the land, to the city and to all who live in it.
2:9 Ah! you who pursue evil gain for your household, setting your nest on high to escape the reach of misfortune!
2:10 You have devised shame for your household, cutting off many peoples, forfeiting your own life;
2:11 For the stone in the wall shall cry out, and the beam in the frame shall answer it!
2:12 Ah! you who build a city by bloodshed, and who establish a town with injustice!
2:13 Is this not from the of hosts: peoples toil for what the flames consume, and nations grow weary for nothing!
2:14 But the earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the s glory, just as the water covers the sea.
2:15 Ah! you who give your neighbors the cup of your wrath to drink, and make them drunk, until their nakedness is seen!
2:16 You are filled with shame instead of glory; drink, you too, and stagger! The cup from the s right hand shall come around to you, and utter shame shall cover your glory.
2:17 For the violence done to Lebanon shall cover you, and the destruction of the animals shall terrify you; Because of the shedding of human blood, and violence done to the land, to the city and to all who live in it.
2:18 Of what use is the carved image, that its maker should carve it? Or the molten image, the lying oracle, that its very maker should trust in it, and make mute idols?
2:19 Ah! you who say to wood, Awake! to silent stone, Arise! Can any such thing give oracles? It is only overlaid with gold and silver, there is no breath in it at all.
2:20 But the is in his holy temple; silence before him, all the earth!
3:1 Prayer of Habakkuk, the prophet. According to Shigyonot.
3:2 O , I have heard your renown, and am in awe, O , of your work. In the course of years revive it, in the course of years make yourself known; in your wrath remember compassion!
3:3 God came from Teman, the Holy One from Mount Paran.  His glory covered the heavens, and his praise filled the earth;
3:4 his splendor spread like the light. He raised his horns high, he rejoiced on the day of his strength.
3:5 Before him went pestilence, and plague followed in his steps.
3:6 He stood and shook the earth; he looked and made the nations tremble. Ancient mountains were shattered, the age-old hills bowed low, age-old orbits collapsed.
3:7 The tents of Cushan trembled, the pavilions of the land of Midian.
3:8 Was your anger against the rivers, O ? your wrath against the rivers, your rage against the sea, That you mounted your steeds, your victorious chariot?
3:9 You readied your bow, you filled your bowstring with arrows.  You split the earth with rivers;
3:10 at the sight of you the mountains writhed. The clouds poured down water; the deep roared loudly. The sun forgot to rise,
3:11 the moon left its lofty station, At the light of your flying arrows, at the gleam of your flashing spear.
3:12 In wrath you marched on the earth, in fury you trampled the nations.
