3:13 You came forth to save your people, to save your anointed one. You crushed the back of the wicked, you laid him bare, bottom to neck. 
3:14 You pierced his head with your shafts; his princes you scattered with your stormwind, as food for the poor in unknown places.
3:15 You trampled the sea with your horses amid the churning of the deep waters.
3:16 I hear, and my body trembles; at the sound, my lips quiver. Decay invades my bones, my legs tremble beneath me. I await the day of distress that will come upon the people who attack us.
3:17 For though the fig tree does not blossom, and no fruit appears on the vine, Though the yield of the olive fails and the terraces produce no nourishment, Though the flocks disappear from the fold and there is no herd in the stalls,
3:18 Yet I will rejoice in the and exult in my saving God.
3:19 , my Lord, is my strength; he makes my feet swift as those of deer and enables me to tread upon the heights. For the leader; with stringed instruments.
ZEPHANIAH
1:1 The word of the which came to Zephaniah, the son of Cushi, the son of Gedaliah, the son of Amariah, the son of Hezekiah, in the days of Josiah, the son of Amon, king of Judah.
1:2 I will completely sweep away all things from the face of the land—oracle of the .
1:3 I will sweep away human being and beast alike, I will sweep away the birds of the sky, and the fish of the sea. I will make the wicked stumble; I will eliminate the people from the face of the land—oracle of the .
1:4 I will stretch out my hand against Judah, and against all the inhabitants of Jerusalem; I will eliminate from this place the last vestige of Baal, the name of the idolatrous priests.
1:5 And those who bow down on the roofs to the host of heaven, And those who bow down to the but swear by Milcom;
1:6 And those who have turned away from the , and those who have not sought the , who have not inquired of him.
1:7 Silence in the presence of the Lord ! for near is the day of the , Yes, the has prepared a sacrifice, he has consecrated his guests.
1:8 On the day of the s sacrifice I will punish the officials and the kings sons, and all who dress in foreign apparel.
1:9 I will punish, on that day, all who leap over the threshold, Who fill the house of their master with violence and deceit.
1:10 On that day—oracle of the — A cry will be heard from the Fish Gate, a wail from the Second Quarter, loud crashing from the hills.
1:11 Wail, O inhabitants of Maktesh! for all the merchants are destroyed, all who weigh out silver, done away with.
1:12 At that time, I will search Jerusalem with lamps, I will punish the people who settle like dregs in wine, Who say in their hearts, The Lord will not do good, nor will he do harm.
1:13 Their wealth shall be given to plunder and their houses to devastation; They will build houses, but not dwell in them; They will plant vineyards, but not drink their wine.
1:14 Near is the great day of the , near and very swiftly coming. The sound of the day of the ! Piercing— there a warrior shrieks!
1:15 A day of wrath is that day, a day of distress and anguish, a day of ruin and desolation, A day of darkness and gloom, a day of thick black clouds,
1:16 A day of trumpet blasts and battle cries against fortified cities, against lofty battlements.
1:17 I will hem the people in till they walk like the blind, because they have sinned against the ; And their blood shall be poured out like dust, and their bowels like dung.
1:18 Neither their silver nor their gold will be able to save them. On the day of the s wrath, in the fire of his passion, all the earth will be consumed. For he will make an end, yes, a sudden end, of all who live on the earth.
2:1 Gather, gather yourselves together, O nation without shame!
2:2 Before you are driven away, like chaff that disappears; Before there comes upon you the blazing anger of the ; Before there comes upon you the day of the s anger.
2:3 Seek the , all you humble of the land, who have observed his law; Seek justice, seek humility; Perhaps you will be sheltered on the day of the s anger.
2:4 For Gaza shall be forsaken, and Ashkelon shall be a waste, Ashdod they shall drive out at midday, and Ekron shall be uprooted.
2:5 Ah! You who dwell by the seacoast, the nation of Cherethites, the word of the is against you! O Canaan, land of the Philistines, I will leave you to perish without an inhabitant!
2:6 You shall become fields for shepherds, and folds for flocks.
2:7 The seacoast shall belong to the remnant of the house of Judah; by the sea they shall pasture. In the houses of Ashkelon they shall lie down in the evening. For the their God will take care of them, and bring about their restoration.
2:8 I have heard the taunts uttered by Moab, and the insults of the Ammonites, When they taunted my people and made boasts against their territory.
2:9 Therefore, as I live— oracle of the of hosts— the God of Israel, Moab shall become like Sodom, the Ammonites like Gomorrah: A field of weeds, a salt pit, a waste forever. The remnant of my people shall plunder them, the survivors of my nation dispossess them.
2:10 This will be the recompense for their pride, because they taunted and boasted against the people of the of hosts.
2:11 The shall inspire them with terror when he makes all the gods of earth waste away; Then the distant shores of the nations, each from its own place, shall bow down to him.
2:12 You too, O Cushites, shall be slain by the sword of the .
2:13 He will stretch out his hand against the north, to destroy Assyria; He will make Nineveh a waste, dry as the desert.
2:14 In her midst flocks shall lie down, all the wild life of the hollows; The screech owl and the desert owl shall roost in her columns; The owl shall hoot from the window, the raven croak from the doorway.
2:15 Is this the exultant city that dwelt secure, That told itself, I and there is no one else? How it has become a waste, a lair for wild animals! Those who pass by it hiss, and shake their fists!
3:1 Ah! Rebellious and polluted, the tyrannical city!
3:2 It listens to no voice, accepts no correction; In the it has not trusted, nor drawn near to its God.
3:3 Its officials within it are roaring lions; Its judges are desert wolves that have no bones to gnaw by morning.
3:4 Its prophets are reckless, treacherous people; Its priests profane what is holy, and do violence to the law.
3:5 But the in its midst is just, doing no wrong; Morning after morning rendering judgment unfailingly, at dawn; the wicked, however, know no shame.
3:6 I have cut down nations, their battlements are laid waste; I have made their streets deserted, with no one passing through; Their cities are devastated, with no one dwelling in them.
3:7 I said, Surely now you will fear me, you will accept correction; They cannot fail to see all I have brought upon them. Yet the more eagerly they have done all their corrupt deeds.
3:8 Therefore, wait for me—oracle of the — until the day when I arise as accuser; For it is my decision to gather nations, to assemble kingdoms, In order to pour out upon them my wrath, all my blazing anger; For in the fire of my passion all the earth will be consumed.
3:9 For then I will make pure the speech of the peoples, That they all may call upon the name of the , to serve him with one accord;
3:10 From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia and as far as the recesses of the North, they shall bring me offerings.
3:11 On that day You will not be ashamed of all your deeds, when you rebelled against me; For then I will remove from your midst the proud braggarts, And you shall no longer exalt yourself on my holy mountain.
3:12 But I will leave as a remnant in your midst a people humble and lowly, Who shall take refuge in the name of the —
3:13 the remnant of Israel. They shall do no wrong and speak no lies; Nor shall there be found in their mouths a deceitful tongue; They shall pasture and lie down with none to disturb them.
3:14 Shout for joy, daughter Zion! sing joyfully, Israel! Be glad and exult with all your heart, daughter Jerusalem!
3:15 The has removed the judgment against you, he has turned away your enemies; The King of Israel, the , is in your midst, you have no further misfortune to fear.
3:16 On that day, it shall be said to Jerusalem: Do not fear, Zion, do not be discouraged!
3:17 The , your God, is in your midst, a mighty savior, Who will rejoice over you with gladness, and renew you in his love, Who will sing joyfully because of you,
3:18 as on festival days. I will remove disaster from among you, so that no one may recount your disgrace.
3:19 At that time I will deal with all who oppress you; I will save the lame, and assemble the outcasts; I will give them praise and renown in every land where they were shamed.
3:20 At that time I will bring you home, and at that time I will gather you; For I will give you renown and praise, among all the peoples of the earth, When I bring about your restoration before your very eyes, says the .
HAGGAI
1:1 On the first day of the sixth month in the second year of Darius the king, the word of the came through Haggai the prophet to the governor of Judah, Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and to the high priest Joshua, son of Jehozadak:
1:2 Thus says the of hosts: This people has said: Now is not the time to rebuild the house of the .
1:3 Then the word of the came through Haggai the prophet:
1:4 Is it time for you to dwell in your paneled houses while this house lies in ruins?
1:5 Now thus says the of hosts: Reflect on your experience!
1:6 You have sown much, but have brought in little; you have eaten, but have not been satisfied; You have drunk, but have not become intoxicated; you have clothed yourselves, but have not been warmed; And the hired worker labors for a bag full of holes.
1:7 Thus says the of hosts: Reflect on your experience!
1:8 Go up into the hill country; bring timber, and build the house that I may be pleased with it, and that I may be glorified, says the .
1:9 You expected much, but it came to little; and what you brought home, I blew away. Why is this?—oracle of the of hosts— Because my house is the one which lies in ruins, while each of you runs to your own house.
1:10 Therefore, the heavens withheld the dew, and the earth its yield.
1:11 And I have proclaimed a devastating heat upon the land and upon the mountains, Upon the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil, upon all that the ground brings forth; Upon human being and beast alike, and upon all they produce.
1:12 Then Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and the high priest Joshua, son of Jehozadak, and all the remnant of the people obeyed the their God, and the words of Haggai the prophet, since the their God had sent him; thus the people feared the .
1:13 Then Haggai, the messenger of the , proclaimed to the people as the message of the : I am with you!—oracle of the .
1:14 And so the stirred up the spirit of the governor of Judah, Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and the spirit of the high priest Joshua, son of Jehozadak, and the spirit of all the remnant of the people, so that they came to do the work in the house of the of hosts, their God,
1:15 on the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month in the second year of Darius the king.
2:1 On the twenty-first day of the seventh month, the word of the came through Haggai the prophet:
2:2 Speak to the governor of Judah, Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and to the high priest Joshua, son of Jehozadak, and to the remnant of the people:
2:3 Who is left among you who saw this house in its former glory? And how do you see it now? Does it not seem like nothing in your eyes?
2:4 Now be strong, Zerubbabel—oracle of the — be strong, Joshua, son of Jehozadak, high priest, Be strong, all you people of the land—oracle of the — and work! For I am with you—oracle of the of hosts.
2:5 This is the commitment I made to you when you came out of Egypt. My spirit remains in your midst; do not fear!
2:6 For thus says the of hosts: In just a little while, I will shake the heavens and the earth, the sea and the dry land.
2:7 I will shake all the nations, so that the treasures of all the nations will come in. And I will fill this house with glory— says the of hosts.
2:8 Mine is the silver and mine the gold—oracle of the of hosts.
2:9 Greater will be the glory of this house the latter more than the former—says the of hosts; And in this place I will give you peace— oracle of the of hosts. 
2:10 On the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month in the second year of Darius, the word of the came to Haggai the prophet:
2:11 Thus says the of hosts: Ask the priests for a ruling:
2:12 If someone carries sanctified meat in the fold of a garment and the fold touches bread, soup, wine, oil, or any other food, do they become sanctified? No, the priests answered.
2:13 Then Haggai asked: If a person defiled from contact with a corpse touches any of these, do they become defiled? The priests answered, They become defiled.
2:14 Then Haggai replied: So is this people, and so is this nation in my sight—oracle of the — And so is all the work of their hands; what they offer there is defiled.
2:15 Now reflect, from this day forward—before you set stone to stone in the temple of the ,
2:16 what was your experience? When one went to a heap of grain for twenty ephahs, there were only ten; When one went to a vat to draw fifty ephahs, there were only twenty.
2:17 I struck you, and all the work of your hands, with searing wind, blight, and hail, yet you did not return to me—oracle of the .
2:18 Reflect from this day forward, from the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month. From the day on which the temple of the was founded, reflect!
2:19 Is there still seed in the storehouse? Have the vine, the fig, the pomegranate, and the olive tree still not borne fruit? From this day, I will bless you. 
2:20 The word of the came a second time to Haggai on the twenty-fourth day of the month:
2:21 Speak to Zerubbabel, the governor of Judah: I will shake the heavens and the earth;
2:22 I will overthrow the thrones of kingdoms, and destroy the power of the kingdoms of the nations. I will overthrow the chariots and their riders, and the riders with their horses will fall by each others swords.
2:23 On that day—oracle of the of hosts—I will take you, my servant, Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel—oracle of the —and I will make you like a signet ring, for I have chosen you—oracle of the of hosts.
ZECHARIAH
1:1 In the second year of Darius, in the eighth month, the word of the came to the prophet Zechariah, son of Berechiah, son of Iddo:
1:2 The was very angry with your ancestors.
1:3 Say to them: Thus says the of hosts, Return to me—oracle of the of hosts—and I will return to you, says the of hosts.
1:4 Do not be like your ancestors to whom the earlier prophets proclaimed: Thus says the of hosts: Turn from your evil ways and from your wicked deeds. But they did not listen or pay attention to me—oracle of the .—
1:5 Your ancestors, where are they? And the prophets, can they live forever?
1:6 But my words and my statutes, with which I charged my servants the prophets, did these not overtake your ancestors? Then they repented and admitted: Just as the of hosts intended to treat us according to our ways and deeds, so the has done. 
1:7 In the second year of Darius, on the twenty-fourth day of Shebat, the eleventh month, the word of the came to the prophet Zechariah, son of Berechiah, son of Iddo:
1:8 I looked out in the night, and there was a man mounted on a red horse standing in the shadows among myrtle trees; and behind him were red, sorrel, and white horses.
1:9 I asked, What are these, my lord? Then the angel who spoke with me answered, I will show you what these are.
1:10 Then the man who was standing among the myrtle trees spoke up and said, These are the ones whom the has sent to patrol the earth.
1:11 And they answered the angel of the , who was standing among the myrtle trees: We have been patrolling the earth, and now the whole earth rests quietly.
1:12 Then the angel of the replied, of hosts, how long will you be without mercy for Jerusalem and the cities of Judah that have felt your anger these seventy years?
1:13 To the angel who spoke with me, the replied favorably, with comforting words.
1:14 The angel who spoke with me then said to me, Proclaim: Thus says the of hosts: I am jealous for Jerusalem and for Zion intensely jealous.
1:15 I am consumed with anger toward the complacent nations; When I was only a little angry, they compounded the disaster.
1:16 Therefore, thus says the : I return to Jerusalem in mercy; my house will be rebuilt there—oracle of the of hosts— and a measuring line will be stretched over Jerusalem.
1:17 Proclaim further: Thus says the of hosts: My cities will again overflow with prosperity; the will again comfort Zion, and will again choose Jerusalem.
2:1 I raised my eyes and looked and there were four horns.
2:2 Then I asked the angel who spoke with me, What are those? He answered, Those are the horns that scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem.
2:3 Then the showed me four workmen.
2:4 And I said, What are these coming to do? And the said, Those are the horns that scattered Judah, so that none could raise their heads any more; and these have come to terrify them—to cut down the horns of the nations that raised their horns to scatter the land of Judah.
2:5 I raised my eyes and looked, and there was a man with a measuring cord in his hand.
2:6 I asked, Where are you going? And he said, To measure Jerusalem—to see how great its width is and how great its length.
2:7 Then the angel who spoke with me advanced as another angel came out to meet him
2:8 and he said to the latter, Run, speak to that official: Jerusalem will be unwalled, because of the abundance of people and beasts in its midst.
2:9 I will be an encircling wall of fire for it—oracle of the —and I will be the glory in its midst.
2:10 Up! Up! Flee from the land of the north—oracle of the ;—For like the four winds of heaven I have dispersed you—oracle of the .
2:11 Up, Zion! Escape, you who dwell in daughter Babylon!
2:12 For thus says the of hosts after the s glory had sent me, concerning the nations that have plundered you: Whoever strikes you strikes me directly in the eye.
2:13 Now I wave my hand over them, and they become plunder for their own servants. Thus you shall know that the of hosts has sent me.
2:14 Sing and rejoice, daughter Zion! Now, I am coming to dwell in your midst—oracle of the .
2:15 Many nations will bind themselves to the on that day. They will be my people, and I will dwell in your midst. Then you shall know that the of hosts has sent me to you.
2:16 The will inherit Judah as his portion of the holy land, and the will again choose Jerusalem.
2:17 Silence, all people, in the presence of the , who stirs forth from his holy dwelling.
3:1 Then he showed me Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the , while the adversary stood at his right side to accuse him.
3:2 And the angel of the said to the adversary, May the rebuke you, O adversary; may the who has chosen Jerusalem rebuke you! Is this not a brand plucked from the fire?
3:3 Now Joshua was standing before the angel, clad in filthy garments.
3:4 Then the angel said to those standing before him, Remove his filthy garments. And to him he said, Look, I have taken your guilt from you, and I am clothing you in stately robes.
3:5 Then he said, Let them put a clean turban on his head. And they put a clean turban on his head and clothed him with the garments while the angel of the was standing by.
3:6 Then the angel of the charged Joshua:
3:7 Thus says the of hosts: If you walk in my ways and carry out my charge, you will administer my house and watch over my courts; and I will give you access to those standing here.
3:8 Hear, O Joshua, high priest! You and your associates who sit before you! For they are signs of things to come! I will surely bring my servant the Branch.
3:9 Look at the stone that I have placed before Joshua. On this one stone with seven facets I will engrave its inscription—oracle of the of hosts—and I will take away the guilt of that land in one day.
3:10 On that day—oracle of the of hosts—you will invite one another under your vines and fig trees.
4:1 Then the angel who spoke with me returned and aroused me, like one awakened from sleep.
4:2 He said to me, What do you see? I replied, I see a lampstand all of gold, with a bowl on top of it. There are seven lamps on it, with seven spouts on each of the lamps that are on top of it.
4:3 And beside it are two olive trees, one on the right of the bowl and one to its left.
4:4 Then I said to the angel who spoke with me, What are these things, my lord?
4:5 And the angel who spoke with me replied, Do you not know what these things are? I said, No, my lord.
4:6 Then he said to me: This is the word of the to Zerubbabel: Not by might, and not by power, but by my spirit, says the of hosts.
4:7 Who are you, O great mountain? Before Zerubbabel you become a plain. He will bring forth the first stone amid shouts of Favor, favor be upon it!
4:8 Then the word of the came to me:
4:9 The hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundations of this house, and his hands will finish it. Thus you shall know that the of hosts has sent me to you.
4:10 For whoever has scorned such a day of small things will rejoice to see the capstone in the hand of Zerubbabel. These seven are the eyes of the that range over the whole earth.
4:11 I then asked him, What are these two olive trees, on the right of the lampstand and on its left?
4:12 A second time I asked, What are the two streams from the olive trees that pour out golden oil through two taps of gold?
4:13 He said to me, Do you not know what these are? I answered, No, my lord.
4:14 Then he said, These are the two anointed ones who stand by the Lord of the whole earth.
5:1 Then I raised my eyes again and saw a flying scroll.
5:2 He asked me, What do you see? I answered, I see a flying scroll, twenty cubits long and ten cubits wide.
5:3 Then he said to me: This is the curse which is to go forth over the whole land. According to it, every thief and every perjurer will be expelled.
5:4 I will send it forth—oracle of the of hosts—so that it will come to the house of the thief, and into the house of the one who swears falsely by my name. It shall lodge within each house, consuming it, timber and stones.
5:5 Then the angel who spoke with me came forward and said to me, Raise your eyes and look. What is this that comes forth?
5:6 I said, What is it? And he answered, This is the basket that is coming. And he said, This is their guilt in all the land.
5:7 Then a leaden cover was lifted, and there was a woman sitting inside the basket.
5:8 He said, This is Wickedness, and he thrust her inside the basket, pushing the leaden weight into the opening.
5:9 Then I raised my eyes and saw two women coming forth with wind under their wings—they had wings like the wings of a stork—and they lifted the basket into the air.
5:10 I said to the angel who spoke with me, Where are they taking the basket?
5:11 He replied, To build a temple for it in the land of Shinar. When the temple is constructed, they will set it there on its base.
6:1 Again I raised my eyes and saw four chariots coming out from between two mountains; and the mountains were of bronze.
6:2 The first chariot had red horses, the second chariot black horses,
6:3 the third chariot white horses, and the fourth chariot dappled horses—all of them strong horses.
6:4 I asked the angel who spoke with me, What are these, my lord?
6:5 The angel answered me, These are the four winds of the heavens, which are coming forth after presenting themselves before the of all the earth.
6:6 The one with the black horses is going toward the land of the north, and the white horses go toward the west, and the dappled ones go toward the land of the south.
6:7 These strong horses went out, eager to set about patrolling the earth, for he said, Go, patrol the earth! So they patrolled the earth.
6:8 Then he cried out to me and said, See, those who go forth to the land of the north provide rest for my spirit in the land of the north.
6:9 Then the word of the came to me:
6:10 Take from the exiles—Heldai, Tobijah, Jedaiah—and go the same day to the house of Josiah, son of Zephaniah. (These had come from Babylon.)
6:11 You will take silver and gold, and make crowns; place one on the head of Joshua, son of Jehozadak, the high priest.
6:12 And say to him: Thus says the of hosts: There is a man whose name is Branch—and from his place he will branch out and he will build the temple of the .
6:13 He will build the temple of the , and taking up the royal insignia, he will sit as ruler upon his throne. The priest will be at his right hand, and between the two of them there will be peaceful understanding.
6:14 The other crown will be in the temple of the as a gracious reminder to Heldai, Tobijah, Jedaiah, and the son of Zephaniah.
6:15 And they who are from afar will come and build the temple of the , and you will know that the of hosts has sent me to you. This will happen if you truly obey the your God.
7:1 In the fourth year of Darius the king, the word of the came to Zechariah, on the fourth day of the ninth month, Kislev.
7:2 Bethelsarezer sent Regem-melech and his men to implore the favor of the
7:3 and to ask the priests of the house of the of hosts, and the prophets, Must I weep and abstain in the fifth month as I have been doing these many years?
7:4 Then the word of the of hosts came to me:
7:5 Say to all the people of the land and to the priests: When you fasted and lamented in the fifth and in the seventh month these seventy years, was it really for me that you fasted?
7:6 When you were eating and drinking, was it not for yourselves that you ate and for yourselves that you drank?
7:7 Are these not the words which the proclaimed through the earlier prophets, when Jerusalem and its surrounding cities were inhabited and secure, when the Negeb and the Shephelah were inhabited?
7:8 The word of the came to Zechariah:
7:9 Thus says the of hosts: Judge with true justice, and show kindness and compassion toward each other.
7:10 Do not oppress the widow or the orphan, the resident alien or the poor; do not plot evil against one another in your hearts.
7:11 But they refused to listen; they stubbornly turned their backs and stopped their ears so as not to hear.
7:12 And they made their hearts as hard as diamond so as not to hear the instruction and the words that the of hosts had sent by his spirit through the earlier prophets. So great anger came from the of hosts:
7:13 Just as when I called out and they did not listen, so they will call out and I will not listen, says the of hosts.
7:14 And I will scatter them among all the nations that they do not know. So the land was left desolate behind them with no one moving about, and they made a pleasant land into a wasteland.
8:1 Then the word of the of hosts came:
8:2 Thus says the of hosts: I am intensely jealous for Zion, stirred to jealous wrath for her.
8:3 Thus says the : I have returned to Zion, and I will dwell within Jerusalem; Jerusalem will be called the faithful city, and the mountain of the of hosts, the holy mountain.
8:4 Thus says the of hosts: Old men and old women will again sit in the streets of Jerusalem, each with staff in hand because of old age.
8:5 The city will be filled with boys and girls playing in its streets.
8:6 Thus says the of hosts: Even if this should seem impossible in the eyes of the remnant of this people in those days, should it seem impossible in my eyes also?—oracle of the of hosts.
8:7 Thus says the of hosts: I am going to rescue my people from the land of the rising sun, and from the land of the setting sun.
8:8 I will bring them back to dwell within Jerusalem. They will be my people, and I will be their God, in faithfulness and justice.
8:9 Thus says the of hosts: Let your hands be strong, you who now hear these words which were spoken by the prophets when the foundation of the house of the of hosts was laid for the building of the temple.
8:10 For before those days, there were no wages for people, nor hire for animals. Those who came and went were not safe from the enemy, for I set neighbor against neighbor.
8:11 But now I will not deal with the remnant of this people as in former days—oracle of the of hosts.
8:12 For there will be a sowing of peace: the vine will yield its fruit, the land will yield its crops, and the heavens will yield their dew. I will give all these things to the remnant of this people to possess.
8:13 Just as you became a curse among the nations, O house of Judah and house of Israel, so will I save you that you may be a blessing. Do not fear; let your hands be strong.
8:14 Thus says the of hosts: Just as I intended to harm you when your ancestors angered me—says the of hosts—and I did not relent,
8:15 so again in these days I intend to favor Jerusalem and the house of Judah; do not fear!
8:16 These then are the things you must do: Speak the truth to one another; judge with honesty and complete justice in your gates.
8:17 Let none of you plot evil against another in your heart, nor love a false oath. For all these things I hate—oracle of the .
8:18 The word of the of hosts came to me:
8:19 Thus says the of hosts: The fast days of the fourth, the fifth, the seventh, and the tenth months will become occasions of joy and gladness, and happy festivals for the house of Judah. So love faithfulness and peace!
8:20 Thus says the of hosts: There will yet come peoples and inhabitants of many cities;
8:21 and the inhabitants of one city will approach those of another, and say, Come! let us go to implore the favor of the and to seek the of hosts. I too am going.
8:22 Many peoples and strong nations will come to seek the of hosts in Jerusalem and to implore the favor of the .
8:23 Thus says the of hosts: In those days ten people from nations of every language will take hold, yes, will take hold of the cloak of every Judahite and say, Let us go with you, for we have heard that God is with you.
9:1 An oracle: the word of the is against the land of Hadrach, and Damascus is its destination, For the cities of Aram are the s, as are all the tribes of Israel.
9:2 Hamath also on its border, Tyre too, and Sidon, no matter how clever they be.
9:3 Tyre built itself a stronghold, and heaped up silver like dust, and gold like the mud of the streets.
9:4 But now the Lord will dispossess it, and cast its wealth into the sea, and it will be devoured by fire.
9:5 Ashkelon will see it and be afraid; Gaza too will be in great anguish; Ekron also, for its hope will wither. The king will disappear from Gaza, Ashkelon will not be inhabited,
9:6 and the illegitimate will rule in Ashdod. I will destroy the pride of the Philistines
9:7 and take from their mouths their bloody prey, their disgusting meat from between their teeth. They will become merely a remnant for our God, and will be like a clan in Judah; Ekron will be like the Jebusites.
9:8 I will encamp at my house, a garrison against invaders; No oppressor will overrun them again, for now I have seen their affliction.
9:9 Exult greatly, O daughter Zion! Shout for joy, O daughter Jerusalem! Behold: your king is coming to you, a just savior is he, Humble, and riding on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.
9:10 He shall banish the chariot from Ephraim, and the horse from Jerusalem; The warriors bow will be banished, and he will proclaim peace to the nations. His dominion will be from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth.
9:11 As for you, by the blood of your covenant, I have freed your prisoners from a waterless pit.
9:12 Return to a fortress, O prisoners of hope; This very day, I announce I am restoring double to you.
9:13 For I have bent Judah as my bow, I have set Ephraim as its arrow; I will arouse your sons, O Zion, against your sons, O Yavan, and I will use you as a warriors sword.
9:14 The will appear over them, Gods arrow will shoot forth as lightning; The Lord will sound the rams horn, and come in a storm from the south.
9:15 The of hosts will protect them; they will devour and conquer with sling stones, they will drink and become heated as with wine; they will be full like bowls—like the corners of the altar.
9:16 And the their God will save them: the people, like a flock on that day; For like gemstones of a crown they will shine on the land.
9:17 Then how good and how lovely! Grain will make the young men flourish, and new wine the young women.
10:1 Ask the for rain in the spring season, the who brings storm clouds, and heavy rains, who gives to everyone grain in the fields.
10:2 For the teraphim have spoken nonsense, the diviners have seen false visions; Deceitful dreams they have told, empty comfort they have offered. This is why they wandered like sheep, wretched, for they have no shepherd.
10:3 My wrath is kindled against the shepherds, and I will punish the leaders. For the of hosts attends to the flock, the house of Judah, and will make them like a splendid horse in battle.
10:4 From them will come the tower, from them the tent peg, from them the bow of war, from them every officer.
10:5 Together they will be like warriors, trampling the mud of the streets in battle. They will wage war because the is with them, and will put the horsemen to shame.
10:6 I will strengthen the house of Judah, the house of Joseph I will save; I will bring them back, because I have mercy on them; they will be as if I had never cast them off, for I am the their God, and I will answer them.
10:7 Then Ephraim will be like a hero, and their hearts will be cheered as by wine. Their children will see and rejoice— their hearts will exult in the .
10:8 I will whistle for them and gather them in; for I will redeem them and they will be as numerous as before.
10:9 I sowed them among the nations, yet in distant lands they will remember me; they will bear their children and return.
10:10 I will bring them back from the land of Egypt, and gather them from Assyria. To the land of Gilead and to Lebanon I will bring them, until no room is found for them.
10:11 I will cross over to Egypt and smite the waves of the sea, and all the depths of the Nile will dry up. The pride of Assyria will be cast down, and the scepter of Egypt disappear.
10:12 I will strengthen them in the , in whose name they will walk—oracle of the .
11:1 Open your doors, Lebanon, that fire may devour your cedars!
11:2 Wail, cypress trees, for the cedars are fallen, the mighty are destroyed! Wail, oaks of Bashan, for the dense forest is cut down!
11:3 Listen! the wailing of shepherds, their glory has been destroyed. Listen! the roaring of young lions, the thickets of the Jordan are destroyed. 
11:4 Thus says the , my God: Shepherd the flock to be slaughtered.
11:5 For they who buy them slay them and are not held accountable; while those who sell them say, Blessed be the , I have become rich! Even their own shepherds will not pity them.
11:6 For I will no longer pity the inhabitants of the earth—oracle of the .—Yes, I will deliver them into each others power, or into the power of their kings; they will crush the earth, and I will not deliver it out of their power.
11:7 So I shepherded the flock to be slaughtered for the merchants of the flock. I took two staffs: one I called Delight, and the other Union. Thus I shepherded the flock.
11:8 In a single month, I did away with the three shepherds, for I wearied of them, and they disdained me.
11:9 I will not shepherd you, I said. Whoever is to die shall die; whoever is to be done away with shall be done away with; and those who are left shall devour one anothers flesh.
11:10 Then I took my staff Delight and snapped it in two, breaking my covenant which I had made with all peoples.
11:11 So it was broken on that day. The merchants of the flock, who were watching me, understood that this was the word of the .
11:12 Then I said to them, If it seems good to you, give me my wages; but if not, withhold them. And they counted out my wages, thirty pieces of silver.
11:13 Then the said to me, Throw it in the treasury—the handsome price at which they valued me. So I took the thirty pieces of silver and threw them into the treasury in the house of the .
11:14 Then I snapped in two my second staff, Union, breaking the kinship between Judah and Israel.
11:15 The said to me: This time take the gear of a foolish shepherd.
11:16 For I am raising up a shepherd in the land who will take no note of those that disappear, nor seek the strays, nor heal the injured, nor feed the exhausted; but he will eat the flesh of the fat ones and tear off their hoofs!
11:17 Ah! my worthless shepherd who forsakes the flock! May the sword fall upon his arm and upon his right eye; His arm will surely wither, and his right eye surely go blind!
12:1 An oracle: The word of the concerning Israel—oracle of the , who spreads out the heavens, lays the foundations of the earth, and fashions the human spirit within:
12:2 See, I will make Jerusalem a cup of reeling for all peoples round about. Judah will be besieged, even Jerusalem.
12:3 On that day I will make Jerusalem a heavy stone for all peoples. All who attempt to lift it will injure themselves badly, though all the nations of the earth will gather against it.
12:4 On that day—oracle of the —I will strike every horse with fright, and its rider with madness. But over the house of Judah I will keep watch, while I strike blind all the horses of the peoples.
12:5 Then the clans of Judah will say to themselves, The inhabitants of Jerusalem have their strength in the of hosts, their God.
12:6 On that day I will make the clans of Judah like a brazier of fire in the woodland and like a burning torch among sheaves, and they will devour right and left all the surrounding peoples; but Jerusalem will again inhabit its own place.
12:7 The will save the tents of Judah first, that the glory of the house of David and the glory of the inhabitants of Jerusalem may not be exalted over Judah.
12:8 On that day the will shield the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the weakest among them will be like David on that day; and the house of David will be like God, like the angel of the before them.
12:9 On that day I will seek the destruction of all nations that come against Jerusalem.
12:10 I will pour out on the house of David and on the inhabitants of Jerusalem a spirit of mercy and supplication, so that when they look on him whom they have thrust through, they will mourn for him as one mourns for an only child, and they will grieve for him as one grieves over a firstborn.
12:11 On that day the mourning in Jerusalem will be as great as the mourning for Hadadrimmon in the plain of Megiddo.
12:12 And the land shall mourn, each family apart: the family of the house of David, and their women; the family of the house of Nathan, and their women;
12:13 the family of the house of Levi, and their women; the family of Shimei, and their women;
12:14 and all the rest of the families, each family apart, and the women apart.
13:1 On that day a fountain will be opened for the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, to purify from sin and uncleanness.
13:2 On that day—oracle of the of hosts—I will destroy the names of the idols from the land, so that they will be mentioned no more; I will also remove the prophets and the spirit of uncleanness from the land.
13:3 If any still prophesy, their father and mother who bore them will say, You will not live, because you have spoken a lie in the name of the . Their father and mother who bore them will thrust them through when they prophesy.
13:4 On that day, all prophets will be ashamed of the visions they prophesy; and they will not put on the hairy mantle to mislead,
13:5 but each will say, I am not a prophet. I am a tiller of the soil, for I have owned land since my youth.
13:6 And if anyone asks, What are these wounds on your chest? each will answer, I received these wounds in the house of my friends.
13:7 Awake, O sword, against my shepherd, against the one who is my associate —oracle of the of hosts. Strike the shepherd that the sheep may be scattered; I will turn my hand against the little ones.
13:8 In all the land—oracle of the — two thirds of them will be cut off and perish, and one third will be left.
13:9 I will bring the one third through the fire; I will refine them as one refines silver, and I will test them as one tests gold. They will call upon my name, and I will answer them; I will say, They are my people, and they will say, The is my God.
14:1 A day is coming for the when the spoils taken from you will be divided in your midst.
14:2 And I will gather all the nations against Jerusalem for battle: The city will be taken, houses will be plundered, women raped; half the city will go into exile, but the rest of the people will not be removed from the city.
14:3 Then the will go forth and fight against those nations, fighting as on a day of battle.
14:4 On that day Gods feet will stand on the Mount of Olives, which is opposite Jerusalem to the east. The Mount of Olives will be split in two from east to west by a very deep valley, and half of the mountain will move to the north and half of it to the south.
14:5 You will flee by the valley between the mountains, for the valley between the mountains will reach to Azal. Thus you will flee as you fled because of the earthquake in the days of Uzziah king of Judah. Then the , my God, will come, and all his holy ones with him.
14:6 On that day there will no longer be cold or frost.
14:7 There will be one continuous day—it is known to the —not day and night, for in the evening there will be light.
14:8 On that day, fresh water will flow from Jerusalem, half to the eastern sea, and half to the western sea. This will be so in summer and in winter.
14:9 The will be king over the whole earth; on that day the will be the only one, and the s name the only one.
14:10 All the land will turn into a plain, from Geba to Rimmon, south of Jerusalem, which will stand exalted in its place—from the Gate of Benjamin to the place of the first gate, to the Corner Gate and from the Tower of Hananel to the kings wine presses.
14:11 The city will be inhabited; never again will it be doomed. Jerusalem will dwell securely.
14:12 And this will be the plague with which the will strike all the peoples that have fought against Jerusalem: their flesh will rot while they stand on their feet, and their eyes will rot in their sockets, and their tongues will rot in their mouths.
14:13 On that day a great panic from the will be upon them. They will seize each others hands, and their hands will be raised against each other.
14:14 Even Judah will fight against Jerusalem. The riches of all the surrounding nations will be gathered together—gold, silver, and garments—in great abundance.
14:15 Like the plague on human beings will be the plague upon the horses, mules, camels, donkeys, and upon all the beasts that are in those camps.
14:16 Everyone who is left of all the nations that came against Jerusalem will go up year after year to bow down to the King, the of hosts, and to celebrate the feast of Booths.
14:17 Should any of the families of the earth not go up to Jerusalem to bow down to the King, the of hosts, then there will be no rain for them.
14:18 And if the family of Egypt does not go up or enter, upon them will fall the plague, with which the strikes the nations that do not go up to celebrate the feast of Booths.
14:19 This will be the punishment of Egypt and the punishment of all the nations that do not go up to celebrate the feast of Booths.
14:20 On that day, Holy to the will be written on the horses bells. The pots in the house of the will be as the basins before the altar.
14:21 Every pot in Jerusalem and in Judah will be holy to the of hosts. All who come to sacrifice will take them and cook in them. No longer will there be merchants in the house of the of hosts on that day.
MALACHI
1:1 An oracle. The word of the to Israel through Malachi.
1:2 I love you, says the ; but you say, How do you love us?
1:3 Was not Esau Jacobs brother?—oracle of the . I loved Jacob, but rejected Esau; I made his mountains a waste, his heritage a desert for jackals.
1:4 If Edom says, We have been crushed, but we will rebuild the ruins, Thus says the of hosts: They indeed may build, but I will tear down, And they shall be called territory of wickedness, the people with whom the is angry forever.
1:5 Your own eyes will see it, and you will say, Great is the , even beyond the territory of Israel.
1:6 A son honors his father, and a servant fears his master; If, then, I am a father, where is the honor due to me? And if I am a master, where is the fear due to me? So says the of hosts to you, O priests, who disdain my name. But you ask, How have we disdained your name?
1:7 By offering defiled food on my altar! You ask, How have we defiled it? By saying that the table of the may be disdained!
1:8 When you offer a blind animal for sacrifice, is there no wrong in that? When you offer a lame or sick animal, is there no wrong in that? Present it to your governor! Will he be pleased with you—or show you favor? says the of hosts.
1:9 So now implore Gods favor, that he may have mercy on us! You are the ones who have done this; Will he show favor to any of you? says the of hosts.
1:10 Oh, that one of you would just shut the temple gates to keep you from kindling fire on my altar in vain! I take no pleasure in you, says the of hosts; and I will not accept any offering from your hands!
1:11 From the rising of the sun to its setting, my name is great among the nations; Incense offerings are made to my name everywhere, and a pure offering; For my name is great among the nations, says the of hosts.
1:12 But you profane it by saying that the s table is defiled, and its food may be disdained.
1:13 You say, See what a burden this is! and you exasperate me, says the of hosts; You bring in what is mutilated, or lame, or sick; you bring it as an offering! Will I accept it from your hands? says the .
1:14 Cursed is the cheat who has in his flock an intact male, and vows it, but sacrifices to the a defective one instead; For a great king am I, says the of hosts, and my name is feared among the nations.
2:1 And now, priests, this commandment is for you: If you do not listen,
2:2 And if you do not take to heart giving honor to my name, says the of hosts, I will send a curse upon you and your blessing I will curse. In fact, I have already cursed it, because you do not take it to heart.
2:3 I will rebuke your offspring; I will spread dung on your faces, Dung from your feasts, and will carry you to it.
2:4 You should know that I sent you this commandment so that my covenant with Levi might endure, says the of hosts.
2:5 My covenant with him was the life and peace which I gave him, and the fear he had for me, standing in awe of my name.
2:6 Reliable instruction was in his mouth, no perversity was found upon his lips; He walked with me in integrity and uprightness, and turned many away from evil.
2:7 For a priests lips preserve knowledge, and instruction is to be sought from his mouth, because he is the messenger of the of hosts.
2:8 But you have turned aside from the way, and have caused many to stumble by your instruction; You have corrupted the covenant of Levi, says the of hosts.
2:9 I, therefore, have made you contemptible and base before all the people, For you do not keep my ways, but show partiality in your instruction.
2:10 Have we not all one father? Has not one God created us? Why, then, do we break faith with each other, profaning the covenant of our ancestors?
2:11 Judah has broken faith; an abominable thing has been done in Israel and in Jerusalem. Judah has profaned the s holy place, which he loves, and has married a daughter of a foreign god.
2:12 May the cut off from the man who does this both witness and advocate from the tents of Jacob, and anyone to bring an offering to the of hosts!
2:13 This also you do: the altar of the you cover with tears, weeping, and groaning, Because the Lord no longer takes note of your offering or accepts it favorably from your hand.
2:14 And you say, Why?— Because the is witness between you and the wife of your youth With whom you have broken faith, though she is your companion, your covenanted wife.
2:15 Did he not make them one, with flesh and spirit? And what does the One require? Godly offspring! You should be on guard, then, for your life, and do not break faith with the wife of your youth.
2:16 For I hate divorce, says the , the God of Israel, And the one who covers his garment with violence, says the of hosts. You should be on guard, then, for your life, and you must not break faith.
2:17 You have wearied the with your words, yet you say, How have we wearied him? By saying, All evildoers are good in the sight of the , And he is pleased with them, or Where is the just God?
3:1 Now I am sending my messenger— he will prepare the way before me; And the lord whom you seek will come suddenly to his temple; The messenger of the covenant whom you desire— see, he is coming! says the of hosts.
3:2 But who can endure the day of his coming? Who can stand firm when he appears? For he will be like a refiners fire, like fullers lye.
3:3 He will sit refining and purifying silver, and he will purify the Levites, Refining them like gold or silver, that they may bring offerings to the in righteousness.
3:4 Then the offering of Judah and Jerusalem will please the , as in ancient days, as in years gone by.
3:5 I will draw near to you for judgment, and I will be swift to bear witness Against sorcerers, adulterers, and perjurers, those who deprive a laborer of wages, Oppress a widow or an orphan, or turn aside a resident alien, without fearing me, says the of hosts.
3:6 For I, the , do not change, and you, sons of Jacob, do not cease to be.
3:7 Since the days of your ancestors you have turned aside from my statutes and have not kept them. Return to me, that I may return to you, says the of hosts. But you say, Why should we return?
3:8 Can anyone rob God? But you are robbing me! And you say, How have we robbed you? Of tithes and contributions!
3:9 You are indeed accursed, for you, the whole nation, rob me.
3:10 Bring the whole tithe into the storehouse, That there may be food in my house. Put me to the test, says the of hosts, And see if I do not open the floodgates of heaven for you, and pour down upon you blessing without measure!
3:11 I will rebuke the locust for you so that it will not destroy your crops, And the vine in the field will not be barren, says the of hosts.
3:12 All the nations will call you blessed, for you will be a delightful land, says the of hosts.
3:13 Your words are too much for me, says the . You ask, What have we spoken against you?
3:14 You have said, It is useless to serve God; what do we gain by observing Gods requirements, And by going about as mourners before the of hosts?
3:15 But we call the arrogant blessed; for evildoers not only prosper but even test God and escape.
3:16 Then those who fear the spoke with one another, and the listened attentively; A record book was written before him of those who fear the and esteem his name.
3:17 They shall be mine, says the of hosts, my own special possession, on the day when I take action. And I will have compassion on them, as a man has compassion on his son who serves him.
3:18 Then you will again distinguish between the just and the wicked, Between the person who serves God, and the one who does not.
3:19 For the day is coming, blazing like an oven, when all the arrogant and all evildoers will be stubble, And the day that is coming will set them on fire, leaving them neither root nor branch, says the of hosts.
3:20 But for you who fear my name, the sun of justice will arise with healing in its wings; And you will go out leaping like calves from the stall
3:21 and tread down the wicked; They will become dust under the soles of your feet, on the day when I take action, says the of hosts.
3:22 Remember the law of Moses my servant, whom I charged at Horeb With statutes and ordinances for all Israel.
3:23 Now I am sending to you Elijah the prophet, Before the day of the comes, the great and terrible day;
3:24 He will turn the heart of fathers to their sons, and the heart of sons to their fathers, Lest I come and strike the land with utter destruction.
MATTHEW
1:1 The book of the genealogy of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.
1:2 Abraham became the father of Isaac, Isaac the father of Jacob, Jacob the father of Judah and his brothers.
1:3 Judah became the father of Perez and Zerah, whose mother was Tamar. Perez became the father of Hezron, Hezron the father of Ram,
1:4 Ram the father of Amminadab. Amminadab became the father of Nahshon, Nahshon the father of Salmon,
1:5 Salmon the father of Boaz, whose mother was Rahab. Boaz became the father of Obed, whose mother was Ruth. Obed became the father of Jesse,
1:6 Jesse the father of David the king. David became the father of Solomon, whose mother had been the wife of Uriah.
1:7 Solomon became the father of Rehoboam, Rehoboam the father of Abijah, Abijah the father of Asaph.
1:8 Asaph became the father of Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat the father of Joram, Joram the father of Uzziah.
1:9 Uzziah became the father of Jotham, Jotham the father of Ahaz, Ahaz the father of Hezekiah.
1:10 Hezekiah became the father of Manasseh, Manasseh the father of Amos, Amos the father of Josiah.
1:11 Josiah became the father of Jechoniah and his brothers at the time of the Babylonian exile.
1:12 After the Babylonian exile, Jechoniah became the father of Shealtiel, Shealtiel the father of Zerubbabel,
1:13 Zerubbabel the father of Abiud. Abiud became the father of Eliakim, Eliakim the father of Azor,
1:14 Azor the father of Zadok. Zadok became the father of Achim, Achim the father of Eliud,
1:15 Eliud the father of Eleazar. Eleazar became the father of Matthan, Matthan the father of Jacob,
1:16 Jacob the father of Joseph, the husband of Mary. Of her was born Jesus who is called the Messiah.
1:17 Thus the total number of generations from Abraham to David is fourteen generations; from David to the Babylonian exile, fourteen generations; from the Babylonian exile to the Messiah, fourteen generations. 
1:18 Now this is how the birth of Jesus Christ came about. When his mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, but before they lived together, she was found with child through the holy Spirit.
1:19 Joseph her husband, since he was a righteous man, yet unwilling to expose her to shame, decided to divorce her quietly.
1:20 Such was his intention when, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary your wife into your home. For it is through the holy Spirit that this child has been conceived in her.
1:21 She will bear a son and you are to name him Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.
1:22 All this took place to fulfill what the Lord had said through the prophet:
1:23 Behold, the virgin shall be with child and bear a son, and they shall name him Emmanuel, which means God is with us.
1:24 When Joseph awoke, he did as the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took his wife into his home.
1:25 He had no relations with her until she bore a son, and he named him Jesus.
2:1 When Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea, in the days of King Herod, behold, magi from the east arrived in Jerusalem,
2:2 saying, Where is the newborn king of the Jews? We saw his star at its rising and have come to do him homage.
2:3 When King Herod heard this, he was greatly troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.
2:4 Assembling all the chief priests and the scribes of the people, he inquired of them where the Messiah was to be born.
2:5 They said to him, In Bethlehem of Judea, for thus it has been written through the prophet:
2:6 And you, Bethlehem, land of Judah, are by no means least among the rulers of Judah; since from you shall come a ruler, who is to shepherd my people Israel.
2:7 Then Herod called the magi secretly and ascertained from them the time of the stars appearance.
2:8 He sent them to Bethlehem and said, Go and search diligently for the child. When you have found him, bring me word, that I too may go and do him homage.
2:9 After their audience with the king they set out. And behold, the star that they had seen at its rising preceded them, until it came and stopped over the place where the child was.
2:10 They were overjoyed at seeing the star,
2:11 and on entering the house they saw the child with Mary his mother. They prostrated themselves and did him homage. Then they opened their treasures and offered him gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh.
2:12 And having been warned in a dream not to return to Herod, they departed for their country by another way.
2:13 When they had departed, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream and said, Rise, take the child and his mother, flee to Egypt, and stay there until I tell you. Herod is going to search for the child to destroy him.
2:14 Joseph rose and took the child and his mother by night and departed for Egypt.
2:15 He stayed there until the death of Herod, that what the Lord had said through the prophet might be fulfilled, Out of Egypt I called my son.
2:16 When Herod realized that he had been deceived by the magi, he became furious. He ordered the massacre of all the boys in Bethlehem and its vicinity two years old and under, in accordance with the time he had ascertained from the magi.
2:17 Then was fulfilled what had been said through Jeremiah the prophet:
2:18 A voice was heard in Ramah, sobbing and loud lamentation; Rachel weeping for her children, and she would not be consoled, since they were no more.
2:19 When Herod had died, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt
2:20 and said, Rise, take the child and his mother and go to the land of Israel, for those who sought the childs life are dead.
2:21 He rose, took the child and his mother, and went to the land of Israel.
2:22 But when he heard that Archelaus was ruling over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go back there. And because he had been warned in a dream, he departed for the region of Galilee.
2:23 He went and dwelt in a town called Nazareth, so that what had been spoken through the prophets might be fulfilled, He shall be called a Nazorean.
3:1 In those days John the Baptist appeared, preaching in the desert of Judea
3:2 [and] saying, Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand!
3:3 It was of him that the prophet Isaiah had spoken when he said: A voice of one crying out in the desert, Prepare the way of the Lord, make straight his paths.
3:4 John wore clothing made of camels hair and had a leather belt around his waist. His food was locusts and wild honey.
3:5 At that time Jerusalem, all Judea, and the whole region around the Jordan were going out to him
3:6 and were being baptized by him in the Jordan River as they acknowledged their sins.
3:7 When he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?
3:8 Produce good fruit as evidence of your repentance.
3:9 And do not presume to say to yourselves, We have Abraham as our father. For I tell you, God can raise up children to Abraham from these stones.
3:10 Even now the ax lies at the root of the trees. Therefore every tree that does not bear good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.
3:11 I am baptizing you with water, for repentance, but the one who is coming after me is mightier than I. I am not worthy to carry his sandals. He will baptize you with the holy Spirit and fire.
3:12 His winnowing fan is in his hand. He will clear his threshing floor and gather his wheat into his barn, but the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire. 
3:13 Then Jesus came from Galilee to John at the Jordan to be baptized by him.
3:14 John tried to prevent him, saying, I need to be baptized by you, and yet you are coming to me?
3:15 Jesus said to him in reply, Allow it now, for thus it is fitting for us to fulfill all righteousness. Then he allowed him.
3:16 After Jesus was baptized, he came up from the water and behold, the heavens were opened [for him], and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove [and] coming upon him.
3:17 And a voice came from the heavens, saying, This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased.
4:1 Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the desert to be tempted by the devil.
4:2 He fasted for forty days and forty nights, and afterwards he was hungry.
4:3 The tempter approached and said to him, If you are the Son of God, command that these stones become loaves of bread.
4:4 He said in reply, It is written: One does not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes forth from the mouth of God.
4:5 Then the devil took him to the holy city, and made him stand on the parapet of the temple,
4:6 and said to him, If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down. For it is written: He will command his angels concerning you and with their hands they will support you, lest you dash your foot against a stone.
4:7 Jesus answered him, Again it is written, You shall not put the Lord, your God, to the test.
4:8 Then the devil took him up to a very high mountain, and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in their magnificence,
4:9 and he said to him, All these I shall give to you, if you will prostrate yourself and worship me.
4:10 At this, Jesus said to him, Get away, Satan! It is written: The Lord, your God, shall you worship and him alone shall you serve.
4:11 Then the devil left him and, behold, angels came and ministered to him. 
4:12 When he heard that John had been arrested, he withdrew to Galilee.
4:13 He left Nazareth and went to live in Capernaum by the sea, in the region of Zebulun and Naphtali,
4:14 that what had been said through Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled:
4:15 Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the way to the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles,
4:16 the people who sit in darkness have seen a great light, on those dwelling in a land overshadowed by death light has arisen.
4:17 From that time on, Jesus began to preach and say, Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand. 
4:18 As he was walking by the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers, Simon who is called Peter, and his brother Andrew, casting a net into the sea; they were fishermen.
4:19 He said to them, Come after me, and I will make you fishers of men.
4:20 At once they left their nets and followed him.
4:21 He walked along from there and saw two other brothers, James, the son of Zebedee, and his brother John. They were in a boat, with their father Zebedee, mending their nets. He called them,
4:22 and immediately they left their boat and their father and followed him. 
4:23 He went around all of Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, proclaiming the gospel of the kingdom, and curing every disease and illness among the people.
4:24 His fame spread to all of Syria, and they brought to him all who were sick with various diseases and racked with pain, those who were possessed, lunatics, and paralytics, and he cured them.
4:25 And great crowds from Galilee, the Decapolis, Jerusalem, and Judea, and from beyond the Jordan followed him.
5:1 When he saw the crowds, he went up the mountain, and after he had sat down, his disciples came to him.
5:2 He began to teach them, saying:
5:3 Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
5:4 Blessed are they who mourn, for they will be comforted.
5:5 Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the land.
5:6 Blessed are they who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be satisfied.
5:7 Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy.
5:8 Blessed are the clean of heart, for they will see God.
5:9 Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.
5:10 Blessed are they who are persecuted for the sake of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
5:11 Blessed are you when they insult you and persecute you and utter every kind of evil against you [falsely] because of me.
5:12 Rejoice and be glad, for your reward will be great in heaven. Thus they persecuted the prophets who were before you. 
5:13 You are the salt of the earth. But if salt loses its taste, with what can it be seasoned? It is no longer good for anything but to be thrown out and trampled underfoot.
5:14 You are the light of the world. A city set on a mountain cannot be hidden.
5:15 Nor do they light a lamp and then put it under a bushel basket; it is set on a lampstand, where it gives light to all in the house.
5:16 Just so, your light must shine before others, that they may see your good deeds and glorify your heavenly Father.
5:17 Do not think that I have come to abolish the law or the prophets. I have come not to abolish but to fulfill.
5:18 Amen, I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not the smallest letter or the smallest part of a letter will pass from the law, until all things have taken place.
5:19 Therefore, whoever breaks one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do so will be called least in the kingdom of heaven. But whoever obeys and teaches these commandments will be called greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
5:20 I tell you, unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will not enter into the kingdom of heaven. 
5:21 You have heard that it was said to your ancestors, You shall not kill; and whoever kills will be liable to judgment.
5:22 But I say to you, whoever is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment, and whoever says to his brother, Raqa, will be answerable to the Sanhedrin, and whoever says, You fool, will be liable to fiery Gehenna.
5:23 Therefore, if you bring your gift to the altar, and there recall that your brother has anything against you,
5:24 leave your gift there at the altar, go first and be reconciled with your brother, and then come and offer your gift.
5:25 Settle with your opponent quickly while on the way to court with him. Otherwise your opponent will hand you over to the judge, and the judge will hand you over to the guard, and you will be thrown into prison.
5:26 Amen, I say to you, you will not be released until you have paid the last penny.
5:27 You have heard that it was said, You shall not commit adultery.
5:28 But I say to you, everyone who looks at a woman with lust has already committed adultery with her in his heart.
5:29 If your right eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one of your members than to have your whole body thrown into Gehenna.
5:30 And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one of your members than to have your whole body go into Gehenna.
5:31 It was also said, Whoever divorces his wife must give her a bill of divorce.
5:32 But I say to you, whoever divorces his wife (unless the marriage is unlawful) causes her to commit adultery, and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
5:33 Again you have heard that it was said to your ancestors, Do not take a false oath, but make good to the Lord all that you vow.
5:34 But I say to you, do not swear at all; not by heaven, for it is Gods throne;
5:35 nor by the earth, for it is his footstool; nor by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.
5:36 Do not swear by your head, for you cannot make a single hair white or black.
5:37 Let your Yes mean Yes, and your No mean No. Anything more is from the evil one.
5:38 You have heard that it was said, An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.
5:39 But I say to you, offer no resistance to one who is evil. When someone strikes you on [your] right cheek, turn the other one to him as well.
5:40 If anyone wants to go to law with you over your tunic, hand him your cloak as well.
5:41 Should anyone press you into service for one mile, go with him for two miles.
5:42 Give to the one who asks of you, and do not turn your back on one who wants to borrow. 
5:43 You have heard that it was said, You shall love your neighbor and hate your enemy.
5:44 But I say to you, love your enemies, and pray for those who persecute you,
5:45 that you may be children of your heavenly Father, for he makes his sun rise on the bad and the good, and causes rain to fall on the just and the unjust.
5:46 For if you love those who love you, what recompense will you have? Do not the tax collectors do the same?
5:47 And if you greet your brothers only, what is unusual about that? Do not the pagans do the same?
5:48 So be perfect, just as your heavenly Father is perfect.
6:1 [But] take care not to perform righteous deeds in order that people may see them; otherwise, you will have no recompense from your heavenly Father.
6:2 When you give alms, do not blow a trumpet before you, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets to win the praise of others. Amen, I say to you, they have received their reward.
6:3 But when you give alms, do not let your left hand know what your right is doing,
6:4 so that your almsgiving may be secret. And your Father who sees in secret will repay you.
6:5 When you pray, do not be like the hypocrites, who love to stand and pray in the synagogues and on street corners so that others may see them. Amen, I say to you, they have received their reward.
6:6 But when you pray, go to your inner room, close the door, and pray to your Father in secret. And your Father who sees in secret will repay you.
6:7 In praying, do not babble like the pagans, who think that they will be heard because of their many words.
6:8 Do not be like them. Your Father knows what you need before you ask him.
6:9 This is how you are to pray: Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name,
6:10 your kingdom come, your will be done, on earth as in heaven.
6:11 Give us today our daily bread;
6:12 and forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors;
6:13 and do not subject us to the final test, but deliver us from the evil one.
6:14 If you forgive others their transgressions, your heavenly Father will forgive you.
6:15 But if you do not forgive others, neither will your Father forgive your transgressions.
6:16 When you fast, do not look gloomy like the hypocrites. They neglect their appearance, so that they may appear to others to be fasting. Amen, I say to you, they have received their reward.
6:17 But when you fast, anoint your head and wash your face,
6:18 so that you may not appear to others to be fasting, except to your Father who is hidden. And your Father who sees what is hidden will repay you.
6:19 Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and decay destroy, and thieves break in and steal.
6:20 But store up treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor decay destroys, nor thieves break in and steal.
6:21 For where your treasure is, there also will your heart be. 
6:22 The lamp of the body is the eye. If your eye is sound, your whole body will be filled with light;
6:23 but if your eye is bad, your whole body will be in darkness. And if the light in you is darkness, how great will the darkness be.
6:24 No one can serve two masters. He will either hate one and love the other, or be devoted to one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon. 
6:25 Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat [or drink], or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food and the body more than clothing?
6:26 Look at the birds in the sky; they do not sow or reap, they gather nothing into barns, yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are not you more important than they?
6:27 Can any of you by worrying add a single moment to your life-span?
6:28 Why are you anxious about clothes? Learn from the way the wild flowers grow. They do not work or spin.
6:29 But I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was clothed like one of them.
6:30 If God so clothes the grass of the field, which grows today and is thrown into the oven tomorrow, will he not much more provide for you, O you of little faith?
6:31 So do not worry and say, What are we to eat? or What are we to drink? or What are we to wear?
6:32 All these things the pagans seek. Your heavenly Father knows that you need them all.
6:33 But seek first the kingdom [of God] and his righteousness, and all these things will be given you besides.
6:34 Do not worry about tomorrow; tomorrow will take care of itself. Sufficient for a day is its own evil.
7:1 Stop judging, that you may not be judged.
7:2 For as you judge, so will you be judged, and the measure with which you measure will be measured out to you.
7:3 Why do you notice the splinter in your brothers eye, but do not perceive the wooden beam in your own eye?
7:4 How can you say to your brother, Let me remove that splinter from your eye, while the wooden beam is in your eye?
7:5 You hypocrite, remove the wooden beam from your eye first; then you will see clearly to remove the splinter from your brothers eye.
7:6 Do not give what is holy to dogs, or throw your pearls before swine, lest they trample them underfoot, and turn and tear you to pieces.
7:7 Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you.
7:8 For everyone who asks, receives; and the one who seeks, finds; and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.
7:9 Which one of you would hand his son a stone when he asks for a loaf of bread,
7:10 or a snake when he asks for a fish?
7:11 If you then, who are wicked, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give good things to those who ask him.
7:12 Do to others whatever you would have them do to you. This is the law and the prophets.
7:13 Enter through the narrow gate; for the gate is wide and the road broad that leads to destruction, and those who enter through it are many.
7:14 How narrow the gate and constricted the road that leads to life. And those who find it are few. 
7:15 Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheeps clothing, but underneath are ravenous wolves.
7:16 By their fruits you will know them. Do people pick grapes from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
7:17 Just so, every good tree bears good fruit, and a rotten tree bears bad fruit.
7:18 A good tree cannot bear bad fruit, nor can a rotten tree bear good fruit.
7:19 Every tree that does not bear good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.
7:20 So by their fruits you will know them.
7:21 Not everyone who says to me, Lord, Lord, will enter the kingdom of heaven, but only the one who does the will of my Father in heaven.
7:22 Many will say to me on that day, Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name? Did we not drive out demons in your name? Did we not do mighty deeds in your name?
7:23 Then I will declare to them solemnly, I never knew you. Depart from me, you evildoers.
7:24 Everyone who listens to these words of mine and acts on them will be like a wise man who built his house on rock.
7:25 The rain fell, the floods came, and the winds blew and buffeted the house. But it did not collapse; it had been set solidly on rock.
7:26 And everyone who listens to these words of mine but does not act on them will be like a fool who built his house on sand.
7:27 The rain fell, the floods came, and the winds blew and buffeted the house. And it collapsed and was completely ruined.
7:28 When Jesus finished these words, the crowds were astonished at his teaching,
7:29 for he taught them as one having authority, and not as their scribes.
8:1 When Jesus came down from the mountain, great crowds followed him.
8:2 And then a leper approached, did him homage, and said, Lord, if you wish, you can make me clean.
8:3 He stretched out his hand, touched him, and said, I will do it. Be made clean. His leprosy was cleansed immediately.
8:4 Then Jesus said to him, See that you tell no one, but go show yourself to the priest, and offer the gift that Moses prescribed; that will be proof for them. 
8:5 When he entered Capernaum, a centurion approached him and appealed to him,
8:6 saying, Lord, my servant is lying at home paralyzed, suffering dreadfully.
8:7 He said to him, I will come and cure him.
8:8 The centurion said in reply, Lord, I am not worthy to have you enter under my roof; only say the word and my servant will be healed.
8:9 For I too am a person subject to authority, with soldiers subject to me. And I say to one, Go, and he goes; and to another, Come here, and he comes; and to my slave, Do this, and he does it.
8:10 When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him, Amen, I say to you, in no one in Israel have I found such faith.
8:11 I say to you, many will come from the east and the west, and will recline with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob at the banquet in the kingdom of heaven,
8:12 but the children of the kingdom will be driven out into the outer darkness, where there will be wailing and grinding of teeth.
8:13 And Jesus said to the centurion, You may go; as you have believed, let it be done for you. And at that very hour [his] servant was healed. 
8:14 Jesus entered the house of Peter, and saw his mother-in-law lying in bed with a fever.
8:15 He touched her hand, the fever left her, and she rose and waited on him.
8:16 When it was evening, they brought him many who were possessed by demons, and he drove out the spirits by a word and cured all the sick,
8:17 to fulfill what had been said by Isaiah the prophet: He took away our infirmities and bore our diseases. 
8:18 When Jesus saw a crowd around him, he gave orders to cross to the other side.
8:19 A scribe approached and said to him, Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go.
8:20 Jesus answered him, Foxes have dens and birds of the sky have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to rest his head.
8:21 Another of [his] disciples said to him, Lord, let me go first and bury my father.
8:22 But Jesus answered him, Follow me, and let the dead bury their dead.
8:23 He got into a boat and his disciples followed him.
8:24 Suddenly a violent storm came up on the sea, so that the boat was being swamped by waves; but he was asleep.
8:25 They came and woke him, saying, Lord, save us! We are perishing!
8:26 He said to them, Why are you terrified, O you of little faith? Then he got up, rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was great calm.
8:27 The men were amazed and said, What sort of man is this, whom even the winds and the sea obey?
8:28 When he came to the other side, to the territory of the Gadarenes, two demoniacs who were coming from the tombs met him. They were so savage that no one could travel by that road.
8:29 They cried out, What have you to do with us, Son of God? Have you come here to torment us before the appointed time?
8:30 Some distance away a herd of many swine was feeding.
8:31 The demons pleaded with him, If you drive us out, send us into the herd of swine.
8:32 And he said to them, Go then! They came out and entered the swine, and the whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the sea where they drowned.
8:33 The swineherds ran away, and when they came to the town they reported everything, including what had happened to the demoniacs.
8:34 Thereupon the whole town came out to meet Jesus, and when they saw him they begged him to leave their district.
9:1 He entered a boat, made the crossing, and came into his own town.
9:2 And there people brought to him a paralytic lying on a stretcher. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralytic, Courage, child, your sins are forgiven.
9:3 At that, some of the scribes said to themselves, This man is blaspheming.
